abstract: Register of Vessels on July 1
snippet: Register of Vessels on July 1
lead_paragraph: The daily increasing dimensions of our navy, which are recorded yearly is the Naval Register render a semi-annual statement of its conditions interesting and useful. Subjoined, we give a full list, corrected up to July 1, 1863, of the regularly constructed ship-of-war of the United States, as there appears to be a very general misunderstanding in regard to the [???] vessels comprising our national fleet. [???] London paper recently stated that "although there are ever 400 ships in the United States navy, not [???] of them were built for war purposes." Similar ignorance being common at home, it may be well to show our friends and foes, that since the rebellion broke out, nearly 140 vessels have been constructed expressly as men-of-war, and of these nearly fifty are iron-clads. Many of the purchased steamers are now as formidable as navy-built craft, but the names of all are excluded, in order to present the reader, for the first time, with a list of our "regular navy." There are, all told, about 530 vessels now registered on the books of the Department, all being purchased save the following:

abstract: The rebels no longer menace Harrisburgh. The Army of the Potomac, under its new commander, Gen. MEADE, was in rapid motion on Monday and yesterday. Its progress on Monday was such as to relieve the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad from rebel cavalry, and to...
lead_paragraph: The rebels no longer menace Harrisburgh. The Army of the Potomac, under its new commander, Gen. MEADE, was in rapid motion on Monday and yesterday. Its progress on Monday was such as to relieve the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad from rebel cavalry, and to restore telegraphic communication with Frederick. What its progress yesterday was will be best indicated by the character of the advices to be received to-day, which will probably be of the moat important character. A dispatch from Harrisburgh expresses the belief, entertained by the authorities there, that LEE was yesterday engaged in concentrating his forces on the line of the Cumberland Valley Railroad, between Shippensburgh and Chambersburgh, in anticipation of an attack by the Army of the Potomac, EWELL's corps, however, was still in front of Harrisburgh until last evening, when it retreated, and is known to have gone beyond Carlisle. A rebel infantry force was seen yesterday morning about fourteen miles from Harrisburgh, moving toward the city, but nothing was subsequently heard from it. On Monday, four hundred of our cavalry, lately under command of Gen. MILROY, had a fight with IM[???]ODEN's cavalry at McConnellsburgh, defeating them and driving them through the town. The rebels lost three killed and thirty-three prisoners. The damage on our side was two men wounded.

abstract: City Inspector BOOLE was visited on Monday by a Committee from the Workingmen's Association -- an organization of ash and dirt cartmen and street sweepers. They complained that some of their members had been discharged from labor on the streets, and wished to know if Mr. BOOLE meant to make fight with the Association. Mr. BOOLE replied that he knew nothing about the Association in the performance of his official duty. The men were discharged for incapacity and other good reasons. He wished the Committee to understand, however, that he would be glad to have the aid of the Association in any reasonable way. It could help him a great deal; but any dictation he would not submit to. He would not have any combination control him as to how many men he should or should not employ, or how many he should set at work in the respective Wards. Opposition to his plans would prompt the sternest resistance by him. He would give all complaints a fair and full hearing, but "strikes," if attempted, he would treat most severely, bringing the strongest powers of the law to subdue them. He instanced the strike of the tailors, several years ago, and the imprisonment of the leaders, as a proof of what the law could do in such cases. To do his duty well, he must be permitted to carry out his own plans, and in their execution the public expected him to use the strongest exertions to overcome all obstacles. The Committee appeared to be pleased with the frank manner of the City Inspector, and retired, expressing themselves satisfied with the interview.

abstract: the new
snippet: the new
lead_paragraph: From and after to-day an entirely new Postal law goes into effect in the United States. It will save much confusion for every citizen to become acquainted with its provisions, and we have therefore placed in the columns of the TIMES, this morning, a complete abstract of it. The substance of every section is given in such direct form, and absence of technical phraseology, as to enable the general reader more easily to comprehend the various provisions.

abstract: suppose, who reads the run of black dispatches reaching us daily from every part of the conntry, that a million or so new rebels, fresh, vindictive, and impetuous, had suddenly emerged from hitherto un-...
lead_paragraph: One might well suppose, who reads the run of black dispatches reaching us daily from every part of the conntry, that a million or so new rebels, fresh, vindictive, and impetuous, had suddenly emerged from hitherto unknown and unsuspected camps, and flung themselves upon the Union lines. JONSTON has sixty or seventy thousand men threatening GRANT's rear. MAGRUDER has 12,000 and BRECKINRIDGE 17,000, threatening BANKS' rear. PRICE and MARMADUKE have 20,000 or more, threatening Helena, and reinforcing PEMBERTON by crossing the Mississippi at night Gen. MORTON threatens Brashear City with hosts of Texans; KIR[???]Y SMITH spreads terror in a dozen parts of the Mississippi Valley. And lastly, JOHN MORGAN crosses the Cumberland River, near Albany, Clinton County, Kentucky, about twenty miles south west of Somerset, and not far from where ZOLLICOFFER was killed, with no less than "15,000" rebels at his heels. His advance is said to be in Columbia, about fifty miles south of Danville and Perryville, Ky., and, of course, it is supposed he is striking directly for the heart of Kentucky, to rob that State as LEE is robbing Pennsylvania.

abstract: And the Peace Party
snippet: And the Peace Party
lead_paragraph: Whatever else Gen. LEE may achieve, one thing is certain -- if he keeps on, he is bound to make an end of the Peace party. Before ever he has reddened Northern soil with a drop of blood, this party falls paralyzed before him, and is already practically defunct. It is motionless and speechless, and it is doubtful whether the breath of life has not even now left it altogether. At all events it is very certain that, if he beats about these parts a fortnight longer, this party will be as dead as JULIUS CAESAR.

abstract: The Army of Gen. LEE, which for a week past has been scattered in detachments over the lower counties of Pennsylvania, from York to Franklin, and from the Susquehanna River to the Potomac--a region sixty miles wide and seventy-five miles long--seems...
lead_paragraph: The Army of Gen. LEE, which for a week past has been scattered in detachments over the lower counties of Pennsylvania, from York to Franklin, and from the Susquehanna River to the Potomac -- a region sixty miles wide and seventy-five miles long -- seems now to be effecting a concentration, either as preparatory to other work or to shield itself from danger. Shippensburgh, a place on the Cumberland Valley Railroad, between Harrisburgh and Chambersburgh, thirty-four miles southwest of the former, and ten miles from the latter, seems to be the point toward which the enemy's columns are tending. They seem, by the news, to have moved in this direction from Chambersburgh, to have fallen back in this direction from Harrisburgh and Carlisle, and to have retired from York and Gettysburgh, in the same direction.

abstract: Fortunately cannot be President
snippet: Fortunately cannot be President
lead_paragraph: There is one circumstance is Gen. MEADA'S history, for which, now that he is in command of the army, we may all feel devoutly thankful. He was born in Spain, and consequently is not eligible for the office of President of the United States. Owing to this happy accident, there is no danger that the approaching campaign will be political as well as military; or that he will have one eye on LEE and another on " the Radicals" or " the Democrats" at home, or that he will march and fight with a view to the appearance which his exploits will make on " the record." We of course do not imagine that the fact of his haying been born abroad had any influence in causing his appointment, but it ought to have had, if it were known or remembered. As things stand, it constitutes one of his highest qualifications, and, we are quite satisfied, will contribute largely to his efficiency. It enables him to give his undivided attention to his work, and to consider his acts and speeches solely with reference to their effect on the enemy, and nut on his own political fortunes. It may seem strange that a man having been born in a foreign country should increase the chance of his making a good General in America; but so it is. "A pity 'tis, but 'tis true." We know by sorrowful experience that to the great mass of politicians the war is but a political campaign on a grand scale, and every General's "points" are scanned the minute he makes his appearance in the field, with a view to "running him" at some future period. The small extent to which Gen. MEADE is known to the public is, considering the good opinion generally entertained of him as a soldier, a subject of general comment and surprise; but we feel satisfied that the real explanation of it lies in the fact that he is not "available." If his nomination were even a possibility of the remotest kind, be would, by this time to a certainty, have had a knot of admirers, let it be ever so small, spreading the fame of his deeds to the four corners of the continent. The enemy would have trembled at his name; his soldiers would have worshipped the tracks of his boots; the persecuted Unionists of the South would have worn miniatures of him next the skin; the contumacious treatment of him by the President and Cabinet would have exceed shouts of horror and execration at various mass meetings; and, finally, thousands or, perhaps, millions of soldiers would be waiting for him to assume the command-in-chief, before enlisting and rushing on the foe. From all this, and much more, he has been providentially delivered by the lucky circumstance that his father and mother, lived in Spain when he first saw light. He consequently eaten on his duties in a far higher character than that worn by any man who has preceded him in that office -- simple soldier and honest gentleman, who loves his work and does it well, and whom politicians and wire-pullers and intriguers, of all sects and parties, pass by without notice. He has the satisfaction of knowing that he is not fit to be their tool, and that he will consequently never be besmirched by their slaver. We wish him all possible success, and take pleasure in calling the attention to the fact that all puffs and orations bestowed on him will be utterly wasted.

abstract: The Position of in Louisiana
snippet: The Position of in Louisiana
lead_paragraph: Next to Gen. MEADE, no man in the military service has a harder job than Gen. BANKS. The operations of GRANT and ROSECRANS are more gigantic, but in some respects not as difficult. Gen. BANKS, with a small force, is besieging, and has for over five weeks been besieging, a very formidable series of works, defended by a strong garrison; he is in an unhealthy country, with un[???]oclimated troops; he is (In a double sense) far distant from reinforcements; he needs to concentrate all his troops at the main point, and yet there are other places, such as New-Orleans and its outposts as far as Brashear City, which he cannot possibly uncover; he has, since the siege was opened, made two general assaults upon the works with his entire besieging force, neither of which was crowned with perfect success; and these attacks were made by troops which had previously undergone long and hard marches, and fought several severe battles; and, farther, bodies of rebels are appearing on his flanks and in his rear, while other bodies are making threatening demonstrations on important points in other sections of his department.

abstract: Following the example of the enemy, your correspondent has concluded to "invade." The transition from the soil of traitorous Virginia to that of loyal Maryland is quite as pleasant to me as to the rebels. We leave barren wastes and desolate ruins for well-tilled fields, quiet villages, and well-filled lardres--only I fear to leave some of these as barren and as desolate as some we have mourned over in other regions.

abstract: We have special dispatches from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to yesterday noon, which give some idea of the movements recently made, and which seem already to have resulted in great advantages for us. It appears now that the rebel cavalry force which made the recent raid on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad...
lead_paragraph: We have special dispatches from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to yesterday noon, which give some idea of the movements recently made, and which seem already to have resulted in great advantages for us. It appears now that the rebel cavalry force which made the recent raid on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was the one under command of STUART in person -- his whole force, with eight pieces of artillery. They were at Westminster, Md., on Monday night. Early on Tuesday morning, Gen. GREGO, commanding a portion of our cavalry, made an attack upon STUART, and drove him eighteen miles, from Westminster to Hanover. Gen. KILPATRICK subsequently attacked him and drove him out of Hanover, after a splendid fight, part of his force going toward Gettysburgh and part toward York. Gen. KILPATRICK captured fifty prisoners, including a Lieutenant-Colonel. During Tuesday a regiment was also driven out of Gettysburgh by Gen. BUFORD. From the best information obtainable yesterday, the rebels appeared to be concentrating their forces on a line running from Cashtown to Berlin. Cashtown is between Gettysburgh and Chambersburgh, and Berlin is about ten miles west of York. Appearances favored two supposition -- that the rebels were preparing to attempt to retreat with their plunder, or concentrating to give Gen. M???ADE battle. They are reported to have burned Cashtown on Monday and twenty-five houses in Shippensburgh.

lead_paragraph: The announcement, which appeared in the columns of the TIMES yesterday, that Gov. SEYMOUR had ordered Inspector-General MILLER to come to NewYork immediately and commence the organization of thirty regiments here and in Brooklyn, gave an impetus to the military feeling. On making inquiry at the proper quarter, we find that no decided action in the matter has yet taken place, but that it is under consideration.

abstract: In these columns, last Saturday, we observed, that though the rebel Gen. LEE might advance with comparatively little fear of the bayonets in the hands of the raw militia suddenly called out to meet him--that though those bayonets might not be held so firmly as his own, and might give back as he advanced --this state of things could not exist long.
lead_paragraph: In these columns, last Saturday, we observed, that though the rebel Gen. LEE might advance with comparatively little fear of the bayonets in the hands of the raw militia suddenly called out to meet him -- that though those bayonets might not be held so firmly as his own, and might give back as he advanced -- this state of things could not exist long. After a while his advance must stop -- after a while he must begin to fall back -- and "woo to him when his retrograde begins!" for then the militia will show their courage.

abstract: United States vs. Neptune, sloop; Prize
snippet: United States vs. Neptune, sloop; Prize
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Sloop Neptune and her Cargo. -- This vessel was captured April 19,1863, by the sloop Housatonic, off Charleston Harbor. The vessel was appraised at $150, and left at Port Royal by the captors, and the cargo was brought here and libeled. No one appeared to defend the action. The ship's papers show that she was registered April 4, 1863, at Charleston, to a resident of that place, and cleared from thence for Nassau, with a cargo of cotton and spirits of turpentine. The evidence of the master showed that the vessel ran the blockade at night and was captured off the harbor.

abstract: The Elections in and Their Meaning
snippet: The Elections in and Their Meaning
lead_paragraph: There is a political, commercial, as well as geographical, meaning in the elections just concluded in Canada, which it would be unwise to overlook. The contest is the most remarkable that has taken place since the year preceding the Canadian rebellion. The differences of the situation, however, are so marked as to supply a subject of contrast, rather than comparison. The Ministerial party have gained, apparently, a working majority in the Assembly. Out of the one hundred and thirty member constituting the Lower House of Parliament, they can safely reckon on having secured from sixty-eight to seventy thorough-paced followers. But the singular part of the story is, that out of this aggregate, the Ministers count no less than forty-four from Western Canada; leaving them in a Lower Canada minority so great as to threaten a revival of the worst sectional strife that has ever beset the Province.
headline: {'main': 'The Canada Elections--New Phases in the British Provinces.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Canada Elections--New Phases in the British Provinces.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The presumption from an article which we find in a late number of the Richmond Sentinel is that there is but a small rebel force garrisoning Richmond. It was reported that our troops had advanced as far as the White House, which seems to have thrown Richmond into quite a panic, and the people were appealed to by the authorities and the press to arm themselves instantly for self-defence. The Sentinel says that "instead of being ready for our work, we (the rebels) are now to present the spectacle of an excited mob meeting to organize when the enemy is at our doors;" and further, that "in the public meeting held the previous night, what looked most like work was a company of grey headed men, and another of little boys, who were organized and drilling," though it is claimed there are thousands of able-bodied men in Richmond who will not enlist until compelled by the strong arm of the law.

abstract: Four Pennsylvania regiments, the One Hundred and Fifty-eighth. One Hundred and Sixty-eighth, One Hundred and Seventy-first, and One Hundred and Seventy-fifth, and three Massachusetts regiments, the Eighth, Forty-sixth, and Fifty-first, whose time is about expiring, have tendered their services for the defence of Pennsylvania, as long as there is an armed rebel north of the Potomac. Their services have been accepted. Returning regiments, that are receiving ovations occasionally in this State and in New-Jersey, would render themselves doubly sure of the gratitude of their country if they would follow this example. They are experienced in the field, and capable of instant service. Volunteers are not.

abstract: -Now that the rebel army is imminently menacing Washington, it is exhilarating to learn, as we do by a special dispatch from there, that the "enrollment under the Conscription act is rapidly progressing." It is four months since the Conscription act became law, and if an enrollment of the citizens of Washington is actually being made thus early, we certainly have some reason to hope it will be completed before the end of the year, and the conscription enforced by the close of the present Presidency, or some time after.
lead_paragraph: -Now that the rebel army is imminently menacing Washington, it is exhilarating to learn, as we do by a special dispatch from there, that the "enrollment under the Conscription act is rapidly progressing." It is four months since the Conscription act became law, and if an enrollment of the citizens of Washington is actually being made thus early, we certainly have some reason to hope it will be completed before the end of the year, and the conscription enforced by the close of the present Presidency, or some time after.

abstract: I am just in from the front, and send by a messenger to Frederick a brief dispatch of the occurrences of yesterday and to-day. The rebel force which made the said on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad consisted of STUART'S whole force, with eight pieces of artillery. On Monday night they arrived at Westminster and interrupted the Western Maryland Railroad.

abstract: People in civil life cannot pretend to criticise, in its present stage, a grand campaign, such as that now entered upon by our Army of Northern Virginia. We do not so much as know its object, and therefore still less can we pronounce on the suitableness of the means. Some of the Confederate newspapers write as if they had expected the cavalry advance into Pennsylvania to have been at once let loose upon a general plundering expedition. But independently of the fact that nothing disorganizes troops and renders them useless like indiscriminate plunder it is well to recollect that it may be absolutely necessary to the general plan to keep that cavalry force well in hand, so as to cover other movements of the main body. On the great chess-board of war there is a mighty game in progress; and neither we at home nor HOOKER the opposite player himself. has yet divined the nature of Gen. LEE's combinations it is true that Confederates owe no consideration or forbearance to their enemies. It is true, further, that our Generals owe it to their own people to visit a terrible devastation and havoc upon the enemy's country, whenever they have the means in their hands to do so effectually, and on a grand scale. But this is not yet the case. Gen. HOOKER, with a vast army, is still to be disposed of, and every movement of each command must, doubtless, be calculated with a view to this needful preliminary business. It may be nee???ful even to deceive the enemy as to the ultimate object of the Confederate General, by adopting the very course complained of -- that is forbearing from plunder now, on the very threshold of the expedition. In order to do the business well and thoroughly the just retaliation (which we demand and the toe expects) must be organized and regulated as deliberately as any other military movement, and it might be fatal to the whole campaign if JENKINS' cavalry were now permitted to load themselves with plunder, and so, for the sake of the paltry booty of Chambersburgh, miss perhaps the splendid prize of Philadelphia or the crushing blow at the enemy's head in Washington.

abstract: Northern Prosperity an Injury to the War
snippet: Northern Prosperity an Injury to the War
lead_paragraph: It is somewhat paradoxical, but strictly true, notwithstanding, that the greatest disadvantage of the war is the prosperity of the country. Everybody admits that, in the main, the industry of the North is very flourishing. The farms teem, the workshops and the factories whir, and the bustle of trade fills the streets. Labor was never in greater demand, or more largely paid. The industry of the country has recovered from the terrible shock given it by the first outbreak of the war; it has adapted itself to the new condition of things, and in new channels is putting forth its energies with an activity, and with a success, seldom if ever surpassed before. Taking all classes of society into account, it may, with very little risk, be averred that in no year in the history of the country has there been so little destitution and so much physical the North, as has prevailed thus far in this third ef the war.
headline: {'main': 'Northern Prosperity a Damage to the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Northern Prosperity a Damage to the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The long pending legal controversy in relation to the plot of ground known as the Gansevoort property, is at last finally determined. The General Term of the Supreme Court, in an elaborate opinion, consider all the questions at issue, and decide that the Comptroller has no alternative but to sign the bonds and take possession of the property. This plot embraces about 130 lots of land near the foot of Fourteenth-street, North River, with a water front of 900 feet. The land is set apart for a market, the design being to remove the Washington Market to this central point, so as to more fully accommodate the upper section of the City. We hope now that the legal obstacles are removed, that no time will be lost in establishing this market so much needed by the public.

lead_paragraph: The Board of Aidermen, yesterday, by a strict party vote, concurred in the resolutions from the Councilmen, lauding Gen. McCLELLAN, and requesting the Administration to place him in the position demanded by the crisis of the country. The twelve Democrats present voted affirma tively, and the two Republican of the Board -- Measrs. HALL and OTTIWELL-- voted in the negative. Mr. MITCHELL, who is an earnest war Democrat, voted for the resolutions, although except to the vagueness of their expression. He said the Administration bad put Gen. MCCLELLAN in what they deemed his proper position at this time, but the aim of the resolutions was to request his appointment to the position desired by a majority of the people. The Special Committee on the DEVLIN and CONOVER controversy over the Street Commissionership, rendered a lengthy report, covering all the details of that memorable affair. The report was laid over, and ordered to published. This is the first lime the subject has been officially investigated and reported upon. The recovery of a lost paper, relative to the charges made against Mr. DEVLIN, of unofficial conduct while in office, gives a coloring to the report in favor of the demands of that gentleman for claims on assignments which he still holds, and which have been denied of payment ever since by the Finance Department. The Committee on National Affairs were directed to receive and lay in state in the Governor's Boom, the body of Col. M.K. BRYAN (who recently fell at Port Hudson.) on its arrival in this City, and until it shall be forwarded to Albany. The Board took a month's vacation, adjourning to the first Monday in August, at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: The Eastern Division
snippet: The Eastern Division
lead_paragraph: We have received several communications, some of them controversial, and others laudatory, in regard to the projected railroad to the Pacific. It seems that some difficulty has arisen concerning the organization of a company for the construction of the Eastern division of the road under the recent act of Congress; and that an old charter, granted by the Kansas Legislature, and covering the same route, has been purchased, and a company organized, of which Gen. FREMONT is President, and SAMUEL HALLETT & CO. are the Bankers. Notices are published that Gen. FREMONT has deposited two millions of dollars with S.H. & Co., to be used for the benefit of the road, and capitalists are invited to come forward and purchase the construction bonds.

abstract: The Convention of 1860; W. H. Payne's Letter; Letter to E. Husted on the Virginia Convention of 1860
snippet: The Convention of 1860; W. H. Payne's Letter; Letter to E. Husted on the Virginia Convention of 1860
lead_paragraph: It is well known that the Convention of the State of Virginia, in 1860, though a very large majority of its members were elected as Union men, was cheated into voting for secession by the most flagrant falsehoods on the part of the secession leaders. The vote by yeas and nays has lately been published, from which it appears that 88 voted in favor of the measure and 55 against it. Among the year appears the name of EPPA HUNTON; and the following letter addressed to him a month before the vote was taken, by a prominent politician of the State, not only shows 'in the clearest manner the fraud of the whole programme, but indicates the influences under which it was perpetrated. The letter was recently found in Virginia, and has never before been published:
headline: {'main': 'Virginia and Secession.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Virginia and Secession.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Almshouse for Hudson County, just completed at the county farm, took place, Wednesday, by a public reception given under the supervision of the Committee of the Board of Chosen Freeholders. The company, numbering about 500, consisting of the authorities of the several cities and townships, and prominent citizens of the county, proceeded by special train on the Erie Railway to within about three-fourths of a mile, and from thence on foot to the county farm, where a couple of hours were spent in examining the buildings and grounds, after which a collation was served up. Speeches also were made by C.H. O'Neil, Director; Alderman Pangborn, of Jersey City: Councilman Bogert, of Hoboken; Gen. E.R.V. Wright, District Attorney lsaac W. Scudder. Rev. Mr. Van Cleef, Rev. Mr. Mayben, Edwin A. Stevens, Peter Bently, Abin W. Duryea, Mr. Muchmore, of Kings County, and seven or eight others. The building is of the French style of architecture, 131 feet 8 inches in length. 48 feet deep with wings projecting from the front, 27 feet 4 inches front, and 28 feet 3 inches wide. There is a tower at the centre main entrance, 20 feet square, and 107 feet high. The building is four stories high, with a high attic. It is at present arranged to accommodate 400 persons, but is capable of accommodating about 300 additional. It is built of brick in the most substantial manner, and cost about $37,000. The farm is on what is known as Snake Hill, and contains 260 acres, purchased at a cost of $12,000. The visitors arrived home at about 6 P.M., after spending a pleasant and agreeable day.
lead_paragraph: The Almshouse for Hudson County, just completed at the county farm, took place, Wednesday, by a public reception given under the supervision of the Committee of the Board of Chosen Freeholders. The company, numbering about 500, consisting of the authorities of the several cities and townships, and prominent citizens of the county, proceeded by special train on the Erie Railway to within about three-fourths of a mile, and from thence on foot to the county farm, where a couple of hours were spent in examining the buildings and grounds, after which a collation was served up. Speeches also were made by C.H. O'Neil, Director; Alderman Pangborn, of Jersey City: Councilman Bogert, of Hoboken; Gen. E.R.V. Wright, District Attorney lsaac W. Scudder. Rev. Mr. Van Cleef, Rev. Mr. Mayben, Edwin A. Stevens, Peter Bently, Abin W. Duryea, Mr. Muchmore, of Kings County, and seven or eight others. The building is of the French style of architecture, 131 feet 8 inches in length. 48 feet deep with wings projecting from the front, 27 feet 4 inches front, and 28 feet 3 inches wide. There is a tower at the centre main entrance, 20 feet square, and 107 feet high. The building is four stories high, with a high attic. It is at present arranged to accommodate 400 persons, but is capable of accommodating about 300 additional. It is built of brick in the most substantial manner, and cost about $37,000. The farm is on what is known as Snake Hill, and contains 260 acres, purchased at a cost of $12,000. The visitors arrived home at about 6 P.M., after spending a pleasant and agreeable day.

lead_paragraph: In the battle fought on Wednesday, near Gettysburgh, an exclusive announcement of which was made in the TIMES of yesterday morning, but a comparatively small portion of Gen. MEADE'S army appears to have been engaged. The advance of our forces passed through Gettysburgh at 10 o'clock in the morning, and a quarter of a mile west of the place, encountered LONGSTREET and HILL, who attacked Gen. REYNOLDS' corps -- that corps having the lead. Gen. REYNOLDS withstood the force of the attack until relieved by another corps -- one account says the Third, and another the Eleventh -- when a commanding position was secured. This position the rebels made a strong attempt to flank, but they were repulsed, and the battle ceased for the day at 4 o'clock P.M., the losses having been about equal. Our loss of officers was heavy -- Gen. REYNOLDS, commanding the First corps, and Gen. PAUL, commanding the Third brigade of the First corps, being among the number killed. During the evening the whole Army of the Potomac reached the field, and Gen. MEADE made his dispositions for a renewal of the battle yesterday morning, with the advantage of a better concentration of his forces than the rebels could hope for -- EWELL's corps not being in the vicinity. Up to a late hour last night no news of the operations of yesterday had been received.

abstract: The people of New-York and the country generally, as well as the Government at Washington, were in hourly expectation of the news of a battle in Southern Pennsvlvania yesterday, when they learned by the special and exclusive dispatch from Gettysburgh to the NEW-YORK TIMES that one had actually been fought on Wednesday at that place. The dispatch was brief, but up to 2 o'clock this morning no material facts had been added to it.

abstract: -That class  of people whose calling imposes more distress on families, more burdens on society, and more expense on Governments than any other class known to our civilization, is always foremost and most notorious in its resistance to the very laws under which its license to do wrong is countenanced and protected. We can mean no other class, of course, than the more degraded liquordealers of this City.
lead_paragraph: -- That class of people whose calling imposes more distress on families, more burdens on society, and more expense on Governments than any other class known to our civilization, is always foremost and most notorious in its resistance to the very laws under which its license to do wrong is countenanced and protected. We can mean no other class, of course, than the more degraded liquordealers of this City. The Tax law of the late Congress imposed a license system on many professions and pursuits, and liquor-dealers came very fitly; under the general law. Each person engaged in the retail traffic of ardent spirits was required to pay to the Government an annual license on his business. The lower class of liquor-dealers in this City have formed a combination to resist the collection of this tax, and have engaged counsel to contest the, matter. Forty or fifty suits have already been instituted against liquor-dealing recusants; and as the penalty of disobeying the law is imprisonment as well as fine three times the amount of the license, there is reasonable hope of reaching and punishing the offenders.

abstract: The war in
snippet: The war in
lead_paragraph: The War Department has sanctioned the issuing of medals and chevrons to the veterans who may rejoin the service after their regular period of enlistment has expired. Public virtue will not suffer by conspicuously distinguishing the men who have nobly offered their lives to maintain it. In every European army the gallantry of regiments, and even of individuals, is thus commemorated. The French soldier would rather part with his life than with one of the little medals that adorns his breast, and the English private who has been decorated for good service is notoriously more tractable, sober and amiable than he who has missed that honor. We have been too jealous of rewarding our humbler heroes with tangible tokens of their merit, arising mainly, perhaps, from the political fiction that to be a citizen is the highest honor to which one can aspire, and that beyond that nothing in the shape of medals and chevrons can be desired to complete the round of human happiness. It is true enough that the sacrifices made in the present war, by almost every one connected with its prosecution, can only be adequately rewarded by the restoration of peace, and of that universal prosperity that prevailed before war was in the land. But the distribution of official honors, representing the applause of a nation for which the soldier fights, will not retard this consummation, whilst, if it but contribute a thrill of patriotic pride to the recipient, it will serve a worthy purpose. Will not the younger members of the army be emulous of the deeds that have thus won recognition? We are persuaded that to be worthy of such a diploma will be no unworthy object of ambition with them.

abstract: The regular monthly meeting of this Board was held yesterday afternoon -- the President, A.A. Low, in the Chair. The following named gentlemen were elected members of the Chamber: George Savory, John Taylor Johnston, George E. Fellows, Oliver K. King, Henry E. Clark, Wm. J. Beebe, Norman S. Bentley. A letter was read and ordered upon the minutes, from PELATIAH PEBIT, Esq., late President of the Chamber, thanking the Board for the resolutions complimentary to himself passed by the Board upon his retirement from office.

abstract: ACCIDENT TO MRS. LINCOLN.  Mrs. LINCOLN met with an accident this forenoon. Her horses took fright and ran away as she was riding from the Soldier's Home to the city. Seeing her imminent danger she leaped from the carriage, and was stunned and severely bruised, but no bones were broken. Surgeons from Mount Pleasant Hospital were promptly in attendance. She soon recovered sufficiently to be taken to the White House.

abstract: Advices from Vicksburgh just received report no chance in regard to the state of affairs. On the night of the 21st, the enemy sprung a mine to blow up an angle of our works. The effort was a complete failure, and killed a number of their own men.

abstract: --It appears that a num  ber of Northern newspapers, declared contraband in Kansas and the Indian Territory, were seized, and burned in the streets of Leavenworth, a few days ago, and that a kind of "war dance" was performed by enthusiastic patriots around the bonfire. It is not so stated, but we have scarcely a doubt that this "war dance" was contributed by a detachment of the 10,000 "warlike Indians" that Mr....
lead_paragraph: -- It appears that a number of Northern newspapers, declared contraband in Kansas and the Indian Territory, were seized, and burned in the streets of Leavenworth, a few days ago, and that a kind of "war dance" was performed by enthusiastic patriots around the bonfire. It is not so stated, but we have scarcely a doubt that this "war dance" was contributed by a detachment of the 10,000 "warlike Indians" that Mr. Commissioner DOLE has just proposed to enlist as soldiers. The belt of scalps dangling about the waist of each naked Indian in this "war dance" must have proved not only a picturesque spectacle, but a salutary warning to every Copperhead and leatherhead present; for it should be remembered that, excepting the scalps of the few hundred white persons lately massacred in Minnesota; Mr. DOLE's loyal but very troublesome 10,000 Indians, soon to be enlisted in the military service, have taken all their tufted trophies from their copperheaded confreres of the Far West! These aboriginal patriots never spare their kind.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price Five CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also all official orders reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEAKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Our correspondence from Gen. MEADE's headquarters, yesterday, announced the fact that communication with Washington, by railroad and telegraph, had been cut off! Singular to say, the country did not regard the situation of Gen. MEADE as at all critical on that account. On the contrary, there was a disposition to consider it one of the happy accidents of his life.

abstract: Runs the blockade
snippet: Runs the blockade
lead_paragraph: -- While the friends of Mr. CLEMENT L. VALLANDIGHAM are besieging Washington and invoking Mr. LINCOLN to relieve that gentleman from the judgment that consigns him to the boundaries of the Southern Confederacy, Mr. VALLANDIGHAM himself treats the judgment and the powers that decreed it with profound contempt, by boldly setting both at defiance. The ship news, yesterday, assured us that Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, some time since, "run the blockade,"(thus treating with marvelous disrespect the Secretary of the Navy,) and that he is already enjoying British protection at the Island of Bermuda. So that the candidate of the Ohio Democracy would seem to be no longer in need of the President's pardoning grace.

abstract: Blockade, The, in the House of Lords
snippet: Blockade, The, in the House of Lords
lead_paragraph: The English House of Lords has had another debate over the blockade and the proceedings of our prize Courts. It was called up by the same Marquis of Clanricarde, who brought on the former debate, and, as our readers will recollect, fared so ill in it. His motion this time was for copies of any reports from the Admiral of the West India Squadron, concerning the protection of British merchantmen by British gunboats from seizure or visitation; and he supported his motion in a long and quite remarkable speech -- stating, in the first place, that "a considerable amount of British commerce was engaged in, violating the blockade;" he said there had also sprung up "a large and perfectly legitimate trade with Mexico and the colonies, which was intercepted by the Federal cruisers." Upon this bead he dilated, talked about the possibility of war, laid down some of the principles of the law of reprisals as being applicable, whatever were the decisions of our Prize Courts, one of which he spoke of as "so absurd that no Court of high standing could come to it," and declared that nothing "could justify war more completely than the defence of our trade and maritime rights." He then proceeded to quote from shipping reports of the London Times, which narrated the proceedings of the British men-of-war in convoying British vessels. In one case "Admiral WILKES had given characteristic orders that a British steamer, named the Ruby, was to be seized wherever found;" whereupon the Ariadne was dispatched in search of the Ruby -- found her coming out of Matanzas and convoyed her to Havana, where, on returning from a voyage to Key West, he found Admiral WILKES ship lying near her. "And of course," added the Marquis, "the Ariadne did not limit her services to convoying her from Matanzas to Havana. We shall probably Lear by the next mail that she saw her clear of the attentions of Admiral WILKES and his cruisers before she left her finally, and that the Ruby has escaped the fate with which she has been threatened." Before this lime the mail has brought the news to the Marquis that the Ruby, whose protection by convoy in this way he says was in accordance with what he had recommended, lies a wreck on the beach off Charleston, sunk by our fleet in endeavoring to break the blockade.

abstract: Emancipation ordinance adopted by Constitutional Convention
snippet: Emancipation ordinance adopted by Constitutional Convention
lead_paragraph: July first, eighteen hundred sixty-three, is a date destined to be forever memorable inAmerican history. It will figure as the starting point of State emancipation. The Constitutional Convention of Missouri on that day adopted an ordinance providing for the complete extinction of Slavery in that State. No act of the kind has been done since the formation of the Federal Constitution, save in a single instance; and that was on so small a scale that it scarcely deserves mention in this connection. We refer to the act provisionally abolishing Slavery in this State of New-York in 1799. But Slavery never existed here as a social system. At that time there were only about twenty thousand slaves in the State. In all the other so-called "Free States" combined, the entire aggregate of slaves, when they were most numerous, was only about seventeen thousand; and provision had been made, long before, for the emancipation -- Massachusetts and Pennsylvania doing this in 1780; Connecticut, Rhode Island, and New-Jersey, in 1784. Of the abolition in Western Virginia a few months since, we make no account, not only because the slaves there were but a mere handful, but because, considering the anomalous civil condition, it could hardly be called State action at all. It was really territorial action and that only.
headline: {'main': 'Emancipation in Missouri--The Beginning of a New Epoch.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Emancipation in Missouri--The Beginning of a New Epoch.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Position of
snippet: Position of
lead_paragraph: The general feeling of thought fat and prudent patriots, when Gen. MEADE was suddenly called on Monday to the command of the Army of the Potomac, was that he should for a few days evade a battle with the enemy, if possible. It was too great a task to throw on him, or on any military man, no matter what the confidence in his skill and genius, to demand him to take command of a great army, in motion, in front of the enemy, almost in actual contact, and direct it to victory through the combinations of an instant. How could he hope to succeed? Why should he be expected to succeed? Who, of all the commanders of the present time, would be equa to the emergency, and handle safely a gigantic army cast upon his bands in this hurried manner in the tremulous initial spring of battle?

abstract: In pursuance of a provision in the School Charter, which stipulates that the exercises on the closing days, prior to the Summer vacation, which commences about this time, shall be marked by the reading of the Declaration of Independence, many of the Public Schools of this City and Brooklyn, yesterday, observed that ceremony. But in most cases, the Principals avail themselves of the opportunity, and hold a reception, at which the pupils are examined, and "speak" pieces, etc. The receptions yesterday though not so -general as in previous years, were, nevertheless, well attended. The regular closing time is some day next week, but to let the pupils "have a mind unfettered and free" for the Fourth, the vacation commences just before that day. In addition to the reading of the Declaration of Independence, there were improvised dramas dialogues, songs, and examinations, in order to better display the proficiency of the pupils. The Grammar Department of Public School No. 15, in Brooklyn, gave a closing exhibition last evening, at the Academy of Music, the proceeds of which are to purchase pianos for the school. Mo. 15 is one of the best, if not the best school in that City, and the entertainment passed off pleasantly.

abstract: Gen. MEADE's campaign against the rebel army in Pennsylvania has been suddenly and unexpectedly initiated by an action of gigantic magnitude, which has already extended over three days, and in which the entire force of Gen. LEE and the entire Army of the Potomac seem to be engaged. The battle which opened with two corps on Wednesday morning, and lasted till well on in the afternoon -- which was reopened late on Thursday afternoon, and continued until dark, by the armies in full force -- which was resumed yesterday morning at early daylight -- does not appear at our latest advices, to have yet reached a definite or decisive result. At one time, as on the first day's battle, the rebels seem to have gained a temporary advantage -- at the terrible battle of Thursday our gallant army, in the words of Gen. MEADE, "repulsed the enemy at all points," -- and at the engagement of yesterday, the rebels, after six hours' fighting, had failed to make any impression upon our position. Of the final point reached in the evening, we have not yet been advised, but the general import of the dispatches are certainly favorable to our arms.

abstract: Our special telegrams this morning give a clear understanding of the momentous events which have taken place at Gettysburgh, Penn., within the past three days. The reports which have previously reached us have been incorrect in essential particulars--especially in regard to the battle of Wednesday. On that day the action was brought on by Gen. REYNOLDS, simply because he thought himself in superior force to that of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: Our special telegrams this morning give a clear understanding of the momentous events which have taken place at Gettysburgh, Penn., within the past three days. The reports which have previously reached us have been incorrect in essential particulars -- especially in regard to the battle of Wednesday. On that day the action was brought on by Gen. REYNOLDS, simply because he thought himself in superior force to that of the enemy. The action was not general, and was not intended to be so by Gen. MEADE. Our forces engaged on that day were repulsed, be-cause overpowered and outflanked, but they subsequently fell back to a position which they held, in the rear of Gettysburgh. On Thursday there was no fighting until 4 1/2 o'clock P.M. At that hour a bloody engagement was commenced, lasting until dark, and resulting in a substantial success to our arms -- the enemy being repulsed with great loss. The battle was commenced by the enemy with terrific force. Their entire army was engaged, and suffered a signal reverse. Yesterday the third day's tattle commenced, at 4 o'clock in the morning, the field of contest being on the south side of Gettysburgh, and the musketry fighting being wholly within the woods, while the artillery was posted on eminences, from which the timber had been cut. The attack on this day, as on the day previous, was commenced by the rebels, our right being the main point aimed at. There the fight was unceasing, until the date of our last dispatches from the battle-field -- 10 o'clock A.M. LONGSTREET'S and HILL'S corps were said to be engaged there, while EWELL was on the front. The enemy, as well as ourselves, had suffered heavily in prominent officers. Gen. BARKSDALE, of Mississippi, had been killed, and his body was within our lines. Prisoners on Thursday reported the death of Gen. LONGSTREET, and prisoners captured yesterday confirmed the report. Sixteen hundred prisoners had up to 10 o'clock been sent to the rear, and more were arriving. The result of the day's battle could not then be predicted, but the determination of our officers and men was to win. Gen. MEADE was managing his forces with admirable skill and prudence, and the troops were in the best of spirits. Important dispatches from JEFF DAVIS and the rebel Adjt.-Gen. COOPER had been captured by our scouts, which indicate anxiety for the position of Richmond, and refused to send LEE reinforcements from BEAUREGARD.

headline: {'main': "THE GREAT BATTLES.; Our Special Telegrams from the Battle Field to 10 A.M. Yesterday. Full Details of the Battle of Wednesday. No Fighting on Thursday Until Four and a Half, P.M. A Terrible Battle Then Commenced, Lasting Until Dark. The Enemy Repulsed at All Points. The Third Battle Commenced. Yesterday Morning at Daylight. THE REBELS THE ATTACKING PARTY. abstract: The President, to-day, received a dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated June 27. He says he learns that JOHNSTON would be reinforced by ten thousand men early this week. He thought we would have Vicksburgh ere that time, but if not, he could take care of both PEMDERTON and JOHNSTON.

abstract: We have before us a letter addressed to the President by the Sanitary Commission in August, 1862, calling his attention to the fact that the health of the army was very much lowered, owing to the fact that regiments in the field, though greatly reduced in numbers, were constantly charged with the same duties as if their ranks were full; "and in consequence of this, and often solely in consequence of this, men and officers had become harassed, feverish, exhausted of strength, depressed and despondent, and had communicated their feelings to their friends at home, and finally to the whole community." The loss of life from other causes than injuries received in battle, during the operations before Richmond, was very great, and made a profound impression on the public mind, and undoubtedly was the immediate cause of the indisposition to volunteer which from that time forward began to manifest itself. Thousands who were ready enough to run the risk of the enemy's bullets, shrunk from the prospect of exhaustion by fatigue and privation, and the ordinary consequences of fever and permanent debility. The Commission likewise dwelt upon the fact, and their warning is just as appropriate now as it was then:

abstract: On Wednesday morning the Erie Railroad machine shops in Paterson took fire, and the larger part of them were destroyed. The entire stock of tools, with a large number of patterns and two fine locomotives were destroyed. The entire loss is stated by the Paterson Guardian at $75,000. One hundred men are thrown out of employment.

abstract: It appears that a number of Northern newspapers, declared contraband in Kansas and the Indian Territory, were seized, and burned in the streets of Leavenworth, a few days ago, and that a kind of "war dance" was performed by enthusiastic patriots around the bonfire. It is not so stated, but we have scarcely a doubt that this "war dance" was contributed by a detachment of the 10,000 "warlike Indians" that Mr. Commissioner. DOLE has just proposed to enlist as soldiers. The belt of scalps dangling about the waist of each naked Indian in this "war dance" proved not only a picturesque spectacle, but a salutary warning to every Copperhead and leatherhead present; for it should be remembered that, excepting the scalps of the few hundred white persons lately massacred in Minnesota, Mr. DOLE's loyal but very troublesome 10,000 Indians, soon to be enlisted in the military service, have taken all their tufted trophies from their copperheaded confreres of the Far West! These aboriginal patriots never spare their kind.

abstract: There has been much ostentatious and wholly unnecessary pressure brought to bear recently on the Administration, to induce a declaration of its policy as to the military rights of black soldiers, and the officers who may command them. The fact that the Confederate Congress had passed a law denouncing death to white officers found in command of colored troops seemed to require, in the opinion of some, a public and high-sounding declaration that our own Government would demand equal military rights for all its soldiers, and retaliate for any such outrages as the Confederates proposed.

abstract: The Confederate Major-Gen. EARLY, in his address to the citizens of York, tells them that he trusts "the treatment you have met with at the hands of my soldiers will open your eyes to the odious tyranny under which, it is apparent to all, you are groaning." It is not often that a stranger so quickly learns the patois of a country, and we can account for this rapid mastery of the Copperhead dialect only by remembering that this Confederate General was himself born in these parts. This groaning under an odious tyranny is idiomatic to the most delicate turn. Put Gen. EARLY by the side of the "Burgess of York" -- himself an editor, and, of course, a purist -- and we will wager that there is not a philologist in the University who could tell by their talk which was the rebel and which the Copperhead.

abstract: An article in our advertising columns this morning, gives some idea of the vigorous movement that is being made in Pennsylvania to obtain the services of able-bodied free men of color for the army. This movement has nothing whatever to do with the present invasion of Pennsylvania, as Copperhead journals tauntingly assert. It was begun before such, a thing as invasion was dreamed of; but the invasion does not put a stop to it; it rather aids it in various ways. In Philadelphia, a half Southern city, whose prejudices appeared invincible, there is now no visible sign of objection to the movement, and the matter has been taken hold of there energetically by men of all parties, as will appear by the list of signatures to the address, where Democrats, Old Line Whigs, Republicans and Abolitionists all appear as aiders and forwarders of the scheme for the enlistment of the blacks. A fund of $15,000 has already been raised there to repay extraordinary expenses, and it is believed that $50, 000 will be obtained. Altogether the measure seems to be a popular one, and we have no doubt it will receive aid from this City.
lead_paragraph: An article in our advertising columns this morning, gives some idea of the vigorous movement that is being made in Pennsylvania to obtain the services of able-bodied free men of color for the army. abstract: The militia troops which Pennsylvania, New-York and New Jersey sent forward to the new military line on the Susquehanna, have as yet had no part in the great operations of the campaign. They are mainly stationed near Harrisburgh, with their faces turned southward, and may be said to be waiting to "see what turns up." They have had one or two skirmishes with small bodies of rebels, in which they are said to have acquitted themselves creditably. Their services against the main rebel army may at any moment be called into requisition, and may bear an important part in the decision of the campaign. Their term of service is very short, and we trust they may have an opportunity to win real distinction before returning to their homes and their business.

abstract: THE LATE COL. M.K. BRYAN. -- A meeting of the friends, residents of this City, was held at the Park Hotel on Thursday, to make arrangements for participating in the reception of the remains. A Committee, consisting of Aldermen TRACEY. JOHNSON and COWELL of Albany, the late residence of deceased, were invited to be present. The remains are daily expected from New-Orleans, and an invitation is extended to all Albanians, now residents at New-York, and to all friends of the deceased in the City, to join in the honors, of which due notice will be given. The Common Council have taken action in the matter, and this is eminently proper, the One Hundred and Seventy-fifth having been largely recruited in and officered from New-York. After the reception here, the remains will be surrendered to the authorities of Albany.

abstract: A MILITARY ORGANIZATION FOR HOME DEFENCE --The exempt members and officers of the Fifth brigade, Thirteenth, Fourteenth, Twenty-eighth and Seventieth regiments, met on Thursday evening and resolved to form an organization for home defence and to preserve order in the city during the absence of the regular militia regiments.
lead_paragraph: A MILITARY ORGANIZATION FOR HOME DEFENCE -- The exempt members and officers of the Fifth brigade, Thirteenth, Fourteenth, Twenty-eighth and Seventieth regiments, met on Thursday evening and resolved to form an organization for home defence and to preserve order in the city during the absence of the regular militia regiments. Col. A.M. HOOD was chosen commanding officer, and the following named gentlemen were appointed Captains to form ten companies: Company A, Capt. Stilwell; company B, Capt. Chas. Steers; company C, Capt. Morris; company D, Capt. Allen; company E, Capt. Tobin; company F, Capt. John Burns; company G, Capt. Hyer; company H, Capt. Stephen Kidder; company I, Capt. Wm. Brown; company K, Capt. Brownell. All citizens who choose to enroll them-selves in this organization can do so either at the City Armory, corner of Henry and Cranberry streets, or the Arsenal in Portland-avenue.

abstract: THE WALLACKIANS IN BROOKLYN.--On the Fourth of July the Academy of Music, in the City of Brooklyn, was a busy place. In the morning the Long Island Historical Society held their grand powwow in its beautiful auditorium; in the afternoon "Black-Eyed Susan" and the "Goddess of Liberty" caused alternate weepings and rejoicings; while in...
lead_paragraph: THE WALLACKIANS IN BROOKLYN. -- On the Fourth of July the Academy of Music, in the City of Brooklyn, was a busy place. In the morning the Long Island Historical Society held their grand powwow in its beautiful auditorium; in the afternoon "Black-Eyed Susan" and the "Goddess of Liberty" caused alternate weepings and rejoicings; while in the evening the "Little Treasure," [???] and a duplicate representation of the "Goddess" [???]csaid appealed to the sympathies of a crowded house. Miss MADELINE HENRIQUES was the belle of the afternoon, and the bright particular star of the evening. At her feet Young Brooklyn lavished its wealth and floral tribute, and her disappearance was the signal for one long melancholy wail. Miss EMILY THORNE, Mr. CHARLES FISHER and Mr. and Mrs. FLOYD were well received, and mightily amused and de lighted the house.

abstract: The "Tammany Society or Columbian Order," celebrated the day at the old Wigwam, in accordance with their invariable custom, and in their noted liberal and Democratic style.
lead_paragraph: The "Tammany Society or Columbian Order," celebrated the day at the old Wigwam, in accordance with their invariable custom, and in their noted liberal and Democratic style. Soon after 1 P.M. the Sachems gathered together upon the platform -- the halt being densely crowded -- and were welcomed in a neat and patriotic speech by Grand Sachem E.F. PURDY, who assured them that as long as the Order of St. Tammany existed, they would continue to meet on each anniversary of our Independence, to "keep alive the patriotic flame of Liberty, Equality and Fraternity, and smoke the calumet of peace and good will with all the supporters and defenders of the Union and the Constitution of our country."

abstract: Moran, Charles, Money
snippet: Moran, Charles, Money
lead_paragraph: -- The New Haven Journal has this curious paragraph. "Some ten months ago, Mr. Charles Monroe, of Fair Haven, was at Lagos and at Accra, on the Guinea Coast, whither he had sailed as Mate, with Capt. Post, in the Bark Elizabeth, and while there he drank of the water of that part of the world, without thinking to take the precautions commonly in use among the natives for the prevention of a terrible disease known as Guinea worm. It appears that the Africans always boil this water before drinking in order to destroy the minute, invisible egg of the worm, which is so small that it is absorbed by the blood vessels from the stomach, and is in that manner distributed in different parts of the body, usually the legs, where it is hatched, and after a long time, makes its appearance in the shape of a white, thread-like worm, pointed on both ends, and it twines and twists all about the muscles and veins and arteries, producing no particular feeling of uneasiness until some part of its body comes near the skin, when bad inflammations take place. It was in March last that Mr. MONROE began to be troubled with them, and for three months he has not walked a step. He is now in the Connecticut State' Hospital under treatment, and one worm has been taken from the bottom of his foot that measures over two feet long. The way it is done is this: When the surface of the skin is so pricked or irritated as to show where the "critter" is, a thread is fastened to him and a small weight attached to the other end of the thread. The worm gets tired of pulling against so steady a strain and gives ground a trifle day by day, and as he comes out, a little spool winds him up until he is all out. The pain is very great -- for forty nights Mr. MONROE hardly slept on account of the suffering. One worm is now in process of being drawn from his heel, and those medical men who have never seen a case of the kind are much interested. Great care has to be taken not to pull too hard, because the worm would break and the trouble be much prolonged. It first appears under the skin like a varicose vein, and after a painful boil has been formed and broken, the head of the animal is discovered.

abstract: The contents of the dispatches captured Thursday, from DAVIS to LEE, are in substance: A per[???] order for Lee to withdraw from Pennsylvania; an order for his transportation to fall back to Hagers-town forthwith; assigning as a reason that the position of LEE is too hazardous, the condition of Richmond too defenceless, to warrant his remaining in Pennsylvania longer -- that the advantages there to be pained are not sufficiently great to compensate for the risk he runs. He also refuses LEE'S request to have BEAUREGARD ra-inforce him, and orders him South of the Potomac forthwith.

abstract: Speech in New-York on July 4; Speech in N. Y.on July 4; Speech on July 4 in N. Y.
snippet: Speech in New-York on July 4; Speech in N. Y.on July 4; Speech on July 4 in N. Y.
lead_paragraph: The Eighty-seventh Anniversary of our National independence, was made the occasion of a great demonstration by the Democracy of this City. The meeting, held at the Academy of Music, was gotten up under the auspices of the New-York Democratic Union Association, and the announcement that Gov. SEYMOUR. of this State, Ex- Gov. Seymour, of Connecticut and Gov. Parker, of New-Jersey, had accepted invitations to be present and address the meeting, drew together a very large audience, in which the ladies were well represented. At two o'clock, the hour appointed for the exercises to commence, but few seats remained unoccupied, and these were soon filed. The musical part of the programme was well executed, though it was observable that selections of a national and patriotic character were not given the greatest prominence. Among the distinguished persons upon the platform, in addition to the speakers for the occasion, were Ex-Gov. BANTLEY, of Ohio, Hon. W.H. ARMSTRONG. Secretary of State of Ohio, GIDEON J. TUCKER, Prof. MO[???]. Prof. CY[???] MASON. Hon. S.J. TILDEN, Rev. Dr. CUMMINGS and HENRY GRINNELL AS the speakers came to the front of the platform, they were received with enthusiastic applause, and "three times three" were given for Gov. SEYMOUR. PHILIP W. B[???]GS was selected as the presiding officer. C. Go[???] GUNTHER read the Declaration of Independence and Hon. BLI P. NORTON read the guarantees of the Constitution. During these readings, all those passages which could be construed into parallels between the tyrannical usurpations of the King of England and the so called usurpations and [???]ies of President LINCOLN, were loudly applauded. Gov. SEYMOUR, on arising as received with great applause. He spoke as follows:

abstract: Wounded at Gettysburgh; Gettysburgh, The Battle of
snippet: Wounded at Gettysburgh; Gettysburgh, The Battle of
lead_paragraph: Our news from the great battlefield of Gettysburgh this morning is of the most cheering and satisfactory character. The great battle of Friday -- the third in the series -- proves to have been by far the most desperate one of the war, and to have resulted in the complete discomfiture of the enemy. At daylight LEE's right-wing batteries opened upon our left, and shortly afterward those of his centre followed, but little damage being done by his fire. Soon afterward an impetuous infantry attack was made upon our right, which was repulsed after a sharp struggle -- the enemy leaving a considerable number of prisoners in our hands. There was then a lull of several hours, and at 10 o'clock LEE, having massed about 80 pieces of artillery, opened a terrific cannonade upon our centre, but their range being imperfect, it did comparatively little damage to us, and was replied to by our artillery with the best effect. Under cover of this fire, LEE advanced his columns of infantry, and made several desperate attempts to carry our lines by assault, but each successive charge was repulsed with terrific havoc in the rebel ranks. About 4 1/2 o'clock P.M., the fire of the enemy's artillery slackerred, and at 5 it had entirely ceased, and their infantry had withdrawn to cover. During the latter we captured upwards of 3,000 prisoners, and lost but very few. LONGSTREET is very positively stated to have been mortally wounded, and to have fallen into our hands. Gen. MILL is said by prisoners to have been killed outright during the battle.

abstract: The celebration of the "glorious Fourth" in this City and vicinity, on Saturday, was characterized by all the heartiness, hopefulness and spirit of the good old times. The news from the Union army of the preceding day had been of a cheering character, yet not sufficiently definite and decisive to allay the anxieties of the people: but the timely arrival, early in the forenoon of the Fourth, of the dispatches of Gen. MEADE, accompanied by the congratulatory proclamation of the President, at once relieved the public mind, and everybody proceeded to celebrate the day with zeal, thankfulness and joy. The public celebrations were not on so extensive a scale as in many former years, but the private exhibitions of fireworks and other patriotic demonstrations, on the part of the citizens generally, were seldom if ever surpassed. The weather was fine, with a cool breeze and a pleasant intermingling of sun and shade; there were few accidents, and none of a serious nature; and altogether the eighty-seventh anniversary of our national Independence met with a reception worthy of the past, and disappeared under circumstances calculated to inspire hope for the future.

abstract: Immediately preceding the present invasion of Pennsylvania all the newspapers of rebeldom were for weeks filled with the most fearful and false accounts of atrocities committed by our armies in different parts of the Confederacy. The indiscriminate butchery of old men, little babies and women -- arson, robbery, rape; general rapine and the freeing of slaves, were among the crimes of which we were always and on every opportunity guilty. JEFF. DAVIS' barrel-organ, the Richmond Enquirer, played on these tunes of horror louder and more madly than any of its cotemporaries. On the 6th of June, just at the time when the rebel army was starting out on its career of invasion, it published an article under the caption of "Barbaric War," in which accusations of Yankee atrocities were piled up, until the rebel brain must have reeled in reading of them. In conclusion, it entered upon a series of historical parallels, in which one of the mildest and most chivalric of our Generals was compared to "GENSERIC, the King of the Vandals;" another to "CARACALLA, the Beast;" others to GALERIUS, GALLIENUS, and similar monsters; and, to an act of one national officer, it could only find a parallel in TIMOUR the Tartar, "who massacred one hundred thousand prisoners because they smiled when an army of their countrymen came in sight!" LINCOLN's policy was characterized in brief to be that of GALLIENUS -- "Tear, kill, hew in pieces!"

abstract: There has not been a closer or more exciting contest during the present season, than the one  which took place on Saturday, between the gray mare, Nellie Holcomb, driven by DAN. MACE, and the buckskin gelding, General McClellan, driven by HIRAM WOODRUFF.
lead_paragraph: There has not been a closer or more exciting contest during the present season, than the one which took place on Saturday, between the gray mare, Nellie Holcomb, driven by DAN. MACE, and the buckskin gelding, General McClellan, driven by HIRAM WOODRUFF. The contest was to a sulky, tin harness,) mile beats, best three in five, and McClellan was the favorite, at $100 to $40. Nellie won the first two heats; on which such another scene of consternation and long faces, as appeared among the betters at long odds, we have seldom seen -- some of whom made random bets, by way of hedging, such as $100 to $20 on the mare. McClellan -- although his fortunes for the time appeared to be obscured -- finally won, to the great delight of his numerous backers. There were about 1,500 people at the course, who were unanimous in their opinion that it was one of those contests which give more real satisfaction than many of greater pretensions, and in which the time is within four or five seconds as fast. The mare proved herself a good one, and but for the superior handling of the General by HIRAM, might have carried off the laurels.

lead_paragraph: The news from New-Orleans is not encouraging. The military force in Gen. BANKS' Department has not been kept sufficiently strong to do all the work required of it. Too many regiments of nine months men were sent thither; and though Gen. BANKS has used his forces with marvelous economy and success, he could not maintain the strength of his army, so constantly weakened by the expiration of the time for which his troops had enlisted.

abstract: The following has just been received:  Major-Gen. Halleck, Genneral-in-Chief:  The enemy opened at 1 P.M., from about one hundred and fifty guns, concentrated upon my left centre, continuing without intermission for about three hours, at the expiration of which time, he assaulted my left centre twice, being, upon both occasions, handsomely repulsed, with severe loss to him, leaving in our hands nearly three thousand prisoners.

abstract: Fourth of July Speech
snippet: Fourth of July Speech
lead_paragraph: Gov.SEYMOUR has our sympathies. Whether he was trammeled by party bonds or whether he was personally incapable of taking any larger view of the great theme which formed the topic of his speech on Saturday, we think him equally entitled to commiseration. With a rebel army pushing to the very heart of the Northern States -- in the very climax of a war which threatens utter and final ruin to the great Republic whose birth-day he was aiding to celebrate, Gov. SEYMOUR could find no more timely or inspiring topic than the degeneracy of our people and the tyranny of the Government which is trying to save the life of the nation. Not a word of condemnation for the rebels in arms -- not a syllable of hope or encouragement for those who are fighting against them, -- not an effort to rouse the patriotic fervor and courage of the thousands who heard him. His only complaints were against the Government: his only grievances were personal and political, and his only appeals were to party prejudices and resentments that ought to be buried forever until the country has been delivered from the peril that overhangs it.
headline: {'main': "Gov. Seymour's Speech.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gov. Seymour's Speech.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The rebels have left great numbers of their wounded in our hands and to our care. The Government and the surgeons will give them precisely the same attention that are bestowed upon our own wounded. They will hare hospital shelter and attendance, plain good food and the most skillful surgical aid. But we also urge that our people bestow upon these fallen rebels, our brethren of the South, a due share of the beneficent kindness and care which will be bestowed upon our own wounded in such unstinted profusion. They too suffer the agony of bullet, bomb and bayonet wounds; they too suffer from fever and other morbid complications. They too need lint and linen, wines, and jellies, and lemons and such other kindly comforts as only into hand of woman can furnish and bestow. Lately our mortal foes and deserving only of the fate they received, they are now at our mercy, and merit only such kindnesses as are dictated by humanity and Christianity to the fallen.

abstract: On Friday last, 1,500 girls and 300 young men, employed in WEST & BRADLEY's hoop-skirt factories, in this City, with a thousand or so of invited guests, went on a picnic excursion up the North River to Dudley's Grove -- the occasion being a gala-day given by that enterprising firm annually to their employes. The day was beautiful, and the anticipations of pleasure, which naturally ran high, were more than realized. The means of conveyance of this mammoth excursion -- probably the largest ever made up In this City by the employes of a single industrial establishment -- were three of our largest river barges, lashed parallel to one another, and towed by two steamers.

abstract: -- Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of JOHN DARNEVILLE, a blacksmith, aged forty years, who resided in Forty-third-street, near Eleventh-avenue. The deceased went to Pier No. 55 North River, for the purpose of bathing, and while in the water he was seized with cramps and was drowned before assistance could be rendered.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilman yesterday, a message was received from the Mayor vetoing the resolution to give the right of the streets for laying mains to the "Anthracite Gas. Lighting and Heating Co.," for the reasons that he knows nothing of the character or responsibility...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilman yesterday, a message was received from the Mayor vetoing the resolution to give the right of the streets for laying mains to the "Anthracite Gas. Lighting and Heating Co.," for the reasons that he knows nothing of the character or responsibility [???] the company, and that anthracite coal is unsuited for illuminating purposes. The Comptroller's current finance reports showed a balance of $1,608,719 38 in the City Treasury on the 30th ult., and that for the half year $3,014,319 47 had been expended on City account, out of $8,426,763 95, which comprises the amount of the appropriations for the year and balances remaining from previous years. The unexpended balances foot up $5,414,782 39. The Relief Fund contained a balance of $123,605 35 on the 27th ult. Only $200,000 worth of the bonds authorized by the sixth half million ordinance for this fund have been issued. For the fortnight ending June 27, $52,591 were disbursed from it, to 12,525 [???]. A letter and certificate from the Mayor and Comptroller, in relation to the selection of the Leader and Dispatch as official papers, was received and ordered on file. The Board adjourned to 4 o'clock P.M. on Thursday.
