abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Extravagant Estimates of the Victory
snippet: Extravagant Estimates of the Victory
lead_paragraph: There is some danger that, after LEE has been driven from Pennsylvania, the Government, as well as large numbers of the public, will cheat themselves into the belief that the result is greater than it really is, and forget the vastness of the task which still remains to be accomplished. We have all been so scared by the invasion, and the consequences of any failure in resisting it have assumed such monstrous proportions in our eyes, that we shall be, probably, tempted to forget, after it is over, that just as the invasion was a means to an end, and not the end itself, so is our repulse of the invader. LEE came into Pennsylvania not simply for the purpose of harrying the North, but that by harrying the North he might coerce it into peace, and into an acknowledgment of the independence of the Confederacy. And so also we, in rising to resist him, have been seeking not simply his expulsion from free soil, but the destruction of the power which he serves. The battle of Gettysburgh has not been fought solely to save Baltimore and Philadelphia, but to crush the Confederacy, and it is highly necessary that through all our rejoicings over our successes this should be kept constantly in mind. People are apt, when they find an enterprise very much more difficult than they expected when beginning it, to narrow the circle of their desires as they proceed, and to sit down satisfied at last at a point far short of the original goal. This is especially true of such enterprises as war.

abstract: LOUIS NAPOLEON seems quite inclined to try his hand again at intervention in our affairs. The news this morning announces that he has invited England to join him, and intimates that if he cannot set England, he will be content with Spain. Spain has suffered, it is said, more than France from our war; and therefore, it is hoped, she will be at least equally anxious to have it ended.

abstract: Work of the Hour, the
snippet: Work of the Hour, the
lead_paragraph: What is the great, fundamental, imperative duty of the Government at this hour? It is undoubtedly to see that the defeat of the rebel army of LEE be made complete and irretrievable. All other duties are secondary; all other necessities less necessary. To this work every energy should be bent, and all available columns, regiments and soldiers should be assigned. It would be an excellent thing to capture Richmond, and we should like to see it done; there are a hundred other duties to which troops could be put, -- none of which could be called altogether needless or contemptible. But the comprehensive duty -- the one thing the achievement of which, involves in itself success in a thousand other things, is the destruction of the main rebel army. It is that which for two years has barred our progress to Richmond; it is that which has prevented our establishing the National authority in Virginia and the Carolinas; it is that which has twice driven our banners back from Manassas -- from the Peninsula -- twice from the Rappahannock, and twice from the Upper Potomac. It is that army which stands, and has for two long years stood, as the great bulwark of the rebel Confederacy. It is that which at last had the audacity to assume the offensive on our soil, penetrate the great and populous State of Pennsylvania, threaten the capital of the nation and imperil the very existence of our Government. It is that army which on Thursday and Friday last dashed itself again and again upon the Army of the Potomac; but which, thanks to Heaven was driven from the field with appalling loss, defeated and discomfited. It was discomfited, but not, as it must be, utterly destroyed. Until it is destroyed, our prime work will be to effect that object. If it were destroyed, the rebel monster would be pierced in the head, pierced in the heart -- and death in all its members, from Richmond to Charleston, Chattanooga and Vicksburgh, would speedily ensue.

abstract: Gen. MEADE on Saturday issued a general order thanking the Army of the Potomac in behalf of the country for the glorious result of previous operations, and announcing that its task was not bet accomplished.
lead_paragraph: Gen. MEADE on Saturday issued a general order thanking the Army of the Potomac in behalf of the country for the glorious result of previous operations, and announcing that its task was not bet accomplished. That task -- the destruction, so far as possible, of the rebel army of Northern Virginia -- it is now moving to accomplish. It was ascertained on Sunday morning that LEX had commenced his retreat during Saturday night, and it was soon found that he was endeavoring to reach the Potomac, their rear-guard having passed through Emmettsburgh on Sunday morning at daylight. Gen. MEADE's headquarters were at Creagerstown, Md., about fifteen miles north of Frederick on Sunday, and yesterday they were probably at Frederick. The whole Army of the Potomac was in motion again yesterday, and entertained the highest hopes of capturing the greater part of the rebel force. In addition to the rebel pontoon bridge at Williamsport, their bridge at Darn No. 4 had been destroyed, and other preparations had been made to prevent a crossing. Our cavalry was also active at all points. Gen. KILPATRICK, on Saturday last, it is reported, intercepted a retreating train of rebel wagons near Monterey, on the Hagerstown and Gettysburgh road, capturing 900 prisoners, including 200 wounded officers, 150 wagons and two guns -- the rebels being completely surprised and unable to make any serious resistance.

abstract: Reply to Ohio Committee on the Arrest of Vallandigham
snippet: Reply to Ohio Committee on the Arrest of Vallandigham
lead_paragraph: GENTLEMEN: The resolutiens of the Ohio Democratic State Convention, which you present me, together with your introductory and closing remarks, being in position and argument mainly the same as the resolutions of the Democratic meeting at Albany, New-York, I refer you to my response to the latter as meeting most of the points in the former. This response you evidently used in preparing: your remarks, and I desire no more than that it be used with accuracy. In a single reading of your remarks, I only discovered one inaccuracy in matter which I suppose you took from that paper. It is where you say: "The undersigned are unable to agree with you in the opinion you nave expressed that the Constitution is different in time of insurrection or invasion from what it is in time of peace and public security." A recurrence to the paper will show you that I have not expressed the opinion you suppose. I expresses; the opinion that the Constitution is different in its application in cases of rebellion or invasion, involving the public safety, from what it is in times of profound peace and public security; and this opinion I adhere to, simply because by the Constitution itself things may be done in the one case which may not be done in the other.

abstract: New Rumors of
snippet: New Rumors of
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship City of Washington we have European advices to the 25th ult., three days later. The case of the seizure of the suspected gunboat Alexandra, at Liverpool, was commenced in the Court of Queen's Bench in London, on the 22d. On the 25th it was decided, by a verdict for the defendants. The Attorney-General, however, presented a bill of exceptions to the Judge's ruling, and the cases is not finally settled. The French mediation rumors continued current. The Emperor had declared to Messrs. LINDSAY and ROEBUCK, who had an audience at Fontainbleau recently, that he entertained the same views as before with respect to the civil war in America; that he was desirous again to interpose his good offices, and equally desirous that England should join him, and that he believed such joint intervention 'would be attended with good results. He further declared that he was moved by no unfriendly feeling toward the North, but solely by a desire to put a stop to the horrible carnage in America. It is stated that if England still refuses to join him, the Emperor will apply to Spain to do so. The intention of sending French reinforcements to Mexico had been adjourned, but warlike stores were being embarked at Cherbourg. It is insisted by the Paris correspondent of the London Herald that France is preparing for war on the Polish question. Affairs in Poland had undergone no change. The Liverpool cotton market was quiet and unchanged. Breadstuffs and Provisions continued dull. Consols for Money, 91[???]@91[???].

abstract: The Unheralded Heroes of
snippet: The Unheralded Heroes of
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has not only won a great battle, and delivered the nation from the gravest peril of the war, but it has triumphantly vindicated its claim to be classed with the veteran and heroic armies that history delights to honor. In all the details that reach us of the Titanic conflict that raged during three days about Gettysburgh, no fact shines out more conspicuously and cheeringly than the fortitude and unflinching valor of our men. They were equal to every crisis in the varying fortunes of the fight. Was it needed to stand firm and unswerving in line of battle, while the air was darkened by the missiles of a hundred guns parked by the rebels to clear the way for an infantry assault? -- there was not a corps in the Union Army that was not equal to the duty; and at least half of the corps composing the army at some time during the battle, were called on to endure this fearful, fiery trial. Was it needed after standing for hours before this withering blast of concentrated artillery fire, to receive the shock of the rebel army, massed and thrown forward in columns, in those impetuous charges that have so often before proved successful -- the veteran soldiers of MEADE's army were ready for the fierce onsets, and met them, steel to steel, as only the brave can meet a foe. Was it needed to fall back before overwhelming odds, yet not to fly; but to give blow for blow in falling back, and watch for the opportune moment to change retreat into victory and win back the lost ground? This, too, the army of the Potomac was capable of, as it again and again illustrated in the three days' battles around Gettysburgh. The annals of warfare are searched in vain for instances of more universal and better sustained valor than characterized our army during the recent combat.

abstract: A MAN SHOT IN THE SIXTH WARD.--At an early hour yesterday morning Officer McGLOIN, of the Sixth Ward, found a man lying upon the sidewalk in Leonard-street, in an insensible and almost helpless condition. He was taken to the Station-house, where it was found that he had received a wound in the head, apparently from a pistol ball.
lead_paragraph: A MAN SHOT IN THE SIXTH WARD. -- At an early hour yesterday morning Officer McGLOIN, of the Sixth Ward, found a man lying upon the sidewalk in Leonard-street, in an insensible and almost helpless condition. He was taken to the Station-house, where it was found that he had received a wound in the head, apparently from a pistol ball. When he was sufficiently revived to speak, he stated that his name was RICHARD LIEMANN, and his residence No. 149 Leonard-street. That while he was standing in front of his own door, some person who is unknown to him, came up behind him, and shot him in the head with a pistol. He further stated that he could form no idea as to the cause of so deadly an assault upon him. LIEMANN was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where, after an examination, the surgeons of that institution pronounced the wound to be a very serious one, the ball having fractured the skull and penetrated the brain. But little hope is entertained of his recovery.

abstract: Fourth of July, 1863 and 1862
snippet: Fourth of July, 1863 and 1862
lead_paragraph: -- The THE FOURTH OF JULY 1863 AND 1862.--The difference between the Fourth of July which has just passed and the one which preceded it was very noticeable. Both days brought to our ears the echo of battle. A year ago the morning told us of the seven days' fighting before Richmond and MCCLELLAN's change of base. It was heralded to us as a great, an unparalleled passage of arms; but though our people accepted the accounts of the bravery of our troops and gloried in them, as worthy of the day we were celebrating yet the enthusiasm was dampened, and we went through the day rather as matter of ceremony.

abstract: On Friday night last, immediately after LEE'S disaster at Gettysburgh, he began to withdraw his columns in a southwesterly direction toward the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night last, immediately after LEE'S disaster at Gettysburgh, he began to withdraw his columns in a southwesterly direction toward the Potomac. Since then we have no definite knowledge of his movements. It was at first reported that he was fortifying in the mountains, but the weight of evidence now strongly inclines to the belief that he pushed by the most feasible route for the Potomac, and is now on or near the north bank of the river, between Harper's Ferry and Williamsport.

abstract: Advices from Europe, two days later, reach us by the steamship Asia, which arrived at Halifax yesterday, having left Liverpool on the 27th, and Queenstown on the 28th ult. In the British. House of Lords on the 26th, Earl RUSSRLL denied that LOUIS NAPOLEON had renewed his overtures for joint mediation between the North and south. Mr. ROEBUCK announced in the House of Commons that he should bring on his motion for the recognition of the South on the 30th. The London Press was taking ground in favor of intervention. The Custom-house authorities at Liverpool had notified the agents of the steamer Gibraltar, (formerly the Sumter) that the guns of large calibre on board must be landed, or the ship would be detained on suspicion that they were intended for the "Confederates." The news of LEE's advance into the loyal States had been received in England by the Persia and the impression prevailed that he had made a mistake. The Polish question presents no new aspects. The journals ate engaged in discussing the probabilities of a war. Meantime the Poles have defeated the Russians near Widawaw, capturing six guns. There had been very little change in the markets since the sailing of the previous steamer. Consols 92@92 1/2.

abstract: THE COMMON COUNCIL COMMITTEE IN HARRISBURGH. -- The Sub-Committee of the Committee on National Affairs telegraphed yesterday that they could get no further than Harrisburgh, as communication with the front had been cut off. abstract: Magazines for July
snippet: Magazines for July
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine, for July, relies for attraction on the old features that have hitherto proved so satisfactory to its readers without venturing on any startling novelty. Mr. LOSSING continues the illustrated narratives of the war of 1812, with a condensed and well written account of Gen. HARRISON's "Northwest Campaign." "An American Family in Germany," is the title of a paper by J. Ross BROWNE, containing information that would, in ordinary times, be welcome to many. Some of the details -- as the "seven small children" -- seem rather mythical, but the general picture of German home-life, its advantages and disadvantages, is cleverly and amusingly related, and the writer's pencil comes, as usual, in aid of his pen. Dr. OSGOOD's "Easter Flowers" is an eloquent plea for the revival and encouragement of the picturesque old ceremonial observances that connect the changing seasons with the home affections and the genial humanities of the Christian Church. "England in the Good Old Times," is one of the most striking chapters from Dr. DRAPER's "Intellectual Development of Europe." Mr. TROLLOPE's and Miss EVANS' serial stories are continued. "Coal and Petroleum" is an article on the subject now assuming gigantic commercial proportions. The usual variety of short stories and sketches of society, criticism and chit-chat, proves the editor's skill in making up a miscellany that caters to the taste of all.
headline: {'main': 'THE JULY MAGAZINES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE JULY MAGAZINES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Surrender of
snippet: The Surrender of
lead_paragraph: The State of Mississippi passed its ordinance of secession on the 9th day of January, 1861. Four days afterward the Governor of the State ordered artillery to Vicksburg, "to hail and question passing boats on the Mississippi River." From that time until the Fourth of July, 1863 -- a period of nearly two years and a half -- there has been no passing of that point on the great river, except by the sovereign pleasure of the rebels, or under a tempest of fire that threatened annihilation. For the last four days the passage has again been free to the American flag, without batteries opened, or questions asked, and so it will remain until the end of time.

abstract: Independence Day and the Rebellion
snippet: Independence Day and the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The Fourth of July proves to have been a very dark day to the enemies of the great principles of Republican government that had their first annunciation on this continent on that day, eighty-seven years ago. Without any premeditation or arrangement -- without any thought of, or striving for dramatic effect -- for events were too serious, and issues too terrible to be thus paltered with, the late anniversary of American Independence has been consecrated afresh by victories of Liberty and Union that must render it more than ever the Sabbath-day of American freedom.

abstract: and Robert Ould's Mission to Hampton Roads
snippet: and Robert Ould's Mission to Hampton Roads
lead_paragraph: A sensation cotemporary published yesterday a dispatch from Washington, that the rebel gunboat Dragon came down the James River on Saturday, the 4th of July, under a flag of truce, having on board no less important a personage than ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, Vice-President of the Confederate States, and Mr. Commissioner OULD, the latter being the officer hitherto charged on the rebel side with the negotiations for the exchange of prisoners. These persons represented that they were bearers of an important missive from JEFFERSON DAVIS, Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy of the Confederate States, to ABRAHAM LINCOLN, Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States, and requested permission, so the story went, to proceed to Washington, in the Dragon, and present the letter to Mr. LINCOLN in person. It is further said that they declined to reveal anything of the nature of their mission.

abstract: Farnsworth, Brig.-Gen. Elon J., killed in battle
snippet: Farnsworth, Brig.-Gen. Elon J., killed in battle
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. ELON J. FARNSWORTH, who fell in the battle at Gettysbursh, was a nephew of Gen. J.F. FARNSWORTH, M.C., of Illinois. He was born in Livingston County, Michigan, in the year 1835, and was educated at the University of that State, at Ann Arbor. In 1857 he went to New-Mexico, and became attached to the United States Commissary Department in that distant frontier. Subsequently he visited Utah, and was engaged there in the same capacity. Love of adventure frequently led him to make long journeys through the mountains on horseback, and it was there, doubtless, that he gained such a knowledge and mastery of the horse as subsequently gave him the reputation of being the best rider in the army. News of the rebellion reached him in the Summer of 1861, and he immediately hastened home to join the Eighth Illinois cavalry, which his uncle was then organizing. He was made Battalion Quartermaster, but soon thereafter promoted to the Captaincy of Co. K of that celebrated regiment. During all the battles of the Peninsula, and POPE's campaign, he never missed a fight or skirmish in which that troop was engaged, and which are said to be forty-one in all.

abstract: On the news of the surrender of Vicksburgh reaching this City, our streets became the theatre of general rejoicing. The bulletins of the different newspapers were surrounded by thousands of anxious citizens. The extra editions of the journals were eagerly sought for, and the Star-Spangled Banner floated triumphantly from hundreds of places of business, and from all the public buildings of the City, and from innumerable masts in the harbor. And what gave a greater zest to the news was that the rebel stronghold fell on the Fourth of July.

abstract: There was a further decline of 5 cent. in Gold yesterday, the price closing 133 1/8 cent. on the news from Vicksburgh.
lead_paragraph: There was a further decline of 5 cent. in Gold yesterday, the price closing 133 1/8 cent. on the news from Vicksburgh. Previous to the news the Railway Share list at the Stock Exchange was firm and upward, but the rise was checked by the excitement in Gold, with the exception of Illinois Central, which went up to 109 1/2 cent. Exchange on London was unsettled after the news, and there was no rate named late in the day.

abstract: Vicksburgh has fallen! At last the announcement of this glorious event can be made, without fear that to-morrow's dispatches will make it necessary to qualify it in any manner.
lead_paragraph: Vicksburgh has fallen! At last the announcement of this glorious event can be made, without fear that to-morrow's dispatches will make it necessary to qualify it in any manner. Official intelligence has been received in Washington that the surrender was made on the 4th of July -- a dispatche to this effect having been received from Admiral PORTER. The dispatch boat, which left Vicksburgh on the morning of the 5th, and arrived at Cairo yesterday, brings the news that Gen. PEMBERTON sent a flag of truce on the morning of the 4th to Gen. GRANT, offering to surrender if his men were allowed to march out. This, of course, was declined by Gen. GRANT, and after consultation with his commanders, PEMBERTON concluded to surrender unconditionally. No further details have yet reached us.

snippet: Wheeler >amp; Wilson Patents Case
lead_paragraph: We publish in our legal columns this morning a decision by Judge NELSON, in the United States Circuit Court, which presents one of the most curious legal imbroglios that has occurred in our Courts. It arises under the Patent laws, which have been so fruitful in great litigations, and is one of the phases of the sewing-machine controversy. A brief statement of the matter will not be uninteresting. The contest is between the owners of the Singer, the Grover & Baker, and the Wheeler & Wilson sewing-machines, on one side, and one J.G. WILSON, who is the assignee of an old patent issued to AKINS & FELTHOUSEN, on the other. This patent has been before the Courts frequently, in sewing-machine controversies, and Judge NELSON himself, in 1860, decided that as between their patent and that issued to A.B. WILSON, on which the Grover & Baker and Wheeler & Wilson companies rest their claim, the invention of A.B. WILSON was prior. The assignee of AKINS& FELTHOUSEN, however, did not rest satisfied with that decision. He applied to the Commissioner of Patents for a reissue to him of the Akins & Felthousen patent. The owner of the Singer patent thereupon claimed that there was an interference between this patent and his own. The parties had a hearing before the Commissioner, who decided in favor of SINGER, and refused to issue the patent applied for. J.G. WILSON still was not satisfied with this decision against him, but appealed to Judge DUNLOP, sitting in the United States Circuit Court at Washington, and the Judge, after hearing the parties, reversed the decision of the Commissioner, and ordered the reissued patent to be made out to J.G. WILSON. The owners of the A.B. Wilson patent thereupon stepped in, declaring that this proposed reissue at any rate interfered with theirs. These parties were heard before the Commissioner, who again decided against J.G. WILSON, and declined to make the reissue for which he applied. Another appeal was taken by J.G. WILSON to Judge DUNLOP from this decision. The Judge decided -- and this is a curious point in the case -- not that the Commissioner was wrong in his decision on the merits between these parties; not that there was no interference between these two patents, but that on the former hearing in the controversy between J.G. WILSON and SINGER, he had ordered the patent to be reissued to J.G. WILSON, and that that order must be obeyed, whether there was any interference between it and any other patent or not; deciding, in fact, that there could be but one hearing in reference to the interference of a patent with any and all others. He thereupon again directed the Commissioner to make out the reissue to J.G. WILSON, and this order the Commissioner obeyed.

abstract: Telegrams from Harrisburgh give reports that the main body of LEE'S army was yesterday between South Mountain and Hagerstown, and it...
lead_paragraph: Telegrams from Harrisburgh give reports that the main body of LEE'S army was yesterday between South Mountain and Hagerstown, and it was thought that LEE would select some place between Hagerstown and the Potomac at which to give Gen. MEADE battle, as there was apparently no hope of his being able to cross the Potomac with his army without the certainty of an attack. The rise in the Potomac amounts to a freshet, which is likely to continue for at least a week, and even if the rebels had pontoons, it is a question whether they could make them available. Meantime our troops are concentrating from all points against the rebel army, and there is reason to believe that the case of LEE is desperate, if not entirely hopeless. There is no confirmation of the report by way of Harrisburgh, published yesterday, that a battle had already commenced near Williamsport. It probably grew out of the operations of our cavalry, who are continually harassing the enemy, picking up prisoners, and destroying the rebel transportation. The enemy's wounded are abandoned all along the route of their retreat.

abstract: The Fighting Qualities not due to McClellan
snippet: The Fighting Qualities not due to McClellan
lead_paragraph: What a prodigious purification of the atmosphere within one brief week! How much easier every loyal man breathes! How much quicker every factionist hears! How much clearer every traitor sees! Last week the air was thick with forebodings, repining, mutterings, revilings, cursings, threatenings -- every thing north of Mason and Dixon's seemed to be turning into "a foul and pestilent congregation of vapors." The weak sank despairing, and even the stoutest felt burdened. It was the baleful, lurid gloom before the Midsummer storm. All this now has passed. We are having the serenest time that has been known since the war began. There is a general sense of relief which every malignant, much as it irks him, can't help heeding. There is no longer a possibility of keeping up the old deceptions. The passions, and prejudices, and fears, and sordid motives, which but just now were so easily stirred into the wildest play are now beyond the reach of even the craftiest demagogue. A genuine public spirit, like some fresh breeze, now rules the hour.

abstract: Renews its Advocacy of Foreign Intervention
snippet: Renews its Advocacy of Foreign Intervention
lead_paragraph: The Tribune renews its advocacy of Foreign Intervention in our affairs. It sees no reason why we should not accept the good offices of France, if NAPOLEON sees fit to tender them, and welcome his aid in restoring peace with the rebels. It counsels great circumspection as to the terms of such a negotiation, and holds out the idea that Foreign Powers ought to urge the rebels to lay down their arms. If they choose to give such advice, of course we can have no objection. But this does not need our assent. LOUIS NAPOLEON, if he sees fit, can advise the rebels to stop the war at any moment he may choose. He is said to be in constant and close communication with the rebel emissaries in Europe, and cannot lack opportunities to make his wishes known to the rebel Government. He does not need our consent for any such proceeding as this.

abstract: Our military correspondent at Frederick cautions the public against estimating too highly the results of the late battle, and then...
lead_paragraph: Our military correspondent at Frederick cautions the public against estimating too highly the results of the late battle, and then says that the number of prisoners captured is twelve thousand. To these may be added two thousand captured by our cavalry at South Mountain, and mentioned by another of our correspondents. This makes altogether 14,000 prisoners from the battle of last week.

abstract: We have later news this morning, both from Vicksburgh and. from Maryland. There is no doubt now of the surrender of the great rebel stronghold on the Mississippi River. The garrison capitulated on the Fourth of July, after a consultation between Gens. GRANT and PEMBERTON, and the arrangement of terms on the 3d. GRANT told the rebel officer that the only terms which he could entertain were those of unconditional surrender -- thus confirming his title gained at Fort Donelson, of "Unconditional Surrender" GRANT. But, in consideration of the bravery the garrison had displayed, Gen. GRANT paroled the soldiers in Vicksburgh, and furnished them rations to carry them beyond our lines. The number of prisoners is 18,000, of whom two-thirds are in fighting condition. The immediate cause of surrender was exhaustion of supplies and of ammunition, and it is said that all we have beard concerning the suffering of the rebels in Vicksburgh has been but half the truth.

abstract: It is impossible for us, in the rejoicing over the two terrible blows which the rebellion has just received, not to think of the effect which...
lead_paragraph: It is impossible for us, in the rejoicing over the two terrible blows which the rebellion has just received, not to think of the effect which they will produce abroad. It will be all the more noticeable because just now the talk of intervention is actively renewed. The rebel envoys are active, their sympathizers are bold, the Court declines to convict the Alexandra, the correspondents talk about the intervention purpose of LOUIS NAPOLEON, and dilate upon his interview with SLIDELL, while MASON boldly announces the programme of the rebels. Right into the midst of all this scheming and apparent success of the rebel emissaries will come the news of the defeat of LEE and the fall of Vicksburgh like a thunderbolt cleaving the ground beneath their feet.

abstract: ARREST OF A TICKET SWINDLER.--A notorious ticket swindler named REUBEN LEAKE, was caught through the exertions of Capt. THORNE, of the Twenty-sixth Precinet, and taken yesterday before Jutice DOWLINE, at the Toombs Police Court.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A TICKET SWINDLER. -- A notorious ticket swindler named REUBEN LEAKE, was caught through the exertions of Capt. THORNE, of the Twenty-sixth Precinet, and taken yesterday before Jutice DOWLINE, at the Toombs Police Court. It appears from the testimony In the case, that LE???KE, aided by an ac???mylice who is yet at large, recently defrauded Mr. PAS???HAL P. SPEARS and a friend of his named PREN??? out o??? 135, by selling t???em spurious tickets for a passage to San Francisco. A bogus check for ??? 300 on the Park Bank, of this City, was ??? found upon L??? at the time of his arrest. He was committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Some of our cotemporaries speak of our recent victories as having ended all thought and all danger of intervention on the part of Foreign Powers.
lead_paragraph: Some of our cotemporaries speak of our recent victories as having ended all thought and all danger of intervention on the part of Foreign Powers. While the Union was losing ground, France and England, they say, would have been willing to interfere; but as soon as victory inclines to the other side, all motive for intervention disappears, and they will become anxious again to stand well with the Government of the United States. We do not concur in this view of the subject. On the contrary, the dangers of intervention were never so near, in our judgment, as on the eve of decisive victories on the part of the United States.

abstract: The funeral of Capt. E.F. MUNN, of the Sixty-  sixth regiment New-York Volunteers, who was killed at Gettysburgh, took place on Wednesday at Westchester. The ceremonies were very impressive the people turned out en masse, and in the procession were the scholars of Harrington's School, and the Empire Engine Company. The remains were escorted to the grave by an invalid corps from Fort Schuyler, composed entirely of wounded soldiers.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Capt. E.F. MUNN, of the Sixty- sixth regiment New-York Volunteers, who was killed at Gettysburgh, took place on Wednesday at Westchester. abstract: -- The battle of Gettysburgh is the first great battle, and the Pennsylvania campaign the first great campaign, which the main rebel army has undertaken since the war opened without the presence and aid of Stonewall JACKSON; and the failure of their campaign has been as complete as their discomfiture in the battle. It may be that these facts had no connection with each other. But it must be remembered that in each of LEE's five previous campaigns it was JACKSON who did the one decisive thing -- it was his action in each case which formed the turning point of the battle. The rebels say that since his death his ghost is still seen hovering near the scenes of battle; but, if they are sure of this, the issue of the late campaign would seem to give color to the assertion of a spiritual medium who has lately been en rapport with JACKSON, and who avers that since his death he has turned Abolitionist and fights for the cause of the North.
lead_paragraph: -- The battle of Gettysburgh is the first great battle, and the Pennsylvania campaign the first great campaign, which the main rebel army has undertaken since the war opened without the presence and aid of Stonewall JACKSON; and the failure of their campaign has been as complete as their discomfiture in the battle. It may be that these facts had no connection with each other. But it must be remembered that in each of LEE's five previous campaigns it was JACKSON who did the one decisive thing -- it was his action in each case which formed the turning point of the battle. abstract: -- Two counterfeiters, known to the Police as HENRY PECKHAM and GEORGE HYER, about four weeks ago broke jail at Riverhead, L.I., and escaped to this City. Last evening Sheriff OSBORN, of Suffolk County, and Constable OVERTON, of Port Jefferson, L.I., succeeded in arresting PECKHAM. HYER has not yet been found. They were convicted in Suffolk County under the names of HENRY WILSON and GEORGE SMITH.

abstract: THE CASE OF THE BALTIMORE POLICE COMMISSIONERS. -- Some weeks since, an attachment was issued by Judge GARRISON, of the Kings County ???. on the application of counsel for the Baltimore Police Commissioners, who, at the commencement of the rebellion, were imprisoned in Fort Lafayette by order of the Government. The writ, placed in the hands of Sheriff CAMPBELL, required him to arrest Col. MARTIN BURKE, the commandant of Fort Lafayette, requiring him to show by what power or authority he detained the Commissioners. The Sheriff proceeded to execute the writ, and failing in his object, made his return to the Court yesterday afternoon. The return states in effect, that COL. BURKE is Commandant of Forts Hamilton and Lafayette; that the forts are garrisoned with troops of the United States, who are well armed and provisioned; that Col. BURKE is within Fort Hamilton, and the Sheriff was unable to gain admission; that he was formally assured by the officer of the day that his orders were to admit no one, and that they were prepared to resist all or any forces the Sheriff might bring against them. The Sheriff, in his return, further states that all the militia regiments of Kings County are absent in Pennsylvania and in the United States service, excepting the Seventieth regiment; that the Sheriff called upon Col. CROPSY, of that regiment, and was informed by him that he had received marching orders from the Federal Government, and that he was not under the control of the Sheriff of Kings County. The Sheriff states in conclusion that, not having a sufficient force or arms at his disposal, he is unable to execute the writ.

abstract: 7 o'clock, as a man named JOSEPH COCKING, was entering the Erie Railway care at Jersey City, some person picked his pocket of about $15,000 in bills. He felt the person in the act, and dropping his carpet bag, containing $4,800 in gold, made his way through the crowd after the thief, and upon his return the carpet bag and gold were also missing. One of the parties was arrested and committed to the City prison.

abstract: Some time since, the Secretary of the Treasury contracted for six new revenue cutters -- one to be built in Baltimore, one in Philadelphia, and some three or four here. The Petux and Ashuelot were launched Wednesday and the day before. The description of one answers for both -- it is as follows: Length, 130 feet; beam, 26 1/2 feet; depth, 11 feet. Their full armament will comprise, for each vessel, one 36-  pound Parrott rifle on a pivot, forward; four 34-  pound guns in broadside, and a pivot-gun aft -- probably a 24-pounder. They will be rigged as topsail schooners, and are to have double vertical oscillating engines, which are to be from the Novelty Works.
lead_paragraph: Some time since, the Secretary of the Treasury contracted for six new revenue cutters -- one to be built in Baltimore, one in Philadelphia, and some three or four here. abstract: The Marquis of Clanricarde said that in asking the question of which he had given notice on this subject, he was not going to discuss the propriety of the justice of the decisions of the American Prize Courts. But he thought that the proceedings of those Courts should be closely watched, for if doctrines were admitted there contrary to those maintained in this country, great confusion would be the result hereafter.

abstract: A meeting, convened by the Leicester Emancipation Society to hear a lecture by Mr. CONWAY, was held in the New Hall, Leicester, on Monday evening. The hall was crowded. Rev. R. BELL. Wesleyan Minister, was called to the chair. Mr. CONWAY enlisted the attention and sympathy of the audience for an hour and a half by the delivery of a very argumentative and convincing lecture upon the American crisis. In the course of his address he alluded to the published correspondence between himself and Mr. MASON, and said that whatever blundering might have occurred in this attempt at diplomacy, the whole affair rested on his own shoulders. Neither Mr. TAYLOR, the member for Leicester, from whose residence the proposition to Mr. MASON was dated, nor Mr. BRIGHT. M.P., who had presided at the London Tavern meeting, nor any of the gentlemen with whom he had acted in this country, had anything whatever to do with the offer he had made in that correspondence. He was anxious that what might be considered haste and mistake on his part should be limited to himself, as no one else had anything whatever to do with the affair.

abstract: -- There is another call upon the women of the North for aid to our wounded. Thousands of our brave soldiers are at this moment suffering all the agonies that flow from war -- loss of limbs and members, and wounds from bullets, bombs and bayonets, in all parts of their bodily frames. These again produce fever, exhaustion, and innumerable complications of disease. Lint, linen, etc., are needed; fruits, jellies, etc. are needed; lemons are needed. The channels through which these can be sent are by this time well known to all, and we only take occasion to remind those who have heretofore and often labored so efficiently, of the new emergency that has arisen.
lead_paragraph: -- There is another call upon the women of the North for aid to our wounded. abstract: Paul, Gen. G. R., killed in battle
snippet: Paul, Gen. G. R., killed in battle
lead_paragraph: This officer, GABRIEL RENK PAUL, who was killed in the battle near Gettysburgh, on the 2d inst., had been a long time in the service, and was highly esteemed, as well for his personal as his military qualities. He was a native of Missouri, and was appointed from this State a cadet in the Military Academy in the year 1830. He was almost the only one in his class who has received distinction during the present war, though a number of his mates won honor on the fields of Mexico. Graduating in June, 1834, with credit, he entered the military service immediately as Second Lieutenant by brevet, and attained the full rank of that grade six months later. He was promoted First Lieutenant, Oct. 26, 1836, but it was nearly ten years before he rose again, which was to the rank of Captain, April 19, 1846. In the Mexican war he behaved with conspicuous gallantry, and was brevetted Major Sept. 13. 1847, for his meritorious conduct in the battle of Chepultepec, He was also distinguished at Cerro Gordo and Contreras. Just previous to the rebellion, we find him third Captain in the line of the Seventh Infantry. This regiment was some years ago stationed near this city, and many of our readers will remember its fine appearance on the occasion of the funeral of Col. BENTON. On the 22d of April, 1861, Capt. PAUL was promoted full Major, transferred to the Eighth Infantry, and soon after was ordered to New-Mexico. It was here that he became particularly distinguished in the latter part of 1861 and early part of 1862, in assisting in the expulsion of the Texans under SIBLEY from that Territory. Upon the rebels menacing the Territory, Col. CANBY, who was in command of the department, placed Maj. PAUL as commandant at Fort Union, while he, Col. (now General) CANBY, moved down three hundred miles to Fort Craig. About this time the subject of our sketch was promoted Lieutenant-Colonel, and had permission to command the Fourth regiment New-Mexican Volunteers. Col. PAUL received great credit for his promptitude and energy in fitting out and expediting a column to march out and attack the enemy, who had then taken possession of Santa Fe, and threatened to overrun the whole Territory. The column sent out by Col. PAUL was composed of the First Colorado, Capt. RUTTER's and Capt. CLAFLIN's batteries, and a battalion of the Filth Regulars, all under Col. SLOUGH, of the Colorado Volunteers. A short time afterwards, however, Col. SLOUGH resigned, and the expedition returned, somewhat disheartened, to Fort Union. Col. PAUL at once re-organized the troops, and putting himself at their head, moved out on the 6th of April of last year. One of the first things done by Col. PAUL was to send back to Santa Fe quicker than they came, a party sent by Gen. SIBLEY, under a flag of truce, ostensibly to effect the release of some paroled Union prisoners, but in reality to delay the junction of PAUL's forces with those of Col. CANBY. This was at Han Jose, near Bernel Springs. After a fight at Apache Canon, in which the rebels were defeated with considerable loss, Col. PAUL proceeded to the vicinity of Fort Craig, (in May) and successfully effected a junction with Col. CANBY at La Tijera in Carmuel Pass. The rebels had concentrated at Paralta, and PAUL's column moved upon them from the north, and CANBY's from the east. An engagement ensued, which, however, was of short duration, as the enemy fled in a panic, retreating upon El Paso. In recognition of his New-Mexican services, Col. PAUL was promoted a Brigadier-General of Volunteers in September last, and assigned to duty under Gen. CASEY, in Washington City, where his talents for organization were displayed in a manner altogether satisfactory to the military authorities. Invidious tongues have accused him of a lurking sympathy for the secession cause but there probably never was any foundation for the impeachment of his loyalty, and of his fidelity to his Government he has just added all the testimony that could be required of a brave and true soldier. His death will be mourned in St. Louis, where he was born, and where he has many family connections.

abstract: The draft which is to be made at once to fill up the existing regiments of the National Guard and to form new regiments will, no doubt, induce many young men, who prefer to choose their associates and to be under experienced officers, to connect themselves with some existing organization without delay. The friends of the Twenty-third regiment, now in the field, are desirous of filling its ranks to the maximum number, and we learn that several members of Company D, who are now at home, will receive applications for membership at the Brooklyn Armory, without regard to the present term of service in the field.

abstract: The proximity to our shores of the pirate Alabama prevented us a few weeks since from duly reporting the accomplishment of a naval feat unparalleled in the constructing history of the Untied States Navy. It was nothing less than the building of an iron-clad vessel-of-war for the protection of the coast of California, and the subsequent separation other different sections, and their shipment for San Francisco. Had the Alabama and the Tacany been aware of the fact, they would probably have watched the vessel carrying toe iron-clad -- but even then they would find her minus some of her most Important parts, which were sent overland. The name of the iron-clad is Comanche. She was built by the Messrs??? SECOR, of Jersey City -- Senator RYAN, of California' being one of her chief contractors.

abstract: Invasion--military advantages of the
snippet: Invasion--military advantages of the
lead_paragraph: When LEE first commenced the passage of the Potomac, the timid and malignant treated the event as if it were not only the knell of the Union, but the ruin of the North. The Administration were denounced for permitting it with as much energy as if they had invited the invasion and were serving out rations to the rebel troops, -- without previously administering to them the oath of allegiance. One of our cotemporaries announced as an awful circumstance that "the trumpets of STUART were ringing in the Valley of the Cumberland," although the horrors of the situation were no more heightened by this incident than by the equally unquestionable fact that STUART was coming through the same region with his back to his horse's tail and his watch in his fob. Even Mr. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD denounced as "nonsense" the notion that a Government is not bound to prevent an invader from ever crossing the frontier. HOOKER's failure to give him battle in Virginia, before he got over the river, was set down as a crowning proof both of his incapacity and HALLECK's imbecility, -- which it might or might not be.

abstract: -- The fall of Vicksburgh was not known at the rebel capital on Monday last. The Richmond Enquirer of that day reported the "garrison to be in splendid condition -- full rations of flour, meal, rice, sugar, molasses, &c., being issued to the men" -- which was perfectly true; but the Richmond organ might have added that these excellent and varied rations upon which the Vicksburgh garrison were gorging, were the free gift of the chivalrous and victorious hero of the Mississippi Valley, Major-Gen. U.S. GRANT, who generously furnished them with supplied of fodder after they had laid down their arms.

abstract: HAMILTON COLLEGE. -- The fifty-first commencement of Hamilton College takes place July 16, in Clinton, Oneida County, N.Y. President FISHER will preach his fifth annual sermon before the Graduating Class, Sunday afternoon, July 12. Sunday evening, Rev. C.H.A. BULKLEY, of Brooklyn, will address the Society of Christian Research. Prize declamation, Monday evening. Tuesday afternoon, Class Day exercises by the class of '63. Tuesday evening, the Sigma Phi Fraternity will be addressed by Hon. CHARLES B. SEDGWICK, of Syracuse, and a poem by Rev. EDWARD HOPPER, of New-York. Wednesday afternoon, the Society of Alumni will be addressed by Dr. JAMES EELLS, of Brooklyn, and a poem will be delivered by Prof. JOHN C. LONG, of Westfield. Thursday, commencement exercises.

abstract: Mr. MAX MARETZEK, whose health has been seriously assailed during the past two months, has sufficiently recovered to visit the City. The preparations for his forthcoming season are being carried on with great spirit. Mme. MEDORI will return to America early in the Fall; indeed, Mr. MARETZEK secured her passage yesterday. The composer o. "lone" will probably accompany her. He is, at -I events, heartily pleased with the reception of is work in America, and only needs the nod from MARETZEK to compose a new one expressly for the Academy of Music. One of the earliest productions of Mr. MARETERK's season will be GOUNOD's opera of "Faust" -- the latest and most successful revival in London, and overwhelmingly popular wherever brought out. In reserve also he has VERDI's opera of "La Forza del Destino." We shall undoubtedly have a season of great activity and success. It will commence immediately after the close of the American Institute Fair -- about the first or second week of October.

abstract: The and The War
snippet: The and The War
lead_paragraph: The Administration is acting wisely in ordering the immediate enforcement of the draft. We have just achieved two great victories which it seems should paralyze the war power of the rebellion. We have beaten its greatest army, and captured its most powerful stronghold. Upon LEE's army the eastern half of the Confederacy depended for protection. Upon Vicksburgh the western half depended for safety. After LEE's defeat and Vicksburgh's fall, it might seem that the rebellion would come to a speedy end, and without further effort on the part of the North. We shall soon know the effect of these losses on the rebel States; but we are prepared to hear that no signs of submission appear, and that redoubled bitterness and frenzy rule the Southern heart.

abstract: It is not easy to calculate the value, in a military point of view, of the capture of Vicksburgh by the Union troops.
lead_paragraph: It is not easy to calculate the value, in a military point of view, of the capture of Vicksburgh by the Union troops. This success compels the speedy fall of Port Hudson -- if, indeed, the two events do not prove cotemporaneous -- and then every rebel cord will be unloosed that has, ever since the rebellion, bound the National aorta -- the Mississippi River. We have taken frequent occasion hitherto to point out in what way the loss of the Mississippi River would embarrass and weaken the rebellion. In the first place, it cuts off utterly all the supplies of beef and bread that the rebel armies long derived in such abundance from Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas. This is of itself an exceedingly heavy disaster. It is well known that during the first two years of the war an immense amount of the rebel subsistence came from the States west of the Mississippi. Texas, it was boasted, could have supplied the entire population of the Confederate States with meat for years. And no one who has ever seen her almost limitless prairies, and the countless herds that lived upon them luxuriantly the year through, doubted the fact. Western Louisiana was similarly rich in animal life. Arkansas and Texas were remarkable for wheat and Indian corn. The Confederate States had reason to be proud of the food-producing and war-sustaining capacity of the vast Secession districts west of the Mississippi River; and it had equal reason to be confident in and feel flattered by the haste, and heartiness, and even passionate enthusiasm with which the population of that trans-Mississippi region embraced the fortunes of the rebellion. The rebel authorities of the States of Arkansas and Texas have boasted that from the records of the Adjutant General's office of the Confederate States they could show that each State had put into the field as many soldiers as there were voters in the respective States, at recent elections.

abstract: One of our Special Army Correspondents, telegraphing from Middletown, Maryland, says the prospect of another collision between the Army of the Potomac and the rebel Army under LEE increases.
lead_paragraph: One of our Special Army Correspondents, telegraphing from Middletown, Maryland, says the prospect of another collision between the Army of the Potomac and the rebel Army under LEE increases. The rebels were trying to push a portion of their force and their wounded across the Potomac at Shepardstown, but PLEASANTON was expected to interfere with the arrangement. They had run the greater portion of their trains into a valley near Williamsport, and covered them by artillery posted on the south bank of the Potomac. Whether they will succeed in saving them remains to be seen. Fully one-third of their transportation had been destroyed up to yesterday morning, and our cavalry were still hard at work. On Wednesday the rebels pressed our cavalry under Gen. BUFORD back upon Boonsboro, and threw a few shells into the place, when Gen. BURFORD dismounted his men and fought the rebels on foot for two hours, finally driving them back to Antietam Creek. A rumor reached Baltimore yesterday that Gen. KILPATRICK had been killed in this fight, but it proves to be false.

abstract: The organization of the Invalid corps is progressing rapidly under the immediate direction of Provost-Marshal-Gen. NUGENT of this District, aided by the Provost-Marshals in each Congressional District, and we learn that uniforms have been ordered for the first battalion. About 520 men have already joined the corps in this City -- 350 by transfer from their regiments, and the remainder by enlistment. From the progress making, Col. NUGENT thinks that he shall soon have a full regiment organized and ready for service. As none but men who have received an honorable discharge from the army, and produce certificates of good character, are received in this corps, the morale of the men is excellent.

abstract: Advices from the City of Mexico to the 10th ult., received by way of Acapulco and San Francisco, are of no particular importance. JUAREZ arrived in San Luis Potosi on the 7th, and established the seat of Government there, while the late garrison of the city, numbering some 19,000, were distributed at points west. It was believed that FOREY had sent a communication to JUAREZ, urging him to accept terms of peace. We also have some details of recent events in Mexico by way of Havana, but nothing later.

abstract: We hope neither the Government nor the country will forget that even if LEE is again defeated on the Potomac, it is not at all probable that the rebellion will be completely suppressed in another fortnight.
lead_paragraph: We hope neither the Government nor the country will forget that even if LEE is again defeated on the Potomac, it is not at all probable that the rebellion will be completely suppressed in another fortnight. At the very best, it is an but certain that a large portion of the rebel army will escape into Virginia let it be in ever so great disorder and disorganization; and once there, we should make [???] great mistake in supposing that all that skill industry, and energy can do, will not be done by the leaders to gather up and reunite the fragments for another struggle. Fresh men will be forced into the field, worse men, perhaps, than those with whom we are now contending -- younger and older, feebler, but still brave men, well officered, and subject to an iron discipline; and if it is not possible to organize them in Eastern Virginia, they will be organized in the mountains or in the Cotton States. We should be strangely and inexcusably blind if we rushed to the conclusion that the dispersal of even two of their best armies will drive the leaders of the insurrection into immediate submission. They will hold out as long as they can keep eve[???] ten thousand men together, in the hope that time may do for them what skill and valor have failed to do, and that some thing or other may "turn up," to restore their fortunes before the last sparks of resistance are trampled out; and even after they have lost all hope, they will hold out for honor's sake. They are not, as they have already abundantly proved, easily moved from their purpose by considerations of humanity, and if the protraction of hostilities for three months or half a year longer, would enable them, even at the cost of thirty or forty thousand lives, to make their appearance in Paris and London, with a little more eclal we may be perfectly certain they will no deny themselves this source of distinction

abstract: The action of the Kings County authorities, in the well-known Fort Hamilton case, seems likely to involve the Executive of the State in serious trouble with the National authorities.
lead_paragraph: The action of the Kings County authorities, in the well-known Fort Hamilton case, seems likely to involve the Executive of the State in serious trouble with the National authorities. Our readers doubtless remember that when, in consequence of the orders of the Secretary of War, the Police Commissioners of the City of Baltimore were arrested and brought North, they were placed in charge of Col. BURKE, the Military Commandant at Fort Hamilton. Upon application of the next friend of the Commissioners, a writ of habeas corpus was issued in behalf of the prisoners by the County Judge of Kings County, and directed to Col. BURKE.

abstract: Gen. FARNSWORTH, who fell in the late battle before Gettysburgh, last week, was not Brig.-Gen. JOHN F. FARNSWORTH, of the Second Congressional District of Illinois. The later officer was disabled during the campaign on the Peninsula, while making a gallant charge. It was for this that he received the encomiums of Gens. SUMNER and STONEMAN, and was appointed Brigadier-General. But the injury was so serious as to impair permanently his health; and being unwilling to receive pay and emoluments when not performing duty, he resigned his commission some time since. He was in this City last week, but was confined to his room all the while, and I fear will never again regain his health. J.B.M.

abstract: The announcement in the TIMES, of Friday, that Capt. MANIERRE, of the Eighth Congressional District, had completed his arrangements for the proposed draft, and had issued his formal notice to the able-bodied citizens of the Eighteenth, Twentieth...
lead_paragraph: The announcement in the TIMES, of Friday, that Capt. MANIERRE, of the Eighth Congressional District, had completed his arrangements for the proposed draft, and had issued his formal notice to the able-bodied citizens of the Eighteenth, Twentieth and Twenty-first Wards that the drawings would take place at the District Headquarters on Monday next, produced the most intense excitement amongst the people of the City, and brought home to them, for the first time, as reality, that which for months has been an expectation, and, to a certain extent, a byword and a joke. In justice to our people, it must be recorded that the almost universal expression is that of satisfaction and acquiescence in the wisdom and propriety of the measure.

abstract: --The mourners and admirers of an estimable character, Chaplain FULLER, will be glad to hear that a memoir of his life, by RICHARD F. FULLEE, has been issued by WALKER, WISE  Co., of Boston.
lead_paragraph: -- The mourners and admirers of an estimable character, Chaplain FULLER, will be glad to hear that a memoir of his life, by RICHARD F. FULLEE, has been issued by WALKER, WISE & CO., of Boston. Chaplain FULLER was a brother of MARGARET OSOLI, and early in the war, accepted the chaplaincy of a New-England regiment. The story of his career is told mainly from the pen of the deceased. The men and things discussed belong to the active present, and are fresh with interest. An excellent account of the combat between the Merrimac and the Monitor will be found to be one of the most interesting chapters of the volume.

abstract: The Tenth regiment, under the command of Lieut.-Col. MISSING, will leave this City for Baltimore to-day. The regiment is ordered to assemble at the Arsenal, corner of White-street, at 3 o'clock P.M. It has now 500 men fully uniformed and equipped, and is ready to receive new enlistments today before their departure. Such as wish to join a Militia regiment and thus avoid the draft have here a last chance afforded them. The Tenth go out for three months service.

abstract: Hoboken; Body of Man Found in Elyrian Fields
snippet: Hoboken; Body of Man Found in Elyrian Fields
lead_paragraph: The body of an unknown man was found on the beach opposite the Elysian Fields yesterday forenoon, and was taken in charge by Coroner F.W. BOHNSTEDT. Upon examination the Coroner found very severe cuts or wounds on the temple, and on the back of the head, which appeared to have been inflicted with some sharp instrument. Deceased is about 5 feet 6 inches in height, dark hair, high forehead. When found there were no pantaloons on the person; had on a coarse white linen shirt, with the initials "J.S." marked with red ink: a black and white checked vest, with suspenders tied together to his back, as though some weight had been tied to the same. The body appears not to have been in the water over twenty-four hours. The body was taken to B.N. CRANE's, undertaker, No. 132 Washington-street, for identification, and the inquest will be commenced to-day.

abstract: The; Its Operations and Exemptions; The and The War
snippet: The; Its Operations and Exemptions; The and The War
lead_paragraph: The Conscription now about to take place for 300,000 men, to serve for three years or during the war, naturally absorbs all other interests for the time being. It is a measure that, in a peculiar manner, comes home to "the business and bosoms" of every family wherein there is an arms-bearing member. The volunteer system long since exhausted the spontaneously patriotic and warlike spirit of the community. When volunteering for the love of the cause came to an end, the bounty system was brought into requisition, and money considerations induced tens of thousands to enlist who otherwise would not have done so. But the charge on national and municipal credit, of keeping up a vast army by bounties, was too great to be long borne. The Government has at last resorted to the means that all great military nations employ to raise and sustain armies; and it is the only means that in the long run can be relied on. The plan is that of general, impartial Conscription.

abstract: Orders have been received by Capt. J.B. GREGORY, Provost-Marshal of the Third Congressional District, (Brooklyn.) and Capt. SAMUEL T. MADDOX,...
lead_paragraph: Orders have been received by Capt. J.B. GREGORY, Provost-Marshal of the Third Congressional District, (Brooklyn.) and Capt. SAMUEL T. MADDOX, Provost-Marshal of the Second Congressional District, (Williamsburgh and the country towns,) to prepare at once for the draft. The enrollment has been completed in both Districts, and the final arrangements, such as preparing slips containing the names and ages of persons enrolled, are being made as speedily as possible. In Capt. GREGORY's office fifty clerks are employed at this business, and it is expected that the names will be drawn on Wednesday or Thursday next, it being impossible to have everything in readiness before that time.
headline: {'main': 'Preparations for the Draft in Brooklyn.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Preparations for the Draft in Brooklyn.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Orders were received from Washington yesterday, directing Admiral PAULDING to dispatch to sea at once such vessels, of proper tonnage, as were at his disposal. In a few hours the corvette Marion, with Midshipmen on board, and the yacht America, were sent off, fully manned and equipped. Two or three regular navy-built steamers are preparing rapidly to follow them, and before a week five or six vessels will be on their track.
lead_paragraph: Orders were received from Washington yesterday, directing Admiral PAULDING to dispatch to sea at once such vessels, of proper tonnage, as were at his disposal. abstract: THE SEVENTEENTH REGIMENT TO GARRISON FORT HAMILTON. -- Orders were received yesterday directing two companies of the Seventieth regiment artillery to prepare to march at an hour's notice. The Colonel ordered the regiment to meet at the arsenal at 10 o'clock A.M., in full uniform and dismounted, with the view of selecting the companies with the fullest ranks. Capt. THOMAS MCCARTY, of Company C, reported 120 men, and Capt. JOHN TIMMES 100 men ready for duty. These companies were selected and ordered to march under command of Maj. ROBERT SMITH. Their destination is either Fort Hamilton or some of the fortifications on the Staten Island side of the Narrows. An artillery company from Rochester, N.Y., was some time since ordered to garrison Fort Hamilton, and if they arrive soon will probably be assigned to that position. If not, the Seventieth will be sent there and the Rochester company to Staten Island. The following are the officers of the Seventieth regiment as far as selected: Colonel, WM. J. CROPSEY; Lieutenant-Colonel, Francis C. Granning; Major, Robert Smith: Adjutant, John McLear; Quartermaster, Robert Sullivan.
lead_paragraph: THE SEVENTEENTH REGIMENT TO GARRISON FORT HAMILTON. -- Orders were received yesterday directing two companies of the Seventieth regiment artillery to prepare to march at an hour's notice. abstract: ATAL STABBING AFFRAY.--About 12 o'clock on Thursday night, a young man named EDWARD CALLOHAN, residing at No. 243 West Seventeenthstreet, entered the drinking saloon of THOS. LANE, on the corner of Baxter and Park streets, and commenced to beat a woman, striking her several times on the head and breast.
lead_paragraph: ATAL STABBING AFFRAY. -- About 12 o'clock on Thursday night, a young man named EDWARD CALLOHAN, residing at No. 243 West Seventeenthstreet, entered the drinking saloon of THOS. LANE, on the corner of Baxter and Park streets, and commenced to beat a woman, striking her several times on the head and breast. The barkeeper of the place remonstrated with him in regard to his conduct, whereupon CALLOHAN tried to fight with all present. He soon got into a quarrel with a man whose name is unknown, during which the latter stabbed CALLOHAN in the region of the heart, inflicting dangerous wounds. The stranger immediately fled, and has not been arrested. The injured man was taken to the New-York Hospital by Officer HYDE. His physicians say that he cannot recover.

abstract: -- We have indubitable evidence from the Richmond papers that there has again been extreme fright in the rebel capital recently. The Richmond Dispatch, of the 7th inst., compliments the alacrity with which, on the first notes of alarm, "the yeomanry," that is, the farmers and inhabitants generally of the adjacent country, flocked into the forts of Richmond and took position for its defence. They came in, of all ages, says the Dispatch, from the silver-haired veteran to the stripling youth, with squirrel guns and whatever other arms were handiest. The Richmond journal declines to say what number of these improvised, shot-gun warriors have resolved themselves into "a wall" around Richmond, lest Gen. DIX should become frightened and decline to seek destruction by throwing himself against their valor.
lead_paragraph: -- We have indubitable evidence from the Richmond papers that there has again been extreme fright in the rebel capital recently. abstract: Persons well informed on the subject, believe that the steamer which has been committing depredations on our commerce at the mouth of the Bay of Funday on the coast of Nova Scotia, is the Lord Clyde, which after examination escaped from Cardiff about 30 days ago. She is a fast steamer, and it will take powerful vessels to protect our coast from her. The Nary Department should see to this.
lead_paragraph: Persons well informed on the subject, believe that the steamer which has been committing depredations on our commerce at the mouth of the Bay of Funday on the coast of Nova Scotia, is the Lord Clyde, which after examination escaped from Cardiff about 30 days ago. She is a fast steamer, and it will take powerful vessels to protect our coast from her. The Nary Department should see to this.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF THE REMAINS OF GEN. ZOOK. -- The flags on the City Hall were at half-mast yesterday, in honor of Brig.-Gen. SAMUEL K. ZOOK, one of the fallen heroes of Gettysburgh, whose remains arrived in this City late on Friday evening, and now lie in state in the Governor's Room. His funeral will take place under the direction of the Common Council Committee on National Affairs, to-morrow.

abstract: A telegram was received from Philadelphia last evening stating that seven hundred wounded soldiers -- New-Yorkers, New-Englanders and Pennsylvanians -- left that city for New-York at 7 1/2 o'clock, and asking that they be "taken care of." Immediately upon the receipt of this intelligence Col. JOHNSON started for Jersey City to receive the sufferers, and Col. FRANK E. HOWE, with a committee from the New-  England Rooms, and the New-York Loyal League Club, consisting of ten gentlemen, quickly followed after, carrying over with them every sort of luxury, including oranges, grapes, jellies broths, wines, brandies, cologne water, etc., etc., for the relief of the poor suffering fellows. Dr. FOSTER, R.G. MOULTON, GRISWOLD KELLY, JOSLAH BENNETT, Mr. FLAWNAGAN, and Dr. HERRICK with the Stewards of the New England Rooms, were also at the Jersey City Depot at one o'clock this morning to render all the aid in their power to relieve the pain and weariness of the wounded.

abstract: We regret to say that the steamer Ruby, Capt. PEAT, from Nassau, got ashore on Folly Island breakers, near this bar, on Wednesday night. A large portion of the cargo was thrown overboard, and everything possible done to get her off, but without success. The Yankees on Folly Island having discovered her early on Thursday, opened on her from a battery. Capt. PEAT was then compelled to set her on fire and abandon her, and she afterwards blew up. While Capt. PEAT and his crew were coming ashore to Morris Island, they were shot at by the Yankees with cannon and small arms, and the balls came dropping around them in every direction.
lead_paragraph: We regret to say that the steamer Ruby, Capt. PEAT, from Nassau, got ashore on Folly Island breakers, near this bar, on Wednesday night. abstract: Gen. LEE was in Maryland something less than a year ago, and is there again. He came this time, we may be sure, with very different plans and expectations from those which he had on his former entrance. Then he proposed to play the port of a liberator.
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE was in Maryland something less than a year ago, and is there again. He came this time, we may be sure, with very different plans and expectations from those which he had on his former entrance. Then he proposed to play the port of a liberator. He put forth an address on the 11th of September last at Hagerstown, informing the State of Maryland that the people of the South had "long watched with the deepest sympathy the wrongs and outrages which have been inflicted upon the citizens of a Common wealth allied to the South by the strongest social, political and commercial ties, and reduced to the condition of a conquered province;" and that his army was there to help them "throw off this foreign yoke" and "regain the rights" of which they had been "so unjustly deprived." Then he expected to receive large reinforcements on crossing the Potomac. He expected to have the aid of Marylanders in destroying railroads, and helping him to isolate Washington from the North, that he might seize it at his leisure.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebet Conduct Toward Maryland.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebet Conduct Toward Maryland.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Saturday, June 13. the U.S. steamer Somerset, Lieut.-Con Mander A.F. CROSMAN, blockading at East Pass. St. George's Sound, near Apalachicola, left her anchorage at the Pass and steamed up to Alligator Harbor, a distance of some ten miles, where the most extensive salt works, for the supply of the Southern Confederacy, are located. After shelling the woods in all directions, a boat expedition, consisting of 72 officers and men, under the command of Executive Officer THOMAS CHATFIELD, assisted by Acting Master VAUGH, and accompanied by the Surgeon of the ship, Dr. G.H. COOKE, effected a landing, and thoroughly destroyed three separate and extensive ranges of salt works. At this place 45 salt boilers were broken up. 8 buildings burned. 200 bushels of salt ruined, and other property of value to the rebels destroyed.

abstract: Our enemy has pursued a singular course of contradiction between his precepts and practice in regard to the subject of humanity as connected with fighting. White professing to conduct a truly Christian war, on strictly religious principles, there has been scarcely known an instance in history where so much deceit, misrepresentation and wanton barbarity has been called to their and by any struggling nation, as hats been the case with the United States.

abstract: The annual work of the venerable Clerk of the Common Council appears this rear with more than ordinary claim for public recognition of thoroughness and careful research. In a handsomely edited volume of 852 pages Mr. VALENTINE has given more information concerning men and things, ways and means, places and plans, than can be found in any or all other similar works heretofore published. There are 61 maps and other illustrations, each gotten up with due regard to accuracy of detail and carefulness of finish, while the typography and general make-up of the work are worthy of the age in which it is issued.

abstract: Among the killed at Gettysburgh was a young; Chinaman, known as JOHN TOMMY. He was attached to the First regiment Excelsior brigade, Capt. PRICK's company. JOHN TOMMY was the only representative of the Central Flowery Kingdom in the Army of the Potomac, and was widely known both from that circumstances and certain peculiarities of this own. JOHN TOMMY came to this country immediately after the breaking out of the war, and was induced to enlist in Gen. SICKLES' brigade, at that time being raised in this city. He was then a mere lad, entirely ignorant of our language. Being bright, smart and honest, he soon become a favorite at Red Hook, States Island, and was at once the bu??t and the wi??? of the whole regiment. Before he became located on the Maryland shore of the Potomac opposite Aquia Creek, in one of the recon???ssances on the south side of the river, TOMMY was taken prisoner and soon become a lion in the rebel camp. He was brought before Gen. MAGRUDER, who surprised at his appearance and color, asked him was he a ???latto Indian or what? When TOMMY told him he was from China, MAGRUDER was very much amused, and asked him how much he would take to join the Confederate army. "Not unless you would make me a Brigadier-General," said TOMMY, to the great delight of the secesh officers who treated him very kindly and sent him to Fredericks-  burgh. Here TOMMY become a great lion, and his picture was published in the Fredericksburgh papers. Subsequently he was sent to the Libby Prison, Richmond, where he met his captain, BENJAMIN PRICE, who had been taken prisoner at Williamsburgh. After his parole TOMMY a??ne to New-York City. where he employed his time in attending upon his sick and wounded comrades. He was the kindest of bu???ses and ??? his little means in providing delicacies for a sick fellow-soldiers. In the subsequent engagements at Frederick ???? and last at Getvsburgh. JOHN TOMMY was one of the bravest soldiers in that bravest of brigade, the Excelsior. He seemed not to know what fear was and was the universal favorite of all his fellow soldiers. He had not been wounded up to Gettysburgh, but in Friday's night he was wounded by a shell, which tore off both legs at the thighs, and he shortly bide to death. The company he was in went into the action with twenty eight men and lost twenty in killed and wounded. TOMMY's ??? is speculier as he was the only representative of the Empire of China in the finest army on the planet -- World.
