He was brought before Gen. MAGRUDER, who surprised at his appearance and color, asked him was he a ???latto Indian or what? When TOMMY told him he was from China, MAGRUDER was very much amused, and asked him how much he would take to join the Confederate army. "Not unless you would make me a Brigadier-General," said TOMMY, to the great delight of the secesh officers who treated him very kindly and sent him to Fredericks- burgh. Here TOMMY become a great lion, and his picture was published in the Fredericksburgh papers. Subsequently he was sent to the Libby Prison, Richmond, where he met his captain, BENJAMIN PRICE, who had been taken prisoner at Williamsburgh. After his parole TOMMY a??ne to New-York City. where he employed his time in attending upon his sick and wounded comrades. He was the kindest of bu???ses and ??? his little means in providing delicacies for a sick fellow-soldiers. In the subsequent engagements at Frederick ???? and last at Getvsburgh. JOHN TOMMY was one of the bravest soldiers in that bravest of brigade, the Excelsior. He seemed not to know what fear was and was the universal favorite of all his fellow soldiers. He had not been wounded up to Gettysburgh, but in Friday's night he was wounded by a shell, which tore off both legs at the thighs, and he shortly bide to death. lead_paragraph: It appears from the letters of our Japanese correspondent, that England is about to plunge into another of those little Eastern wars which have so often led to great results. The time has come when Japan must either atone for the offences of her people toward British subjects, or else suffer, and already a formidable squadron of English ships is assembled in Japanese waters to commence hostilities, should the government of the Tycoon evince any disposition to reject the ultimatum which the representative of VICTORIA at the Court of Yeddo has addressed to it.

abstract: woman named CATHERINE NORMAN, was shot by her husband, CHARLES NORMAN, at her residence, No. 98 West Forty-ninth-street, yesterday morning. She died from the effects of the wound about 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Nothing has thus far transpired to show how the shooting occurred, but it is alleged to have been accidental. The Coroner was notified, and will hold an inquest this morning. NORMAN was arrested by the Twenty-second Precinct Police, and locked up for examination.

abstract: Ill-informed and impatient people are already giving went to their ignorance and impatience, by complaining that Gen. MEADE has not again fallen upon the retreating army of the rebels.
lead_paragraph: Ill-informed and impatient people are already giving went to their ignorance and impatience, by complaining that Gen. MEADE has not again fallen upon the retreating army of the rebels. Having resisted LEE's attack at Gettysburgh, and compelled his retreat, they think that Gen. MEADE should have given him chase next day, or at least within a week, and completed the work which he had so gloriously begun.

abstract: Defenders in the Confederacy
snippet: Defenders in the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: JOHN BRIGHT lately made a speech upon American affairs, speaking again as heretofore in our favor. He drew his argument for hoping that we should succeed, from the cotton trade -- telling his hearers that the trade of Lancashire, "as they all knew, had been for some years resting on a most insecure foundation;" that the supply of cotton from America must always have been insufficient and insecure, because there was a want of labor at the South which could not be remedied under a state of Slavery, and that it was Slavery, therefore, which had made the production of cotton insufficient and insecure; but let the Union be restored and Slavery abolished, and free laborers would flow to the South, and this want would be supplied. He spoke of the question "as one of business, though he was glad that in this case business coincided with high sentiment and high morality."
headline: {'main': 'The Confederacy and Slavery.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Confederacy and Slavery.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Despotism of the King
snippet: The Despotism of the King
lead_paragraph: The despotic sceptre which the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH has wisely laid aside, WILLIAM of Brandenburg is wielding recklessly. He is delighted with the usurped bauble as is a schoolboy with a new toy, and seems determined that his subjects shall have ample experience of its properties ere he retires to Carlsbad. Austria and Prussia have in fact suddenly changed places. The former has risen to the dignity of a constitutional monarchy, the latter has sunk into a despotism. In Prussia, neither press nor people any longer enjoys liberty. Since the closing of the Diet the law has become impotent, and the destinies of the nation have been at the mercy of the King.
headline: {'main': 'Prussian Kaiserism.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Prussian Kaiserism.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

snippet: Valentine's Corporation Manua; Lewis, Dio, M. D.; Our Weak Lungs >amp;c.; Frank Warrington; Fairy Book, the by author of John Halifax
lead_paragraph: If any one among us may calculate surely on a sublunary immortality, Mr. VALENTINE is the man. He has linked his name indissolubly with one of the greatest cities in the world in a manner" which time shall strengthen not efface." As the laborious digger and delver among old Dutch manuscripts in search of the first faint traces of the municipal existence of N???ew Amsterdam, or as the recorder of the rising glories and meridian splendors of the New-York of our own day, his name will meet the future investigator as every step. All that honest JOHN STOWE did for Elizabethan London has been effected by him under equal difficulties, and no one among us has wrought so much, to deserve the character which THOMAS HEARNE de-ired to be the sole inscription on his tomb: "A lover and preserver of Antiquities." Services to pos???erity of this nature are generally tendered at the sacrifice of the present, and it is a happy coincidence which has placed Mr. VALENTINE in a position of such usefulness both to our own and to succeeding generations. The present volume of the Manual forms the twenty-second of the series, and its portly proportions, clad in scarlet and gold, forms as great a contrast with the little black-covered 24mo. of 1841, as the New-York of ??? does with that of 1863. Independently of the Immense mass of statistical information that renders the work indispensable to all citizens, the new volume is very rich in antiquarian treasures, embracing several documents of great interest, recently disinterred from the collections in the British Museum, by Mr. GEORGE H. MOORE, of the New-York Historical Society. Amongst them is the earliest known survey of Manhattan Island, copied in fac-simile from the original. It was in all probability executed by order of Col NICHOLLS, and transmitted to the Duke of York soon after the English the conquest in 1664. It is so correct and conformable to the natural configuration as to be recognized at a glance, and represents the small ??? at the southern end of the island, and the few scattered dwellings the only evidences of human occu???, as just peeping out from the untrodden ??? which envious them on every side. "New-York City under British military rule, 1777-1783," is a cop??? us ??? of original documents from the ??? cords, illustrating that exc'ting period of its ???"Indian wars in and about New-Amsterdam" "Low and Lawyers in New-Amsterdam;" "The first establishment in the village of Haarlaem;" "Slaves and the Slave-trade in the New-Nether-??? are all papers prepared with the editor's usual ??? and research, while the embellishments abound in portraits, fac similes. views. &c., all tending to illustrate the men and things of "the days [???]."

lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from headquarters of the Army of the Potomac state that these was no fighting yesterday beyond a few unimportant skirmishes, but that our forces were in a position to advance and give battle when the proper time should arrive. On Friday our cavalry forced the rebel advance back to Funkstown on the right, and beyond Bakersville on the left.

abstract: The AEronautic Corps; The rebel conduct in
snippet: The AEronautic Corps; The rebel conduct in
lead_paragraph: An item of news, received from Washington a short time since, was to the effect that the "Aeronautic Corps" of the Army of the Potomac had been dispensed with, and the balloons and inflating apparatus had been sent back to that city. It does not appear whether it is intended, but it is evidently implied by the form in which this announcement is made, that balloons have been found of no value in the conduct of military operations, or at least not of sufficient value to justify the expense and trouble of them. This will excite some surprise, for the public has been led to put considerable confidence in balloon reconnoissances from facts heretofore given. And the rare use made by the rebels of similar means of observation has always been attributed to their lack of fit material for the construction of balloons and for the preparation of gas to inflate them. There is not more than one authenticated case of a balloon reconnoissance by the rebels since the war began, and that occurred in its early stages. If they satisfied themselves by one experiment of the inapplicability of balloons to purposes of war in this country they deserve credit for dropping them so soon and avoiding the expense.
headline: {'main': 'Use of Balloons in War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Use of Balloons in War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: What It Means
snippet: What It Means
lead_paragraph: In our Havana correspondence, published yesterday, there occurs a somewhat remarkable and instructive document--the decree of confiscation or sequestration issued by the French functionary in Mexico. From it may be gotten an idea of the beneficent workings of French intervention. It provides that sequestration will be imposed upon all the real estate and personal property of such Mexicans as adhere to their own country; and in this category are comprised not merely such as "carry arms against the French intervention," but also such as are in a "state of hostility against France" -- whatever that means -- and even such as had fled from their homes for fear of the invader and had not returned to them at the date of the issue of the decree. The political prefect of each State, an appointee and tool of the invaders, with three other persons, appointees and tools of his, are to form a committee to designate the individuals thus subject to confiscation, and to make out lists of their real and personal property. This will doubtless furnish the French Government and its allies, the Mexican traitors, a large amount of plunder; while the method of its execution will furnish room for the practice of a prodigious amount of corruption, and the exercise of a merciless and malignant social persecution.
headline: {'main': 'What Intervention Means.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What Intervention Means.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: New-York, the Draft Commenced in
snippet: New-York, the Draft Commenced in
lead_paragraph: Not until yesterday morning did the majority of the citizens of New-York really believe that the Government was in earnest about the draft. The enrolling officers went quietly from street to street, and from house to house, creating no excitement and making no trouble, so that, to all intents and purposes, public attention was in no way called to the absolute fact of the draft, until the announcement in Friday's TIMES.

abstract: It seems that we are to be deluged with prisoners. Nearly as many Yankees as there are citizens of Richmond, are to be thrown upon our hospitalities. By a General Order of the beaten Gen. MEADE, the prisoners taken by LEE's army refuse to be paroled on the field; and must be brought away somewhere, under guard. The meaning of this is plain: If the enemy cannot drive our army from Pennsylvania in any other way, they hope to get rid of it by creating the necessity of detailing a large part of it at a guard to the prisoners on their way through a hostile country to Richmond. It is truly a smart people, this Yankee nation; it calculates on gaining trebly by this method; first, diminishing our force in the North; second, burdening us with such multitudes of mouths to be fed; third, giving a chance for their cavalry to recapture the prisoners en route if too weakly guarded, and cut off the troops who guard them. In fact, it is possible that this surrender en masse has been determined upon, and their new General Order issued in contemplation of it, with the very intention of embarrassing us and crippling our army in its future operations throughout the North. Of course our Generals are aware of the object of this trick, and will take the best measures to frustrate it. One of those measures, we trust, will be to supply the guard largely with cartridges, and send a few light guns with them -- so that on the first sign of insubordination the prisoners may be slain without mercy. Another advisable thing would be to make each prisoner carry with him Pennsylvania provisions for two weeks at least. But why bring those prisoners to Richmond at all? Some safe encampment can surely be had for them among our mountains near Winchester, so situated as to be easily commanded at every point by batteries; and as it is Summer weather they will need no shelter -- they were not too solicitous in providing shelter for our poor unfortunate people of Tennessee, even in Winter.
lead_paragraph: It seems that we are to be deluged with prisoners. Nearly as many Yankees as there are citizens of Richmond, are to be thrown upon our hospitalities. By a General Order of the beaten Gen. MEADE, the prisoners taken by LEE's army refuse to be paroled on the field; and must be brought away somewhere, under guard. The meaning of this is plain: If the enemy cannot drive our army from Pennsylvania in any other way, they hope to get rid of it by creating the necessity of detailing a large part of it at a guard to the prisoners on their way through a hostile country to Richmond. It is truly a smart people, this Yankee nation; it calculates on gaining trebly by this method; first, diminishing our force in the North; second, burdening us with such multitudes of mouths to be fed; third, giving a chance for their cavalry to recapture the prisoners en route if too weakly guarded, and cut off the troops who guard them. In fact, it is possible that this surrender en masse has been determined upon, and their new General Order issued in contemplation of it, with the very intention of embarrassing us and crippling our army in its future operations throughout the North. Of course our Generals are aware of the object of this trick, and will take the best measures to frustrate it. One of those measures, we trust, will be to supply the guard largely with cartridges, and send a few light guns with them -- so that on the first sign of insubordination the prisoners may be slain without mercy. Another advisable thing would be to make each prisoner carry with him Pennsylvania provisions for two weeks at least. But why bring those prisoners to Richmond at all? Some safe encampment can surely be had for them among our mountains near Winchester, so situated as to be easily commanded at every point by batteries; and as it is Summer weather they will need no shelter -- they were not too solicitous in providing shelter for our poor unfortunate people of Tennessee, even in Winter.

abstract: two months in Mississippi and in Virginia have furnished a vast field for the beneficent labors of the Sanitary Commission. Since the war began there has been no call upon them equal in magnitude to that at present from Pennsylvania. The wounded of both sides left in our hands will not number less than twenty thousand men. It is impossible for one unacquainted with the battle-field to comprehend the innumerable wants of these wounded soldiers, and the vast supplies required to satisfy them.

abstract: The London Times anticipates hostilities, and hopes England has public servants in the East who can devise a method for rendering them short and decisive. With an immense Indian army to draw upon, and with a large fleet in those seas, an operation equal to the necessity would seem to be neither difficult nor very costly. If, however, England is about to repeat her old Chinese mistake of demonstrations on the coast, she is committed to a very long and a very expensive business.

abstract: -- The Richmond Dispatch of the 7th, infers from Gen. MEADE's dispatches that "LEE has at last obtained the object of his long and anxious labors, and that he has brought the remnant of the Army of the Potomac into a position in which he may destroy it at a single blow." We should like to know the process of reasoning by which the astute rebel speculator arrives at this remarkable conclusion. From this point of view, it certainly looks as if the truth lay in a statement of precisely opposite character, that Gen. MEADE "had at length brought the remnant of the rebel army into a position," etc. The proof that rebel philosophy is usually at war with fact appears in another part of the same journal, where we find the statements that "GRANT is evidently feeling very uneasy," and that "GRANT begins to feel the pressure of the iron hand which JOHNSTON has cast around him."

abstract: Roobuck, J. A., Motion for Recognition in House of Com mons
snippet: Roobuck, J. A., Motion for Recognition in House of Com mons
lead_paragraph: The debate in the British House of Commons on Mr. ROZBUCK'S motion for the recognition of the independence of the rebel Confederacy, came up on the last day of June. The motion was to the effect "that a humble petition be presented to Her Majesty praying that she will be graciously pleased to enter into negotiations with the great Powers of Europe for the purpose of obtaining their cooperation in the recognition of the independence of the Confederate States of America." The principal participants in the debate were Mr. ROEBUCK, Mr. GLADSTONE, and Mr. BRIGHT; and Mr. FORSTER, Lord R. CECIL, Lord R. MONTAGUE, and Sir GEORGE GREY also expressed their opinions on the matter.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED AGENT FOR THE SOUTHERN CONFEDERACY.--A Southern gentleman named JOHN MOORE, who had been boarding at the Pierrepont House, in Montague-street, with his wife
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED AGENT FOR THE SOUTHERN CONFEDERACY. -- A Southern gentleman named JOHN MOORE, who had been boarding at the Pierrepont House, in Montague-street, with his wife and daughter, for the past two months, was induced to leave the hotel on Thursday night to go to New-York by a man known as Col. SHERMAN, and since ascertained to be a Government detective. After reaching the other side he was conveyed to Jersey City, and it is believed sent on to Washington. The charges against him, if any, have not been divulged. The circumstances of the arrest appear to be these: SHERMAN made frequent visits to the Pierrepont House since Mr. MOORE came there, and became very intimate with him, and it is supposed that he obtained sufficient information by "pumping" to warrant his arrest. SHERMAN went by the name of Jones during this time. He not only became intimate with Mr. MOORE but with his family. About 9 o'clock on Thursday night he persuaded Mr. MOORE to accompany him to New-York, and that is the last seen of him. On Friday morning SHERMAN, accompanied by another Government detective, called at the house, and requested the privilege of searching Mr. MOORE's baggage. The proprietor, Mr. BURNS, told him he should allow no one to enter their rooms without the consent of Mrs. MOORE, who was absent at the time, having gone to New-York in search of her husband. SHERMAN then left, and the other detective occupied a room opposite Mr. MOORE's apartments. A short time thereafter SHERMAN returned in company with Mrs. MOORE, who consented that he should examine their baggage. The detectives proceeded to do so in presence of Mrs. MOORE and daughter and the proprietor of the house. They overhauled everything, and took possession of a few scraps of manuscript and several daguerreotypes, with which they left. Mrs. MOORE expressing confidence that there was nothing in the trunks to implicate her husband in any respect, or in any offence, interposed no objections whatever. Mr. MOORE is about 60 years of age, and is a native of Maryland. Col. SHERMAN stated that Mr. MOORE's real name was HYLAND, and that he was an agent of the Southern Confederacy. He also informed Mr. BURNS that he should call again on Monday, (to-day,) and inform him what disposition had been made of Mr. MOORE. The affair creates a good deal of excitement throughout the City.

abstract: -- MORGAN's cavalry raid into Indiana is certainly an extraordinary and audacious affair. It is much more daring than JENKINS' raid into Pennsylvania, for JENKINS had the rebel army in his rear, and an easy line of retreat. JENKINS' was but the advance of LEE, but MORGAN is the advance of nothing but himself, who is advance, main body and rear-guard. The great so-called raids of our cavalry, such as those of GRIERSON through Mississippi, of CARTER into East Tennessee, and of STONEMAN to Richmond, had all an important military bearing upon the movements of the three great armies of GRANT, ROSECRANS and HOOKER; and JENKINS' so-called raid also was of the same nature in its bearing upon the movement of LEE's army. But MORGAN's raid is a raid pure and simple. Its object is to obtain plunder and produce consternation.

abstract: ENROLLING IN THE SECOND CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT. -- Provost-Marshal MADDOX has completed the enrollment for the Second Congressional District, and the figures show an aggregate of 33,155 names. This is an excess of about 15,000 names over the poll list of the district, which is a sufficient guarantee that the work has been thoroughly done, while at the same time it shows that a large number of our citizens have absented themselves from the polls within the past few years. The following are the figures of the Second Congressional District, which comprises the Sixth, Eighth, Ninth, Tenth, Twelfth, Fourteenth, Sixteenth, Seventeenth and Eighteenth Wards of the City of Brooklyn, and the country towns:

abstract: The Philadelphia Press says that coal shippers have stated that the present advance in the price of coal will be only temporary, and that the price, as soon as the present excitement is over, may fall lower than it was before the advance. The increase of price was caused by the action of the coal operatives, who agreed to send regiments to the field and provide for a temporary suspension of operations in the mining regions.

abstract: The draft, which commenced in this City on Saturday morning, will be continued to-day in the Ninth Congressional District, and will be commenced in the Eighth. About half of the names allotted to the Ninth District were drawn on Saturday, and the draft will probably be completed in that district to-day. In the Eighth District -- comprising the Eighteenth, Twentieth and Twenty-first Wards -- the draft will be made under the direction of Hon. B.F. MANNIERRE, Assistant Provost-Marshal, at the headquarters No. 1,190 Broadway. This to the largest district in the City, and the number of names to be drawn will exceed 5,000. The preparations for draft are nearly completed in several other districts, and in some of them it will, doubtless, commence before the close of the week. In the Second and Third Districts (Brooklyn) it is announced to commence on Wednesday. We understand that no notices will be served on persons drafted until the completion of the draft in the district. After the service of notice the drafted person will have ten days to procure a substitute, pay three hundred dollars, or prove himself exempt; at the end of which time, if he has failed to do either of these things, he is expected to present himself at the place designated in the notice, to take his place in the ranks of the Grand Army of the Republic.

abstract: By the arrival of the Great Eastern at this port, and the Jura off Cape Race, we receive advices from Europe five days later -- to the 3d inst. The news is of considerable importance. On the 30th alt. Earl RUSSELL made the declaration in the House of Lords, that the French Minister had on that day stated to him that there was no truth in the announcement that the French Emperor intended to make another proposition to England for an offer of joint mediation between the North and the South. On the same day Mr. ROEBUCK, in the House of Commons, made his motion for the recognition of the South, and in the course of his remarks made statements directly at variance with those of the French Minister. He asserted positively that in his recent interview with the Emperor, that personage assured him that he did intend to make such a proposition. Mr. ROEBUCK's motion for recognition met with strenuous opposition -- the declaration being made from the Government benches that the "time for recognition had not yet arrived." It was generally taken for granted, however, that the restoration of the Union was impossible. The English Press very generally commented on the news of LEE's second attempt to invade the North. The theories in regard to it are various. The London Times was disposed to believe it would be successful. The steamer Gibraltar formerly the Sumter detained on account of having cannon on board, was to be allowed to sail with them, as they were found to be of too heavy calibre to be used on board of her. Their alleged destination is Callao. The Paris Pat???s contradicts the assertion that a large armament is being undertaken in France, with a view to certain eventualities which may take place in the north of Europe. The rebels ate reported to have made proposals to the Spanish Government for recognition, with the sanction and support of the French Emperor, but no authority for the report is given. In the Liverpool market, cotton was firmer but quiet, and rates unchanged. Breadstuffs were heavy, with a downward tendency. Provisions were dull and unchanged. Consols were quoted at 92@92???.

abstract: New-York; Norman, Catherine, shot by Charles Norman
snippet: New-York; Norman, Catherine, shot by Charles Norman
lead_paragraph: In the TIMES of yesterday, we published an account of the arrest of CHARLES NORMAN on the charge of having caused the death of CATHARINE NORMAN, by shooting her through the head with a revolver. The parties resided at No. 98 West Forty-ninth-street. The affair occurred about noon on Saturday, and the woman survived but a short time after the shot was fired. Officer CONNELL of the Twenty-second Precinct, took NORMAN into custody and held him to await the result of the inquest.

abstract: The Morning Chronicle has reason to believe a change will shortly take place in the representative of the Emperor of the French at the English Court, and that M. PERSIONY, it is stated, will leave Paris for St. Petersburgh, not on a special mission, but to succeed the present Ambassador at the Russian Court.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. -- The eminently successful drama of the "Duke's Motto" will be repeated here to-night and until further notice. Thanks to Mr. WHEATLEY's liberality in placing it on the stage, and to the excellent cast bestowed on the play. It has won a success which will safely carry it into the Fall. We are not surprised to hear from a competent authority that the general mise en scene of Mr. BROUGHAM's piece is immeasurably better here than in London.

abstract: There has been four days' fighting near Gettysburgh, commencing on Wednesday July 1, and ending on Saturday night, July 4. It is reported here that A.P. HILL, EARLY and RODES fought the enemy principally on Wednesday, beginning at 1 o'clock and lasting two hours. We drove the enemy through Gettysburgh and two and a half miles beyond. At Gettysburgh we captured their wounded--3,500 in number.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the Richmond Enquirer.

abstract: Life and Services of
snippet: Life and Services of
lead_paragraph: On the night of May 21, 1861, the writer hereof, returning at a late hour to his hotel in Washington, saw in the shade of some stately buildings on the avenue a regiment of soldiers. For days before that there had been uneasy rumors of actual war to supersede the armed and arming neutrality which had reigned up to that moment. Would the Government "invade" Virginia? Would it send its mudsills to the sacred soil? The question was about to be answered, for the regiment we saw was the Michigan First -- since known to fame -- and as we passed along the street other regiments, hushed and silent, debouched from the various crossings. To go to our hotel, lead pistols, change boots and hire a carriage was a brief and easy task. The driver had directions to follow the troops until he was stopped. The "stop" happened at the eastern terminus of the Long Bridge where, all our efforts to cross being futile, we stood and witnessed the first grand invasion of Virginia. The scene was beautiful. From out a heaven ???peace looked down a placid moon at its full. On two streets that there converge lay a mass of 8,000 troops, at that time an immense Army. A group of officers on horseback gathered near the head of the bridge, and presently came among them one who, by the light of a lantern, communicated to them their orders. I could hear his voice, since grown familiar to thousand's on many a battle-field. It was that of Maj. EEINTZELMAN. First infantry, U.S.A., at that time; since then became Maj.-Gen. HEINTZELMAN, the the Marshal NEY of the armies of the Union. "You understand it, gentlemen," closed the brief directions which opened the terrible programme of this war. A low whistle scanded, the tramp of a regiment smote the planks of the bridge, the bayonets glistened in the moonlight, and a half-hour later Virginia was "actually Invaded," Arlington Heights were secured, and the next morning was born the phrase, since repeated ???d nauseam, "Washington is safe."

abstract: This regiment, which served with so much distinction at Hatteras, Roanoke, Camden, South Mountain, Antietam, Fredericksburgh and elsewhere, is again to proceed to the seat of war, under command of its late Major, now Col. E. JARDINE, an officer who began his military career in the Mexican war. Recruiting is progressing rapidly for all of its ten companies. Discharged two years' or nine months' soldiers receive $550 bounty, new recruits $175. The headquarters are at No. 510 Broadway.

abstract: The funeral of Brig.-Gen. SAMUEL K. ZOOK, who fell at the battle of Gettysburgh, July 3, will take place at 3 P.M. to-day, under the direction of the Common Council Committee on National Affairs. The First and Third New-York cavalry, under command of Cols. PRICE and POSTLEY, will act as escort, and the procession will start from the City Hall and pass through Chatham, Bowery, Bond street and Broadway to the South Ferry. The remains will be interred in Greenwood. The body lay in state, under a guard of honor, in the Governor's Room yesterday, and was visited by large numbers of people. Gen. Zook had hosts of friends in New-York, and was universally esteemed. An opportunity will be afforded to the public to view the remains at the Governor's Room, City Hall, to-day, up to the hour of the funeral.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Brig.-Gen. SAMUEL K. abstract: -- We again urge upon persons who belong to the pell-  mell school of strategy to hold their tongues and rein in their passions for awhile yet. It has been to them a nine-days' wonder that Gen. MEADE, during the last nine days, has not gobbled up Gen. LEE. Had a pell-mell man been in command of the Army of the Potomac, he would have mounted a fast horse, drawn his sword, and rushed out at full gallop after the rebels on the morning of the Fourth of July, with his whole army behind him on the double-quick. It is true that he and his army might have been brought to a sudden halt, and perhaps compelled unexpectedly to take the back track, had they rushed against some strong position where the rebels might be strongly posted, with perhaps a hundred and fifty pieces of rifled ordnance and fifty thousand troops to do battle. But then, wouldn't they have had another big fight, with prodigious heaps of killed and wounded on both sides? Would not this have produced an immense sensation, and illustrated in deeper crimson the beauties of pell-mell strategy? It is impossible to convince this class of people that war consists of anything but simply fighting and killing. They grow very loud-mouthed always after a battle, and immediately want another -- overlooking the fact that in all great wars battles are but the consummation of long and intricate speculations and manoeuvres in strategy. There are few campaigns that can be justly or intelligently criticised while they are in progress -- as has been often illustrated in this war, where we have seen so many campaigns handsomely begun end in disaster. The present campaign of LEE had for its object the capture of Washington, the crushing of our army and the humiliation of the North. The present campaign of MEADE has for its object the destruction of the main rebel army and the breaking up of the rebel power. In any event, LEE has failed in his campaign, This was decided on the 3d of July. And Gen. MEADE is but commencing his campaign. No one knows his plan, but it must be a large and comprehensive one, and one which, in the nature of things, cannot very well be wrought out in an instant.

abstract: The, a Great National Benefit
snippet: The, a Great National Benefit
lead_paragraph: The National Enrollment Act, the enforcement of which was commenced in this City on Saturday, will be carried into execution until the quota of the State of New-York and of every State in the Union shall be raised and in the field. It may not be necessary that a man of those drafted shall ever go into line of battle during this war. Yet it is a national blessing that the Conscription has been imposed. It is a matter of prime concern that it should now be settled, once for all, whether this Government is or is not strong enough to compel military service in its defence. More than any other one thing, this will determine our durability as a Republic and our formidableness as a nation. Once establish that not only the property, but the personal military service of every ablebodied citizen is at the command of the national authorities, constitutionally exercised, and both successful rebellion and successful invasion are at once made impossible for all time to come. From that time it will be set down as a known fact that the United States is the most solidly based Government on the face of the earth.
headline: {'main': 'The Conscription a Great National Benefit.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Conscription a Great National Benefit.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our dispatches from headquarters of the Army of the Potomac state that there was no fighting on Saturday beyond a few unimportant skirmishes, but that our forces were in a position to advance and give battle when the proper time should arrive. Yesterday morning the position of affairs appeared to be mainly unchanged, though a report reached Boonsboro that the rebels were retreating toward Hancock.

abstract: Poltroonery of at Gettysburgh
snippet: Poltroonery of at Gettysburgh
lead_paragraph: -- The infamy and cowardice of the rebel Surgeons in deserting the men of their army wounded at the battle of Gettysburgh is without parallel in the war. In every battle in which fortune has been adverse to our arms, and our wounded have been temporarily left within the rebel lines, the brave and self-denying Surgeons of the regiments have either remained with the fallen, or have immediately applied for passes within the rebel lines that they might be cared for. But the rebels left lying on the field many thousands of their wounded -- Dr. VELLUM reports the number at ten thousand -- and left with them neither Surgeons, stores nor nurses, but literally abandoned them to their fate. These men complained bitterly of the cruelty of their Surgeons in thus forsaking them, but bore up patiently under their sufferings for many days until they could be attended to by some of our own Surgeons, most of whom had at once to hasten forward with their own regiments to other fields. We published yesterday a thrilling letter from the battle-field, written on Thursday last, six days after the close of the contest, which stated that there were hundreds of the rebel wounded not then reached, -- that hundreds of them it had been found impossible even to cover and that they lay in the woods with broken limbs and torn bodies, drenched in the rain, some having even been drowned in the floods which rose around them. Of course everything possible was being done for them, and doctors, wound-dressers and nurses were arriving. We were not prepared for, and could not have foreseen, the flight of all the rebel Surgeons. It will be long remembered to their disgrace, both by the unfortunate rebels and by the whole country.
headline: {'main': 'INHUMANITY AND POLTROONERY OF THE REBEL SURGEONS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'INHUMANITY AND POLTROONERY OF THE REBEL SURGEONS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: About 700 wounded soldiers from the late battle fields arrived in Jersey City at 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, where they were met by Col. JOHNSON, Col. FRANK E. HOWE, of the New-England Rooms, a Committee from the Loyal League Club, Drs. FOSTER and HERRICK, Messrs. Moulton, Kelly, Bennett, Flanagan, and other sympathizing Samaritans, and supplied with all the luxuries which their condition required. The soldiers were conveyed in a steamboat to David's Island.

abstract: A RETURNED HEROINE. -- About two years ago, Mrs. MARY SEIZGLE left this City for the seat of war, with the Forty-first regiment New-York Volunteers, of which her husband was a member. She returned on Saturday night last, dressed in a soldier's uniform. The Police took her into custody, under the act which forbids a woman to walk the streets in male apparel. She was taken to the Twenty-seventh Precinct Station-house, where it was satisfactorily shown that she had lost all of her clothing in the late battles of Gettysburg, and that she had no other alternative but to put on a soldier's uniform. It further appeared that during her two years' absence she has rendered herself very useful as hospital nurse. She was sent to the residence of her husband's brother. No. 8 Spring-street.

abstract: Presidential candidates and the command of the army
snippet: Presidential candidates and the command of the army
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Gen. MEADE's accession to the command of the army, we mentioned as a circumstance much in his favor that, having been born in Spain he was not eligible for the Presidency, and added that the campaign was in the eyes of most politicians a political as well as military campaign, and that for this reason it was desirable that the General in command of the Army of the Potomac should not be "available" as a candidate. It since appears that Gen. MEADE's father having been resident abroad in an official capacity at the time of his son's birth, the General is legally a native, and consequently might be President if he was nominated and got votes enough. Since his appearance in his present position, too, he has won a battle -- one of the greatest battles of modern times, and the first great battle on open ground in which the Army of the Potomac has driven the enemy fairly off the field. He is consequently, therefore, at this moment, one of the most inviting bones that was ever thrown into the political kennel, and we strongly advise the dogs of faction to go to work at him at once. We believe we gave the animals some pain by our insinuation that when they were barking at the President's heels about the command of the army and the conduct of the war, they were simply hunting for prey; that, in fact, to use the language of the Richmond Enquirer of June 12, about them: "This whole two years' war, and the two years more war that has yet to be gone through, is itself, in their eye, but a Presidential campaign, only somewhat more vivacious than ordinary." We are, however, of the same opinion still, but as we do not wish to hurt their feelings more than may be necessary, we urge upon them Gen. MEADE's "availability" as a slight atonement for the apparent roughness of our language. But if they wish to profit by our advice, they really must not lose time. There has not been much done by way of puffing him so far, but it is not too late to begin. We beg to supply a few facts for the inauguration of the great movement. They may not sound fresh, but they are full of virtue.

abstract: -- Gen. BROWN, who has been appointed by Gen. WOOL to take command of the United States troops in this City, is the veteran officer of the army whose last and most prominent military service was as commander at Fort Pickens, in Florida, where, it will be remembered, he performed three admirable actions -- the repulse of the rebels from Santa Rosa Island, and two bombardments of Gen. BRAGG's troops, who were then laying siege to Fort Pickens. Gen. BROWN graduated at West Point, entered the army in 1818, first saw service in the Florida war, where he achieved great distinction as Lieutenant-Col. of a regiment of Mounted Creek Volunteers. In the Mexican war, he was at Monterey and Vera Cruz, and so conspicuous was his gallantry at Contreras and Churubusco that he was breveted Lieutenant Colonel, and subsequently obtained the still higher brevet rank of Colonel for his distinguished bravery at the storming of the Garita de Belan. After these experiences in the field, he was assigned to various professional military duties of great responsibility, and at the commencement of this war Gen-  BROWN was selected to carry succor to the garrison, under the gallant SLEMMER, at Fort Pickens, which was beleagured by the rebels. He effected his task, and then took command of the fort, which he held for over a year, gaining great distinction both in defence and attack, as we have already mentioned. Worn out by hard work in that debilitating climate, he returned to his native State of New-Jersey, where he received a vote of thanks from the State Legislature. Latterly he has been on duty in connection with the works in the harbor. The appointment of an officer of such great ability and high character to command the troops in this City, at the present time, will give great gratification to the people of New-York.

abstract: Up to a late hour last night we had not heard that a collision had taken place between the Army of the Potomac and the rebel army under LEE. Dispatches from Washington estimate the strength of the rebels at fifty thousand.
lead_paragraph: Up to a late hour last night we had not heard that a collision had taken place between the Army of the Potomac and the rebel army under LEE. Dispatches from Washington estimate the strength of the rebels at fifty thousand, LEE was understood to occupy a strong natural position, and our cavalry were busily engaged at last accounts in feeling his lines. The belief is generally expressed in our dispatches that the escape of the rebels across the Potomac is impossible.

abstract: -- When Winchester was evacuated by the forces under Gen. MILROY there were left behind a number of women and children, relatives of the officers and men stationed there. It had been represented to the women that the place could be held, so well was it forti???ed, no matter what number of the enemy should engage in the attack. This made them indifferent about leaving, and very few of them did so. When the town was taken possession of by the rebels they took these women and children prisoners and conveyed them to Richmond, where they were placed in Castle Thunder. Those of them who had any clothing, except what was necessary for immediate use, were deprived of it, and it was sold at auction. After being kept in confinement until last Thursday, they were sent in a flag of truce boat to Annapolis, and from thence to Washington, where the Government took charge of them and provided for their transportation to their homes. Fifteen of the women, with some eight or ten children, arrived to this city on Wednesday night and were lodged and entertained at the Union Volunteer Refreshment Saloon. They state that their treatment in Richmond was as good as could have been expected; that while in Castle Thunder they were fed on wheat bread and rye coffee, and had the privilege of buying such food as they could afford to do. Occasionally bacon was given to them, but it was in such a state that it could not be eaten. The last three days they had fresh beef. They were not permitted to know anything that was going on outside of Castle Thunder. On the day of their departure they saw a number of soldiers parading about the streets of Richmond. Several of the women were wives and mothers of Ohio Volunteers, others belonged to Pennsylvania. They all left for their homes yesterday. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 10.

abstract: Mayor OPDYKE has called for volunteer policemen -- to serve for the special and temporary purpose of putting down the mob which threatened yesterday to burn and plunder the City. Let no man be deaf to this appeal! No man can afford to neglect it. No man, whatever his calling or condition in life, can afford to live in a City where the law is powerless, and where mobs of reckless ruffians can plunder dwellings and burn whole blocks of buildings with impunity. Let the mob which raged yesterday in our streets with so little of real restraint, obtain the upper hand for a day or two longer, and no one can predict or imagine the extent of the injury they may inflict, or the weight of the blow they may strike at our peace and prosperity. This mob must be crushed at once. Every day's -- every hour's delay -- is big with evil. Let every citizen come promptly forward and give his personal aid to so good and so indispensable a work.

abstract: Fairly vs. McCurdy; Foreclosure of Advertisement
snippet: Fairly vs. McCurdy; Foreclosure of Advertisement
lead_paragraph: Fairley, Respondent, vs. McCurdy, Executor and Appellant. -- This action was brought in the Supreme Court to restrain the foreclosure of a mortgage by advertisement, and an injunction was issued. An installment of interest was due upon the mortgage, April 1, 1856, the amount of which was tendered April 12, 1856. The tender was refused, the holder of the mortgage claiming that a foreclosure had been commenced by advertisement then in type in the Sandy Hill Herald, and ready to be issued in the weekly edition of that newspaper upon the following Tuesday, and that the attorney's lees in preparing the notice, and the printer's fees for one insertion, must be tendered also. The foreclosure was continue: until restrained by injunction.

abstract: Excitement about Morgan's Raid
snippet: Excitement about Morgan's Raid
lead_paragraph: -- The raid of JOHN MORGAN into the States of Indiana and Ohio, will go far to mitigate the surprise that was felt at the unresisted advance of LEE's cavalry into Pennsylvania. MORGAN's troopers presented themselves, about a week ago, almost unannounced, on the line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, about thirty miles south of Louisville, where a railway train was stopped and robbed, and a bridge burnt, so as to delay pursuit. The people of Louisville flattered themselves that MORGAN then retreated. But he was next heard from on the banks of the Ohio River, forty miles below Louisville; where he seized two passing steamers, crossed the river into Indiana, burnt one of the boats, and immediately moved northward, aiming apparently for the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad. His course was soon turned easterly, as if he meant to strike at New-Albany, just opposite to the City of Louisville. Louisville was, as a matter of course, thrown into great consternation, and several millions of coin were at once shipped by the banks of that City to Indianapolis for safety. No leading town was, however, attacked by the rebels. They continued their eastern course until it began to be surmised that they were intending to strike the Ohio River again, above Louisville and between that city and Cincinnati, and retreat thence through the belt of secession counties that run through Northern and Central Kentucky.

abstract: The mob yesterday was unquestionably started on the basis of resistance to the draft.
lead_paragraph: The mob yesterday was unquestionably started on the basis of resistance to the draft. But that was a very small part of the spirit which really prompted and kept it in motion. It was, probably, in point of character the lowest and most ruffianly mob which ever disgraced our City. Arson, theft and cowardly ferocity seemed to be the animating impulse of a very large portion of the mass that composed it. We have never witnessed a more disgusting or more humiliating sight than was offered in every street which these gangs of outlaws tramped through with their hideous uproar. A large portion of them were mere boys, and their special delight seemed to be to hunt negroes. One would have supposed that every colored man, woman and child must be a wild beast -- to judge from the savage and eager delight with which they were chased and beaten and stoned by these wretched brutes in human form. It seems inconceivable that so much of pure, unadulterated ferocity -- so much of that clear, undiluted cruelty which feels a keen and ecstatic relish in the infliction of torture upon others for its own sake, can dwell in the human heart. But such hideous outbreaks as that of yesterday draw aside the curtain and show us how much of the wild beast, in spite of our better qualities, really belongs to the baser elements of our social life.

abstract: Attack on Tribune Office; Burning of Colored Orphan Asylum
snippet: Attack on Tribune Office; Burning of Colored Orphan Asylum
lead_paragraph: The initiation of the draft on Saturday in the Ninth Congressional District was characterized by so much order and good feeling as to well-nigh dispel the forebodings of tumult and violence which many entertained in connection with the enforcement of the conscription in this City. Very few, then, were prepared for the riotous demonstrations which yesterday, from 10 in the morning until late at night, prevailed almost unchecked in our streets. The authorities had counted upon more or less resistance to this measure of the Government after the draft was completed, and the conscripts were repaired to take their place in the ranks, and at that time they would have been fully prepared to meet it; but no one anticipated resistance at so early a stage in the execution of the law, and, consequently, both the City and National authorities were totally unprepared to meet it. The abettors of the riot knew this, and in it they saw their opportunity. We say abettors of the riot, for it is abundantly manifest that the whole affair was concocted on Sunday last by a few wire-pullers, who, after they saw the ball fairly in motion yesterday morning prudently kept in the back ground. Proof of this is found in the fact that as early as 9 o'clock, some laborers employed by two or three railroad companies, and in the iron foundries a the eastern side of the City, formed in procession in the Twenty-second Ward, and visited the different workshops in the upper wards, where large numbers were employed, and compelled them, by threats in some instances, to cease their work. As the crowd augmented, their shouts and disorderly demonstrations became more formidable. The number of men who thus started out in their career of violence and blood, did not probably at first exceed threescore. Scarcely had two dozen names been called, when a crowd, numbering perhaps 500, suddenly made an irruption in front of the building, (corner of Third-avenue and Forty-sixth-street,) attacking it with clubs, stones, brickbats and other missiles. The upper part of the building was occupied by families, who were terrified beyond measure at the smashing, of the windows, doors and furniture. Following these missiles, the mob rushed furiously into the office on the first floor, where the draft was going on, seizing the books, papers, records, lists, &c. all of which they destroyed, except those contained in a large iron safe. The drafting officers were set upon with stones and clubs, and, with the reporters for the Press and others, had to make a hasty exit through the rear. They did not escape scatheless, however, as one of the enrolling officers was struck a savage blow with a stone, which will probably result fatally, and several others were injured.

abstract: The outrages upon law and public order yesterday, in this metropolis, will revive
lead_paragraph: The outrages upon law and public order yesterday, in this metropolis, will revive the heart of every rebel, and of every hater of our institutions the world over. The assiduous fanning of every malignant passion by a portion of our public Press, and by platform demagogues, has at last resulted in an open outbreak, and for hours a mob, embracing thousands, raged at its full bent through an extended section of our City, with arson and bloody violence. The absence of nearly our entire military force, in their great patriotic work of aiding to beat back the invaders of Northern soil, gave these public enemies a rare opportunity for carrying things with a high hand. The law was not only defied but was successfully resisted. For the first time within the memory of this generation, it could not command means for its protection. It stood paralyzed, helpless, humbled. It was a spectacle that may well crimson the check of every true American with shame. Yet, if that were all, there might be some resignation, for public humiliations have been no rarity in New-York. But, unfortunately, there is danger in it, as well as disgrace. There is something portentous in this lawlessness at this juncture.

abstract: No sooner had it become certain that the draft would take place in this City and State, than recruiting for the regular army and navy sprung up as if by magic.
lead_paragraph: No sooner had it become certain that the draft would take place in this City and State, than recruiting for the regular army and navy sprung up as if by magic. The regular army, which, if full, should consist of over 40,000 men, had nearly dwindled away, and even the marine corps, and the navy proper, were feeling severely the dullness of enlistments. Since Friday, however, men have been flocking to the military and naval offices to join the service. All the double battalion regiments recently added to the army are taking advantage of the excitement, and have sent out independent recruiting parties. Commissions are given to outsiders who bring in men. The Marine corps now consists of 3,000 rank and file -- 1,000 having recently been added to the usual force. There are some 35,000 men of all grades and ranks attached to our ships-of-war, but many more are needed in consequence of the number daily receiving their discharges. All the necessary hands can now be easily obtained, and the fighting force of the ships put up to its proper level. The mounted part of the regular army, it is proper to remark, is daily receiving as many men as could be expected, were there no volunteer organizations to compete with it.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met by special call at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, "to take action in such business as might come before them."
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met by special call at 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, "to take action in such business as might come before them." The call was signed at about 9 o'clock in the morning, before the riot up town had begun, and the real object o??? the meeting was to authorize the Corporation Counsel to associate such eminent counsel with him as he might choose, and take steps to test the constitutionality of the National Enrollment Act, under which the draft is being made. Alderman FARLEY was the prime mover in the matter. The whole plan failed, however, for want of a quorum. A quorum failed to appear because of the excited state of feeling in the community, consequent upon the riot up town. It was at first designed to carry out Alderman FARLEY's idea, but the excitement that soon became alarming in the streets, led several of the Democratic members to the conclusion that it would be impolitic to take any action on the subject of the draft till quiet should be restored. Hence, when the Board met, only five members answered to their names -- Messrs. HENRY, REED, JEREMIAH, HARDY and FARLEY.

abstract: Our City authorities yesterday acted with commendable energy and promptitude in taking steps to suppress the riot.
lead_paragraph: Our City authorities yesterday acted with commendable energy and promptitude in taking steps to suppress the riot. But the means at their command were and still are entirely inadequate to the accomplishment of that object. Nothing could exceed the courage and the devotion with which the police performed their perilous and difficult duties; but what can a thousand men do toward suppressing a riot which has the whole of this vast City for the field of its operations? We have no military force at hand at all sufficient for the emergency, and the troops which were under arms yesterday were not handled with the slightest vigor, nor did they contribute in any marked degree to the restoration of the public peace.

abstract: I am not, perhaps, much in error in supposing  that the question not by the Marquis of Clanricarde to Lord RUSSELL in the House of Lords, on Friday  evening last, had some reference to the statements in...
lead_paragraph: I am not, perhaps, much in error in supposing that the question not by the Marquis of Clanricarde to Lord RUSSELL in the House of Lords, on Friday evening last, had some reference to the statements in my letter of Tuesday on the renewal of propositions for a joint me???on in America. Lord CLANRICARDE, however, spoke of the proposal of the Emperor of the French to the British Government "to recognize the existing Government of the Confederate States." The word "recognize," or "recognition," does not occur in my letter, and may not be formally expressed in Baron GROS' note, though, of course, the overtures have recognition for their ultimate object. What I spoke of was a proposal for mediation or diplomatic intervention. Lord RUSSELL, strictly speaking, might deny that there was a proposal for recognition. I should be surprised, however, if he denied that proposals for mediation had been made. It is certain that the Emperor held the conversation I alluded to in my letter with Mr. LINDSAY and Mr. ROEBUCK as I related it; and the Memorial Diplomatique of yesterday -- a paper which I know to be in direct communication with the French Foreign Office -- corroborates my statement in every word. It corroborates it and adds something of its own:

abstract: Pennsylvania Reserves at Gettysburgh
snippet: Pennsylvania Reserves at Gettysburgh
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Reserves marched from Washington on the 26th of June, and by forced marches, under the command of Gen. CRAWFORD, reached the Army of the Potomac just in time to participate in the great battles lately fought on the soil of their native State. When it was manifest that the enemy had established themselves in Pennsylvania, nothing could exceed the enthusiasm of this tried corps in their desire to meet them on their soil. They were soon gratified, and the orders to march were received with loud cheers. A toilsome march was borne without a murmur, and at Frederick they were assigned as the Third division of MEADE's army corps. Thence they marched to Pennsylvania. Before crossing the line, Gen. CRAWFORD addressed them as follows:

abstract: The appearance of this elegant volume is sufficient to enlist the sympathies of the reader in its favor. The paper, printing and illustrations will bear comparison with any specimens of American book manufacture that have come under our notice, and indeed excel, in those particulars many of the expressly ornamented works, as annuals, &c. As a present book for intelligent young people, it is almost without a rival. The author informs us that the work was commenced as a History of the World upon Christian Principles. Circumstances, however, led to a change of plan, so as to make it a series of First Things in History to the Christian Era. Assuming the inspiration and divine authority of the Holy Scriptures, they are taken as the guide-book down the stream of time, and the incidents they relate are considered in order as "The Garden of Eden, the First Abode," "The First Man," "The First Marriage," "The First Sin," "The First Promise of a Saviour," &c. Much novelty is imparted to familiar subjects by this mode of treatment. The writer's thorough knowledge of the Bible is shown on every page, and he has also availed himself of the researches of travelers and antiquarian scholars. From these sources are derived the illustrations of the volume. They reproduce remarkable Egyptian and Assyrian antiquities from Sir GARDNER WILKINSON, and Mr. LAYARD's discoveries, and Oriental sites famous in Sacred Writ, from DAVID ROBERTS' splendid work on The Holy Land. In some respects Mr. SCHIEFFELIN's book may be compared with Rev. HENRY TULLIDGE's work, Triumphs of the Bible recently noticed in this paper. The object of both is to exalt the reverential feeling for the Scriptures, and to show that all science, rightly considered, is but the handmaid to Revelation. The Foundation of History is, however, not a controversial work and so better adapted for some purposes of instruction. The writer was induced to undertake it by a desire to forward the views of the Board of Publication of the Reformed Dutch Church, who promise a series of Christian school-books, expressly prepared by able men, whose hearts are in this work.

abstract: Blot, Pierre; What to Eat, and How to Cook it
snippet: Blot, Pierre; What to Eat, and How to Cook it
lead_paragraph: The tempting bill of fare, set fort h in M. BLOTS' title page, will be found realized in his work. More business-like than the romantic SOYER, his little manual is plain and precise in its directions, bringing American practice to test the theories of French science. If it is true, as most travelers assert, that the profusion of the good gifts of nature in the United States is as remarkable as the waste and neglect that too often accompanies the process of their conversion into the food of man, the multiplication of the works of this nature is a positive service to the economic interests of the country. "French Cookery" is often used as if the term implied luxury and extravagance, but so far is this from the truth, that its most noticeable feature is the elegant simplicity of its methods, based on enlightened experience, and equally adapted to the cottage home as to the gilded salons of the capital.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment or going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: it??? of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -- For several weeks past a 13-inch gun, of RODMAN's model, cast at Fortress Monroe, has undergone a series of experiments. Its weight is 33,615 pounds, and it is fourteen feet long. A 275-pound shot has been fired, with a charge of 30 pounds of powder, and as yet there is no perceptible enlargement of the bore, though the piece has been discharged nearly 300 times. Thus far the experiments have been confined to trying the gun's durability; but, in a few days, the test will be made as to the distance and penetrability of the projectiles thrown. -- Pittsburgh Dispatch.
lead_paragraph: -- For several weeks past a 13-inch gun, of RODMAN's model, cast at Fortress Monroe, has undergone a series of experiments. Its weight is 33,615 pounds, and it is fourteen feet long. abstract: The steamship Persia, from Liverpool on the 4th, and Queenstown on the 5th inst., arrived at this port last night. Her advices are two days later. According to the Paris correspondent [???] the London Times, proposals of recognition have been made on behalf of the South to the Spanish Government, with the cognizance and full sanction of the French Emperor. The proposals are said to be under consideration, with a knowledge that, if Spain consents, she will have the support of France. In the British House of Lords, the Duke of Newcastle had made an explanation regarding the Northwestern boundary. In the House of Commons, in answer to a question by Hr. FOSTER, Mr. LAYARD had positively denied that any communication whatever had been received by the British Government from the French Emperor [???] regard to mediation since last November. There is nothing new regarding the Polish question, as it affects the politics of Europe. The Russians are stated to have suffered several serious defeats at the hands of the revolutionists. The financial and commercial news is not important. Cotton was rather dull of sale.

abstract: "Private letters from Madrid inform me that proposals of recognition have been made on behalf of the Southern States of America to the Spanish Government, and that those proposals are made with the cognizance and full sanction of the French Emperor. The proposals are at this moment under the consideration of the Marquis of Maraflores and his colleagues, who are, of course, aware they are approved by the Emperor, and also aware that if Spain consents she will have the support of France. The Confederate States are preparing to guarantee the independence of Cuba, either by treaty with her or by joining in the treaty with other Powers, in return for certain not unreasonable advantages. The answer of the Spanish Government is not given, though, with France by her side, it may not be unfavorable. It is thought at Madrid that in any case the Emperor of the French will not much longer postpone recognizing the Southern Confederacy -- if with others well and good -- if not, alone."
lead_paragraph: "Private letters from Madrid inform me that proposals of recognition have been made on behalf of the Southern States of America to the Spanish Government, and that those proposals are made with the cognizance and full sanction of the French Emperor. It is thought at Madrid that in any case the Emperor of the French will not much longer postpone recognizing the Southern Confederacy -- if with others well and good -- if not, alone."

abstract: -- Our Common Council has not covered itself with special glory in the outbreak which has just disgraced the City. It has not been possible even to get together a quorum of the members of either branch, and those who have assembled and ventured to express any opinion on the subject, have talked as if they either sympathized with the mob or stood in terror of its brutal power.

abstract: If Monday's lesson of life in a City under the rule of a mob was not sufficient to fix the mind of every citizen as to his duty in the present crisis, then yesterday's experience must have removed all remaining doubts. He who hesitates to give all his influence, his time, his money and his personal services to the City authorities, until the rightful authority of law is restored and the rule of the mob put down, must himself be either an agrarian and robber at heart, or a poltroon.
lead_paragraph: If Monday's lesson of life in a City under the rule of a mob was not sufficient to fix the mind of every citizen as to his duty in the present crisis, then yesterday's experience must have removed all remaining doubts. He who hesitates to give all his influence, his time, his money and his personal services to the City authorities, until the rightful authority of law is restored and the rule of the mob put down, must himself be either an agrarian and robber at heart, or a poltroon.

abstract: The last of the rebel dead on the battle-field were buried only yesterday. They were principally found near the foot of Round Top Ridge, where some of the most terrific fighting of the battle took place, between a portion of LONGSTREET'S forces and the Excelsior brigade. The bodies numbered, in all, about fifty. Quite a number, nearer the centre, had been buried the day previous.
lead_paragraph: GETTYSBURGH. Saturday, July 11, 1863.

abstract: -- It may be proper to state, by way of explanation, that neither SAMUEL HALLETT nor Gen. FREMONT have any connection whatever with the Union Pacific Railroad. These gentlemen, as is reported, recently purchased the Leavenworth, Pawnee and Western Railroad, of Kansas, for which name they substituted the "Pacific Railroad, Eastern Division." This is their only claim to represent, the great work which is to extend from the Missouri River to the Pacific, and which is now in the hands of a very different set of men. The object of Mr. HALLETT, at least, appears to be, to secure some reputation to the railroad of which he is banker, by giving to it the name of a work in which the public feel so great an interest.
lead_paragraph: -- It may be proper to state, by way of explanation, that neither SAMUEL HALLETT nor Gen. FREMONT have any connection whatever with the Union Pacific Railroad. abstract: Among other absurdities proposed at the present time by demagogues, to "tide over" the reign of rioters in our City, is the appropriation by the City Council of $2,500,000 to pay the $300 exemption to relieve "poor men" from the draft. The impracticability of administering a relief measure of this kind fairly and satisfactorily, should prove an insuperable objection to it. The draft required from the City is for about 20,000 men. To exempt the whole of them would require the sum of six millions of dollars. It is fair to assume that two-thirds of the drafted persons in the City -- where the masses are undoubtedly laboring men, of small means -- would be unable to pay the exemption fee. But to exempt two-thirds of the 20,000 conscripts would require $4,000,000 -- a sum much larger than the City Government proposes to divide in its anti-military charity. How shall the discrimination between "poor men" be made, when there is less money than will go round? What "Committee" would be honest enough and just enough to trust with so delicate a work as deciding what "poor conscripts" must go to war, and what "poor conscripts" must stay at home? Would not the decision of cases between competitors for the City's exemption breed new discontents, and complicate our civil disorders instead of simplifying them?

abstract: Rumors of all kinds were in circulation, to the effect that the pirate Alabama was in the vicinity of the islands. One report was that she had been spoken, on June 14, by H.B.M. sloop Scarecr[???]w, another that she was seen about the same time off Port Royal, but all these stories were contradicted nearly as soon as they were started. It was also reported and authoritatively denied that the Sir William Peel, steamer, had sailed to take stores to the pirate.

abstract: Gov. Seymour's arrival, address and proclamation
snippet: Gov. Seymour's arrival, address and proclamation
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR arrived in this City yesterday morning, and at 12 1/2 o'clock addressed a large crowd of men and boys, numbering 800 or over, from the steps of the City Hall. On taking the stand he was greeted with vehement and prolonged cheers. He said he had come from his quiet home to this scene of excitement to do what he could to preserve the public peace.

abstract: There was even more excitement at the Navy-yard yesterday than on the day previous. The following ships-of-war were drawn up in such a manner as to command the entire premises: Steam gunboat Granite City, 8 guns; steam gunboat Gertrude, 8 guns; corvette Savannah, 22 guns; receiving ship North Carolina, 4 guns; steam gunboat Unadilla. 8 guns; steam gunboat Jump, 6 guns. The Iron-clad battery Passaic, and the steam gunboat Fuchia, were sent down to the Battery to insure the safety of Fort Columbus, in case the sending of its garrison to the City might leave it at the mercy of the mob. All the approaches to the yard, to the Commandant's residence, and to the vessels in the stream, were guarded by sailors with howitzers and boat-pieces. Capt. DEAYTON, of the Ordnance Department, had a guard placed over the armory and on the magazine; he had also several pieces of ordnance in readiness to be turned on the mob if necessary. All the available marines were under[???]rms, and the guard on the gate had their muskets loaded. After the roll being called at 1 o'clock, the workmen were speedily turned into their shops, to prevent the possibility of their joining with the outsiders.

abstract: Murder of Col. O'Brien
snippet: Murder of Col. O'Brien
lead_paragraph: The reign of the mob which was inaugurated on Monday morning has not yet ceased, although today will probably witness the end of its infamous usurpation. All Monday night the rioters, unchecked, prosecuted their depredations, and yesterday morning found the lawless spirit not a whit abated. On the contrary, the malignant originators of the disturbance grew bolder at the impunity with which they were necessarily permitted to indulge in their first day's career, and at one time more serious consequences than any which have yet occurred were threatened. Happily, however, the military and police authorities early in the day recovered from the partial paralysis into which the sudden demonstrations of the mob had thrown them, and in sufficient force were able to contend with the truly formidable organization of lawless men. A few wholesome but severe lessons were administered to the rioters during the day wherever they showed themselves most turbulent, and toward evening there seemed to be unmistakable indications that the supremacy of law would soon be acknowledged even by the most rabid of the offenders. Perhaps, however, the mere fact that a score or more of the rioters were killed in the various conflicts with the military and the police was not solely the cause of this abatement of the spirit of violence. The proclamation of Gov. HORATIO SEYMOUR, and the announcement, made early in the afternoon, that President LINCOLN had ordered the draft in this City to be suspended, may also have had something to do with restoring the malcontents to reason. At any rate, after nightfall the streets were comparatively quiet.

abstract: Late in the afternoon the rioters commenced to barricade First-avenue, near Eleventh-street, and First-avenue, near Fourteenth-street. The telegraph poles, which they had torn down, were used for these barricades, together with numerous carts, which had been picked up in the adjacent streets. At Thirteenth-street two street-sweeping machines, which had been captured the previous evening were burned amid the shouts of the men, women and boys who thronged the avenue. The especial spite the rioters had against these machines was that they were labor-saving, and to their ignorant minds, they appeared their prime enemies. The moving spirit in this riotous conduct was a man who announced himself a returned soldier, but who declared that his sympathy had been aroused for the South by the emancipation of the "niggers." He made excited, speeches to crowds of people, and seemed particularly desirous of stirring up a fight with any one who should have the hardihood to combat his sentiments. He and others inveighed, bitterly against grain-elevators as labor-saving machines -- as inimical to the poor man, and intimated a purpose to destroy them as they had destroyed the street-sweepers. Upon the adjacent tenement houses were numbers of men, some of them armed with guns in anticipation of an attack by the soldiers. A gun-store in Fifth-street near Avenue A had been broken open in the morning and completely gutted of its contents. The mob were in a great state of fear lest the militia should make their appearance, the false alarms of mischievous boys causing a general scampering.

abstract: Not only must this infamous and dastardly mob be put down, but it must be balked in the object for which it was gotten up. It was ostensibly to defeat the enforcement of the Conscription. The Conscription is a necessity; the Conscription is a law; the Conscription is just. It is demanded for the suppression of the Southern rebellion; it is needed to fill up our heroic but shattered regiments; the country called for it, and acquiesced in its passage; the army is a unit in urging its enforcement. It is the justest mode of raising an army -- just to the people of every class and condition, poor and rich, black and white. No class or order of citizens is exempt from its operation -- even poor clergymen, if drafted, being compelled to shoulder their musket.
lead_paragraph: Not only must this infamous and dastardly mob be put down, but it must be balked in the object for which it was gotten up. It was ostensibly to defeat the enforcement of the Conscription. The Conscription is a necessity; the Conscription is a law; the Conscription is just. It is demanded for the suppression of the Southern rebellion; it is needed to fill up our heroic but shattered regiments; the country called for it, and acquiesced in its passage; the army is a unit in urging its enforcement. It is the justest mode of raising an army -- just to the people of every class and condition, poor and rich, black and white. No class or order of citizens is exempt from its operation -- even poor clergymen, if drafted, being compelled to shoulder their musket.
