abstract: The formidable riot which commenced in this City on Monday was continued throughout yesterday with unabated, but fortunately not, as on the previous day, unchecked fury. As a natural consequence of the universal excitement of Monday the numbers of the rioters were largely increased yesterday, but so also were the preparations of the authorities to meet them. By a vigorous use of these preparations and the shooting of a score or more of the rioters by the military a decided check was given to the career of the mob; and although the demonstrations made by the rioters were on a more extensive scale, yet their achievements were of far less magnitude.

abstract: The London Times sees in the latest American advices proof of the report, that LEE is resolutely bent upon invading the North, and carrying the war into Federal territory, and in an editorial upon the subject, it says the indifference, carelessness or unconcern of the North at the calamity with which it is threatened is most surprising. It argues that if LEE wins, the cause of the North is lost; while if he loses, the cause of the South is not essentially injured. If HOOKER's army is defeatvd. Washington occupihd, and Pennsylvania overawed by a Confederate army -- says the Times -- it is difficult to see now the demand of the South for independence can be any longer refused.

abstract: The excellent entertainment provided at this establishment, under the auspices of Miss EMILY THORNE and Mr. MARK SMITH, deserves the best patronage of the public. In the Summer season we do not expect a first-rate company at any theatrical establishment, but with regard to the Winter Garden, we can hardly recall a time when the company was better. The fair manager and her associate are a host in themselves.
lead_paragraph: The excellent entertainment provided at this establishment, under the auspices of Miss EMILY THORNE and Mr. MARK SMITH, deserves the best patronage of the public. In the Summer season we do not expect a first-rate company at any theatrical establishment, but with regard to the Winter Garden, we can hardly recall a time when the company was better. The fair manager and her associate are a host in themselves. Mr. MARK SMITH is an artist whose versatility and talent are well known and appreciated. Miss EMILY THORNE has had fewer opportunities, but she has already won a place in the esteem of our public. During the present engagement she has displayed a vein of comic talent, and an ability to sing pleasantly, that bid fair to speedily place her at the head of the profession in those respects. There are other artists connected with the company who are deservedly popular with the community, foremost among whom we place Mr. A.H. DAVENPORT, Mr. PEARSON and Mr. SETCHELL. It would be difficult to select a company at any season of the year comprising elements of a more mirth-provoking character.

abstract: -- As a general thing the Press of the City, without distinction of party, dealt in terms of just, denunciation with the cowardly and ferocious mob which made our streets hideous with the most revolting crimes day before yesterday. The Daily News, while it denounces the conscription with unjust and, what seems to us, unpatriotic severity, reminds the men who resort to violence against it that they are only disgracing themselves, and bringing ruin upon the very cause they profess to serve. The World, with still more emphatic and mischievous denunciation of the draft, brands, in the sharpest terms, the resort to mob law as a remedy, and declares that "no Government can tolerate it for an instant." The Journal of Commerce calls upon every citizen to stand by the laws and the constituted authorities of the City, State Nation.

abstract: The mob in our City is still rampant. Though the increasing display of armed force has done something to check its more flagrant outrages, it is yet wild with fury, and panting for fresh havoc. The very fact of its being withstood seems only to give it, for the time, new malignity; just as the wild beast never heaves with darker rage than when he begins to see that his way is barred. The monster grows more dangerous as he grows desperate. More than ever, everything depends on the energy and vigilance of the authorities, and the sustaining cooperation of all true men. Official duty and public spirit should supremely rule the hour. The man in public place, or in private place, who falters in this dread crisis should stand accursed.

abstract: There is no important news from this place. At noon on Friday, June 19, Gen. AMIE LEGROS and seven others -- the leaders of the late revolution -- were shot at St. Marc. One of the new line of coasting steamers had arrived.

abstract: -- If this mob was originated in a passionate spirit of resistance to the Conscription law, it very soon changed its purpose, and assumed the character merely of a mob for robbery, plunder and arson. This is shown in the rifling of houses, hotels and stores, and the assaults and felonies upon the persons of unoffending citizens. Some of the ringleaders are noted thieves, who have served out several terms in Sing Sing and other penitentiaries and prisons. Hundreds of the workmen who joined with the crowd on Monday were, of course, as honest as the average of us, but they were at once joined by all the knaves of the City, who saw in the occasion an opportunity for plunder such as had never before presented itself. They made good use of their opportunity, as hundreds of unfortunate citizens can testify. The whole thing, if it continues, bids fair to become a gigantic mob of plunderers, with no more reference to the Conscription than to the Koran. It is remarkable, and almost incredible, how infectious this spirit becomes. A man who joins in such a mob as this may never have stolen a pin's worth in his life before, but when a jewelry store like that up town, or a mansion like those in Fifth-avenue, is broken into, the temptation is almost irresistible to rush in, and obtain a share of things. If this affair is allowed to go on, if it be not promptly put down, it will quickly result in a state of things such as was never before known in a civilized city. It is now a question of the protection of firesides, property and persons against general plunder. It has nothing to do with the conscription.

abstract: Immediate steps should be taken, either by State or City authorities, or by extensive individual organizations, for the proper care and maintenance of the families of poor men who shall be taken to the field by the draft. It needs not to be said, or enforced by any sort of argument, that the pay of a private soldier, even if the whole of it were devoted to the purpose, is not at all adequate to the support of a helpless wife, much less of a helpless wife and children, living in the City of New-York. It is no slight demand, therefore, on the patriotism of a man who supports his family by daily labor, to require him to go to war for an indefinite period under the draft, with the knowledge that he leaves his family in a rented house, and without the means of procuring food for a week to come after he leaves them.

abstract: The military news of this morning is of the highest importance. LEE'S army has effected its passage across the Potomac and into the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia. Port Hudson has been captured, with all its garrison. A renewed attack on Charleston has been begun, and has resulted in the capture of all but one of the batteries on Morris Island.
lead_paragraph: The military news of this morning is of the highest importance. LEE'S army has effected its passage across the Potomac and into the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia. Port Hudson has been captured, with all its garrison. A renewed attack on Charleston has been begun, and has resulted in the capture of all but one of the batteries on Morris Island.

abstract: LEE's Army has escaped! Such is the official news from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac this morning. Gen. MEADE telegraphs to Gen. HALLECK, under date 3 o'clock P.M. yesterday, that the enemy were all across the Potomac, with the exception of a brigade of infantry, 1,500 strong, captured by the cavalry at Falling Waters. They also secured two guns, two caissons, two battle-flags, and a large number of small arms. The rebels appear to have crossed at two points -- Falling Waters and Williamsport.

abstract: O'NEIL, JACOB HEILAND and JOHN BENEDICT were brought to the city on Saturday, from New-York son the charge of conspiring against the United States; also, with corresponding with the enemies of the same. In the afternoon they had a hearing before Commissioner A.H. SMITH, when ABRAHAM LOUR, Jr., one of the detective officers of the Government, testified to having repeated interviews with the defendants since the 25th of June last, on which day he first met JACOB HEILAND, then known as JOHN MOORE. LOUR had introduced himself and was known to the accused as Mr. SPAULDING, of St. Mary's County, Md., and Officer SHERMAN, who was operating with him, as JOHN DAWSON, of Wilmington, N.C. Most of the interviews took place at the store of FISHER & RICKETTS, No. 84 Wall-street, New-York. Officer LOUR, in the assumed character of Mr. SPAULDING, of St. Mary's, Md., represented that he was going to Richmond, and it was arranged that he should take a mail there in the schooner Lady's Delight, which was to be fitted up to run the blockade.

abstract: The forces engaged in the recent Peninsular campaign have reached Yorktown, KEYES' corps, GETTY'S division and Gen. R.S. FOSTER'S brigade coming overland, arriving here last night, and are already on their way to new scene. There are some features of this march that will serve to render it one of the most memorable marches of the war.
lead_paragraph: YORKTOWN, Va., Saturday, July 12, 1863.

abstract: -- It has heretofore been the boast of this country that liberty regulated by law was the principle which governed its citizens. The most perfect freedom to every man in every relation of life -- freedom of person, of speech and in the pursuit of happiness, has been our glory, while the universally upheld governance of law has been the safety both of ourselves and of our liberty. The dominance of the mob strikes at the root of this great and special American principle. It reverts us back to semi-barbarism, and throws us forward into despotism. A mob is un-American, anti-American. Every grievance can here be remedied, every wrong can here be righted by law, which has its power in the will of the people and "its fountain in the bosom of God." It will be a dark day for the liberties of America, for its honor, its greatness, its power, its glory, when this excrescence of European despotism fastens itself upon our free institutions and society. Every man who prides himself in the name of American must use his determined efforts to drive back this black and deadly tide of human depravity.

abstract: Third Day; Mayor Opdyke's Proclamation
snippet: Third Day; Mayor Opdyke's Proclamation
lead_paragraph: The ravages of the mob which commenced its diabolical career on Monday are not yet ended, and it is impossible to say at the hour of going to press this morning whether the worst has yet been seen. All through Tuesday night marauding bands of plunderers in greater or less numbers, continued to commit their depredations in various parts of the City, but at daylight yesterday morning they had generally dispersed and there was a fair prospect of a speedy res[???]o[???]ation of quiet and order. The authorities, both State and military, appeared to considers the riot as substantially subdued, and after a consultation early in the forenoon between Mayor OPDYKE, Gov. SEYMOUR and Gen WOOL., at the St. Nicholas Hotel, the following proclamation was issued from the Mayor's office:

abstract: Between eight and nine thousand rebel soldiers are within forty miles of Philadelphia. Brig.-Gen. ARCHEE, another Brigadier, and not less than four hundred commissioned officers besides, are among them.
lead_paragraph: Between eight and nine thousand rebel soldiers are within forty miles of Philadelphia. Brig.-Gen. ARCHEE, another Brigadier, and not less than four hundred commissioned officers besides, are among them. They are, however, entirely harmless just now, being prisoners of war. A visit to Fort Delaware, during its present occupation, cannot fail to be interesting. The fort itself is a fine work, and when the moat is finished, and other improvements on the Island are made, it will still be more attractive. Brig.-Gen. ALBIN SCHEPFF, who made for himself a lasting fame in the Western campaigns, is in command, and the garrison consists of sixteen or eighteen hundred men, the larger part of which are of a new and rather raw regiment, the Fourth Delaware volunteers.

abstract: Our City was last evening the scene of a riotous demonstration, which, though attended with comparatively trifling results, was still sufficient to create considerable excitement and alarm.
lead_paragraph: Our City was last evening the scene of a riotous demonstration, which, though attended with comparatively trifling results, was still sufficient to create considerable excitement and alarm. On some accounts it may be regarded fortunate, inasmuch as it tended to forewarn our authorities in a manner that will cause them to be forearmed against any more serious consequences in the future.

abstract: On Tuesday morning a band of about 70 or 80 coarse-looking men passed along the Harlem Railroad, from Mott Haven to the junction with the New-Haven road, a mile or so above Williams' Bridge, and tore up the track at several points. Going up they passed through the suburbs of Morrissania, and through the village of West Farms, going along with clubs, but with, quite orderly demeanor, offering no one any indignity. It was understood from them that they were bent on obstructing the railroad, fearing that it might be used to bring troops over from the East. The crowd came in part from New-York, it was believed, and in Westchester County they were joined by a considerable number of the railroad laborers and others. At Williams' Bridge they tore up the track three different times, and it was twice relaid by a section of workmen, who twice fled from the rioters. Exasperated at the prompt manner in which the track was relaid, they set to work to burn the passenger depot at Williams' Bridge, but were dissuaded from this purpose on being assured that it was private property, belonging to the man who keeps a refreshment saloon in it. They broke open the ticket office, however, and threw the papers and tickets outdoors, scattering and destroying them by tearing them up. They then destroyed the telegraph apparatus, and afterward broke down the telegraph and cut down three or four of the poles. When they proceeded up the track, news of their progress reached the village of Mount Vernon, three miles distant, on the New-Haven Railroad. It was supposed they were going there to destroy the cartridge factory of Messrs. Dow & JOHNSON, who recently located there. The firm took every precaution to disappoint the rioters. If they came there. The hands were all dismissed for the day. These are chiefly young girls. The stock of powder and other material was then removed to the magazine, which is located some distance off, in an out-of-the way place. The report that rioters were likely to visit the village created much consternation. Some families left their houses, and went to others considered more secure. In consequence of the cars not running, many of the male residents, who mostly come to the City daily, were at home, and steps were taken to defend private property from damage. The rioters did not come near the village, but went on up the Harlem road. Had they visited Mount Vernon they probably would have met with a damaging repulse, the citizens being determined to resist them and to put them down. On Wednesday morning the track was all in good order on both roads, the brakes having been repaired, but no cars were running, in consequence of the disturbed state of affairs in the City. Persons who felt obliged to come to the City came in private conveyances and on foot. In going back all sorts of means were resorted to. Conveyances were scarce, and exorbitant prices were in general asked for them. In many cases even ladies walked from Harlem Bridge out from one to ten miles, rather than pay the excessively high prices charged for wagons. The people living out of town, and doing business in the City, at least those who daily travel over the Harlem and New-Haven Railroads, have suffered great inconvenience this week. One train went out on each road on Monday night, from Mott-Haven, but on Tuesday morning the trains were all running right again. Tuesday afternoon no trains ran, nor did any run yesterday. Every night this week, persons going to Mount Vernon and above there have been from two to fire hours in making the journey.

abstract: Riots; "The Left Wing of Lee's Army"
snippet: Riots; "The Left Wing of Lee's Army"
lead_paragraph: When the plots of the Southern rebels for the overthrow of the Union and the inaugurartion of war first took form and shape, one of the great elements of power and success upon which they counted was the cooperation of the "New-York mob," or the "Northern mob." This mob, these masses of the great industrial centres of the North were, in fact, at one time looked upon as the chief tool in the hands of the Secessionists for the accomplishment of their purposes. Being at once selfish, ignorant and brutal, totally destitute of any sentiment of patriotism, easily deceived, and inclined to "treason, stratagem and spoils," they would, as soon as the Government was weakened by the secession of the Southern States, and business was destroyed by the withdrawal of Southern trade, rush into scenes of violence, blood and anarchy, before which the enfeebled "concern" at Washington would rapidly sink into ruin, while in the mean time the rebels of the South could establish their power, consolidate their authority and enter upon their separate career. The speeches of the rebel leaders and the articles in the rebel newspapers, propounding these schemes and setting forth these hopes, must be fresh in the memory of all. For this "mob," however, the bitterest contempt was always expressed. It was a "greasy" mob, a "vulgar" mob -- the product of the soothing masses of brutalism, ignorance and poltroonery, which the traitors asserted existed in and controlled the great cities and densely populated manufacturing regions of the North.

abstract: Riots; Gov. Seymour's Proclamation, Announcing "A State of Insurrection"
snippet: Riots; Gov. Seymour's Proclamation, Announcing "A State of Insurrection"
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning a Proclamation by the Governor was published declaring this City "in a state of insurrection;" yet in the face of that manifesto, unprecedented in our City annals, gold at the Stock Exchange fell four per cent! Was the like ever heard of? In a European city, such a step by the Government is always taken as a signal that society is in danger; and gold, the first of cowards, precipitately hides itself. It forth with "makes itself scarce." But here, while it is officially heralded that the Metropolis is "in insurrection," gold is found more easily than it has been for a whole twelvemonth previously. In fact, from the very beginning of the disturbance, it has all the while been growing cheaper. All the threats of anarchy and havoc have not given it a flutter; and every hour's tidings of fresh outrage has only been followed by a new manifestation of its fresh confidence. At first blush, this is certainly a curious phenomena. We doubt if anything like it has ever been seen before. And yet it is entirely rational, and just what, under the circumstances, ought to have been expected.

lead_paragraph: The Tribune of yesterday morning has the following: "It is a curious fact, that of all the arrests made, every one is Irish." However this may be, it is a fact, patent to every one who has seen anything of the mob, that it is composed almost exclusively of Irishmen and boys. In view of this fact, the following appeal from the distinguished prelate whom the Irish particularly revere, and whom everybody respects, is timely and appropriate:

abstract: The Canada letter mails for the steamer China arrived in this city this morning by steamer from Yonkers. Mr. MCGILLURAY, the officer in charge, arrived at Yonkers last evening, in the regular train from Toronto, but was unable to proceed further on account of the track of the Hudson River Railroad being torn up below that point. He reports that all was quiet at Yonkers this morning when he [???]t. The citizens had organized for mutual protection, and two companies were on guard last night at the Arsenal. At Tarrytown also the citizens were on the alert, and when the train passed through last night they had cannon drawn out to overawe the hostile demonstrations of the rioters.

abstract: The ship Maggie V. Hugg arrived at this port yesterday, reports that on the 1st inst., when in latitude 41 and longitude 63.50, she as boarded by a boat from the U.S. bark Ethan Allen, the latter then being in pursuit of a bark which she deemed, a suspicious character. At 2 o'clock on the following morning she she Saw the flash of some half-dozen guns in the direction of the chased. On the 6th inst., when in latitude 38.50 and longitude 71, the Maggie V. Hugg was chased by a bark with decks full of men, but finding that she was out-siled, after dark hau[???]ed off and started in the direction of a vessel to leeward, that had squared away before the wind some time previously. -- Baltimore Sun, July 14.

abstract: Thanksgiving Day Appointed for Aug. 6; Thanksgiving Proclamation for Aug. 6
snippet: Thanksgiving Day Appointed for Aug. 6; Thanksgiving Proclamation for Aug. 6
lead_paragraph: It has pleased Almighty God to hearken to the supplications and prayers of an afflicted people, and to vouchase to the army and the navy of the United States, on the land and on the sea, so signal and so effective as to furnish reasonable grounds for augmented confidence that the Union of these States will be maintained, their Constitution preserved, and their peace and prosperity permanently preserved; but these victories have been accorded not without sacrifice of life, limb and liberty, incurred by brave, patriotic and loyal citizens. Domestic affliction in every part of the country follows in the train of these fearful bereavements. It is meet and right to recognize and confess the presence of the Almighty Father, and the power of His hand equally in these triumphs and these sorrows.

abstract: It is in time, we trust, to address a few works of earnest exhortation to the truly honest and well-meaning laboring classes of this City. Yesterday gangs of mischief ...
lead_paragraph: It is in time, we trust, to address a few works of earnest exhortation to the truly honest and well-meaning laboring classes of this City. Yesterday gangs of mischief making and riotous men were proceeding from workshop to factory, in different parts of the City, warning proprietors to discharge all the hands in their employ, under threats of violence to them and their establishments if they refused. In some cases, we are sorry to hear, proprietors complied with the demands of the mob. They were not much to blame, perhaps. They did not know how fully the lawless spirit of the past two days had been checked, and it was pardonable to wish to escape arson and murder, if dismissing their men would secure them exemption.

abstract: The excitement in brooklyn (E.D.) is subsiding. During Tuesday night and yesterday it ran...
lead_paragraph: The excitement in brooklyn (E.D.) is subsiding. During Tuesday night and yesterday it ran pretty high in the Fourteenth Ward of the city, but the announcement that the draft has been suspended by the authorities has produced a most happy effect. Citizens are rapidly enrolling in volunteer companies, and all is doing that is necessary to maintain the good order of the city.

abstract: -- No less than four great military campaigns have come to a conclusion since the beginning of June -- Gen. MEADE's campaign in Pennsylvania and Maryland against LEE; Gen. ROSECRANS' campaign against BRAGG; Gen. GRANT's campaign against Vicksburgh; Gen. BANKS' campaign against Port Hudson. The two latter campaigns and victories are final in themselves; the two former will doubtless be resumed on new fields, or rather new campaigns will succeed those just closed.

abstract: Robbery of Brooks' Brothers store; Sack of Mr. Samuel Sinclair's house; Gen. Banks' Official Report of Captures
snippet: Robbery of Brooks' Brothers store; Sack of Mr. Samuel Sinclair's house; Gen. Banks' Official Report of Captures
lead_paragraph: At a late hour on Tuesday night the mob, numbering 4,000 or 5,000, made an attack upon the clothing-store of Messrs. BROOKS BROTHERS, in Catharine-street, corner of Cherry. Sergeant FINNEY, of the Third Precinct, while in the discharge of his duty in endeavoring to protect the property of this establishment, was knocked down, beaten on the head and body with clubs, and afterward shot in the hand by a pistol by one of the rioters. He was subsequently conveyed to the Station-house, where his wounds were dressed. He is very severely injured, and no hopes are entertained of his recovery. Officer DANIEL FIELDS, of the same Precinct, was knocked down and brutally beaten about the head and face at the same time.

abstract: The ravages of the mob which commenced in this City on Monday, had not ceased when we went to press this morning, but were more violent than ever.
lead_paragraph: The ravages of the mob which commenced in this City on Monday, had not ceased when we went to press this morning, but were more violent than ever. The each part of the day was comparatively quiet, but as evening closed in the rivers renewed their work with redoubled fury, and in [???] instances were armed with rifles. A serious conflict between the mob and the military occurred at 6 o'clock in the evening in Nineteenth-street, and another at 11 o'clock last accounts the military were masters of the field.

abstract: And the New-York Riots
snippet: And the New-York Riots
lead_paragraph: Throughout the infamous riot which has raged through our streets for the last three days, we have carefully abstained from everything like partisan crimination, and especially from all attempts to implicate our brother journalists, of whatever stripe, in the responsibility for the state of things which now exists. We have, on the contrary, eagerly seized upon every indication that the Press of this City was unanimous in denouncing on rages, which brand our whole community with disgrace, and make every American worthy the name blush with shame and indignation for his country and its laws. We were not only willing but anxious to forget for the moment that there were any such things as political parties among us, -- and to remember only that we had a country to save, laws to vindicate, public peace and public honor to preserve, and the character and quiet of our outraged community to rescue from the contempt into which they have been plunged by the most reckless and infamous gang of ruffians that ever disgraced and imperiled any civilized society on the face of the earth.
headline: {'main': 'This Press and the Mob.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'This Press and the Mob.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There will be a meeting of the old members of the First New-York Cavalry, now in the City, at 9 o'clock this morning, in the arsenal, corner of ThirtyFifth-street and Seventh avenue, to organize a cavalry company for duty in the present emergency.
lead_paragraph: There will be a meeting of the old members of the First New-York Cavalry, now in the City, at 9 o'clock this morning, in the arsenal, corner of ThirtyFifth-street and Seventh avenue, to organize a cavalry company for duty in the present emergency. The company will be immediately equipped by the City authorities. The call is made by Capt. ADAMS, Capt. BATTERSLY. Lieut. LAVERTY and Lieut. LENGERKE, and all members now in the City are earnestly invited to attend.

abstract: -- A few days since, as the employes in one of our City Banks on Broadway were about leaving for the evening, one of the book-keepers stepped into the vault to put away some papers, and just at that moment the porter, who was fastening up the premises, stepped in from another room, shut to and bolted the inside door of the vault, then slammed to the outside doors and locked it, it being a double vault; it was done so quick the caged book-keeper supposed it was for a joke, but in a moment the confined air and Egyptian darkness caused him to consider it rather too serious a matter to joke long about; he knew the practice of the porter was, as soon as he closed the vault doors, being the last thing he did, to put the keys in his pocket and wend his way home. As the feeling of confined air and horrors of suffocation came over him, he commenced making all the noise he could by voice and pounding; but the reverberating sound came back upon him with such deafening roar it nearly set him crazy. One of the clerks who still lingered in the room fancied he heard a stifled voice, like the intonation of a ventriloquist, from the wall opposite the vault; he listened; "Let me out. I'm suffocating," was faintly heard; it was repeated, but hardly audible, seeming to come from another part of the room; then again, near the vault -- finally traced to the vault; the key was applied, doors soon unlocked and unbolted, when nearly helpless, pale and weak, from fear, exertion and want of air, tottered forth the horror-stricken book-keeper; five minutes' incarceration, tortured with the thought that, by accident, he was left to die a slow and lingering death, had so changed him as to be scarcely recognized. He is now very nervous about vaults, and even after many days shudders at the sight of one. Those short five agonizing minutes, he says, seemed days to him, while the rush of thought is inconceivable and indescribable. As it was, the escape was a narrow one, for if the porter, with the clerks, had left the place soon as the vaults were closed, as was their general habit, no human being outside could have heard the faint cry of "Let me out, I'm suffocating." and it is questionable if any person could live over an hour, much less till next day in the forenoon, in such a place. Would it not be well for those closing up such vaults, when they have double doors, to look in, and be sure they do not accidentally inclose some one who may be more valuable than "filthy lucre?"

abstract: Satisfactory evidence having been received that the rebels have invaded Indiana in considerable force, it is hereby ordered and required that all able-bodied white male citizens in the several counties south of the National Road forthwith form themselves into companies of at least sixty persons, elect officers, and arm themselves with such arms as they may be able to procure.

abstract: Gen. GRANT has been blamed for paroling the rebel soldiers at Vicksburgh, instead of bringing them East and holding them as prisoners of war until regularly exchanged, on the ground that they could at once proceed to do garrison duty in Mobile and other places, and relieve for active service against our armies the soldiers now stationed there. But the form of parole forbids this action on the part of the liberated rebels. As will be seen by our Vicksburgh letter, the paroled men not only swea[???] that they will not take up arms until duly exchanged, but that they "will not serve in any military, police or constabulary force, in any fort, garrison, or field work" held by the rebels, "nor as guard of prisoners, depots or stores, nor discharge any duties usually performed by soldiers."
lead_paragraph: Gen. abstract: We are gratified at finding in the PortHudson news as communicated to a Cincinnati paper, that Gen. BANKS completed the reduction of that stronghold and received its capitulation, without the aid of reinforcements from Gen. GRANT.
lead_paragraph: We are gratified at finding in the PortHudson news as communicated to a Cincinnati paper, that Gen. BANKS completed the reduction of that stronghold and received its capitulation, without the aid of reinforcements from Gen. GRANT. It might have detracted somewhat from the glory of his triumph if he had owed any part of it to the flushed legions that captured Vicksburgh. And these latter heroes needed no new honors or laurels.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent telegraphs the reports of persons from the vicinity of Leesburgh, that LEE'S headquarters, on Wednesday morning, were at Bunker Hill, half way between Martinsburgh and Winchester--the advance of his army having reached the latter place, while the rear was at Martinsburgh. It was understood that he had sent his trains down the Shenandoah Valley to Culpepper, and was following with his army in the same direction.

abstract: It is some consolation to know that "Mr. ANDREWS, of Virginia," whose bloody thirsty harangue to the mob on Monday, gave the first public and notorious indorsement to the horrible scenes of pillage, cruelty and murder that followed, has been arrested, and is in a fair way to reap the full reward that his conduct courted. No doubt his bold, bad words, led many thoughtless people to believe that Government was powerless, law overthrown, and the floodgates of unpunishable passion and pillage fully opened. If, animated by this belief, any portion of the misguided multitude plunged into the mad riots and found death in mid career of their crimes, their own blood and the curses of ruined families must rest upon him.

abstract: The British iron steamer Britannia -- a prize to the United States gunboat Santiago de Cuba -- arrived at Boston on Saturday, in charge of Acting Master MERRIMAN and a prize crew. She has a cargo of about 400 bales of cotton. The Britannia is a side-wheel steamer, of about 375 tons, built at Leith, Scotland, and she is reported to have made two successful trips as a blockade runner before her capture.

abstract: The Express is a very curious journal. We seldom attempt the difficult task of translating its spasmodic rhapsodies into the language of common sense, and we probably thus lose the benefit of a good deal of wisdom which may be wrapped up in them.
lead_paragraph: The Express is a very curious journal. We seldom attempt the difficult task of translating its spasmodic rhapsodies into the language of common sense, and we probably thus lose the benefit of a good deal of wisdom which may be wrapped up in them. Now and then, however, it becomes intelligible. Yesterday's issue, for example, remonstrates against our statement that the President has not ordered the draft to be suspended in this City; it "begs" and "implores" us, even if this be true, "to hush it up, if only to cheat the laboring people into acquiescence." And the Express enforces its urgent advice by a striking illustration. "The Devil himself," it says, "hushed up when he was worming his way into the Garden of Eden, and cheated Mother Eve and Father Adam. For mercy's sake, then -- if only for mercy's sake -- if this hitherto peaceful Paradise of ours is to be turned into a Hell -- do as the Devil did -- talk smooth words for a day or two only, until the Eves and Adams are seduced into eating the fruit." We remain unconvinced. The little transaction which seems to the Express so eminently worthy of admiration and imitation, does not strike us in the same light. It has not been conducive to peace. We leave to others the congenial task of "doing as the Devil did;" we prefer, for our own part, to tell the truth, and shame the Express.

abstract: A more entertaining chapter for reading than the reports concerning this horrible riot will be found in the account furnished by our own correspondent of the scenes and incidents attendant upon the surrender of Vicksburgh. It was a very dramatic and thrilling affair, and everything was conducted with a due regard to propriety and a proper tone of chivalry. View it in what light or in what relation we may, the capture of the great rebel stronghold on the Mississippi River was the most signal victory of the war.

abstract: A placard was posted about town yesterday afternoon purporting to be an invitation from Archbishop HUGHES "to the men of New-York who are now called in many of the papers rioters," to pay him a visit at his residence at 2 o'clock this afternoon, when he would make them a speech. It closed by a promise that "they should not be disturbed by any exhibition of municipal or military presence," and was signed, as the Archbishop never signs, "JOHN Hughes, Archbishop of New-York."

abstract: Riots; The Unfortunate Blacks
snippet: Riots; The Unfortunate Blacks
lead_paragraph: In the name of a humanity which they enjoy in common with all of us, we make an appeal to Christians, Christian churches and all humane citizens, in behalf of the unfortunate blacks of this City, whose persecutions during the three days of mob rule, have been so heartrending. We have already spread some of the facts and scenes -- only a tithe of what occurred, however -- before our readers. Hundreds of them have been killed in the public streets with atrocities such as we have never before read of in a civilized country, and such as will inflict indelible disgrace upon this Christian City for all time; hundreds of them have had their houses sacked and burned, and their little all forcibly taken from them; thousands of them have fled from the city in abject terror; and nearly all of them have been thrown out of employment. Neither sex, no age was spared; but wherever on this Island, for three days, a black man, woman, or piccaninny showed his or her head, the demon yell arose, and the most dreadful assaults and butcheries followed. It was a sort of St. Bartholomew massacre, more limited in extent, but with incidental horrors greater even than those of that day. There is no doubt that one-half the world will disbelieve that such things could take place in New-York in the Nineteenth Century; but, unfortunately, no one in this City can disbelieve it. No crime was charged upon them but their color, except in one or perhaps two instances, where distracted negroes undertook to defend their own lives. They were mostly inoffensive persons, and a large number of them were members of the various colored Methodist and Baptist Churches of the City. We do not help our case by saying that these atrocities upon our native blacks were not the work of persons of American birth; for, if Americans were incapable of active participation in such crimes, they at least stood passively by while they were being committed.
headline: {'main': 'The Unfartunate Blacks--An Appeal', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Unfartunate Blacks--An Appeal', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Alderman MASTERSON denies, in the most explicit manner, that he used any such language in his remarks to the mob, on Monday, as was attributed to him in the report of the Daily News. He was there represented as having said that he rejoiced at the burning of the Provost-Marshal's Office, but protested against the burning of poor men's dwellings. He asserts that he said nothing of the kind, -- that he denounced the burning of any buildings whatever, and did everything in his power to extinguish the flames and save the property. We publish this correction with pleasure, and of course withdraw the comments which we made, and which would have been perfectly just, on the assumption that he made the remark ascribed to him by the Daily News.
lead_paragraph: Alderman MASTERSON denies, in the most explicit manner, that he used any such language in his remarks to the mob, on Monday, as was attributed to him in the report of the Daily News. abstract: River opened; change of base for Gen. Banks
snippet: River opened; change of base for Gen. Banks
lead_paragraph: The capture of Port Hudson by Gen. BANKS, closes the campaign in the West for the recovery of the control of the Mississippi river. It will not be safe, indeed, to predict immediate and uninterrupted navigation of its waters for purposes of commerce. For reasons that we presented in these columns a short time since, a restoration of active commercial operations in the Mississippi Valley, is impossible until the final establishment of peace. The National Government has had undisputed possession of the Mississippi river as far down as Memphis, for more than twelve months, but yet we well know that no unarmed boat at any time in all that period, or even to-day, dares land within five miles of Memphis, above or below. It is impossible to plant a police thick enough on the two banks of the Mississippi river between Cairo and New-Orleans -- a distance of fully one thousand two hundred miles, or two thousand four hundred miles if we include both sides -- to prevent such guerilla firing on passing boats as will place an effectual bar on general navigation for commercial purposes.
headline: {'main': 'The Mississippi Open--Change of Base for Gen. Banks.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mississippi Open--Change of Base for Gen. Banks.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The practice of garroting has been again introduced in this City, with all the other crimes of the riot. Garroting is only one of the arguments which the virtuous opponents of the Conscription law use to show the intensity of their convictions against the validity of that law. It will doubtless flourish briskly while the mob retains sway, or until we have martial law to bring to condign punishment the criminals who have inaugurated the reign of terror. It is hardly worth while making war upon this special crime until the great crime which includes this and all others is crushed out. The safest way at present is for respectable people to keep in their houses after dark, and give up the guardianship of the streets to the military the police and other officers of justice.

abstract: What most amazes is not the existence of this mob, but its hideousness. There have been other abominations of the sort in America, but nothing that began to be infernal as this. As cholera is said to begin with what other fatal diseases close with--death--so this insurrection begun with what the worst of other outbreaks end in, cruelties the most fiendish and the most wanton.
lead_paragraph: What most amazes is not the existence of this mob, but its hideousness. There have been other abominations of the sort in America, but nothing that began to be infernal as this. As cholera is said to begin with what other fatal diseases close with -- death -- so this insurrection begun with what the worst of other outbreaks end in, cruelties the most fiendish and the most wanton. From the very first day, the horde has shown a vileness and depravity of spirit scarcely to be paralleled in any civilized land since the French Reign of Terror. Pillage is common enough in such emeutes, and arson, and even hot-blooded murder; but the dashing out the brains of infants, the kicking and torturing of dying men, as in the case of Col. O'BRIEN and scores of others, the mutilating of corpses and subjecting them to every mockery amid the general plaudits of the rabble, exhibit an abandonment of human feeling, that was hardly deemed possible in any portion of American society, even the foreign-born. Few imagined that there was such a race of miscreants extant. It is appalling to think of it! At a time like this we look, as it were, down the very crater of the volcano. The liquid fire and the bitter ashes, which from time to time devastate and pollute the world, roll and toss in that abyss. Other political perils that we have undergone, have been comparatively superficial; here we scan the depths to the very bottom. The spirit we now see, is the very spirit of the French Revolution, surviving still -- sent over the water like some fiend from the pit, to make freedom detestable, to exterminate the laws of God and of society, and to turn the triumphs of civilization into a state of things as insecure as savage existence, and as degraded as that of the vilest brutes.

abstract: The preparations of the authorities to put down the mob in this City are now so ample, that a speedy return of our accustomed quiet is certain. Several of the ring-leaders of the mob have been arrested, and the operations of the rioters were confined yesterday to a limited section of the East side of the town. A desperate conflict, which took place there last night, between the desperadees and the military, resulting in the complete triumph of the latter, it is thought will be decisive.

abstract: I have just learned by telegraph that my two last letters on the campaign in Tennessee formed part of the mail the other day captured by JOHN MORGAN on the line between Nashville and Louisville. As the facts and incidents therein recorded are now somewhat passe, and as the public attention is engaged by more stimulating events on both flanks of our great line, it is, perhaps, hardly necessary to attempt to repeat them.

abstract: -Every respectable Christian in town felt a greater sense of security yesterday for his person and property when he learned that the gallant and famous Seventh regiment had arrived in town. Every rioter and thief in town felt a dawning conviction as to the error, or at least the danger of his course, when he learned the same fact. The Seventh has done excellent service in its brief campaign in Maryland, and it is all ready again for service here. It reported for service instantly, and, as will be seen, was almost instantly assigned to a very important sphere of duty.

abstract: The City yesterday, during the daytime, was comparatively quiet. The streets were no longer under the control of the mob. No more buildings were fired--no more citizens were assassinated--no more negroes were hung--no more manufacturing establishments were stopped and their workmen turned adrift.
lead_paragraph: The City yesterday, during the daytime, was comparatively quiet. The streets were no longer under the control of the mob. No more buildings were fired -- no more citizens were assassinated -- no more negroes were hung -- no more manufacturing establishments were stopped and their workmen turned adrift. The railroad cars and omnibuses resumed their regular trips, the shops of all kinds were again opened, and business seemed once more to flow in its accustomed channels. Late in the evening, by far the most desperate and sanguinary fight of the whole riot took place in Second-avenue; but the indications were that this was the expiring struggle of the chief band of rioters. We hope that the riot has spent the fiercest of its fury, and that the public authorities will have no difficulty henceforward in preserving the public peace.

abstract: Since the fight between the military and the mob in Second-avenue, on Thursday night, there has been no fresh disturbance of the peace by the ...
lead_paragraph: Since the fight between the military and the mob in Second-avenue, on Thursday night, there has been no fresh disturbance of the peace by the rioters deserving of notice, and there is little doubt that the usual quiet and order of the City are again permanently restored. The precautions of the authorities have not, however, been abated, and should there be a renewal of the outbreak, the preparations are such as to secure its prompt suppression and to vindicate the majesty of the law.

abstract: Riots; Justice to the Victims
snippet: Riots; Justice to the Victims
lead_paragraph: There are not spires enough in this City to avert the wrath of Heaven, it something is not speedily done to lighten the awful misery which this mob has brought upon our colored population. It is not sufficient to lift from them the nightmare of terror. They have physical wants that must be provided for, or they will perish. Hundreds of women and children have been forever deprived by murderous hands of those whose daily labor was their sole dependence. Hundreds of them have been plundered of their clothing and of every article of their personal property. Thousands of them have been kept by violence from their work, and thus left with their families exposed to starvation. They are all, in the present condition of things, absolutely helpless. They can make no appeal. They can do nothing but hide and crouch, terror-stricken and famishing. The movement for their relief cannot come from them. They can at best only be passive. Just men must think and act for them, and do it promptly, too, or themselves become partners in the dreadful guilt.

abstract: And the Rioters; and the Rioters
snippet: And the Rioters; and the Rioters
lead_paragraph: We were surprised to learn yesterday that the call purporting to be issued by Archbishop HUGHES "to the men of New-York, who are now called in many of the papers rioters," was a genuine document. It did not seem to us possible that any person holding a position of so much dignity and responsibility could say a word which could be construed to imply that he did not regard as "rioters" men who had burned down public buildings, plundered private dwellings, set fire to orphan asylums, assailed with bludgeons and stones the-legal defenders of the public peace, hung innocent and defenceless men, murdered, with every conceivable brutality, the officers of justice, and done everything which men could do to overthrow the law and plunge society into the very depths of anarchy and crime. If the mob had burned the Catholic Orphan Asylum next door to the Bishop's Cathedral, somebody beside "the papers" would probably have called them "rioters:" -- that Archbishop HUGHES could regard the term as less applicable to the men who burned the Colored Orphan Asylum, seemed to us incredible. Nor did we dream for a moment that in a City convulsed with a bloody and raging riot, Archbishop HUGHES could presume to call a meeting of the rioters, and, of his own authority, say to them, "you shall not be disturbed by any exhibition of municipal or military presence." Such an assurance implies the assumption of a power superior to that of the law: and whatever the Archbishop might feel, we did not think he would be unwise enough openly to proclaim the possession of such a personal or official supremacy.
headline: {'main': 'Archbishop Hughes and the Rioters.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Archbishop Hughes and the Rioters.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- We are glad that the citizens are so generally organizing into Home Guards and other associations for the defence of the City. It is shameful to us that it should be necessary to send here the war-worn regiments of the Army of the Potomac to keep the peace in our streets. There are enough law-abiding citizens here to crush out all the felons and rioters in the City, though they were ten times more numerous than they are. We ought to do it. It is an excellent opportunity for our citizens of all classes to exercise themselves in military drill and perfect themselves in military manï¿½uvres. If regiments are to be sent from MEADE's army to put down the wretched demonstrations in all the cities of the North where they have taken place, it will weaken our army so that we need not look for an effective pursuit of LEE, nor for the crushing out of the great rebellion until a considerable time after the conscription is enforced. Let us attend to our own defence, while our gallant army in the field attends to the enemy.
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad that the citizens are so generally organizing into Home Guards and other associations for the defence of the City. It is shameful to us that it should be necessary to send here the war-worn regiments of the Army of the Potomac to keep the peace in our streets. There are enough law-abiding citizens here to crush out all the felons and rioters in the City, though they were ten times more numerous than they are. We ought to do it. It is an excellent opportunity for our citizens of all classes to exercise themselves in military drill and perfect themselves in military manuvres. If regiments are to be sent from MEADE's army to put down the wretched demonstrations in all the cities of the North where they have taken place, it will weaken our army so that we need not look for an effective pursuit of LEE, nor for the crushing out of the great rebellion until a considerable time after the conscription is enforced. Let us attend to our own defence, while our gallant army in the field attends to the enemy.

lead_paragraph: The conflict between the military and the mob in Second-avenue, on Thursday night, proved, as has been anticipated, to be the decisive struggle between anarchy and order, and yesterday morning beheld a restoration of peace and quiet throughout the length and breadth of the City. Nearly all kinds of business was resumed, and, except for the military precautions observable around the theatres of the late riots, a stranger would not have mistrusted that there had been any departure from the usual serenity of the Metropolis. Toward noon, the following proclamation was issued from the Mayor's Office, and was felt to embody a much nearer approach to the actual state of things than the one of similar tenor, issued from the same quarter: on Wednesday:

abstract: There were no riotous demonstrations in this city yesterday, Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Thursday night a fire broke out in a stable in the upper part of Henderson-street, Jersey City, ownedby Mr. PETER HENDERSON, gardener. There being considerable hay in the upper part, when the fire was first discovered, the flames spread rapidly, and the entire building was soon in flames. There were three horses in the barn at the time, two of which were rescued, and the other, valued at $300, was burned to death. The Fire Department was very efficient in preventing a spread of the fire. Less about $600; no insurance. The fire is supposed to have been caused by vagabond boys.

abstract: The suggestion was casually made in conversation yesterday in a party of three gentlemen, that something ought to be done for the ...
lead_paragraph: The suggestion was casually made in conversation yesterday in a party of three gentlemen, that something ought to be done for the families of those members of the Police, Fire and Military Departments who have been killed or injured in the defence of law and order and in the protection of life and property during the recent riots. A paper was at once put in circulation, and in less than two hours nearly twenty thousand dollars was subscribed. The utmost alacrity was shown by every one to contribute to so excellent an object: -- and we run no risk in saying that before night at least $60,000 will have been contributed for this purpose. The men who have had property exposed to the depredations of the lawless mob, are quick to recognize and prompt to meet the obligations they owe to those who have so nobly interposed for its protection.

abstract: All remained quiet yesterday and the night previous, although many threats had been made to sack and burn the houses of citizens, which caused a great deal of excitement, and a number of persons came to the office of the Inspector of Police for protection. The Police being all concentrated at one point, so as to act in any great emergency, it was impossible to grant all the requests that were made. Several families were notified that their residences would be visited during the night, and in some instances the families removed to other places to escape danger. No house was set on fire, however, and but few persons were molested in any way.

abstract: Washington thirty-one of the regimental battle-flags captured at the late battle of Gettysburgh. Thirteen of these were taken from Virginia infantry regiments, four from North Carolina regiments, two from Georgia regiments, one from an Alabama, one from a Mississippi and one from a Florida regiment, and nine were from regiments whose States were not known. These facts, and many others that have appeared from time to time, go to show that the bulk of LEE's army is made up of Virginians and North Carolinians. The greater part of the rebel army of the Southwest, comprising the regiments raised in the States of Mississippi and Alabama and the States west of the Mississippi River, has been captured as prisoners of war by Gens. GRANT and BANKS. The army of Gen. BRAGG is composed mainly of regiments from Tennessee, Georgia and Kentucky, with others from the Gulf States; but a large part of the Tennesseeans and Kentuckians deserted lately when he fell back into Georgia. All the rebel armies are in a very bad way at present.

abstract: instructions to Vice-President STEPHENS on the occasion of his late attempted mission to Washington, reveal the real object of that mission, and perhaps not. Ostensibly, the object was, in DAVIS's own words, "to place this war on the footing of such as are waged by civilized people in modern times, and to divest it of the savage character which has been impressed on it by our enemies, in spite of all our efforts and protests." We do not see that there was any necessity of sending the Vice-President of the Confederacy to Washington in a Confederate steamer for this purpose. STEPHENS could have seen the officer in James River who is authorized by our Government to enter into negotiations with the rebel authorities on the subject. "The savage character impressed on the war by our enemies" is rather a remarkable expression, considering the treatment and terms given to the garrison at Vicksburgh by Gen. GRANT, on the day succeeding the on which DAVIS' letter is dated; and considering, also, our treatment of the ten thousand rebel wounded who were deserted by the rebel surgeons, and left on the field at Gettysburgh. There never was such humanity shown to a foe in any war as we have shown toward the rebels in this war, and on every occasion. But the likelihood is that STEPHENS, in his visit to Washington, had other ends to servo than those which appear in his letter of instructions.

abstract: It most be the most painful and humiliating event of all the war to our brave soldiers, that, after voluntarily taking upon themselves ...
lead_paragraph: It most be the most painful and humiliating event of all the war to our brave soldiers, that, after voluntarily taking upon themselves the defence of the nation against its foes, and spending months and years in the midst of the hardships and perils of warfare, they are called home at last to maintain, against ingrates and cowards here, the very laws that they went forth to defend. It is no longer the fire in front that galls. Thanks to the self-denying services and successful courage of those tried and true heroes, the rebel armies are repulsed from every front.

abstract: Riots; The Laws of the Mob--Gov. Seymour's Action; his firmness and prudence during the riot
snippet: Riots; The Laws of the Mob--Gov. Seymour's Action; his firmness and prudence during the riot
lead_paragraph: There is nothing which needs to be impressed more strongly on people's minds just now, than the fact for fact it is that the question which we have to decide in the next few days is not simply whether the United States army shall be recruited by draft, but in whose hands the resources of the country, its means of offence and defence are to be lodged in time of war, or of other public danger or difficulty. We must not forget that this rebellion is the first great peril of a young and inexperienced nation, and that every one of our acts and declarations at this crisis will be a precedent for the guidance and direction of future generations. Great and desperate as is the struggle in which we are now engaged, greater and more desperate struggles are doubtless still in store for us, and it is more than likely that even should the Government ride out the present storm in safety, its salvation at some later period will depend on the nature of the example which we are about to set.

abstract: Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday on the body of WM. HENRY YATES, a colored man, 41 years of age, who committed suicide at the house of ...
lead_paragraph: Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday on the body of WM. HENRY YATES, a colored man, 41 years of age, who committed suicide at the house of his employer, JAMES MARTIN, in Madison-street, by first cutting his throat, and then hanging himself to a cellar door by means of a small cord. The deceased resided in Water-street, and when the houses of the colored people were attacked by the mob on Thursday night, he undertook to defend his wife and children. The resistance which he offered was such as to excite them to the highest pitch, and many swore that he should be burned alive if caught. He secreted his family in the best way possible, and when resistance became hopeless he ran to the house of his employer where he was soon after found dead in the condition above stated.

abstract: Gens. WOOL and KILPATRICK, GOV. SEYMOUR and Mayor OPDYKE were in consultation at the head-quarters at the St. Nicholas Hotel, yesterday morning. It was generally considered that the rioters had reached the length of their rope, and that hereafter the military force already here, and that which is to arrive, will be able to keep down all further demonstrations of the insurgents. A thorough organization of the military, including the infantry, cavalry, and artillery, has been effected, and positions assigned to each company and regiment. By to-day a general rendezvous will be established, so that in event of an emergency a sufficient force can be immediately dispatched to the place of disturbance.
lead_paragraph: Gens. WOOL and KILPATRICK, GOV. SEYMOUR and Mayor OPDYKE were in consultation at the head-quarters at the St. Nicholas Hotel, yesterday morning. abstract: a statement in one of the papers that reinforcements for the New-York mob were arriving from the Plug-Uglies and other clubs in Baltimore. Those who know the political sentiment of this, and the other associations that comprise what are called the lighting men of Baltimore, saw at once the absurdity of the statement. Reinforcements for the upholders of law and order in the City, however, could easily have been had from Baltimore. A letter from there states that two regiments of Union League men, armed and drilled, would have been instantly sent here on any day of this week to assist in putting down the mob. It is but two years since regiments from this City marched to Baltimore to put down a desperate secession mob in that city, but so great has been the growth of loyalty there that the city is now in turn prepared to help New-York. In Baltimore they have now an excellent regiment of colored soldiers, beside thirty-five hundred drilled negro laborers on the ramparts. Contrast this with the treatment of unoffending blacks in-this City. In loyalty, Baltimore is now the model for us.

abstract: The advent of Gen. GILLMORE has awakened this Department from its lethargy. Taking Folly island as the base, he has commenced siege operations against Charleston which bid fair to result successfully. The batteries on the Southern extremity of Morris Island were captured on the morning of the 10th inst., and our troops now occupy the Island and are threatening Fort Wagner and Cummings Point batteries, which are situated at the Northern extremity and command the entrance to the harbor and. Fort Sumter.

abstract: dispatch from Gen. BANKS, announcing the fall of Port Hudson, was sent to Gen. GRANT, and by him communicated to the Government, has led many to suppose that the former is acting as a subordinate to the latter. Such is not the fact.
lead_paragraph: -- The fact that the dispatch from Gen. BANKS, announcing the fall of Port Hudson, was sent to Gen. GRANT, and by him communicated to the Government, has led many to suppose that the former is acting as a subordinate to the latter. Such is not the fact. Each general has an independent command, Should the two generals officially. Gen. BANKS would rank Gen. GRANT. It is gratifying to know that these two distinguished chieftains are warm personal friends. The soldiery feeling existing between Gen. GRANT, at a certain crisis in his operations, invited Gen. BANKS to come up the river with his command and join him. "Tell BANKS," said GRANT, "there will no quarrel between us about rank." It will be remembered that the same noble spirit animated Gen. BANKS when Gen. POPE (a subordinate officer) was ordered to command the Department of Virginia. This order made it necessary for BANKS to report to POPE. While FREMONT declined to obey and was relieved, Gen. BANKS remained with his command like a true soldier and patriot -- and it was well hat he did, for at the head of his gallant corps he gave the enemy a check at Cedar Mountain that cost him a delay in his advance of nine days, which enabled enough of the Peninsula troops to come up and save POPE from total annihilation. This battle also saved Washington from capture.

abstract: -- An officer of Gen. McPhersonï¿½s Staff has had a sword made in Cincinnati, which he intends to present to Gen. U.S. Grant. The scabbard is of solid silver, appropriately carved and beautifully finished. The handle of the sword represents a curved figure of a young giant crushing the rebellion. The box in which the weapon is kept is made of rosewood, bound with ivory, and lined with purple velvet and white satin. On the interior of the lid Gen. Grant's, name is marked in crimson silk. The sword and box cost $1,000.
lead_paragraph: -- An officer of Gen. McPhersons Staff has had a sword made in Cincinnati, which he intends to present to Gen. U.S. Grant. The scabbard is of solid silver, appropriately carved and beautifully finished. The handle of the sword represents a curved figure of a young giant crushing the rebellion. The box in which the weapon is kept is made of rosewood, bound with ivory, and lined with purple velvet and white satin. On the interior of the lid Gen. Grant's, name is marked in crimson silk. The sword and box cost $1,000.

abstract: Our reporter yesterday took a general Stroll around the upper portion of the town, on a reconnoitering expedition. Broadway and the Bowery presented an unusually animated appearance. Business appeared brisker, the sheets were more frequented,...
lead_paragraph: Our reporter yesterday took a general Stroll around the upper portion of the town, on a reconnoitering expedition. Broadway and the Bowery presented an unusually animated appearance. Business appeared brisker, the sheets were more frequented, the policemen occupied their old positions on the street corners; the ladies, without whose presence the promenade is ever dull, were there In countless numbers; and the turpout of carriages and other vehicles was far greater than on any previous day during the week.

abstract: BURNSIDE'S Ninth Army corps, which in the crisis at Vicksburgh, was sent down to cooperate with Gen. GRANT, has returund to Kentucky, and will now, under BURNSIDE, cooperate with Gen. ROSECRANS. Our two illus  trious Western commanders work together very harmoniously.
lead_paragraph: -- We learn that Gen. BURNSIDE's Ninth Army corps, which in the crisis at Vicksburgh, was sent down to cooperate with Gen. GRANT, has returund to Kentucky, and will now, under BURNSIDE, cooperate with Gen. ROSECRANS. Our two illus trious Western commanders work together very harmoniously. When GRANT required all the troops that could be spared in the West for his work at Vicksburgh, Gen. ROSECRANS, though needing to retain some of them himself, said: "Never mind, it is right; pile them up; pile them up; give them all to GRANT or to me; let there be enough at one point to accomplish the object in view, no matter where. I would like to have them, but it is well they are going to GRANT." On the other hand Gen. GRANT, now that complete victory has crowned his efforts, is anxious to cooperate with Gen. ROSECRANS. He has a large force that can be spared for that purpose, and he himself will be glad to take them in any direction, and command them in any work. Neither of these great men quarrel for the highest seat in the synagogue, though each is more anxious than the other to serve his country.

abstract: for not making an immediate pursuit of LEE'S army after the battle of Gettysburgh, are very unjust. History does not afford a single example of a vigorous and long pursuit made by the troops who gained the victory after a severe conflict.
lead_paragraph: for not making an immediate pursuit of LEE'S army after the battle of Gettysburgh, are very unjust. History does not afford a single example of a vigorous and long pursuit made by the troops who gained the victory after a severe conflict. This work is always the duty of a reserve, and Gen. MEADE unfortunately had no reserve. The whole of his force was engaged in the battle. The reason of the inability of troops to pursue after the cessation of a severe battle, is the nervous exhaustion which instantly overtakes them. The beaten army may escape for some distance, by making one more desperate effort to save dear life, but the successful army has no such tremendous impelling motive; and half-an-hour after the question of victory is settled -- after the pressure of the engagement is taken off, an immediate renewal of exertion is next to impossible. The rebels suffer from the want of proper reserves as well as our army. They have never pursued successfully after any of their victories. Had we had a reserve of twenty thousand men at Gettysburg, to pursue LEE on the morning of the 4th inst., his army would have been demolished.

abstract: And Reconstruction
snippet: And Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: As might have been expected, the blows which the rebellion has recently received have made a good many people busy about plans for peace and reconstruction. We hear from various quarters announcements that the time has at last come to hold out the time has at last come to hold out the well-known "Olive Branch," and invite the South back to the fold; and some persons of luxuriant imagination and large sympathies, are already eagerly discussing the precise nature of the terms which we ought to offer. Some think we should regard everything that has happened, -- the war, the confiscation act, the emancipation decree, -- as what the French would call non avenu; and put everybody, as far as it is physically possible, in the position in which he stood before the fall of Fort Sumter. Others, again, would treat with the insurgents on the basis of existing facts, and leave everybody who still retains his slaves, or other property, in possession of them, and while assuming all slaves who are de facto, to be also de jure free, assuming the insurgents, in all our dealings with all of them -- the leaders as well as the others -- to be good fellows, who have been laboring under a temporary hallucination, but still entitled to our confidence and esteem. And others, again, propose to offer or accept no terms which do not involve a clean sweep of Slavery and all its appurtenances, and the entire assimilation of the social organization of the South to the social organization of the North, and the condign punishment of all traitors of high degree.

abstract: Yesterday, like the day before, was a day of quiet in the City, and in addition to the quietness there was a general feeling of security and an absence of all apprehensions of further disturbance which did not exist on Friday. This was owing not merely to the increased and ample preparations of the authorities for crushing out any further riotous demonstrations, but in a still greater degree to the...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, like the day before, was a day of quiet in the City, and in addition to the quietness there was a general feeling of security and an absence of all apprehensions of further disturbance which did not exist on Friday. This was owing not merely to the increased and ample preparations of the authorities for crushing out any further riotous demonstrations, but in a still greater degree to the universally expressed determination of the people themselves that this thing had got to stop -- at once and forever. Everybody was occupied throughout the day in discussing the features of the horrid demon when, for four days of the week, had stalked through our streets, and the feeling was unanimous that he must never be permitted to show his front [???]. The conversations which one heard in the streets and places of public resort, betrayed everywhere the most astonishing reaction in the popular mind upon those questions which are alleged by the apologists of the mob to have furnished a pretext for their crimes. Hundreds of men who have heretofore been opposed to the draft, and hoped that it might be avoided, if it could be done in a legal and peaceful manner, are now strongest in favor of the measure, and demand that the law shall be enforced at all hazards. Nor is the change of feeling with regard to the negro question less decided. The preaching of a hundred men like GARRISON and PHILIPS, continued through a life time, could not have wrought such change of sentiment toward the blacks, such expression of sympathy in their behalf, and such utter detestation of the demagogues who, for the last six months, have been doing their utmost to excite the passions and prejudices of the mob against them, as has been produced by the demon-like atrocities that have been perpetrated upon these unoffending people by the rabble of this City since Sunday last. It would be strange, indeed, if the causes which have produced this change in public feeling did not also create in the minds of some a desire for revenge. That such has been the result, any one whose business or curiosity has led him to mingle with the promiscuous gatherings in our streets during the last two days must have been convinced. It is to be hoped that no renewal of the outrages of the mob will give occasion for this spirit to manifest itself. Its peaceful and appropriate vent will be found in the ballot-box and at the polls, and judging from the sentiments expressed by the masses of our law-abiding citizens, there is where it will show its power.

abstract: Emperor, the; Modifications of his Cabinet
snippet: Emperor, the; Modifications of his Cabinet
lead_paragraph: The political lessons which NEPOLEON learned during his long residence in England may save him from the fate of the Orleanists and elder Bourbons. The prompt modification of his Cabinet immediately after the Paris elections indicates, at all events, that he has adopted one of the cardinal maxims of British rulers -- always to yield when the point of danger is reached. The warning from his Capital has not been thrown away on the Emperor. Ere the Opposition have organized themselves in battle array he has set about putting his house in order. PERSIGNY, the great enemy of free voting and free speech, has been dismissed from the Ministry of the Interior; M. BILLAULT, the great advocate of peace, and the antagonist of Prince NAPOLEON in the Senate, has supplanted M. WALEWSKI, the friend of Poland, in the State Department; while M. FOULD, the patron of economy, is still retained as Minister of Finance. His Majesty has also decided that there shall be no more Ministers without portfolio, and henceforward the task of explaining and defending the measures of Government will devolve on the President of the Council and the Secretary of State.

abstract: The firemen labor under the impression that they should be exempted from the draft, in consequence of the demand for their services at home in protecting the property of citizens from the dangers of fire.
lead_paragraph: The firemen labor under the impression that they should be exempted from the draft, in consequence of the demand for their services at home in protecting the property of citizens from the dangers of fire. A meeting of the Board of officers of the western Di[???]t Department was held in the office of the Chief Engineer last night, in relation to the matter. There was a full attendance. Mr. JOHN CUNNINGHAN, the Chief Engineer, presided. He stated that the Fire Departments of New-York and the Eastern District or Brooklyn had appointed Committees to call upon Gev. SEYMOUR, with the object of ascertaining his views as to the liability of firemen, and to urge him to use his influence in securing their exemption, as a body, from the operations of the forthecoming draft. After an interchange of sentiment, Mr. N.L. PETTIT moved that a Committee of five be appointed to act in conjunction with the Committees representing the other Departments. Mr. WM. B. BURRELL expressed the opinion that the Government had taken the matter under its our control, and that Governor SEYMOUR had no authority to act, in relation thereto. He thought it advisable to apply to the President or to the War Department. Some further remarks were made by other gentlemen, and the motion was carried unanimously. The Chairman named as the Committee, Mr. NICHOLAS L. PETTIT of Engine No. 20; J. PRYER BORKE, of Engine No. 14; FRANCES McGRATH. of Hook and Ladder No. 24; DENNIS McNAMARA, of Engine No. 5, and JOHN CAMPBELL, of Hose No. 6. The Chief Engineer was added to the Committee and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: Intervention, London Times' Precedent for
snippet: Intervention, London Times' Precedent for
lead_paragraph: The London Times is convinced that it has at length discovered a precedent which will justify Anglo-French intervention in America. The case of Russia and Poland, and the case of the North and the South, are, in its opinion, quite analogous. There are belligerents, and rebellion, and civil war in both cases; yes, and fighting, and devastation, and slaughter; but wh[???] further analogy exists between them, it wou'd puzzle even the Times man to show. In the one case is a people struggling to regain a nationality of which they were treach[???]ously deprived. In the other some half a score of States are striving to break up a Union to the formation of which their progenitors Lad f[???]eely assent ed. In the one case there is resistance to oppression; in the other there is no oppression to resist. Were Ireland in revolt, and England endeavoring to resubjugate her, there would be a case which might be fairly pronounced analogous to that of Russia and Poland; but none, save the distorted vision of a shop-keeping Secession ist, could have discovered a parallelism between the latter case and that of the North and South.
