abstract: Killed on the 1st July, at the battle of Gettysburgh, while gallan[???]y leading his company, Capt. THOMAS W. QUIRK, Company A, Ninth regiment N.Y.S.M.. son of the late THOMAS QUIRK, of this City, in the 20th year of his age. His remains were taken to Albany for interment. Capt. QUIRK was among the first who volunteered his services at the commencement of this war, was promoted from the ranks to a Captaincy for gallantry in action in the numerous battles in which his regiment were engaged, and severely wounded in the first battle at Fredericksburgh; he was universally beloved by officers and men, and by all who knew him. Thus has fallen, in the prime of youth and vigor, one of New-York's noblest, most gallant and patriotic sons. Had he lived, he would have added fresh laurels to those already acquired. He leaves a widowed mother, brothers and sister to mourn his loss. May his memory be ever green in the hearts of his friends and acquaintances.

abstract: Yesterday was another busy day with the Coroners. Their energies have been taxed to the utmost during the week just closed. In addition to the great number of cases of an ordinary nature which always occur in New York at this season of the year, they...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was another busy day with the Coroners. Their energies have been taxed to the utmost during the week just closed. In addition to the great number of cases of an ordinary nature which always occur in New York at this season of the year, they have held inquests upon the bodies nearly seventy victims of the riot. Sixty-six of these have been returned to their office. No. 4 Centre-street. From the papers in there cases we have obtained the following interesting facts. It must be recollected that these ate not all the inquests which have been held. Owing to the great amount of labor, the Coroners have been unable to make out their returns further than those above referred to.

abstract: The Assault on Fort Wagner
snippet: The Assault on Fort Wagner
lead_paragraph: The United States transport Fulton, Capt. ELDRIDGE, from Port Royal, S.C., 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday, and reports that a combined attack was made on Morris Island on the 10th inst, by the land and naval forces, consisting of five ironclads and the troops under Gen. GILLMORE. They have taken all the batteries on Morris Island but Port Wagner, at which place they were repulsed. Gen. GILLMORE had commenced mining the fort, and it was expected that he would take it in a few days, as the siege was progressing favorably.

lead_paragraph: possession of Gen. ROSECRANS, as has been stated by several journals of this City. Gen. ROSECRANS has his headquarters at Tullahoma, and his line extends easterly from that point, but it does not anywhere touch the Tennessee River. When BRAGG retreated from Murfreesboro before the advancing columns of ROSECRANS, he made first for the Tennessee, wi[???]ch he crossed, and then pushed to Chattanooga, where he left a force strong enough for its defence, while the position of the bunk of his army is not yet [???]xed, but it is believed to he pushing down to Northern Georgia. It is impracticable, as yet, for ROSECRANS to advance as far as Chattanooga, as his lines of communication are now of such great length as to make their defence at once difficult and [???]precarious[???]. [???] however, establishing a new base for his army, and when that is accomplished, the capture of Chattanooga will be in order.

abstract: Detatils of Gen. GILLMORE'S operations against the defences of Charleston, in cooperation with the naval force under Admiral DAHLGREN, to the 15th inst., have reached us by the arrival at this...
lead_paragraph: Detatils of Gen. GILLMORE'S operations against the defences of Charleston, in cooperation with the naval force under Admiral DAHLGREN, to the 15th inst., have reached us by the arrival at this port of the steamship Fulton, which arrived at this port yesterday. We have already had an account of operations to the 12th, which proves to be correct. After the failure of the attack on Fort Wagner, which was caused by the hesitation of the supports of the storming party to come up after the parapet was gained, Gen. GILLMORE commenced approaches by mining, and it was expected that it would soon be captured. All the fornications on James Island, as far as Secession-ville, were also in our possession. During the operations a rebel steamer attempted to land reinforcements on Morris Island, but she was driven off and destroyed by our gunboats, the troops on board barely escaping. There is a report also that a rebel gunboat, which came down the harbor to reconnoiter, ventured a little too near our craft, a[??]l was "taken in." The news by the Fulton, it will be seen, pretty effectually disposes of the report that Charleston was captured on the 14th.

abstract: Brodsky vs. lhrus; Fraudulent Debt; Right to Order of Arrest
snippet: Brodsky vs. lhrus; Fraudulent Debt; Right to Order of Arrest
lead_paragraph: John Brodsky vs. Anthon Ihrus. -- By the Court: DALY, F.J. -- As the action was upon contract, the defendant could be arrested only for fraud in contracting the debt, or upon the ground that he had removed or disposed of his property, or was about to do so, with intent to defraud his creditors. There is no evidence of any fraud in contracting the debt; but what is r[???]ed upon as warr[???]ing [???]is arrest is a statement on his part that he meant to continue his business in Alexandria, Va., until the close of the war, when he intended to go with his family to Germany to remain there and not to return to the City of New-York; that he sold his entire stock of goods, and all his property in this City and received the proceeds; that it was his intention to go, in a few days after to Alexandria, and that he told the plaintiff that he intended to buy more goods in the City and not to pay for them.

lead_paragraph: Mayor OPDYKE, SIMEON DRAPER, Senator MORGAN and MOSES H. GRINNELL, were in consultation with Gen. CANRY at Police Headquarters, for a long time, yesterday. Of course, nothing has transpired re[???]ve [???] action, but it no doubt related to the perfecting of the millitary and Police arrangements for the protection of the City against any further ravages of the mob. There is a deeply-rooted determination, not only at Headquarters but throughout the entire length and breadth of the City, among officials of all classes, and also among all respectable citizens, to maintain law and order, and to preserve the lives and property of the people at all hazards, and this feeling is hourly deepening and strengthening.

abstract: At Saints Peter and Paul's Church, Brooklyn, E.D., located in Second-street, between North Second and North Third, there was gathered, yesterday morning, a very large congregation, in the expectation that Rev. Father MALONE would address his people in reference to the recent troubles in New-York. In this they were not disappointed. After the usual preliminary and musical exercises, his reverence said that he did not think he should trench on political ground in calling the attention of those present to some truths which were intimately connected with the stirring and disgraceful proceedings during the past week in the Metropolis. He was aware that none of his congregation had been identified with the dark deeds there enacted, and it was a pleasure to him to know that the portion of Brooklyn in which, for over fifteen years, he had been endeavoring to give a tone to public and religious sentiment, had been so orderly and quiet. Still there was no little feeling existing, which rendered it not amiss that he should publicly call attention to the great Catholic truths that underlie all Governments as well as all religions. The Church taught most unmistakably that obedience to the constituted authorities is a Christian duty, in which no good Catholic could fail. St. Paul to the Romans distinctly stated this, and pronounced a damnation upon those proved false to the teachings of such obedience. He did this, too, at a time when the country in which he lived was subject to a tyranny of Pagan oppression. In the present trouble the general and fundamental rule of the Church, which it taught all its members should not be forgotten, or neglected. Every good Catholic would now threw his influence on the side of law and order, showing himself in the hour of trial to be a man of peace, and obedient to the laws of the powers that be. There were cases which might justify revolution and rebellion, but no Irishman should forget the freedom, civil and religious, which he enjoyed in this land of liberty, and to contrast it with the limited privileges of the land of his birth would just at this time produce wholesome results. Now, more than ever, was the time for every Catholic to prove himself a good citizen and frown down the riotous conduct of those too debased to belong to any Church or care for any religious belief.

abstract: --It is not an easy thing to put Europe in your pocket, but the editor of Harper's Handbook not only enables you to accomplish that feat, but also to bag a good portion of the East into the bargain.
lead_paragraph: -- It is not an easy thing to put Europe in your pocket, but the editor of Harper's Handbook not only enables you to accomplish that feat, but also to bag a good portion of the East into the bargain. The second edition of Mr. FETRIDGE's useful traveling companion has just been issued by the HARPERS, and should find its way into the hands of all who contemplate a trip across the Atlantic. The information it contains is necessarily of a brief character, but it will suffice for that large class of tourists who regard rapidity of movement as one of the charms of travel, and who hardly require to know more of a town than the name of a good hotel, and one or two pegs of local tradition whereon to hang an occasional reflection. For such there is no work extant of equal value; but they who visit foreign countries with the intention of studying them thoroughly, will not find their Murray or Badeker superseded. In one respect Mr. FETRIDGE might materially enhance the value of his volume. There is a large class that visits Europe in search of health. The members composing it generally resort to the Springs of Germany, France or England. Most of these are briefly referred to in the Handbook, but there are no particulars given of the peculiar qualities of the water, and hence the invalid is in the dark until he has possessed himself of a local guide containing the information he needs. We would suggest to Mr. FETRIDGE, that in future editions he incorporates the analyses of the principal European waters. They will be alike useful to physicians and patients. The practical hints on traveling are not the least valuable portion of the work, and the routes are generally well chosen and adapted to the usual brief periods devoted to travel by Americans. The Handbook is bound in a convenient form, and is illustrated with a general Map of Europe and a route map of Europe and the East.

abstract: Mr. WARNER, on the 6th, asked the First Lord of the Treasury whether there was any foundation for a statement which had appeared in the newspaper La France, to the effect that England was so far com- ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. WARNER, on the 6th, asked the First Lord of the Treasury whether there was any foundation for a statement which had appeared in the newspaper La France, to the effect that England was so far committed upon the question or Poland that in the event of war arising out of it between France and Russia she could not remain neutral; whether there was any ground, so far as this country was concerned, for a suggestion which had been repeatedly put forward in French newspapers, and particularly in the Constitutionnel, that the negotiations relating to Poland might terminate in war; and whether Her Majesty's Government had laid down as a principle in those negotiations that this country would in no case intervene with armed force in the quarrel between the Emperor of Russia and his Polish subjects.

abstract: Mr. J. GRAU, the well-Known impresario, whose gallant raids into management have been marked by as much tact as talent, and whose last season here and in the West extended without break through eight months, takes his departure for Europe to-morrow in the steamship Great Eastern. It is Mr. GRAU's intention to secure there two or three leading artists for his company. He will then resume operations in the principal cities of the Union, drawing upon his extensive repertoire for those incessant changes of programme that make his management so acceptable everywhere. Mr. GRAU's activity may be gathered from the fact that in Cincinnati he gave twenty-two operas on twenty-four nights, being a change of programme on almost every night. To accomplish this he requires necessarily a double company, and that the new additions may be good, he visits Europe with the intention of hearing them himself before engaging them. It is Mr. GRAU's first visit to the Old World in the character of an operatic manager, but we venture to predict that his reputation as an active, honorable and perfectly responsible man of business has already preceded him. Undertaking management when no one else would do so, it was essential that he should not venture out of his depth. Prudence lent a steady hand to enterprise and success was the result. We hope Mr. GRAU will never be less fortunate.

abstract: Among the atrocities committed by the mob last week was the sacking of a Mission Sabbath School for poor white children, a branch of St. George Episcopal Church, under the superintendance of Mr. VINCENT COLYEN. The school had been in operation for over a year under the change of Rev. Mr. TRIMBLN, and numbered over 100 scholars. Every thing in the room was destroyed.

abstract: The Seventh-Avenue Arsenal, corner of West Thirty-fifth-st., yesterday, presented as animated an appearance as on the previous days. Col. MYERS is in command, and Capt. SAGE acting as Colonel, has command of the Fire Zouaves. There are upwards of 3,100 troops at the Arsenal. Four 12-pounders guard the streets, with one of the new 25-barrel batteries, which would do dreadful execution, if brought into play. Crowds, during yesterday, flocked around the corners of the streets, but all was perfectly quiet.

abstract: The Enforcement of The
snippet: The Enforcement of The
lead_paragraph: There can be no doubt that the late riots in this City have been due in very large degree to the intrigues and machinations of traitors and rebels in the North. Whether their motive has been sympathy with the South or partisan hatred of the Administration, the result is the same: -- they have been stimulating a bloody civil commotion in the North for the purpose of aiding the rebellion in the South, and hostility to the draft has been the main lever which they have employed. A draft for military service must always be obnoxious in any country, although no one can doubt that, properly managed, it is the most equitable mode of securing that service which is absolutely indispensable to every nation. For our Government now to abandon or suspend the draft, in consequence of the violent hostility it has encountered, would be simple abdication of its most essential functions. It would be a surrender of all authority, -- a complete abandonment of the right which every Government has to the services of its citizens. We are glad the Government at Washington does not for a moment entertain the thought of such a step. The laws of the nation must be enforced. The draft must go on, and the official authorities must be supported by adequate military force in carrying it out.

lead_paragraph: At the beginning of this month, all our chief armies were in battle or on the march. The results have been the defeat of LEF, the retreat of BARGG, and the surrender of the two Confederate strongholds on the Mississippi River.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon two or three delegations from the towns situated on the Hudson river, in the County of Westchester, and which are included in the Metropolitan Police District, visited headquarters, and represented to the authorities there in charge that many threats had been made, by persons connected with the mob, to the effect that on Sunday night these towns would be attacked, plunddred and burned. The rumors and sayings of what was to be done by the mob on Sabbath night were truly of an alarming nature.

abstract: Soldiers in the Mississippi Valley. Cor. "Touissaint"; the Negro Regiments in the Mississippi Valley
snippet: Soldiers in the Mississippi Valley. Cor. "Touissaint"; the Negro Regiments in the Mississippi Valley
lead_paragraph: The nation has reason to be grateful for themercy which has saved the life of the Adjutant General of the army. He was stricken down with fever in the midst of his great labors in the Mississippi Valley. The disease took deep hold of a frame exhausted with over-work and care, and brought one of the purest and most devoted patriots in the country -- in many respects one of the ablest, and in all respects the most valuable officer in the Army -quite up to Death's door. There was joy in the War Department over the telegram written in the Soldier's Hospital in Louisville, that the crisis of his disease was passed, and that the veteran was saved to the public service.

abstract: Rev. Mr. FROTHINGHAM preached, yesterday morning, a very admirable discourse on the recent riots in this City.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Mr. FROTHINGHAM preached, yesterday morning, a very admirable discourse on the recent riots in this City. His text was "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do;" and the general drift of the sermon was to apply the same sentiment of charity and of consideration to those who have been concerned in these scenes of tumult which he began by comparing with those in the midst of which the execution of our Saviour took place. After giving a vivid picture of the riots of last week, and the horrible scenes of outrage and persecution which accompanied them, he spoke of the hostility which new measures always encounter from the uninformed masses of the community, and then drew attention to the causes of the recent outbreak. He found them, first, in the Conscription law -- a measure which always conveys to persons of foreign birth and education the tearing of people from their homes to fight the battles of ambition and of tyranny; and second, to the exemption clause, which, however well intended, was calculated to excite the distrust and resentment of the poorer classes, whom it seemed most sharply and severely to touch. He thought we should make great allowances, also, for the ignorance which pervades the community in regard to the character and causes of the war, saying that nothing else could possibly explain the bitter hatred which seems to have been aroused toward the colored race. He deprecated the effect of these excesses upon our reputation abroad, and urged the necessity of sustaining law, order and equity in all our civil and political relations.

abstract: The strategy of
snippet: The strategy of
lead_paragraph: Details of Gen. GILLMORE'S operations against the defences of Charleston, in cooperation with the naval force under Admiral DAHLGREN, to the 15th inst., have reached us by the steamship Fulton, which arrived at this port on Saturday. After the failure of the attack on Fort Wagner, which was caused by the hesitation of the supports of the storming party after the parapet was gained, Gen. GILLMORE commenced engineering approaches, and it was expected that it would soon be captured. All the fortifications on James Island, as far as Secession-ville, were also in our possession. During the operations a rebel steamer attempted to land reinforcements on Morris Island, but she was driven off and destroyed by our gunboats, the troops on board barely escaping. There is a report also that a rebel gunboat, which came down the harbor to reconnoitre, ventured a little too near our cralt, and was "taken in." The news by the Fulton, it will be seen, pretty effectually disposes of the report that Charleston was captured on the 14th. We also have rebel accounts to the 16th, in telegrams to the Richmond papers. Gen. GILLMORE was said to be massing his forces on Morris Island, preparatory to another attack on Fort Wagner, which was expected to be made very soon.

abstract: The disturbances last week interfered seriously with the prosperity of the various places of amusement, and caused so much general alarm that both the Winter Garden and NIBLO's were closed on Wednesday -- the latter remaining closed for the balance of the week. Now that we are once more enjoying a comfortable sense of security, these establishments will reopen their welcome doors, and enjoy the usual flush of country visitors. At NIBLO's the "Duke's Motto" is the all-sufficient attraction; at the Winter Garden a light piece and Mr. FRANK WOOD's uproarious extravaganza of "Leah, the Forsook." There is but one other place of amusement on Broadway -- Barnum's Museum -- but the entertainments will be found endless there.

abstract: -- The appeals which we made on Friday and Saturday last for the negro victims of the brutal mob has induced many responses from charitable quarters. Generous contributions have been offered by benevolent gentlemen, and various societies and churches have also taken the matter up. A preliminary meeting of merchants, to take the subject into consideration, was held on Saturday, and a general meeting of the same class will be held at 2 P.M. this day at MCCULLOUGH's salesroom, corner of Maiden-lane and Front-street, at which resolutions will be offered and subscription lists opened. It is to be hoped that there will be a good attendance; and that something of the munificence which we have already recorded as having been shown toward the suffering members and families of the Police, Fire and Military Departments, will also be displayed to the innocent and unfortunate colored victims of the indiscriminating mob.

abstract: THE ROBBERY OFF BROOKS BROTHERS' CLOTHING STORE. The parties arrested on Thursday, at  Catharine Ferry, with goods in their possession, supposed to be stolen at the sacking of BROOKS BROTHERS' clothing store, were arraigned before Justice PERRY on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: THE ROBBERY OFF BROOKS BROTHERS' CLOTHING STORE. -- The parties arrested on Thursday, at Catharine Ferry, with goods in their possession, supposed to be stolen at the sacking of BROOKS BROTHERS' clothing store, were arraigned before Justice PERRY on Saturday. The names of the accused are RICHARD C. BATTENSHAY, ELIZABETH ARCHER, ANTHONY SMITH (a boy,) and THOMAS SMITH. Articles amounting in value to $30 were found in possession of BATTENSHAY. The goods were identified by the foreman of the establishment, Mr. JACOB N. POST, and the accused was committed to await the action of the Grand Jury on the charge of grand larceny. The woman ARCHER had stolen material for two coats valued at $15. She was sentenced to the Penitentiary for six months. ANTHONY SMITH was discharged on account of his youth, and the goods in THOMAS SMITH's possession being claimed as his own, and not having been identified as stolen property, he also was discharged.

abstract: The City was perfectly quiet yesterday, and everything gave indications of a permanent restoration of law and order.
lead_paragraph: The City was perfectly quiet yesterday, and everything gave indications of a permanent restoration of law and order. Large numbers of people visited the scenes of the late riots, and the events of the past week were almost the sole topic of conversation. It appears to be generally understood that the Government is determined to enforce the draft here, as in other places, and the consequences that are likely to ensue when the drawing recommences formed a large staple of conversation among the people. The number of persons who oppose this determination on the part of the Government is largely decreasing; but those who continue their opposition are more desperate and violent in their language than ever. They are full of threats and warnings as to the havoc which they are going to make with all sublunary things -- which, together with the flood of anonymous letters that they have commenced sending hither and thither, is the best evidence of their weakness, and of the forlorn condition of their cause. Many are under the impression that the draft is to commence again to-day, but we are informed that it will not begin until the exact quota of this City is definitely determined and publicly announced, by which time the Government will be prepared to execute this as well as all other laws of Congress in this City, regardless of anonymous threats or of open violence.

abstract: Militiamen as soldiers
snippet: Militiamen as soldiers
lead_paragraph: We made an attempt in the war of 1812 to defend Washington against capture, by means of State militia, raised and officered precisely as our militia now is, and offered battle with them to regular troops on open ground. The result was the battle of Bladensburgh and the destruction of the Capitol. At New-Orleans we fared better, because we attempted less. JACKSON's troops intrenched themselves and waited for the enemy under cover, and consequently achieved a signal success. But it is not unfair to conclude that had his followers been as ambitious as the Marylanders, and attempted to exclude the British not simply from New-Orleans, but from American soil, they would have in like manner come to grief. If the war had lasted longer, and had been carried on to a greater degree on land, we should doubtless have learnt a lesson which would have served us in good stead in the present conflicts, of the absolute necessity of discipline and organization, of the absolute uselessness of mere bravery in operations carried on against trained soldiers. We should have been saved from the many blunders and disasters which forgetfulness of this great fact has recently brought upon us, and which, we regret to say, it is still likely to bring upon us. Cur march on Bull Run would never have taken place if ANDREW JACKSON had had to conduct a campaign in the open country. His success has caused us ever since to assign to pluck the place which properly belongs to science.

abstract: -- It ought to be, and we presume is, generally understood that Gen. HARVEY BROWN was relieved of the command of the military forces in this City, from no lack of ability or vigor in the discharge of his duties, and from no lack of confidence in him on the part of the Government and the people. No man could possibly have acted with more energy, firmness and decision than he has shown in the suppression of the riot. We presume that Gen. CANBY was assigned to the command here, mainly because he was more fully possessed of the views and sentiments of the Government in regard [???] matters in this department than any officer [???]ess intimately connected with the War Office could be presumed to be. But the thanks of our citizens are eminently due, and will be heartily returned to Gen. BROWN, for his services in this emergency.

HARVEY BROWN was relieved of the command of the military forces in this City, from no lack of ability or vigor in the discharge of his duties, and from no lack of confidence in him on the part of the Government and the people. No man could possibly have acted with more energy, firmness and decision than he has shown in the suppression of the riot. We presume that Gen. CANBY was assigned to the command here, mainly because he was more fully possessed of the views and sentiments of the Government in regard [???] matters in this department than any officer [???]ess intimately connected with the War Office could be presumed to be. But the thanks of our citizens are eminently due, and will be heartily returned to Gen. BROWN, for his services in this emergency.

abstract: Duty of American Citizens to Preserve the Nation
snippet: Duty of American Citizens to Preserve the Nation
lead_paragraph: There is, at least, one delusion which has heretofore been very wide-spread, which this war and its incidents are rudely dispelling -- the notion that this nation, more than any other, is, to use BURKE'S language, "nothing better than a partnership in a trade of pepper and coffee, calico and tobacco, and some such other low concerns, to be taken up for a little temporary interest, and to be dissolved by the fancy of the parties." It is this notion, diligently exploited by traitors and demagogues, which, more than aught else, has been working the havoc which has disgraced this City during the last week. Ever since the war began, the men who are bent on pushing their own fortunes at the cost of everything that is respectable or valuable in our institutions and manners, have devoted themselves to inflaming the laboring classes, and particularly those of foreign birth, against the Government, on the avowed ground that it was carrying on the war, and that the war was productive of loss and suffering, and entailed heavy sacrifice on most classes of the community. They have labored to spread the idea that every man who came to the United States and became a citizen, acquired ipso facto a right to lifelong ease, comfort, and prosperity, and that any action on the part of the Government in defence of honor or existence, which curtailed the smallest of the working-man's comforts, was a fraud and imposition. According to this theory of the National organization, the National Government is a sort of swine-herd, whose sole business is to see that its hogs get their meals and their sleep regularly, and are not troubled by anything that impedes or delays the growth of fat. The cares, anxieties, duties and sacrifices of citizens are all very well for the down-trodden serfs of Europe, but once on American soil, the man rises into the full dignity of a swopping, trading, hoarding animal, and any attempt to make him raise an arm or contribute a cent for the defence of the common honor, or dignity, or even safety, is declared to have no counterpart except in the tyrannical and ferocious caprices of the Czar or the Shah.

abstract: The correspondence relative to the seizure of the schooner Will-o'-the-Wisp by the United States ship Montgomery is published.
lead_paragraph: The correspondence relative to the seizure of the schooner Will-o'-the-Wisp by the United States ship Montgomery is published. The facts of the case as detailed before the United States Prize Court are already known. The Court held that the capture was not warranted, but owing to some suspicious circumstances the Court deemed that the captors should only pay their own expenses. Correspondence ensued upon this, and Earl RUSSELL requested Lord LYONS to state to Mr. SEWARD that Her Majesty's Government were dissatisfied with the decision, and considered that some compensation should be granted to the owers. Mr. SEWARD replied that if the owners were dissatisfied they might carry the case to the Court of Appeals. Earl RUSSELL, therefore, writes to Lord LYONS requesting him to inform Mr. SEWARD that Her Majesty's Government have heard with regret the answer which he has returned on behalf of the United States, and still hopes he will reconsider the matter. "The circumstances of the case," he says, "presents so clear an instance of unmistakable seizure, and the ground alleged by the Judge for not awarding the costs, at least, if not also damages, is so inadequate on the face of it, as to enable Mr. SEWARD upon consulting the law officers of the United States Government, to grant the redress prayed for without subjecting the injured parties to the delay and expense of further judicial proceedings."

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamer City of London, from Liverpool, and the Hansa, from Southampton, we have European advices to the 9th inst., four days later. The English Press were busy in commenting upon the invasion of Pennsylvania by LEE. The London Times sees in it untold disasters for the National cause, and the auguries of the other papers are hardly less unfavorable. A correspondence between Secretary SEWARD and the British Government, relating to the case of the British schooner Will-o'-the-Wisp, seized by the gunboat Montgomery, for having on board contraband of war, while engaged in the Matamoras trade, is published, and a synopsis of it is given in our columns. In the British House of Commons on the 6th, a member asked for an explanation of the conduct of the gunboat Rhode Island in firing into the ship Margaret and Jessie, on the coast of Bermuda. Mr. LAYARD stated that when Mr. SEWARD become acquainted with the facts, he at once wrote to Lord LYONS, assuring him that an inquiry would be made, and, if the facts were as stated, "the transaction should be disavowed, and the most ample reparation made." This explanation was received by the House with loud cheers. Lord PALMERSTON, who appeared for the first time since his illness, in reply to Mr. ROEBUCK, said be would fix the next Monday night for the adjourned debate on the recognition of the Southern States, provided certain business was accomplished in the meantime. Mr. LINDSAY, M.P., has written a letter to the Times, in which he states that he can confirm all that Mr. ROSBUCK has said respecting their joint interview with the Emperor of the French. The Polish question is still in an unsettled condition. In answer to a question as to how far the English Government was committed to a Russian war, in the event of the failure of the present negotiations, Lord PALMERSTON said, the Government had not contracted any engagements, but were at perfect liberty to act according to the course of events. The revolutionists appear to be gaining headway every day, and the Russians are pressed in other quarters than Poland, if we may credit a telegram from Constantinople. According to this information, the Circassians are pushing their invaders closely. They have taken a fortified village, and have lately obtained a decided success. The Financial and Commercial news by these arrivals is not important. Cotton, Breadstuffs and Provisions were mainly unchanged. Consols were quoted at 92 [???]@92 1/2 for money.

abstract: A large meeting of merchants was held yesterday afternoon at McCULLOUGH'S Salesroom, in Front-street, to adopt measures for the relief of the colored sufferers by the late riots. Speeches were made by JONATHAN STURGES, J.D. McKENZIE, RICHARD WARREN, A.F. Dow and others, and resolutions were adopted pledging the protection of the merchants to the colored people in pursuing their customary avocations.
lead_paragraph: A large meeting of merchants was held yesterday afternoon at McCULLOUGH'S Salesroom, in Front-street, to adopt measures for the relief of the colored sufferers by the late riots. Speeches were made by JONATHAN STURGES, J.D. McKENZIE, RICHARD WARREN, A.F. Dow and others, and resolutions were adopted pledging the protection of the merchants to the colored people in pursuing their customary avocations. A Subscription was taken up and $5, 131 85 was contributed on the spot. Further contributions may be sent to JONATHAN STURGES, No. 126 Front-street, who is treasurer of the fund.

abstract: Among the names of those who fell, on the 10th inst., in the assault upon Fort Wagner, on Morris Island, near Charleston, is that of Capt. LEWIS H. LENT, commanding Company A, Forty-eighth New-York Volunteers. Capt. LENT was a resident of this City, and at the opening of the war, was attached to the Seventh Regiment, in which he served as a private during the three months' campaign, making with his comrades the famous thirty miles' march from Annapolis to the railway junction en route to the defence of Washington. When the regiment returned to the City, young LENT was not long in determining to again enter the field, and the organization of the Forty-eighth Regiment in Brooklyn, under the Rev. Mr. PERRY, its first Colonel, (who died at Fort Pulaski, Ga.,) gave him the opportunity that he desired. Although Col. PERRY did not personally know the young man who presented himself with the request for a command, yet he was so favorably impressed with his fine physique and martial air, that he made him Captain of Company A, and to the day of his death he had no occasion to regret this confidence. In the various engagements, in which his regiment has encaged -- at Fort Royal Ferry, Pocotallgo, Bluffton, and in several skirmishes -- Capt. LENT conducted himself in such a way as to merit the commendation of his superior officers. By his company he was idolized, and he died while gallantly leading them. Among his brother officers he was much beloved for his many noble traits of character, and in this City a large social circle will miss his genial intercourse.

abstract: Admiral PAULDING yesterday morning received instructions to dispatch the iron-clad battery Passaic to Charleston with all convenient speed. Accordingly the officers of the vessel were immediately summoned on board, steam was got up, and at 5 o'clock in the afternoon the vessel dropped from her anchorage down the river. She made a trial trip day before yesterday for the purpose of testing the value of a "basket" intended to protect the propeller when moving amid obstructions. The invention failed, and the ship sailed without it. The following is a list of her officers: Commander, EDWARD SIMPSON; Assistant Surgeon, Edgar Holden; Assistant Paymaster, Jesse P. Woodbury; Acting Master, Samuel House; Paymaster's Steward, J. Dunklee; Second Surgeon, O.W. Davis; First Assistant Engineer, N.B, Littig; Second Assistant Engineer, H.W. Robie; Third Assistant Engineers, J.W. Mitchell, W.A. Dripps and J. HOOPER; Acting Ensi ns, L.C. Emmerson and H.R. Baker; Yeoman, W.J. McCoombs.
lead_paragraph: Admiral PAULDING yesterday morning received instructions to dispatch the iron-clad battery Passaic to Charleston with all convenient speed. Accordingly the officers of the vessel were immediately summoned on board, steam was got up, and at 5 o'clock in the afternoon the vessel dropped from her anchorage down the river. She made a trial trip day before yesterday for the purpose of testing the value of a "basket" intended to protect the propeller when moving amid obstructions. The invention failed, and the ship sailed without it. The following is a list of her officers: Commander, EDWARD SIMPSON; Assistant Surgeon, Edgar Holden; Assistant Paymaster, Jesse P. Woodbury; Acting Master, Samuel House; Paymaster's Steward, J. Dunklee; Second Surgeon, O.W. Davis; First Assistant Engineer, N.B, Littig; Second Assistant Engineer, H.W. Robie; Third Assistant Engineers, J.W. Mitchell, W.A. Dripps and J. HOOPER; Acting Ensi ns, L.C. Emmerson and H.R. Baker; Yeoman, W.J. McCoombs.

snippet: Brooklyn; Mayor Ralbfleisch to the Corporation, on Providing Relief from Draft; Message on the Draft
lead_paragraph: There were no indication in any portion of the city yesterday of a return of the spirit of lawlessness. The Districts to recently and seriously in??? were free from anything like an excitement, and ??? the indications are that law and order have reamed a away not again to be interrupted, Those who have participated in the riots have realized the horror of a struggle with the authorities, and seen the latter tally of the conflict. They are bringing good common sense bear upon the distasteful question of the draft, and while their opposition to it is as dec???dedes ever, and their denunciation bitter, threats of another resort to violence are but seldom heard, and when heard are not from those whose connection with the mob was from sympathy with. He prejudices, but because of the opportunity it afforded them for murder and plunder. Apprehensions, however, are entertained by many that on a renewal of the draft the frenzy will be renewed; but the excellent precautions taken, the wise counsels and better feeling pre???aiting, lead us to believe otherwise, and to anticipate, if any demonstration should unhappily be made, that it can assume no formidable dimensions.

abstract: From Capt, DAVIS, of the One Hundred and Forty-first Pennsylvania Volunteers, who arrived in this city yesterday from Gettysburgh, we learn that it is not true, as reported, that the rebel Gen. KEMPER was killed at the battle of Gettysburgh. He is now lying at Brean's Mill, three miles from Gettysburgh, having been shot through the breast, the ball lodging in his back. He was is command of a portion of the force comprising the forlorn hope of the rebels, and was wounded in the last desperate charge made by the latter to retrieve their lost ground.

abstract: Law The and Its Expounders
snippet: Law The and Its Expounders
lead_paragraph: There are many cogent reasons why the Conscription Act should be construed liberally. There is much that is penal in its character and incidents. It plunges a large portion of the community into anxiety and uncertainty before the names are drawn, and after they are drawn it unavoidably inflicts a large amount of hardship upon thousands of worthy men; and what is, if possible, of more importance than these things, is that, owing to the magnitude of the struggle which has called for it, it is, in the eyes of a large portion of the population a novel and it may be a vexatious law. The old militia laws, which it has superseded, were certainly tenfold more vexatious, and would, if carried out, have inflicted tenfold greater hardships. But then they never were enforced, because we have never before been engaged in a great war; and demagogues are consequently able to persuade those who never read them, and know nothing of their provisions, that the present act is an innovation, copied from the despotic models of Europe.

abstract: how to deal with them
snippet: how to deal with them
lead_paragraph: The men, the very men, and only the been who, through two long years of agony, have been endeavoring to palliate the crimes of the rebels, are now doing all that they can to palliate the crimes of the rioters who passed the greater part of last week in endeavors to make New-York as infamous as Delhi or Cawnpore. During Monday and Tuesday they said all that could be said both to inflame the passions of the Thugs who were desecrating our streets by murder and pillage, and to excuse their ferocity, and as soon as the tumult was quelled by the strong hand of the law, they set to work both to predict its renewal and to preach forbearance and gentleness to the Police. It will not do any longer to tell people who have passed four nights in their houses with the hideous uproar of street massacres ringing in their ears, and the flames of their neighbors' houses reddening the sky above their heads, that this havoc was wrought either by the people," or the laboring population," or by outraged conscripts." They know well that if these atrocious libels were true, it would be the duty of those who have enough manhood and religion left them to make them refuse to belong to a community of thieves and assassins, either to take their muskets and bring about a reform, or else quit the country. If either the people" or the laboring population of New-York were fairly represented by the bands of brigands who cut throats and fired houses for four days, it would be an insult to every decent man in the City and the State to suppose that he would live in the same place with such a people, or with such laborers one minute, after he had found it impossible to get them hanged or banished. These wretched apologists of assassination and, arson evidently came to the conclusion that the troubles of the times had deprived the American people of their moral sense, and that there are men and women amongst us so besotted by party feeling as to have lost their horror of murder and cruelty, and their respect for property, whenever opponents of the Administration choose to sally out and kill, mutilate and rob.
headline: {'main': 'How to Deal with Mobs.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How to Deal with Mobs.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: OUR CAVALRY. -- An admirable and connected resume of the recent extraordinary exploits of Gen. MEADE's cavalry force will be found in the TIMES of this morning. Without perusing it, no one can have any idea of the brilliant service recently rendered by this arm. It was written in the field, "surrounded with all the paraphernalia of actual war, a deadly contest still raging within hearing," by a gentleman who accompanied the cavalry in all its gallopades, who was a witness, if not a participator, in all the battles, and who was wounded while in the discharge of his duty to us and the country. He begins his narrative by coolly saying: "I have to record fifteen more engagements of our cavalry with the enemy, all within sixteen days."

abstract: Philadelphia Papers on New-York Riots
snippet: Philadelphia Papers on New-York Riots
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Press, and the Press all over the country, have administered a terrible castigation to New-York for the scenes exhibited in its streets last week. We will not say that a good deal of it is not deserved, though we wish they had drawn a clearer line between the rioters and the great mass of citizens in the Empire City. New-York is a very large town. By last census it had a population of over eight hundred thousand souls; and though the rioters had free sweep for several days, they never numbered more than two or three thousand. If the city were such a seething mass of corruption, lawlessness and villany as is represented, we should have seen a state of things that could not have been repressed by a few hundred policemen and soldiers. The fact is that the high character of New-York never appeared to better advantage than during the late riots. The mob took the City by surprise, and was carrying on its ravages before people generally were aware of its existence; but no sooner did the citizens see and comprehend the real upshot of the riot than they hastened, almost en masse, not merely to express their disapproval, but to enrol and arm themselves to repress disorder and sustain the laws.

abstract: We have seen a document to which are appended the signatures of many of our best known lawyers, which tendered on behalf of the signers legal assistance to the colored people who were despoiled of their goods or property during the recent riot. The City and county are liable for the damage done these poor people, and it is the benevolent intention of the legal gentlemen named, to prosecute the claims of any colored person who may desire it, and to follow up the matter without delay, and what is equally to the purpose, without charge. The offer is a great charity and speaks volumes in behalf of the sense of honor and of justice possessed by the Bar of our City.

abstract: This body assembled, pursuant to the call of the Committee of the Fremont Legion, on Thursday, the 16th inst., in Poughkeepsie, and organized by electing Rev. Dr. PENNINGTON as Chairman, NIMROD THOMPSON, of Buffalo, Vice Chairman, and Dr. P.B. RANDOLPH, of Utica, Secretary. A manifesto and call to the colored population, defining their position, and setting forth their hopes, was drawn up, together with a series of patriotic resolutions by the Secretary, and unanimously passed and adopted by the Convention.

abstract: A meeting of the Board of Commissioners of Health was held yesterday, at which the Health Officer reported yellow fever existing in a most malignant form en vessels now arriving from Havana. To avoid the great danger which will arise from any such vessel or cargo coming up to the City, the Board adopted a resolution that no infected ship or cargo shall be permitted to pass the Quarantine Station. This is an effective and timely measure, and will remove all apprehensions of contagion.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the Board of Commissioners of Health was held yesterday, at which the Health Officer reported yellow fever existing in a most malignant form en vessels now arriving from Havana. abstract: RETURNED REGIMENTS. -- The Forty-seventh regiment, which returned to Brooklyn (E.D.) on Sunday evening, is still under orders for any special service to which, in the anticipated exigencies of the case, they may be assigned. While absent they were for the most part engaged on picket duty near Fairfax Seminary, in Virginia. The Brooklyn (E.D.) companies of the Twenty-eighth regiment returned late on Sunday, and were escorted to their homes in the Sixteenth Ward by a detachment of the Home Guard. One of their company, a man named JACOB WEHN, died of exhaustion on the 12th of July; that was the only casualty which the regiment experienced.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Africa at Halifax, we have advices from Europe three days later. She left Liverpool on the 11th and Queentown on the 12th inst. The English Press were still engaged in discussing the rebel invasion of the loyal States, and the probability of LEE's success -- generally taken for granted. The Morning Post says that Mr. LINDSAY was expected on the 13th to favor the House of Commons with a detailed account of his second interview with the Emperor NAPOLEON. Lord PALMERSTON had requested Mr. ROEBUCK to drop the further discussion of the question of recognition, as it was not desirable to resume it or to bind the Government to pledge themselves as to future action. Mr. ROEBUCK postponed his answer until the 13th. It is denied in Paris that Mr. DAYTON said the United States would consider the recognition of the rebels a casus belti. M. DROUYN DE. LHUYS had asked Mr. DAYTON whether a first offer of mediation would be well received at Washington, and Mr. DAYTON had given a negative answer. Encounters between the Poles and Russians continue to be daily reported -- the latter being generally defeated. There is no change to note in Cotton. Breadstuff's or Provisions. Consols were quoted at 92 1/8 @ 92 3/4 for Money.

abstract: MORGAN's RAID. -- It would seem that MORGAN and his men have come to grief. Their grand raid through Indiana and Ohio had resulted in nothing but their own capture and dispersion. MORGAN had some forty-five hundred men with him when he crossed the Ohio twenty days ago; and we judge from the various telegrams that have reached us, particularly those of this morning, that about half of his force has been killed and captured. The most important man in the whole expedition, the man who even more than MORGAN was its leader, Col. BASIL DUKE, is a prisoner in our hands. BASIL DUKE is a well-known Kentuckian, an old citizen of Covington, and it was his great ability, his skill and audacity, and his thorough acquaintance with the region of country on both sides of the Ohio, that gave to the marauders such impunity and success as they have enjoyed. Now that he is a prisoner, MORGAN will find it difficult to navigate, and we expect to see the remainder of his force completely dispersed. Several attempts have been made by them to cross the Ohio at different points, but they have all failed.
lead_paragraph: MORGAN's RAID. -- It would seem that MORGAN and his men have come to grief. Their grand raid through Indiana and Ohio had resulted in nothing but their own capture and dispersion. MORGAN had some forty-five hundred men with him when he crossed the Ohio twenty days ago; and we judge from the various telegrams that have reached us, particularly those of this morning, that about half of his force has been killed and captured. The most important man in the whole expedition, the man who even more than MORGAN was its leader, Col. BASIL DUKE, is a prisoner in our hands. BASIL DUKE is a well-known Kentuckian, an old citizen of Covington, and it was his great ability, his skill and audacity, and his thorough acquaintance with the region of country on both sides of the Ohio, that gave to the marauders such impunity and success as they have enjoyed. Now that he is a prisoner, MORGAN will find it difficult to navigate, and we expect to see the remainder of his force completely dispersed. Several attempts have been made by them to cross the Ohio at different points, but they have all failed.

abstract: Gen. GRANT has already another large job on hand, and, as a matter of course, he will accomplish it, either at the first effort, or the second, or the third, or, at all events, before he gives it up. He has determined to capture JOHNSTON's entire army. A body of his troops under Gen. SHERMAN has chased them up to Jackson, and has been fighting them there for some time; and the latest rebel telegrams reveal some ominous facts for them. One from Jackson, of the 16th, announces the continued arrival of heavy reinforcements for GRANT, "who are massed on our (rebel) right, for the purpose of crossing Pearl River above and flanking us." A subsequent rebel dispatch gives the opinion that GRANT is "trying to flank us on the right." From all of which, we think JOHNSTON had better look out for his right flank, not to speak of his left flank, his front and his rear. GRANT is equally at home in moving upon the enemy's works from every side and angle, and JOHNSTON did a very foolish thing not to ???ie away to the Tombigbee as soon as he heard that GRANT was after him. When GRANT captures JOHNSTON and his force, he will sigh for another rebel army to conquer.
lead_paragraph: Gen. abstract: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Buffalo has issued a most earnest and beautiful address to his flock concerning rioting, which is transferred to our columns, and which will be found well worthy of perusal by every rioter and by every loyal citizen. He urges them by every motive to abstain from violence, to uphold the laws, and to submit to the draft. He refers to the New-York rioters, some of whom have fallen, others have been ruined, and all of whom, if they do not sincerely repent of their riotous conduct, will, he says, "be lost forever." He says that those who are drafted will be aided and protected, and closes with some most excellent Scriptural exhortations. Pastoral letters such as this must be admired and commended by people of all denominations and parties, and must have an excellent effect on the misguided men to whom they are addressed.

abstract: The Little Rock True Democrat, of June 17, says: "From the west, we learn that 5,000 Federals arrived at Cassville on the evening of the 6th, with their artillery, to reinforce Phillips. STAND WATIR is above Maysville, going to the neutral land, where there are about 500 negroes camped. Col. MONROE has crossed back to this side of the river."

abstract: An East Tennesseean of good family, a man of intelligence and superior information, who escaped from BRAGG'S army on its late retreat, and who is ...
lead_paragraph: An East Tennesseean of good family, a man of intelligence and superior information, who escaped from BRAGG'S army on its late retreat, and who is vouched for by the best authority in Nashville as a man of integrity, gives interesting information to the Nashville Union. He was conscripted some thirteen months ago, put in a Mississippi regiment, and carried off to Mobile, which is strongty fortified, being girdled with intrenchments for fifteen miles, a battery being placed every 350 yards. The embankment is four feet high and the ditch eight feet wide. The garrison was quite small, not over 2,000. He came from Mobile to Tullahoma about the 1st of May. BRAGG had about 45,000 troops at Stones River, and about two months ago had his force increased to 60,000 troops. They are generally armed well, with Enfield rifles and Mipie muskets. They are for the most part wretchedly clad, some being bareheaded, and many without shoes, or nearly so. There is no clothing in the Quartermaster's Department. The cavalry horses, especially WHEELER's, are wearing out very fast. This arm of their service is weakening rapidly. They have, very few tents, and all these were abandoned in their retreat from Tullahoma. BRAGG being fully satisfied that ROSECRANS had reinforced GRANT largely, was on the point of attacking him in his fortifications just previous to ROSEORAN's advance. About three weeks ago, one-half of HARDEE's corps was sent to reinforce JOHNSTON, after changing their battle-flag.

abstract: A dispatch from Hagerstown, 21st, published in Philadelphia yesterday, gives a report that the whole rebel army under LEE has been checked at Bunker Hill, and that Gens. EWELL and HOOD are in strong force between Martinsville and Hedgesville, the former thirteen, and the latter.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Hagerstown, 21st, published in Philadelphia yesterday, gives a report that the whole rebel army under LEE has been checked at Bunker Hill, and that Gens. EWELL and HOOD are in strong force between Martinsville and Hedgesville, the former thirteen, and the latter six miles from Williamsport -- the rebel pickets forming a front from Hedgesville to the Shenandoah River, eight miles from Harper's Ferry.

abstract: -- The City experienced an unusually severe gale early yesterday afternoon, which played havoc with signs, awnings, &c. In the harbor it was felt to a greater extent, many vessels dragging their anchors, but none going ashore except the U.S. steamer Honduras. She came side on to the Battery Enlargement, and was pulled off by four steam-tugs. Prof. HALL's baths suffered some from the action of the sea. One of them sunk and partly went to pieces. The bridge leading from the Battery to them was carried away. Some slight collisions also occurred in the North River, but nothing of consequence.

abstract: London Press on the War
snippet: London Press on the War
lead_paragraph: The London papers, at our last advices, were in a delightful frame of mind. They looked upon the triumph of the Southern Confederacy as a fixed fact, and were preparing to celebrate it with all the exultation becoming a neutral and a Christian nation. LEE's invasion of Pennsylvania struck them as the climax and consummation of military generalship, and of his complete and speedy success they did not permit themselves for a moment to doubt. The Times expected to ???ear "within a week" that JEFFERSON DAVIS was in Washington; the downfall of that Capital was regarded as a foregone conclusion. The Army and Navy Gazette, edited by an old friend, Dr. RUSSELL, pronounced LEE's attempt to be one of the most audacious military movements of modern times, and, while confidently anticipating its success, was candid enough to admit that failure would be "ruin" to the Confederate cause. At the same time, it began to speculate on the contingency of being addressed from Washington by "another Government," and on the difficulty -- not to say the impossibility -- of refusing to acknowledge it. Even the Daily News, which has kept its faith in the Union cause more steadfastly than any other London journal, began to fear that the "Confederate successes in the very neighborhood of Washington" would compel a speedy termination of the war; and the Times announced, with its usual air of confidence, that gold, which was then selling at about 150, "must again advance."

abstract: Riots; Compromises with Rioters and Rebels
snippet: Riots; Compromises with Rioters and Rebels
lead_paragraph: One of the marked features of our "state of insurrection," last week, was the quick development of the counter policies of conciliation and coercion. From the very first day one portion of the community was for appeasing the wrath of the mob by urgent entreaties and by large concessions to its demands; the other scouted all parleying, and all use of any other means than the policeman's club and the soldier's bayonet. Gov. SEYMOUR, as the leader of the first class, took early occasion to "implore" the crowd to refrain from all further destruction; and he assured it that he "had sent his Adjutant-General to Washington to ask the Government to stop the draft in this City for the present." On the other hand, Maj.-Gen. WOOL, at the first stage of the riot, representing the feelings of all who wished to see law vindicated, issued a call for soldiers "to stay the ravages of the City by men who have lost all sense of obligations to their country;" and Mayor OPDYKE in the same spirit made a call upon "all loyal citizens" to enroll themselves "as special policemen for the restoration of law and order."

abstract: ARREST OF SUSPICIOUS CHARACTERS--ONE OF THEN AN ESCAPED CONVICT.--
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF SUSPICIOUS CHARACTERS -- ONE OF THEN AN ESCAPED CONVICT. -- Detective ELDER took into custody two well-known burglars whom be round under suspicious circumstances in a doorway on the corner of Sixth-avenue and Ninth-street. One of them was subsequently Identified as an escaped convict from Sing Sing, named RORY SIMMS. He was serving out a long sentence there; but a few weeks since he advoitly managed to get outside the walls of the prison, and fled to this City. STMMS and his accomplice made a desperate resistance when they were captured by the officer, but, with the aid of a Fifteenth Ward Policeman, they were finally over powered. Each officer then took charge of his man, and marched them toward the Station-house. When nearly there the Ward officer's man broke away from him, and when recaptured, after a short chase, he fought with great desperation, making several attempts to stab the officer in the heart. He was finally overcome by means of the club and secured. Upon being searched, a Colt's revolver and a quantity of burglars' instruments were found upon each of the prisoners. A dispatch to the Warden of the prison has been sent from Police Headquarters, and no doubt SIMMB with this morning leave for his home on the Hudson. But for the timely interference of Officer ELDER a burglary would doubtless have been committed at the house where they were arrested.

abstract: In this crisis of the Southern Confederacy, JEFF. DAVIS has done the best, the worst and the last thing that he can do. He has ordered.
lead_paragraph: In this crisis of the Southern Confederacy, JEFF. DAVIS has done the best, the worst and the last thing that he can do. He has ordered to the field every man in the Southern Confederacy capable of bearing arms, between the ages of 18 and 45 years, This action he took on Wednesday of last week -- the day on which the riot against a moderate, just and equitable draft, embracing only young men, had reached its climax in this City. Nothing daunts him and his coconspirators in their purpose. Riots they have had in the South against the successive and atrocious conscriptions that have already swept into the field and to the grave the greater part of the able-bodied white men of every class; but none of them have affected their purpose, but rather made them more determined in their work of ruin. Inflexible and reckless, DAVIS issues his peremptory proclamation taking counsel only of the necessities of his situation.

abstract: The wife of Senator POMEROY died, a day or two since, on board the America, just before reaching Albany. She was on her way to Geneva, the home of her family, from Washington, where she had completely exhausted her strength in building up an Asylum for Colored Orphans. She was a woman of rare excellencies of character, and had devoted her-self with the utmost self-denial to doing good to others. The Surgeon-General indicated his estimate of her services by giving her a special steamer ???t bring her North for the restoration of her health.

abstract: The unnaturalized residents of Charleston, who refuse to fight for the rebels, are dealt with rather summarily, and their "foreign protection papers" are treated rather cavalierly, if we may believe the papers of that city. A number of workmen in Charleston refused lately to join a military company, and exhibited in self-defence their foreign protection papers; but a rebel military commandant quickly sent them and their papers to an enrolling officer, who, says the Charleston Courier, "as quickly forwarded them to Morris Island, where ditching is going on, and foreign papers are not respected." Those madmen in this City who oppose the execution of a law because they pretend to think a single clause of it unjust, would find, if the rebellion, which they are aiding, were to succeed, that none of their rights, nor law nor justice either, would be respected if they stood in the way of JEFF-DAVIS.
lead_paragraph: The unnaturalized residents of Charleston, who refuse to fight for the rebels, are dealt with rather summarily, and their "foreign protection papers" are treated rather cavalierly, if we may believe the papers of that city. abstract: The European news telegraphed from Halifax conveys information of the death of WILLIAM MULREADY, the celebrated painter. Mr. MULREADY was born at Ennis, in Ireland, in 1786, and very early gave evidence of his talent as an artist. When fourteen years of age he was admitted a student of the Royal Academy, and some of his first pieces were of greater pretension than those with which his name is now generally associated. Pictures of this ambitious sort, however, soon gave place to others of more modest size and merit, and still more modest subject. Although most of these studies -- productions of a youth of twenty -- were comparatively unnoticed at the time of their original exhibition, when again placed before the public, thirty years later, they excited general admiration. In 1815 one of his pieces, "Idle Boys," secured his election as Associate of the Royal Academy, and in the following year as R.A. -- a rapidity of promotion very unusual. His pictures are remarkable for humor and graphic telling of the story, and in subject are mainly of the "domestic" class. As a painter he was perfect in his art -- distinguished for huminous splendor of color, for delicacy and completion of drawing, and for what artists term breadth of manner, showing that it was choice, not necessity, that confined him to small canvasses. In 1840 he illustrated the Vicar of Wakefield with twenty designs, and from this source have since been derived many of his finest pictures -- "The Whistonian Controversy." "Choosing the Wedding Gown," "Burchell and Sophia," &c. From his perfect command, of the language of his art, MULREADY's careful sketches for his pictures, whether in outline or in color, will always have a rare value. His Academy studies from "life" are also unique for truth, power of drawing and fine coloring, although only executed in red and black chalk. In 1848 an exhibition of his works was formed at the Society of Arts, which was highly appreciated by the lovers of art, and since that date he has given nothing of importance to the public.

In 1840 he illustrated the Vicar of Wakefield with twenty designs, and from this source have since been derived many of his finest pictures -- "The Whistonian Controversy." "Choosing the Wedding Gown," "Burchell and Sophia," &c. From his perfect command, of the language of his art, MULREADY's careful sketches for his pictures, whether in outline or in color, will always have a rare value. His Academy studies from "life" are also unique for truth, power of drawing and fine coloring, although only executed in red and black chalk. In 1848 an exhibition of his works was formed at the Society of Arts, which was highly appreciated by the lovers of art, and since that date he has given nothing of importance to the public.

abstract: THE DRAFT--HALF A MILLION DOLLARS TO BE APPROPRIATED TO PURCHASE EXEMPTION FROM THE CONSCRIPTION.--
lead_paragraph: THE DRAFT -- HALF A MILLION DOLLARS TO BE APPROPRIATED TO PURCHASE EXEMPTION FROM THE CONSCRIPTION. -- The Common Council Committee, appointed on Monday night, to consider the Mayor's communication, in which he recommends an appropriation by the city for the purpose of mitigating the severity of the Conscription act, met with the Board of Contracts, yesterday morning, to decide upon the amount to be raised. The Mayor opened the business by asking if his proposition had met the approval of the Committee, to which Alderman TE???NAN answerd in the affirmative. A discussion as to the power of the Common Council took place, and the Mayor gave it as his opinion that the money could be legally raised. He said that $30,000 only of a fund appropriated for encouraging enlistments, out of $150,000 voted, bad been expended, and recommended that the sum remaining be used for the purpose contemplated in his message.

abstract: Now that quiet is once more restored to our City, the main questions which agitate the minds of the people are--What is to be done next? How ...
lead_paragraph: Now that quiet is once more restored to our City, the main questions which agitate the minds of the people are--What is to be done next? How about the draft? What is the Government going to do? What is Gov. SEYMOUR going to do? &c, &c The rioters and their sym pathizers, including all the Secessionists and Copper heads who do not wish the Government to get any more-soldiers on any terms, Whether by drafting or volunteering, are flattering themselves that they have gained complete victory; that the doings of the during the past-week have struck terror to the hearts of the officials-here and at Washington, and that the Government dare not (that is the word) renew the draft in this City. On the other hand, those who are in favor of the draft (and this class has largely increased within a week) are no less positive that the Government dare enforce the draft, that it can enforce the draft, and that it will must and shall enforce the draft, whether it wants soldiers or not. This is the talk that one hears about the streets, as littered toy the two extremes of popular sentiment. Then there is e large class of citizens more moderate in their views, conservative and law-abiding citizens, who are in favor of the enforcement of all laws that are deemed necessary, bat who thinks that the easiest way is the best way, and would like to see some kind of compromise effected which would avoid the contingency of further collision between the Government and the disaffected. This class are even more anxious that the other two to know what action the Government designs to take in the matter of the draft, and what position the Governor lakes upon the subject. Our reporter spent a large part of the day yesterday, in trying to obtain some satisfactory answer to these inquiries, but he is obliged to confess that his labors proved, fort lie most part, a failure. The position of Gov. SEYMOUR, so far as it could be ascertained from a brief interview with him at the St. Nicholas Hotel, is this: He and his friends, as well as a large number of inferential supporters of the Administration, are of opinions, that injustice has been done to this State in the master of the quota which she is called upon to furnish under the draft. They claim that New-York has furnished more than her quota under the calls for volunteers, and that this excess should be deducted front the quota to de raised by draft. They also claim theist the services of the State Militia, which has been several limes called out for it short term, should be allowed, and the aggregate time of such service deducted from the draft quota. Pending the settlement of these claims Gov. SEYMOUR is urging upon the Government to postpone the draft, and he also urges that if not inconsistent with the public safety, it should be postponed until a case can be brought before tie highest Court, and the constitutionality of the draft law be tested.

abstract: We should think that after the late experiences of the rebels, they would cease talking in heroic style about fighting to the last ditch, and all that sort of thing. Vicksburgh was an excellent place for a last ditch. It was, in fact, the last rebel ditch on the Mississippi River. Beginning at Belmont, GRANT had fought their troops and chased them from one point to another for over a thousand miles; and here at last they were in a corner, with no chance whatever of escape except by the practice of the heroics which they had so long been singing. But even here they hung out a white flag on their last ditch, and surrendered unconditionally.

abstract: The Committee of Merchants for the relict of the colored sufferers by the late liots, met yesterday and determined to open at once a central office, where applicants for relief can be supplied, and legal help and medical advice obtained. They will keen a careful registration of the names of ail sufferers and the amount of their leses. A list of those out of employment of there and of citizen aedings servants. A depot where clothing, &c, can be left and be distributed. They hope to able to announce the location tomorrow. in the meanwhile, the Committee find the suffering more widespread than they had at fust supposed, and a large amount of money will be required. Contribution in cash may be sent to the Treasuier, JONATHAN STURGIS. Esq., No. 125 Front-street, New-York.

abstract: Everything passed off on Saturday as though each citizen had made a solemn promise to be a model of propriety. The drafting was conducted in the fairest manner, as all who looked on will testify.
lead_paragraph: Everything passed off on Saturday as though each citizen had made a solemn promise to be a model of propriety. The drafting was conducted in the fairest manner, as all who looked on will testify. It is remarkable how few Irishmen happened to be drawn; their names were all in the wheel the same as others. Our authorities, in conjunction with the officers of the U.S. Government, had made the most thorough preparation to have the peace and good order of the town maintained, and during the whole day and late into the night, we did not see a single intoxicated person. The Courier Office is quite fortunate -- six of its force, editorial and mechanical having the high honor awarded to them of serving their country without the animadversions which follow office-seeking. The Post-office, too, is well represented -- not less than seven gentlemen connected with the mail service having been drawn, to wit: three clerks, two letter carriers and two route agents. The Palladium is also greatly favored, and the Register sends one representative, just to keep its memory green in the minds of the loyal. The Board of Enrollment were assisted by citizens selected by the residents of the different wards, who cheerfully volunteered to further the drawing of their own names. Hon. JAMES E. ENGLISH was there; also, HIS Honor Mayor TYLER, the whole Board of Enrollment, with a number of clerks and markers, and a large proportion of the policemen of the city. Sergt. HERMANCE, of the Knight Hospital, had eighty of the Invalid corps present, every man of whom had an honorable scar to show, and they leaned over the falling of the skylight opening on the floor below, while the drawing went on. WILLIE SERGENT, the brave young fellow who lost both arms at the battle of Fair Oaks was with this company, and everybody was glad to see him looking so well. Col. WRIGHT explained that the runaways counted if drawn, and that their cowardice did not increase the liability of those who staid to obey the law, and further said, that no matter how many might pay the $300, each payment would count "one," and would not make the chances any more disadvantageous to the others than if they were to go to the war.

abstract: As has been previously announced the military post at the Seventh-avenue Arsenal was turned over to Col. BERRIAN, of the Eighth Regiment N.G.N.G., by Gen. SANDPORD Monday. Last evening a number of the General's friends, including his own personal staff assembled at the Arsenal for the purpose of testifying to him, in a brief address, their appreciation of his high military abilities. abstract: The Southern rebels are altogether too exultant over the riot in this City. When they find out how short-lived it was -- how quickly it was put down -- how rapidly the Empire City rallied to the support of law and loyalty -- they will be less jubilant. They send their compliments to their Northern "brethren," and urge them to burn and gut more houses, and kill and mutilate more men; and JEFF. DAVIS' organ desires this "excellent outbreak" to go on until the North is a "desert of blood-soaked ashes." This last is what LEE set out to accomplish, but failed in most gloriously; and they can only now hope that the left wing of his army may achieve a greater success. They are doomed to another disappointment.
lead_paragraph: The Southern rebels are altogether too exultant over the riot in this City. abstract: We think we can heartily congratulate, our city-Bens upon an entire and permanent restoration of order. What little excitement existed on Monday has wholly disappeared, and a pretty thorough tour of the City furnishes not an indication, however slight, of a disposition to again in d???y the laws, and to again endure a terrible restriction. It seems to be conceded by the disaffected, that another outbreak would be followed by immediate and fearful punishment, and that prudence Should control their prejudices a reason check their passions. They have the evidences that the authorities are now ready, at a moment's warning to-meet any emergency, and they have the experience -- which it were well to lay to heart -- that in dealing with rioters gloves will be, as they have been, laid side. Military forces, intelligently distributed, are ready to meet immediately any disturbances in their respective vicinities, and reserve sufficient to quell any demon-stration, however formidable, and wherever and wherever made, is hold in constraint readiness, Beyond this, we have our Police, a body of men who have covered themselves with honey by their noble and heroic conduct, and have was the confidence and admiration of the entire Community. Still more, we have organization of Citizen, 'Police -- specials -- in the several precincts, men who value life, property and peace, and who pledge. themselves to aid in seeing that each are protracted and preserved. Verily, should the lawless enter upon a repetition of the work of last week, the consequences to them would be swift and terrible.

abstract: The Pittsburgh Catholic says: "Several of our clergy have been lucky or unlucky enough to have been drawn in the draft. At the Cathedral the three assistants, Revs. J. Hicky, James Holland and Walter Burke; at St. Philomena's, Rev. F. Swickart, C. SS. R.; at the Seminary, Revs. F. Tobin and E. Bush; at St. Mary's, Lawrenceville. Rev. A. Gibbs, Pastor; at St. Michael's, Birmingham, Rev. Father Vincent, Pastor; at Holy Trinity, Pittsburgh, Rev. J.M. Bierl, Pastor; at St. James. Temperanceville, Rev. M. Carroll, Pastor; at St. Peter's, Allegheny, Rev. T. O'Farrel, have been 'drafted into the military service of the United States.' In all cases in which the reverend gentlemen were not exempt by law, the congregations to which they were attached promptly contributed the amount necessary to relieve them from the service, from entering on which they were forbidden by the laws of the Church."
