abstract: On the 20th, at 9:30 P.M., in nine fathoms water, Barnegat bearing north by west, she struck on a sunken wreck, and after having been got off, found she was leaking badly, and was run in for the beach to save her and the lives of the crew. Before reaching the beach she struck on the outer bar, near Little Egg Harbor, and filled. The crew launched one yawl, which swamped, and in the other they hailed a schooner, loaded with ???ay, bound south, who refused to pick them up. They were afterward picked up by the schooner --, from Alexandria, and brought to this port. The Romer was built in 1841, in New-York, by JOHN and JA???ES FRIEND; was valued at $4,000, and was owned by JAMES J. WILKIE, JAMES CONNER, ROBERT W. JOHNSON and GEORGE H. SISCO. It was the Romer that was once chartered by the Press, and went to Europe for them.

abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29. -- The ship Free Trade, from New-York, has half discharged: her cargo is coming out very much damaged. She experienced the same gale that caused so much damage onboard of the Midnight, from Boston. Both of these ships had their booby hatches washed away, and let large quantities of water below.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29. -- The ship Free Trade, from New-York, has half discharged: her cargo is coming out very much damaged. abstract: Empress, bark vs. United States
snippet: Empress, bark vs. United States
lead_paragraph: The Bark Empress and her Corgo vs. The United States. -- NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel and cargo were captured on the morning of the 28th November, 1861, by the sloop-of-war Vincinnes, at the mouth of the Mississippi, off the Southeast Pass, some three miles from the Balize. The vessel was under a charter party entered into by the master at Rio Janeiro, 5th September, 1861, to ship a cargo of coffee to New-Orleans or Mobile, as may be ordered by the charterers, and if the vessel, on arrival, be warned off by a blockading squadron, to proceed either to New-York, Baltimore or Philadelphia, which second place is likewise to be named by the charterers previous to the departure of the vessel from Rio de Janeiro. "If warned off New-Orleans or Mobile, the master to deliver at the port of discharge the order from the officer warning him off," &c.

abstract: The, R???eling; Stand to your Guns
snippet: The, R???eling; Stand to your Guns
lead_paragraph: The Confederacy is reeling. Desperation is fast seizing all classes of its adherents. The rebel sends out as agonizing cry for more men. The Copperhead beats about like mad to stir up civil war in the North; The foreign sympathizer strains every nerve to bring in foreign intervention. All feel it to be the supreme hour. The time for their forlorn hope has come. The last rally and the extreme stratagem are now to be essayed. More than ever it is now the duty of all loyal men to be firm and vigilant. Let them see to it that they are not carried one inch from their old ground. Let them look to it that the old flag is not lowered one hair's breadth from its proudest pitch. Let the only order of the day be to load heavier, and fire quicker; and let there be no other order until the last stone of the accursed fabric is tumbled into the dust.
headline: {'main': 'Stand to Your Guns.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Stand to Your Guns.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Staten Island; Investigation
snippet: Staten Island; Investigation
lead_paragraph: Sergt. VAUGHAN, of the Twenty-first Precinet, with a squad of men, made another search yesterday for goods stolen during the riot. They searched, upward of one hundred houses in the neighborhood of Twenty-eighth-street and Second-avenue, especially those in "Cat-alley," and recovered a large amount of furniture, groceries, clothing, firearms, etc., in all to the value of $600. The plunder made six large cart-loads, and was taken to the Station-house. Most of the property had been stolen from the colored people in the neighborhood.

abstract: Gen. ALBERT G. JENKINS, commanding a cavalry brigade in the Confederate army, was wounded in the head while making a reconnoissance on the left, on the morning of the second day of the fight at Gettysburgh. He was standing with map in hard, holding his horse by the bridle reins, when a shell passed immediately over his head, cutting a large gash to the bone, passing through his horse and killing the animal eruditely. His wound is not regarded as dangerous. The command of the brigade then fell upon Col. TENNYSON.
lead_paragraph: Gen. ALBERT G. JENKINS, commanding a cavalry brigade in the Confederate army, was wounded in the head while making a reconnoissance on the left, on the morning of the second day of the fight at Gettysburgh. He was standing with map in hard, holding his horse by the bridle reins, when a shell passed immediately over his head, cutting a large gash to the bone, passing through his horse and killing the animal eruditely. His wound is not regarded as dangerous. The command of the brigade then fell upon Col. TENNYSON.

abstract: Nothing definite transpired yesterday with regard to the future action of the Government authorities relative to the draft in this City. Provost-Marshal NUGENT has received no further instructions from Washington upon the subject, but he is prepared to proceed with his duties in the premises as soon as he receives orders. When the draft is resumed it will be publicly announced beforehand, and every peaceably-disposed citizen will be allowed to see how It is done; those who are not peaceably disposed will be permitted to see something else. Gov. MORGAN and the other gentlemen who went on to Washington to confer with the Government authorities relative to alleged errors in the quota assigned to this City, returned yesterday. The Government has promised that New-York shall be credited with all the excess of volunteers which it can be shown she has furnished in previous calls, also with the whole term of service of her militia.

abstract: -- The cargo of the prize schooner Hunter, which was captured off Mobile by the United States steam gunboat Kanawha, arrived at this port in the transport Bermuda. It consists of 43 bales of cotton, which was all the cargo the Hunter had on board. The vessel was taken to Pensacola, where a survey was had. which led to her being condemned as unseaworthy. The cotton has been taken in charge by the United States Marshal. -- Philadelphia Ledger, July 21.

abstract: Yesterday noon twenty more prisoners reached here from Philadelphia, under charge of Acting Masters HOFFNER and FORD, and Surgeon JAMES McCLELLAND, U.S. steamer Princeton. They were at once taken to Fort Lafayette. All were blockade runners, and among them was one name FYLES, who was identified as a Captain in the rebel army. He was en route to Europe, on a mission, when the vessel carrying him was captured, and energetically claimed to be only a passenger. The balance of the prisoners were Southerners, and evinced a great distaste to the quarters to which they were assigned.

abstract: NATIONAL GUARD MANUAL. -- The foregoing is the title of a very instructive work on military matters, compiled by STEPHEN R. PINOKNEY, late Major of the Eleventh Regiment N.Y.N.G. It minutely describes and explains all the military movements adopted in the United States army, and elucidates with clearness and accuracy the numerous orders and terms in use. It takes up separately the different branches of the service, and notes the peculiarities of each. The ranks of officers, the styles of suns, the weight and force of projectiles, the subject of fortifications, and the materials for the same, are intelligently discussed, and the manual of arms, the movements on the field, duties at camp and on post, and all other matters appertaining to the subject military, are fully considered in regular order. The work is illustrated with engravings which aid greatly in the comprehension of the matters treated of. Maj. PINCKNEY is an officer of long experience and acknowledged ability, and his thorough acquaintance with military affairs guarantee for his Manual favor and reputation as a standard work, not only among military men, bat also among citizens desirous of gaining an insight into the matters of which it treats. The book is published by FRANE McELROY, No. 113 Nassau-st.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL GUARD MANUAL. -- The foregoing is the title of a very instructive work on military matters, compiled by STEPHEN R. PINOKNEY, late Major of the Eleventh Regiment N.Y.N.G. It minutely describes and explains all the military movements adopted in the United States army, and elucidates with clearness and accuracy the numerous orders and terms in use. It takes up separately the different branches of the service, and notes the peculiarities of each. The ranks of officers, the styles of suns, the weight and force of projectiles, the subject of fortifications, and the materials for the same, are intelligently discussed, and the manual of arms, the movements on the field, duties at camp and on post, and all other matters appertaining to the subject military, are fully considered in regular order. The work is illustrated with engravings which aid greatly in the comprehension of the matters treated of. Maj. PINCKNEY is an officer of long experience and acknowledged ability, and his thorough acquaintance with military affairs guarantee for his Manual favor and reputation as a standard work, not only among military men, bat also among citizens desirous of gaining an insight into the matters of which it treats. The book is published by FRANE McELROY, No. 113 Nassau-st.

abstract: The promotion of this officer to a Lieutenant-General has been announced. The Petersburgh Express says he has been assigned to duty in the Army of the West, under Gen. JOHNSTON. Gen. HILL passed through Petersburgh on Sunday morning last, en route for his new field of operations. Lieut.-Gen. PEMBERTON having fallen into the hands of the enemy upon the surrender of Vicksburgh, it is supposed that Gen. HILL has been commissioned a Lieutenant-General to supply the vacancy, at least temporarily.

abstract: The bark Zingarella, Capt. Bunker, arriv[???] to-day fm. Rio Janeiro, and reports that the ship Jabe, Snow, Capt. Gwin, from Newport, Eng., with a cargo of coal, bound to Montevideo, was captured May 26, in lat. 12 S., lon. 34 W., by a Confederate privateer, and burnt; also that the bark Amazonian, Capt. Loveland, hence for Montevideo, was captured by the same vessel on the 2d June, in lat. [???]; 15 8., lon. 34 30 W., and burnt. Both crews were transferred to the Hanoverian brig Viva, and arr, at Rio Janeiro June 9.

abstract: THE DRAFT QUESTION IN HUDSON CITY. -- A special meeting of the Common Council of Hudson City was convened by call of the Mayor on Wednesday night, to take action on the impending draft. A private discussion took place, after which the meeting was organized, and. on motion, the whole matter was referred to the Committee on National Affairs, with instructions to report at the next meeting.

abstract: Dr. GUNN, Health Officer of this port, has of late had serious cause for complaint against many captains of vessels coming from infected ports for making false statements as to the health of their vessels.
lead_paragraph: Dr. GUNN, Health Officer of this port, has of late had serious cause for complaint against many captains of vessels coming from infected ports for making false statements as to the health of their vessels. In a number of cases, vessels having yellow fever patients onboard, or with justice supposed to be infected, have been declared to be free of all disease. A charge has been preferred against Capt. PRIEST, of the Acadia for thus falsifying. The following from Dr. WALSER, Deputy Health Officer, relates thereto:

snippet: Hammill and Ward Soull match at Poughkeepsie
lead_paragraph: Starting from Chambers-street by the 7 o'clock Hudson Railway Express train for Albany, and noting the squads of military occasionally to be seen on guard on the Hudson River for a short distance out of New-York perhaps still a necessary precautionary are measure on the part or the authorities -- and [???]m[???]nating upon the late disastrous riots, our reporter's wandering imagination is disturbed by the conductor's gentlemanly request to see his ticket, and, [???]using himself up, he begins to appreciate the beauty of the scenery on the river -- the stoops and schooner hardly stemming the tide with the light breeze which tans over the unruffled bosom of the noble Hudson. He sees with curiosity the crowds of exited passengers as they rush for seats in the New-York train from their Yonkers -- the first stop of the Albany Express -- and wonders what important event will transpire among all that crowd of humanity, old and young, manly and fair, before they return at night from their daily trip to the great emporium of the Western Hemisphere, that may affect their future destiny.

abstract: America and France; French Residents of New-Orleans
snippet: America and France; French Residents of New-Orleans
lead_paragraph: Our Paris letter this morning merits special attention. Taken in connection with a paper prepared by the French residents of New-Orleans and transmitted by them to the Emperor, a copy of which will be found appended to our Paris letter, it suggests possibilities in the future, which may very well enlist the notice of our Government and people. The French citizens residing in New-Orleans have represented to the Emperor, through his Vice-Consul at that port, that the action of the United States authorities there, tends to bring about a collision between the blacks and the whites of that city -- that in the event of such a conflict their persons and properties would be seriously endangered -- and that the United States Commander-in-Chief of that Department has taken from them all the arms with which they could defend themselves; they, therefore, request that the Emperor will send to the Mississippi several vessels of war for such action as the emergency may require.

abstract: CONTINGENT DRAFT FUND. The employes of PARKER  Co.'s carriage factory, No. 65 East Twentyfifth-street, at the suggestion of the firm, have instituted a "Contingent Draft Fund," to meet the exigencies of the conscription.
lead_paragraph: CONTINGENT DRAFT FUND. -- The employes of PARKER & CO.'s carriage factory, No. 65 East Twentyfifth-street, at the suggestion of the firm, have instituted a "Contingent Draft Fund," to meet the exigencies of the conscription. They number upward of one hundred and thirty, and the factory, as the proportion runs, is of course likely to have a large quota among the drawn. The employes have therefore resolved to fund one-tenth of their weekly earnings, to be applied to the procuring of substitutes, or to paying the commutation fee of any of their number drafted, whose home ties are such that they cannot leave their families, or to be used as a bounty to any of their number who may choose to "shoulder arms," if called upon by the "wheel of fortune." Mr. PARKER, in behalf of the firm, donated $500 to the fund. Those of the workmen who are past the lucky figure "45," and others, who from different causes are not subject to the draft, generously agreed to bear their portion of the financial call.

abstract: The draft took place in Auburn, N.Y., yesterday, and everything passed off with the best of order.
lead_paragraph: The draft took place in Auburn, N.Y., yesterday, and everything passed off with the best of order. The occasion, instead of being one of rioting, arson and murder, was rather one of rejoicing and demonstrations of loyalty. The drafted men formed in procession, with a band of music, and marched through the streets cheering for the draft, the Union, &c., and in the evening listened to patriotic speeches from the Provost-Marshal, the Mayor and others.

abstract: The public mind is fast settling down into a conviction that the late outbreak was the result of a deliberate plot, devised and managed by men of talent, who did not at all appear on the scene.
lead_paragraph: The public mind is fast settling down into a conviction that the late outbreak was the result of a deliberate plot, devised and managed by men of talent, who did not at all appear on the scene. It seems impossible to account otherwise for its exceeding suddenness, and the entire absence of premonitory symptoms. An emeute, which is legitimately the product of popular passion, is always preceded by visible ferment and agitation -- as invariably so as an irruption of Vesuvius is preannounced by rumblings and tremors. But it is the notorious fact that, up to the very Monday of the first outburst, the popular temper was apparently just as composed and tranquil as it had been at any time for months previous. The morning papers of that date all agreed in reporting that the draft then in progress was accepted by the people with entire cheerfulness; and in no quarter was expressed the faintest apprehension of trouble. And yet within four hours after those papers were in the hands of their readers, the streets were startled with an irruption of Vandals that could have been hardly less looked for had they sprung from straight beneath the pavements themselves. No new event had occurred that day to stimulate passion. No new light had broken upon the people to kindle opposition. The object of the draft, its scope, its methods, its effects had all been just as perfectly understood for days previous, when the first names were so quietly drawn, as on the day when the mob precipitated itself upon up with such fearful fury. This in itself furnishes almost a positive demonstration that the mob was not generated spontaneously, but was an artificial product.
headline: {'main': 'The Late Riots a Conspiracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Late Riots a Conspiracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: During the riots, the members of Black Joke Engine Company No. 33, Broadway and Eighth-avenue, were active, fearless and invaluable in the protection of the lives and property of citizens in their vicinity. The night the mob fired the dwelling of Mr. HURLEY, on fifty-second-street, they were twice engaged in a conflict with the rioters and twice dispersed them. From the commencement of the troubles until now they hare faithfully done petrol duty and will continue to do so as long as the least necessity exists. All this manly conduct and great service has been appreciated by the residents of Fifty-second, Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth streets who have made the Company a handsome present, and whose houses were always open to them, and also by the Sixth, Eighth and Ninth avenue Railroad Companies, who also made to the Company a handsome acknowledgment. For all this the members return thanks in cards published elsewhere.

abstract: Army; The Last Prop of the Rebellion
snippet: Army; The Last Prop of the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: According to a dispatch from Baltimore, LEE's army is not so far south of the Potomac as we have been led to suppose. Yesterday morning, at 3 o'clock, it was in motion, and moving rapidly in the direction of Winchester -- EWELL's corps, which had made a move in the direction of Cumberland, falling back and following the main body. A body of rebel cavalry, numbering about 400, encamped three miles from Point of Rocks, attempted to cross the Potomac on Wednesday night for a raid on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, but they were driven back by a band of independent rangers.

abstract: There is reason for believing that very many order-loving citizens know where goods, stolen during the riots, were carried, or have since been stored, yet are hesitating in giving information to the Police, lest so doing would beget for them trouble.
lead_paragraph: There is reason for believing that very many order-loving citizens know where goods, stolen during the riots, were carried, or have since been stored, yet are hesitating in giving information to the Police, lest so doing would beget for them trouble. Such hesitancy is culpable, cowardly and groundless as well; information given at headquarters, or at any of the precincts, will not involve the party in any way whatever, and publicity will not be given to the name. It is the bounden, imperative duty of citizens having such information, to give it at once; not only this information, but all they possess which can in any way aid in the intelligent action of the authorities in their efforts to recover the stolen property, or arrest principals in or accessories to the riots. No man who will withhold information of this character is worthy of his citizenship.

abstract: -- During the late campaign in Maryland, a farmer of Washington County waited upon Gen. Howard, and after telling him that the rebels had taken nearly all of his flour, hay, crops, &c., and that as the Federal army were then bivouacking on his place, he would necessarily suffer other losses, asked if there was not a prospect of his being remunerated for the losses sustained. Gen. Howard advised him, after he had taken his harvest, to make a careful calculation of his losses, and present the statement to the Government, "and," added the General, "If they do not pay you, give it to them on the same terms that I gave my right arm -- without any compensation."
lead_paragraph: -- During the late campaign in Maryland, a farmer of Washington County waited upon Gen. abstract: In the House of Commons on July 10, Mr. BLAKE  said that according to the information that had been furnished to him, Mr. BELSHAM, a British subject, ...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on July 10, Mr. BLAKE said that according to the information that had been furnished to him, Mr. BELSHAM, a British subject, went some time ago to reside in Alabama, and in consequence of his refusal to serve in the Confederate army he was, in the month of April last, three or four times dipped in a tank of water, and on eoming to the surface each time was asked whether he would serve or not. He refused to do to until he was apprehensive that his life would be forfeited, and then he consented to serve under protest. The case was referred by his friends to Her Majesty's Minister at Washington, who directed the Consul at Richmond to inquire into the subject. He had further been informed that Mr. BELSHAM had been sent to Montgomery, to order to have his case investigated, but that since that time his friends had heard nothing of him, and he (Mr. BLAKE) wished to ascertain from the Under Secretary of State what had become of him. His question was, whether the remonstrance addressed by the British Consul at Richmond, by direction of Her Majesty's Minister at Washington, to the Confederate authorities, against the compulsion exercised upon Mr. R. REDMOND BELSHAM, a British subject, at Montgomery, State of Alabama, to force him to serve in the Confederate army, had been attended with effect; and whether there was any object on to state the substance of whatever communications had been received from Lord Lyons oh the subject.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers reads for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers reads for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The first of a home and home match between the Champion Base Ball Club the Eckford of Williamsburgh and the famous Mutual Club of New-York ...
lead_paragraph: The first of a home and home match between the Champion Base Ball Club -- the Eckford of Williamsburgh -- and the famous Mutual Club of New-York, took piace Wednesday afternoon at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, in presence of between four and five thousand spectators, among whom were many ladies. In view of the coming great match between the Eckfords and the Atlantic Club, the match was watched with intense interest, and especially on the eighth innings of the Eckfords, when they had two men out and two on the bases; a fine hit by DEVYR to left field finishing the innings, and bringing home REACH, and SPRAGUE just previous to the ball being fielded back in time to put DEVYR himself out on second base.

abstract: His Army--What will it Do next?
snippet: His Army--What will it Do next?
lead_paragraph: The magnificent army, a hundred thousand strong, with which Gen. GRANT has carried on the siege of Vicksburgh, has now com pleted its work of opening the Mississippi River. It can fight no more great battles, carry on no more great sieges, on or near the banks of the river, for the reason that nowhere on its banks, from Cairo to the Delta, does the enemy exist in any great organized force. Gen. GRANT began his work in the Mississippi Valley eighteen months ago by the capture of the first large rebel army that was there organized, and the reduction of the first great rebel stronghold there, and he has just completed his gigantic labors by tie capture of the last great rebel army in the Mississippi Valley, and the reduction of its last and greatest stronghold. His army at Vicksburgh was five times greater than his army at Donelson, and consisted of a larger body of men than he had at any previous time commanded. In many respects it is the finest army in our service. It consists almost entirely of old Western campaigners. It has performed longer marches than any other of our armies, has achieved more successes, and has seen on the whole more hard service. It is compact, admirably organized, enthusiastic and thoroughly devoted to its commander.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Grant's Army What Shall He Do With It?", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Grant's Army What Shall He Do With It?", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE COMMITTEE OF CONFERENCE IN RELATION TO THE DRAFT. The Joint Committee of the Boards of Aldermen and Supervisors met in the City Hall yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of taking into ...
lead_paragraph: THE COMMITTEE OF CONFERENCE IN RELATION TO THE DRAFT. The Joint Committee of the Boards of Aldermen and Supervisors met in the City Hall yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of taking into consideration the proposition to appropriate a sum of money for the purpose of mitigating the rigors of the draft. On the part of the Board of Supervisors it was stated that there was no authority to appropriate money for such a purpose by the county; while on the part of the city it was contended that the appropriations could be made, and it was suggested that the county should take the entire responsibility, so as to include the towns in the benefits to be derived as well as the city wards. There was a good deal of conversation about the matter, but nothing definite was decided, and the Committee adjourned, to meet this morning at 10 o'clock.

abstract: A letter has been received in Liverpool from New-Orleans in which it is stated that in the battle in which so many negroes were killed, the negro corps were forced on to the conflict by the Federals at the point of the bayonet; that on their approach the Confederates reserved their five till the unhappy blacks were close to the muzzles of the guns, which then fired upon them with the most destructive effect, and they were driven back with great loss. As they retreated they were met by the Federals and again forced back to fight at the point of the bayonet.

abstract: Provost-Marshal NUGENT has received no further instructions from Washington relative to the draft in the City, and the time fixed for renewing the drawing is not known; but that it will be renewed, and the law enforced, here as elsewhere, our citizens may rely upon as certain -- all reports, rumors and guesses to the contrary notwithstanding. The Conscription law is a law duly enacted by Congress, having received a large majority of the votes of both Houses, and until it is repealed or declared unconstitutional, it is the business as well as the sworn duty of the Executive officers of the Government to execute it the same as all other laws. The President could not exempt New-York from its operations, if he would, and it is not likely he would if he could. The law has been, and is now being enforced in other States, as well as in other cities and towns in this State, without difficulty or disturbance; and there is no doubt the same quiet would have attended its enforcement here had it not been for the inflammatory speeches and appeals made to ignorant men by demagogues and secession sympathizers. Before the draft is resumed in this City, the exact quota of New-York will be settled to the satisfaction of all, and full particulars of the number of men required from each district, with the data on which the estimate is based, will be published for the information of all.

abstract: Livingston, Lieut. Manning, of New-York, killed in battle
snippet: Livingston, Lieut. Manning, of New-York, killed in battle
lead_paragraph: A Young soldier of New-York, who fell gallantly fighting in the battle of Gettysburgh, will to-day be laid in the ancient resting-place of his family. The name of LIVINGSTON belongs to the history of New-York. It is traceable in all our annals, political, military and judicial, and the brave and gentle youth for whom his kindred are this day mourning, was worthy to wear it in this life as in his death. MANNING LIVINGSTON, the youngest son of MORGAN LIVINGSTON, Esq., of this City, and a grandson of Gen. MORGAN LEWIS, entered the service of the Union soon after the war broke out, as a Lieutenant in the Third regiment of Regular artillery. He was but a boy of twenty, and from his childhood had been remarkable for the charming simplicity of his character, and the intellectual refinement of his tastes. But in his case also, it was to be proved that the "gentlest are the bravest," and Lieut. LIVINGSTON so bore himself through the ordeal of the fierce battles before Richmond, and of the terrible disasters at Fredericksburgh and Chancellorsville, as to command the warmest confidence alike of his men and of his brother officers. Spared through all these darker days it was his fate to die in the hour of victory. He was struck by a rifle ball in the first wild charge made by the Confederates upon the positions of Gen. REYNOLDS, near Gettysburgh, July 3, and dying instantly, was buried on the field by his comrades.
headline: {'main': 'LIEUT. LIVINGSTON.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LIEUT. LIVINGSTON.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Riots; The Mob Unmasked--Who They Were
snippet: Riots; The Mob Unmasked--Who They Were
lead_paragraph: We advise everybody who wants to study the contortions of wizards who are being torn to pieces by the demons they have themselves evoked, to read carefully the articles of the anti-draft journals of this City upon the late riot. They raised the devil in order to confound and embarrass the Administration, and, as most of us expected, he behaved like a devil, and they are now tearing their hair, and calling on Heaven to witness that he horribly changed after they first made his acquaintance. They strove in vain to control him by a liberal use of euphemisms, just as the Irish peasantry seek to placate the fairies by calling them "good people," and showered on him such endearing epithets as "the laboring population," "the people," "the oppressed and outraged conscripts" -- but in vain. He was not to be cheated into forgetfulness of his true character by any amount of caressing. They had introduced him into our streets, put a whole city at his mercy, and, true to his instincts, he rent and tore everybody within his reach, but especially the weakest, most helpless, most innocent and inoffensive.
headline: {'main': 'The Mob Unmasked Its Character and Spirit.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mob Unmasked Its Character and Spirit.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FIRE IN BEACH-STREET. -- Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out on the top floor of the provision establishment of Messrs. A. & [???].M. MOSES, No. 65 Beach-street. The prompt action of the firemen prevented the destruction of the building. The damage to the stock will amount to about $500. Insured for $7,500 in the Citizens', Merchants' and St. Nicholas Insurance Companies. The building is owned by CHAS, MOSES. It is insured for $5,000 in the Citizens' Insurance Company. The damage is about $400. Cause of fire unknown.

abstract: Sergeant PETTY, of, the Twentieth Precinct, makes the following report to Inspector CARPENTER: "Our officers are still engaged in collecting property that was plundered during the riots of last week. I wish to remark in reply to the assertions of those papers and individuals who sympathized with the rioters, and who say that the same class who originated the not were not concerned in stealing and plundering, that all the stolen property we recover is found, without exception, in the possession of inmates of Irish tenement houses, the very same class who first moved in the outbreak."

abstract: The colored man who was murdered and subsequently hung to a lamp-post on the corner of Seventh-avenue and Twenty-eighth-street, during the riots of last week, has been fully identified. His name was ABRAHAM FRANKLIN, aged 23 years. He resided one block below where he was murdered. Roundsmen GUNNER and ROBERTS, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, have arrested PATRICK BUTLER, who is charged with having aided the murder and hanging. This arrest is additional to those published in the TIMES of yesterday for the same offence.

abstract: The only great rebel army in the whole Confederacy that now appears on the field intact and formidable is the army of Gen. LEE. It is still stationed in the vicinity of Winchester. It has not yet moved any great distance down the Shenandoah Valley, as we were led to believe it had done. It shows no purpose of making a precipitate retreat upon Richmond, as was universally believed it would do.
lead_paragraph: The only great rebel army in the whole Confederacy that now appears on the field intact and formidable is the army of Gen. LEE. It is still stationed in the vicinity of Winchester. It has not yet moved any great distance down the Shenandoah Valley, as we were led to believe it had done. It shows no purpose of making a precipitate retreat upon Richmond, as was universally believed it would do. LEE seems to be waiting at Winchester inviting attack, or watching the movements of Gen. MEADE, or seeing if he cannot invent some mode of retrieving his prestige and his fortunes. For all these purposes Winchester is the best position he can assume north of the Rappahannock.

abstract: Quachila, Steamer, vs. United States; Prize
snippet: Quachila, Steamer, vs. United States; Prize
lead_paragraph: as prize by the steamship Memphis, Lieut. Watmough, of the United States Navy, commanding, on the 14th of October, 1862, off the southern coast north of Charleston, S.C., in lat, 30 and lon. 77 26[???] west. At the time of her capture she was some one hundred and fifty miles from land; when first discovered by the Memphis but fifty or sixty miles. The Ouachita was owned by T.S. Begbie, a British subject, claimant, and commanded by T.S. Gilpin, also a British subject. She was a screw steamer of about fifty tons burden. Her voyage was from London to Havana. She left in ballast in August, 1862, and stopped at Bermuda, St. Georges, where she took in a cargo of arms and ammunition for Nassau, consigned to a resident there named Hart. The master had verbal directions from the owner, upon his arrival at Nassau to deliver the vessel to Hart, together with whatever she had on board. Among the papers is a letter from Hart to the master, received by him while at Bermuda, in which the writer says that he has been advised by the owner, Begbie, that the vessel would touch at that place, and pointing out to the master the difficulties of escaping the United States vessels of war in the passage to Nassau, and how to avoid them. When the master left London, some letters were delivered to him by the owner, which on opening he found instructions to report to a person of the name of Bowne, at Bermuda, and he would supply him with whatever was needful. Another letter was an introduction to Hart, of Nassau, and also of like purport of the one to Bowne.

abstract: a Splendid Record
snippet: a Splendid Record
lead_paragraph: that "nothing goes well (for the rebels) in the Southwest." That is so, now, and has been so from the beginning. Noting has ever gone well for the rebels in the Southwest. They have never gained one great battle -- though they have fought twenty. They claimed the battle of Perryville, but it was really one of their greatest failures. Every one of their strongholds that we have besieged, we have captured -- from Donelson and Columbus to Vicksburgh and Port Hudson.. All their large cities have fallen, from Nashville and Memphis to New-Orleans; and they now only hold Mobile tremblingly, until our troops shall be prepared to march into it. Our army has not entered upon the conquest of any South-western State that it has not conquered, including Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana -- not to speak of Missouri and Kentucky, half of each of which was at one time held by large rebel armies.

abstract: On the day of our visit there were not so many people as usual on the grounds -- a fact attributable by the park keepers to the unsettled state of the public mind after the recent disturbances. But in spite of this the boats on the lake were in great demand. A trip in one of these gaudy shallops, either with a select party or in the more public omnibus craft, with a neat, civil and attentive boatman to answer questions, is thoroughly enjoyable and is quite popular as one of the minor attractions of the Park. The gondola of solemn funereal aspect is the genuine article from Venice, It is not generally considered beautiful, but the Dogs objects to any less sombre hue, and therefore this forlorn affair is a faithful representative of the water transportation of the Queen of the Adriatic.

abstract: -- The jury in the case of CHARLES MURPHY, a citizen killed in the late riot at State.. Island, rendered a verdict that he came to his death by a gunshot wound received from one of the Hawkins' Zouaves. The jury severely censure the officers having control of the soldiers for having allowed them "to go about with loaded weapons, fire upon the people, commit murder and rob and plunder the inhabitants." The jury set forth that had the officer in command been sober and exercised control over his men there would have been no difficulty with the people.

abstract: NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel was captured on the 29th of May. 1862, off Charleston, S.C., some twenty miles west of the Gulf Stream, about 8 o'clock A.M., by the steamer Keystone State, E. Le Roy, master. She was laden with arms and munitions of war, partly at Havana, and partly at Nassau. N.P., and cleared from the latter port for St. Johns. N.B., on the 24th of May preceding her capture. Her heading had been toward land off Charleston when she first discovered the blockading vessel; she then changed her course to that of east by north. The vessel had been out of the port of Nassau only four or five days when captured. She is what is called an auxiliary steamer, using both sails and steam. No satisfactory reason is given for the position of the vessel at the time of the capture; and the inference is irresistible from the evidence, not in dispute or doubt, that the intention was to run the blockade of Charleston, and was in the act of doing so when she discovered the Keystone State, and changed her course.
lead_paragraph: NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel was captured on the 29th of May. 1862, off Charleston, S.C., some twenty miles west of the Gulf Stream, about 8 o'clock A.M., by the steamer Keystone State, E. abstract: SIR : I notice, by the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 22d inst., that you are one of the number of noble lawyers who have tendered, free of charge, legal aid to colored sufferers by the late riot. We are told that the claims for redress lie against the City or county, and must be promptly made.
lead_paragraph: SIR : I notice, by the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 22d inst., that you are one of the number of noble lawyers who have tendered, free of charge, legal aid to colored sufferers by the late riot. We are told that the claims for redress lie against the City or county, and must be promptly made.

abstract: -- A person who was enrolled and drawn as a conscript in the Fourth District of Boston received his exemption papers, on Wednesday afternoon, under rather peculiar circumstances. He presented a certificate from the Warden of the State Prison that he had been a convict in that institution on the charge of felony, and had served out his full term of imprisonment. Of course, after such an experience, he is exempt from serving in so honorable a position as that of a soldier of the Union army.

abstract: Nothing of importance transpired in any of the Military Departments yesterday. In pursuance of orders issued by Gen. SANDFORD on Thursday, Brig.Gen. EWEN assumed command of the special department assigned him, making his headquarters at the Metropolitan Police Office, Mulberry-street. Orders have been issued for the various detachments of the City regiments which have been on duty for the past few days at different portions of the Island, to report to their respective headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Nothing of importance transpired in any of the Military Departments yesterday. In pursuance of orders issued by Gen. SANDFORD on Thursday, Brig.Gen. EWEN assumed command of the special department assigned him, making his headquarters at the Metropolitan Police Office, Mulberry-street. Orders have been issued for the various detachments of the City regiments which have been on duty for the past few days at different portions of the Island, to report to their respective headquarters. The localities vacated by the troops will be patroled, as formerly, by the police. A force of one hundred men from each regiment under Gen. SANDFORD's command, are on duty at the several regimental armories, so that in case of necessity, a portion or all of them are in readiness to render efficient aid to the municipal authorities. Yesterday, Gen. EWEN appointed Major ROBERT TAYLOR, of his Staff, officer of the day.

abstract: About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, some twenty-five rioters, mostly Irishmen, under the leadership of a man mounted on a jackass, besieged the Nautilus Hotel. Tompkinsville, Staten Island, and commenced pounding at the doors, and demanding admittance. The proprietor opened the door, when the whole party entered the house, and then demanded that all the men in the house should come belong, on pain of having the house sacked. This was complied with, and ten men made their appearance. The [???]oters then announced that each man most in [???] treat the whole party, and if that was done they would spare the house. Fearing that violence might be the result of a refusal, each of the inmate treated the crowd, at an expense of about two dollars each, after which the sc[???]undreis left. The leader of the gang was armed with a large carving knife, and flourished it among the inm[???]es of the house in a most promise[???]ous manner: this with the fact of the whole party being armed, caused the acquiescence in the deman[???]s. About an hour and [???],after they departed, the whole party reap[???]ed at the hotel, this time mounted upon horses. They bust in the doors of the house are made a cavalry charge inside through the bed-room, during room, and on the po[???]ch, and destroyed furniture generally. When they had thus wantonly sat[???]? themselves, they left. It is supposed the horses were stolen from the neighboring [???] very stable on the island. The rioters are most of them known by parties on the Island, and they will probably be promptly arrested.

abstract: Capt. CAMERON, of the Eighteenth Precinct, with a squad of twenty men and a company of the Seventh regiment, patroled the Eighteenth Precinct yesterday, from noon until 4 o'clock, in search of stolen arms. They succeeded in recovering two carbines from the house No. 122 East Sixteenth-street, and sixty-four carbines from the armory on the corner of Twenty second-street and Second-avenue, which the rioters had overlooked. This property was conveyed to Police Headquarter?.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- This handsome and refreshing Summer establishment reopened for the season on Thursday evening -- having been closed, as our readers are aware, for a week, in consequence of the severe indisposition or Mr. WHEATLEY. This excellent and energetic artist has entirely recovered, and plays the role of Capt. Legardere with even more than his usual spirit. The "Duke's Motto" will be given until the end of August.

abstract: His Honor Mayor OPDYKE, on complaint of JOSIAH PORTER, whose dwelling was burned by a gang of ruffians on the 15th, issued his warrant for the arrest of FREDERICK HAMNIERS, PATRICK POWERS, PATRICK KIERNAN, BERNARD, CLARK, PATRICK FAGAN and TERENCE REYNOLD'S. The parties were arrested by Officers MCKNIGHT and MARKSLAND, of the Nineteenth Precinct, and yesterday were brought before the Mayor for examination. CLARK and REYNOLDS were discharged, there being not sufficient evidence to hold them.

abstract: FIRES. -- Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the wood yard of Mr. D. FAHEY, Nos. 17 and 19 Furman-street. The flames communicated to an adjoining stable, in which there were eight horses belonging to different persons. Every effort was made to get the animals out, but without avail, and they were burned to death. One of the horses belonged to D. FAHEY, one to Mr. DONNINGTON, two to Mr. P. MCDONOUGH, and four to Mr. R.H. QUINN, valued at $150 each. Mr. QUINN was insured in the Home Company of New-York. The dwelling of OWEN GILLIGAN was damaged about $200; insured in the Tradesmen's Company. The cooper shop of LOUGHLIN & Co. was damaged to the extent of $150: Insured in the Commercial Company. Mr. FAHEY lost $1,400: fully insured.... A fire occurred at the corner of Fulton and Clark streets, about 9 o'clock yesterday morning, caused by the explosion of some powder in a flash, which set fire to the premises and blew out the skylight. Some furniture in the upper story where the accident occurred was also damaged. The fire was extinguished without further damage.

abstract: Drafting the Only Resort
snippet: Drafting the Only Resort
lead_paragraph: If demagogues ever bestowed any attention on the future, or gave themselves the least trouble about the consequences of the troubles they excite, we might well ask those who are now endeavoring to make capital out of opposition to the Conscription, what they propose to substitute for it in case they succeed in intimidating or cajoling the Government into an abandonment of all attempts to enforce it. They do not profess to wish to put a stop to the war. They pretend to rejoice in the triumphs of our arms. They believe in the possibility and in the legality of reducing the South to submission by force. They acknowledge that war cannot be carried on without men, and that we have now not nearly men enough in the field; and they cannot deny that volunteering is, if not at an end, so much exhausted that the reinforcements derived from this source are ridiculously inadequate to the supply of our wants. They do not deny, moreover, that the United States has both constitutionally, as well as in virtue of the mere fact that it is a Government and exists, a right to summon to its own defence as many of the able-bodied men of the country as it may require. And yet, in spite of all this, we have not had one word from one of them as to what they propose to do in case the Conscription act is not enforced.
headline: {'main': 'No Resort but Conscription The State and National Laws.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'No Resort but Conscription The State and National Laws.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Wednesday one of Judge MCCUNN's writs of habeas corpus was served on Brig.-Gen. CANBY, who was directed to produce the body of a rioter arrested by the military authorities. The General consulted a well-known Democratic lawyer as to what he should do, and was advised to pay no attention to the writ. Yesterday the Judge issued an attachment against the General for contempt, and placed it in the hands of Sheriff LYNCH to serve. The Sheriff also took counsel as to his duty in the premises, and was advised not to serve the attachment. What steps the Judge will take next is not known. It is due to the attorney who applied for the writ against Gen. CANBY to state, that as soon as he ascertained that the person in custody of the military authorities was one of the parties engaged in the late riots be refused to have anything further to do with it.

abstract: The ship Guiding Star, which arrived at this port yesterday from Calcutta, reports: July 1, lat. 12° 27', long. 43° 1'. passed a ship's mast with lower yard attached, apparently a mizzen mast, with spider and truss bands, also and iron pin rail; the mast painted white and burned in several places. July 20, lat. 34° 37', long. 69° 43', boarded brig Antonio. MATTHE, hence for Belize (Hond.), 7 days out, which reported 18th, in lat. 36°, on the southern edge of the Gulf stream saw a sloop-rigged privateer with one large gun amidships; saw her chasing a large ship; the sloop was of about 100 tons; was confident she was a privateer; was quite near her.

abstract: His Kitchen Throne
snippet: His Kitchen Throne
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, the story is, they had a "Kitchen Cabinet," which used to deliberate amongst the stew-pans of the White House. How it was made up, nobody precisely understood; but it was known to be a consultative body of very grave functions. Banks, tariffs, land distributions, Cumberland roads, Indian removals, French indemnities, vetoes, proclamations, circulars, heads of Departments and their wives, foreign ministers, village postmasters -- there was nothing it did not put its mind to; and it is said that its influence over Old Hickory was quite as wonderful as was the influence of Old Hickory himself over the country.

abstract: Regarding substitutes, the Hartford Post of yesterday says: "The number of Canadians arriving here is on the increase. This is equally true of other cities. Over two hundred reached Boston yesterday. There has been so much skedaddling from the States into Canada, that it has greatly reduced the demand for and price of labor, so that the Canadians themselves find it to their advantage to come here and offer themselves for substitutes, realizing the large premiums offered."

abstract: The great testimonial to Capt. JOHN ERICSSON, subscribed by the various ship-builders, is now completed, and is a splendid model of the new class Mentors. It is made of 14 pounds of 18 carat gold, and contains all the machinery, with a music-box in addition, which plays nine tunes, among them the National air of Sweden. This magnificent piece of workmanship will be at W.B. DAVIS' private establishment, at Fort Hamilton, on Sunday. July 26. He respectfully invites members of the Press, and his friends generally, to pay him a visit at that time. The model will be exhibited to the President and Cabinet at Washington next week.

abstract: NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel was captured on the 1st October, 1861, by the war steamer South Carolina, in the Gulf of Mexico, off Timballer Island and Barataria Bay, on the coast of Louisiana. She was of the burden of 145 tons, and laden with arms, ammunition, coffee, & c., on a voyage from Havana to Tampico, Mexico. The vessel belongs to Aymar, a British subject, doing business at New-Orleans, where he has resided for the past eight year. He was on board at the time of the capture. The cargo belonged to Spanish subjects, and was shipped on board at Havana, ostensibly destined for Tampico.

abstract: Last year the visitors to the Park were over four millions -- this fact being ascertained by the Park-keepers, whose business it is to keep an accurate tally. This year the number bids fair to be no less. Generally speaking, in the earlier part of the day the visitors are equestrians. but few pedestrians, and those mainly walking for exercise, showing themselves. These are followed, after an early breakfast, by visitors from all parts of the country, on foot or in carriages, citizens not engaged in business, and ladies with their children, often bringing with them baskets of refreshments to be partaken of at some quiet place about the grounds. In the afternoon the numbers increase, and at one hour or another, according to the season, the Park is gay with a throng of citizens and gay equipages not equaled elsewhere on this continent. Of course, on occasions of special interest, the numbers are largely augmented.

abstract: Yesterday, the Grammar Department of Ward School No. 33, located on West Twenty-eighth-street, favored the public with an unusually interesting entertainment in the way of a reception. As on former occasions, the rooms were crowded to repletion by the parents and friends of the pupils. lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Grammar Department of Ward School No. 33, located on West Twenty-eighth-street, favored the public with an unusually interesting entertainment in the way of a reception. As on former occasions, the rooms were crowded to repletion by the parents and friends of the pupils. The exercises consisted of singing, reading, recitation, calisthenics, , and were conducted in a very creditable manner by the Principal, Miss CLARA M. EDMONDS, and her assistants. The programme was excellently arranged, and it may be said of the pupils who took an active part on the occasion, that their efforts could scarcely be excelled. From beginning to end the exercises were listened to with marked attention by those present, and it was evident that none went away disappointed. After an address by City Superintendent of Schools, Mr. S.S. RANDALL, a preservation of certificates was made to the following graduates:

abstract: How She is to be Pacified
snippet: How She is to be Pacified
lead_paragraph: Earl RUSSELL's propositions for the solution of the Polish difficulty are set forth in his dispatch of the 17th of June to the British Ambassador at St. Petersburgh, which has been recently published. These propositions recommend the adoption of the six points as the bases of negotiation; a provisional suspension of hostilities on the part of the Czar, and a conference of the eight Powers which signed the Treaty of Vienna. If Russia would but assent to these preliminaries, the English Foreign Secretary thinks that the Polish question might be solved. We are of opinion, however, that his Lordship bears rather bard on Russia in this matter. Is it reasonable, for instance, to ask the Czar to grant a general amnesty, a national diet, and a national administration to a people while in open insurrection against his authority? Or is it reasonable to require him to proclaim a suspension of hostilities, while his enemies are waging war on him? How would England have felt had the French Emperor required her, during the Sepoy revolt, to pacify India by withdrawing thence her civil and military officials, and restoring to the Rajahs their old supremacy? Or how would she feel were he to urge her to allay the discontent of Ireland by repealing the act of union and giving back to the Green Island her legislative independence? There are more oppressive nations in the world than Russia, and the British Foreign Secretary should have been among the last to forget this. Had Earl RUSSELL asked these concessions from the Czar on condition that the Poles would lay down their arms, and return to their allegiance, the requisition would be less offensive. But his Lordship was not authorized by the insurgents to make any such offer, and if he had pressed them to compromise on any such ground, they would undoubtedly have refused. Deeply interested as this scion of the House of Bedford is in the case of Poland, and much consideration as he has given to it, he yet does not understand the object of the revolted Poles. While the English diplomat is absorbed with the treaty of 1815, and is seeking to eke out autonomy for the petty realm which the Congress of Vienna created, the Poles are struggling to reconstruct that great kingdom which was dismembered in 1772, and till they are utterly crushed, they will not abandon this object, or accept any terms that ALEXANDER can concede. Neither by the proclamation of an amnesty, nor by the promise of a Constitution, can he lure them back to allegiance, and his assent to the preliminary propositions of the British Minister can have no other effect than to demonstrate the anxiety of Russia to avoid a second war with the Western Powers.
headline: {'main': 'How Poland is to be Pacified.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How Poland is to be Pacified.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The United States steamer Circassian, Commander W.B. EATON, arrived at Fortress Monroe on the 21st inst. from Charleston and Wilmington. She left Charleston on the 19th. A general engagement was just commencing as she left. Gen. GILMORE had erected a masked battery in the woods, quite near Fort Wagner, and expressed no doubt but that the attack by himself and Admiral DAHLGREN would prove successful. As the early morning shadows disappeared the attack began, and a perfect shower of shot and shell was poured into Wagner. The Circassian's orders were imperative, and she could not stay to see the termination of that day's fighting.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Circassian, Commander W.B. EATON, arrived at Fortress Monroe on the 21st inst. from Charleston and Wilmington. She left Charleston on the 19th. A general engagement was just commencing as she left. Gen. The Circassian's orders were imperative, and she could not stay to see the termination of that day's fighting.

abstract: The bark Amazonia, of Boston, which was destroyed by the rebel pirates, was valued at  $28,000. There were war risks on the vessel to  the amount of about three-quarters of her value.
lead_paragraph: The bark Amazonia, of Boston, which was destroyed by the rebel pirates, was valued at $28,000. There were war risks on the vessel to the amount of about three-quarters of her value. One quarter was owned by Capt. D.F. MAYO, a quarter by Mr. JAMES MERRILL, of Newburyport, and a portion by Mr. E.H. RYDER, of Boston, and the remainder by other parties. The largest war risk on the vessel was effected at the Columbian office, New-York. Capt. LOVELAND was master at the time of capture. One item of her cargo was 60,000 gallons of kerosene oil.

abstract: Lying at the foot of Wolcott-street is a tiny craft, smaller than the average of our river tugs, and of not more than half the tonnage of the largest.
lead_paragraph: Lying at the foot of Wolcott-street is a tiny craft, smaller than the average of our river tugs, and of not more than half the tonnage of the largest. Yet this little thing has crossed the wide Atlantic, traveled the dangerous course of the St. Lawrence, and made the circuit of the lakes in safety. She arrived in the river here late on Thursday evening. This wonderful little vessel is about sixty-three feet in length, seventeen feet broad, and has twelve feet of depth in the hold. Her tonnage is only fifty-five tons. She is a saucily rigged vessel of the sloop pattern, having but one mast. She came from Bergen, in Norway, direct to Chicago, leaving the former port on the 11th day of April, having thus consumed ninety-six days on the voyage. She is named the Skjoldmen, and brings a cargo of 789 packages of pickled herrings, 50 versts of codfish and 270 barrels of salt. She was laden so heavily that in the salt water her deck was only one foot above the water-line. Her crew consists of six men, all told; their temerity entitled them to a place in history. The following is the master roll:

abstract: Prospect of the Rebellion
snippet: Prospect of the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The fortunes of the Confederacy look cheerless indeed. Their hopes in the East are confounded by the repulse of LEE, and the best their main army can look for is a safe retreat to Richmond. The whole of the Southwest has been wrested from them, and in no event can they ever reclaim the vast empire of the Mississippi Valley. If with their entire force there in the field, and planted in the most formidable defensive positions that the country affords, they have shown themselves unable to stand their ground, or to hold those positions, how can they hope, with shattered armies, ever to assume the offensive and regain what they have lost ? If such armies as those which fought at Shiloh, Murfreesboro and Edwards' Station, have been completely overthrown -- if such strongholds as those at Donelson, Columbus, Vicksburgh, Tullahoma and New-Orleans, have been torn from them, where shall they find armies to be victorious over the victors? where shall they build strongholds that shall stand against their besiegers ? If LEE, with the great army of the Confederacy intact and at its full strength, was discomfited and driven back by the Army of the Potomac when it was weaker in numbers than it had been for months before, how can he hope to succeed after he has lost a third of his army and has no means of repairing his losses? Failing in the offensive at the East -- failing on the defensive at the West -- with not a single untried resource to fall back upon -- how can the rebels look forward to anything but the ultimate demolition of their short-lived though gigantic power?

abstract: Selected by Rebels for Retaliation; Letter from
snippet: Selected by Rebels for Retaliation; Letter from
lead_paragraph: Capt. HENRY WASHINGTON SAWYER is one of the two who were selected by the rebel Government by lot on the 6th of July, to be executed in retaliation for the two rebel officers executed by Gen. BURNSIDE for recruiting for the rebel service in his military department. When this fact became known to Capt. SAWYER's friends in Philadelphia, they induced our respected townsman, Capt. WILMON WHILLDIN, long associated with the steamboat interest in this city, to visit Washington to ascertain the policy of the Government in regard to the inhuman threat of JEFFERSON DAVIS. He was kindly received by the President and the Secretary of War, and carried back to Philadelphia, from them, the assurance that the Government will adopt such a course as would possibly prevent the execution of Capts. SAWYER and FLINN, and at all events punish it fearlessly and promptly. When Capt. WHILLDIN reached this city, the wife of Capt. SAWYER received a letter from him, in, which he stated that the rebel Government would permit her and their children to visit him before his execution. In company with Mrs. SAWYER, he immediately started for Washington, and having received the authority of our Government, went to Fortress Monroe, where they are now waiting a flag of truce to go to Richmond. We have been permitted to take a copy of Capt. SAWYER's letter to his wife, which, we subjoin. It requires no compliment at our hands. It is the letter of a brave and patriotic man, and will be read, with pleasure and pride by all loyal citizens:

abstract: THE REPORTED ATTACK ON NAUTILUS HALL, STATEN ISLAND. -- Mr. WILLIAM WALSH, proprietor of the Nautilus Hall, Tompkinsville, S.I., desires it stated that there was no attack made on his house on Friday morning, as reported; that the affair which gave rise to the report was a harmless one, and originated by his friends, who had no malicious or riotous purpose, and that none of the inmates of his house were disturbed, or any overt act committed.

abstract: The Morning Post controverts the notion that the Confederates, if victorious, would consent to reunion on any terms. The North, it says, would not be unwilling. The people of the Free States have witnessed, without the slightest feeling of shame, an army cross their frontier, threatening their principal towns, and with the same absence of shame, they would see Gen. LEE march into their Capital and dictate the conditions which should henceforth regulate the political system of the American federation, but separation and independence are essential to the South.

abstract: -- Now that the Southwestern rebel army under JOHNSTON -- what there is left of it and him -- have retreated from the capital of Mississippi and the line of Pearl River, it is generally supposed that their next position will be at Meridian, Miss., at the junction of the Mobile and Ohio and Mississippi Central Railroads, and their next defensive line the Tombigbee River, in Alabama. To make a stand here is the best thing they can do under the circumstances. But even this line they cannot hold for any length of time. When we secure Mobile, which will soon be done, the line of the Tombigbee becomes untenable for the rebels, since it can be taken in flank and rear by the Black Warrior and Alabama Rivers. Shut off in turn from both of these latter rivers, the enemy's next line is the Coosa, with Montgomery, the old rebel capital, as their advance position, and their base at Macon, Ga. It may be considered doubtful whether any part of JOHNSTON's army will be able to hold together through such a series of retreats as this.
lead_paragraph: -- Now that the Southwestern rebel army under JOHNSTON -- what there is left of it and him -- have retreated from the capital of Mississippi and the line of Pearl River, it is generally supposed that their next position will be at Meridian, Miss., at the junction of the Mobile and Ohio and Mississippi Central Railroads, and their next defensive line the Tombigbee River, in Alabama. To make a stand here is the best thing they can do under the circumstances. But even this line they cannot hold for any length of time. When we secure Mobile, which will soon be done, the line of the Tombigbee becomes untenable for the rebels, since it can be taken in flank and rear by the Black Warrior and Alabama Rivers. Shut off in turn from both of these latter rivers, the enemy's next line is the Coosa, with Montgomery, the old rebel capital, as their advance position, and their base at Macon, Ga. It may be considered doubtful whether any part of JOHNSTON's army will be able to hold together through such a series of retreats as this.

abstract: The Indianapolis Journal publishes a document, captured by Col. WILDER from a rebel courier, complaining of the plunder of rebel citizens by MORGAN's command. It is dated, "Headquarters 25th Tennessee regiment. Fairfield, Tenn., June 17, 1863," and is signed by Col. HUGHES, Twenty-fifth Tennessee, with the indorsement of Brig.-Gen. BUS???ROD R. JOHNSON, Maj.-Gen. A.P. STEWART, Lieut.-Gen. HARDEE, Maj.-  Gen. WHEELER and W.W. MACKALL, Chief of BRAGG's Staff, who directs Gen. WHEELER to take "proper and energetic measures" to remedy the "crying evil" complained of. The document asserts that universal complaints come in from citizens against MORGAN's men for stealing, impressing and swapping horses, stealing corn and other provisions, burning rails, tearing down fences, &c. To this MORGAN made the following reply:

abstract: convicted of heresy by the Georgetown Ecclesiastic al Council
snippet: convicted of heresy by the Georgetown Ecclesiastic al Council
lead_paragraph: The following record gives the result of the Ecclesiastical Council held at Georgetown, for the trial of Rev. CHARLES BEECHER. The charge against Mr. BEECHER was that he does not preach according to the creed of the Church and of the Orthodox Churches generally of New-England, specially in presenting his views of the preexistence of man, the condition of souls after death, the Atonement and Divine Sorrow. Fourteen Churches were represented in the Council, which was presided over by Rev. T.W. DWIGHT, D.D., of Portland. After listening to the evidence against Mr. BEECHER and his defence, the Council in private session appointed a committee, consisting of Rev. Messrs. BARROWS, of Reading; ALLEN, of Marblehead; HOOKER and CAMPBELL, of Newburyport, to draw up a report embodying the opinion of the Council, and at the adjourned meeting yesterday the Committee unanimously presented the following result, which, after discussion, was adopted by a vote of sixteen Yeas to five Nays:

abstract: By the arrival of the steamships City of NewYork at this port, and Scotia off Cape Race, we receive advices from Europe one week later to the 19th inst.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamships City of NewYork at this port, and Scotia off Cape Race, we receive advices from Europe one week later to the 19th inst. A report had reached England by the Barbados steamer that the California steamship Moses Taylor has been captured by the Alabama, which thus secured a million dollars in gold. The large amount of treasure given in this statement inclines us to doubt the whole story. No such amount has been shipped for New-York for several months. Our London files by the City of New-York bring us the proceedings of the British House of Commons on the 13th, the occasion when the debate on Mr. ROEBUCK's motion for the recognition of the South was to have been continued. The news expected by that gentleman from America not having arrived, he concluded to withdraw his motion, and after some desultory debate the matter was dropped. In the course of the debate Mr. LINDSAY took occasion to give his promised version of the interview of himself and Mr. ROEBUCK with the French Emperor. Another call was made on the 14th, in the House of Lords, for information regarding the case of the Margaret and Jessie, fired into on the Bermuda coast by the gunboat Rhode Island, but Earl RUSSELL had no further information to give. The news of the battles of Gettysburgh had been received, and caused considerable sensation. There was much anxiety for the details. The English journals generally accord praise to the Union troops. The London Times, however, cannot see the ground for Mr. LINCOLN's hopeful anticipations, and says the principal struggle is to come at Vicksburgh and Port Hudson! The Russian reply to the propositions of England, France and Austria, on the Polish question, had been received, but was not made public. It was believed to assent to the six points, but to propose an amnesty instead of an armistice. The Liverpool cotton market was firm. Breadstuffs and provisions were steady. Consuls, 93@93 1/???.

abstract: The extraordinary health enjoyed by our Northern troops along the unwholesome regions bordering on the lower Mississippi, is not only contradictory of what had been predicted by the rebels, but of what had been expected by the country generally. Neither at Memphis, at Vicksburgh, at Port Hudson, at New-Orleans or on the Teche, has any epidemic appeared, and the amount of febrile disease has been unexpectedly small. The troops in the army of Gen. BANKS, who are mostly from New-England, have carried on the land operations of the siege under the blazing sun of Southern Louisiana; and the troops of Gen. GRANT, most of whom were born and raised far north of the Ohio, have ceaselessly fought, and delved, and struggled, from the beginning of the year until now, in the low swampy country opposite Vicksburgh, and in the unwholesome regions round about Vicksburgh, and have not suffered much more than is usually suffered by armies in the field. Our reports this morning from the latter point say that the health of the army is "first-  rate."

abstract: Last evening our drafted men assembled in front of the Exchange Hotel, where, after mingling with the congratulatory crowd of friends gathered together ...
lead_paragraph: Last evening our drafted men assembled in front of the Exchange Hotel, where, after mingling with the congratulatory crowd of friends gathered together they were formed in line headed by the band, and initiated into the marching exercises of Uncle Sam's service. Each Ward of the city was represented, its "quota" marching under a banner, of which there were five, with appropriate and spirited inscriptions, and borne proudly by their respective supporters. The draft fell quite heavily upon the good-looking men of our community, and the procession was consequently one well worth witnessing. "The boys" evinced the utmost patriotism, jollity, and good spirits generally, and the entire throng of lookers on were filled with pride and admiration at their manly bearing. As the procession marched down Genesee- street, led by the fine music of the band, we noted the following inscriptions on the various banners:

abstract: The subjoined extract of a letter is from an officer of the Twenty-second regiment New-York State Militia, addressed to his father, who is a professor in one of our colleges.
lead_paragraph: The subjoined extract of a letter is from an officer of the Twenty-second regiment New-York State Militia, addressed to his father, who is a professor in one of our colleges. It illustrates the character of the service rendered by our militia regiments, during the recent invasion of Pennsylvania, by the rebels, and the hardships and privations endured by a class of young men, who have been brought up in case and luxury, but who, in obedience to the call of their country, almost at a moment's warning, left comfortable homes and their peaceful avocations, and subjected themselves to tolls and trials from which even veteran soldiers' might be tempted to shrink. It also illustrate the cheerful and buoyant spirit with which these labors were performed, and these hardships and privations were endured, in a righteous cause. And it administers a scathing rebuke to the selfish and heartless men who resist the honest efforts of our Government to reinforce our wasted armies, and to crash the rebellion which is aiming its deadly shafts at the life of our nation:

abstract: Whiting vs. Putnam; Arrests by District Courts
snippet: Whiting vs. Putnam; Arrests by District Courts
lead_paragraph: Whiting va. Pu???tam et al. -- By the 16th action of the act of 1857, to reduce the several acts relating to the District Courts in the City of New-York in to one act, defendant in an action commenced in one of those Courts may be arrested by warrant where he has been guilty of a fraud in contracting the de??? or incurring the obligation for which the action is brought and by so??? 50 of the same act, when a judgment is rendered in a case where the defendant is subject to arrest and imprisonment thereon, it must be so stated on the judgment and entered on the docket. In this case the defendant Gardner, was not arrested by warrant, but allegations were made in the complaint that the debt was fraudulently contracted by reason of certain representations made by him, and that the plaintiff was ready to prove the fraud charged. The Justice, having found in favor of the plaintiff, stated in the judgment. "defendant liable to arrest and imprisonment," and upon the docket is entered these words. "defendant, Gardner, liable to arrest; judgment for plaintiff $70 02 -- $12 57 extra costs against both parties -- defendant, Gardner, liable to arrest." The defendants were sued, as partners, but the process was served upon the defendant, Gardner, only. Whether the allegations of fraud were proved or not, does not appear. We are to presume, however, that they were proven, inasmuch as the Justice has found them to be true by his finding that the defendant, Gardner, was liable to arrest. If it were otherwise the defendant should have appealed and reversed that judgment. We cannot reverse that judgment in effect by discharging the defendant from arrest under the execution. Whether the allegations of fraud were necessary in the complaint is not a question to be considered on this motion, the Justice having found that the defendant was liable to arrest and imprisonment. It may have been upon the complaint or upon other testimony, but having so adjudged as before stated, we cannot, on motion like this, subvert the judgment. The defendant, not having appealed, has acquiesced in the judgment, and must take the consequences. Such is my view of this question. The same answer must be given to the alleged irregularity in the service of the summons. We cannot set aside such a judgment for irregularity, nor can we do so upon the ground that the Court had not jurisdiction, unless such an objection was taken at the trial, and then only on appeal. The process against the person of the defendant. Gardner, was authorized, therefore, by the record, and cannot be set aside. I think, however, that the questions presented on this motion being novel, no costs should be awarded against the defendant.

abstract: We find in the Richmond papers of the 23d, three dispatches from BEAUREGARD, according to which our land forces under Gen. GILLMORE were ...
lead_paragraph: We find in the Richmond papers of the 23d, three dispatches from BEAUREGARD, according to which our land forces under Gen. GILLMORE were repulsed in their second assault on Fort Wagner, on the 18th inst. The first dispatch, dated at Charleston, 18th, states that Fort Wagner had been bombarded furiously all day by the gunboats and land batteries. The second dispatch, dated the 19th, states that after a furious bombardment of eleven hours, the National forces assaulted the enemy's position "desperately and repeatedly," but were repulsed with great slaughter, the rebel loss being slight but including many valuable officers. The third dispatch, dated the 22d, states that we commenced shelling again on the 21st. The rebel loss on the 18th is put at 150 killed and wounded; ours at about 2,000, including prisoners, nearly 800 having been buried under a flag of truce. Col. PUTNAM, acting Brigadier, and Col. SHAW, commanding the Massachusetts negro regiment, were killed. It is well to receive these dispatcher with all due allowance until we receive our own accounts. Meantime it will be remembered that the gunboat Circassian arrived at Fortress Monroe a day or two ago, from Charleston on the 19th, with the report that a general engagement was commencing as she left. This is one day after the assault is said by BEAURNGARD to have been made.
