abstract: DANIEL S. DICKINSON addressed the people of Geneseo, on the 15th last, on the topics of the day. In the course of his remarks, he said he never saw a problem that he was less able to solve than this:
lead_paragraph: DANIEL S. DICKINSON addressed the people of Geneseo, on the 15th last, on the topics of the day. In the course of his remarks, he said he never saw a problem that he was less able to solve than this: How a man, outside a lunatic asylum, should want to see this rebellion petted, treated quietly, olive-branched, and asked what it would please to have. The rebellion had its existence to-day in the hope of having help here; and its sympathizers at the North are more guilty for its continuance than JEFF. DAVIS is. [Applause.] It would have been put down before to-day if a party had not arisen to cry for peace. They say they are our brethren and must be treated kindly. Suppose they are our brethren: what filial man would stand by and see a desperate brother, madly, insanely, recklessly, imbrue his hands in the blood of his mother. We shall fall into Roman degeneracy, which permitted TARQUIN to trample on the nation, if we fail to put down this rebellion. Let us remember the dark and dying days of the Revolution, what this Government cost, and then see what miscreant shall raise his hand against it. BENEDICT ARNOLD and all the traitors of the past will stand fairer in the future than he who shall attempt to destroy this Government.

lead_paragraph: The people of this City, or at least that portion of them who are accustomed to read the newspapers, must be well apprized of the fact that New-York has one judicial officer whose especial business seems to be to issue writs of habeas corpus. It need hardly be said that this officer is no less a personage than Hon. JOHN H. MCCUNN, City Judge. Indeed, so well known is the propensity of our City Judge to dabble with that famous writ, that he has obtained among his associates and members of the bar, the soubriquet of "Habeas Corpus MCCUNN." Does the Government arrest a rebel spy or a traitor in our midst, almost invariably forthwith from the "chambers" of Judge MCCUNN issues a writ of habeas corpus, and the man is discharged. Does a soldier who has volunteered in the United States service, and received his bounty from the State and City, wish to get released from such service, he forthwith applies to Judge MCCUNN, and with the aid of a parent or guardian, who swears he is a minor and enlisted without their consent, he gets his discharge, and walks off with the bounty money in his pocket. It is reported, on good authority, that during the last year Judge MCCUNN has discharged from the United States service more than two full regiments of soldiers, on one pretext or another, and that in a large majority of cases the persons discharged had received large bounties for enlisting, while in very few, if any, cases has the bounty money been returned. So accustomed have our citizens become to seeing reports of habeas corpus cases in connection with the name of Judge MCCUNN, that many have been led to suppose that he was the only Judge in the City who was authorized to issue these writs. So far from this being the case, however, it so happens that he is about the only Judge of a Court of Record in the City whose power to issue the writ is questioned.

abstract: Our Victory at
snippet: Our Victory at
lead_paragraph: A gentleman who saw and conversed with many soldiers of the rebel army which lately entered Pennsylvania, informs us that, on its advance march, every man in it was possessed of the most positive conviction that they would capture Washington; that they would again defeat the Army of the Potomac; that they would overthrow the Government, and establish their supremacy in the Nationa??? Capital. Not a shadow of a doubt crossed their minds that they would do this, and citizens of Pennsylvania who suggested doubts were sneered at by the rebels as excellent fools. They were very exultant over their prospects, and very defiant in their bearing.

abstract: Fairbanks vs. Fairbanks; Divorce
snippet: Fairbanks vs. Fairbanks; Divorce
lead_paragraph: Sarah Fairbanks vs. Jonathan Fairbanks. -- In December, 1862, the plaintiff, by her attorney, brought an action against the defendant, who is her husband, for a divorce from bed and board forever, upon the grounds of cruel and inhuman treatment toward her by the defendant, she charging that during a greater portion of their married life, extending over a period of seven years, the defendant had repeatedly treated her with great cruelty and inhumanity by striking her, knocking her down, and otherwise ill-treating her to such an extent that in March, 1862, she was compelled to leave him, and take with her their only child, a son, aged about seven years. The charges the defendant denied generally, and averred that he had always treated his wife with great kindness, and had never struck her or knocked her down, and that she had left her home without cause.

abstract: A memorial, signed by thirty of the first shipping-  houses in Liverpool, has been presented to Earl RUSSELL, suggesting an alteration in the Foreign Enlistment act. The memorialists urged upon Earl RUSSELL the expediency of the introduction of such amendments into the Foreign Enlistment act as might have the effect of giving greater power to the Executive to prevent the construction in British ports of ships destined for the use of belligerents; and they further suggested, that endeavors should be made to secure the of assent of the Government of the United States of A???ies, and of foreign countries, to the adoption of similar regulations.

abstract: Waters, Bishop >amp; Co.'s Bank o $5,000
snippet: Waters, Bishop >amp; Co.'s Bank o $5,000
lead_paragraph: A bold bank robbery was perpetrated yesterday in broad day light, at Brockport, in this county. A fellow went into the banking office of WATERS, BISHOP & CO., while Mr. B. was absent at dinner, and asked the lad in attendance, 15 years of age, to change a ten dollar bill. While the boy was in the act of doing as requested, he was felled by a blow upon the head, dragged into the bank va??? and the lock turned upon him. The rascal who made the assault, and an accomplice standing outside, at once gathered all the funds they could find -- about $5,000 -- and fled. They had left a horse and buggy standing in the shed of the Presbyterian Church, not far distant, and to that they fled with their booty. In their haste to get out of the church-yard they turned the buggy over and broke it. They then took to their heels. Meanwhile the robbery was discovered -- the alarm given, and everybody was on the lookout. One of the villains was speedily captured, but he had no money. His accomplice with the booty had left and eluded pursuit.

abstract: Alliance, The, vs. United States; Prize Case
snippet: Alliance, The, vs. United States; Prize Case
lead_paragraph: NELSON, C.J. -- This steamer was captured in the act of entering the port of Wilmington, N.C., a blockaded port, on the morning of the 2d September, 1862, by the United States steamer State of Georgia. She belonged to Laforce, merchant of Liverpool, and British subject, who was also owner of the cargo, except eighteen bales of merchandise, worsted stuffs, belonging to J. Greenwood, of Bradford, York County, England, manufacturer of the article. The cargo of Laforce consisted of powder, lead, arms, boots, shoes, &c., and was put on board at Liverpool in August, 1862. The bales of worsted stuffs at the same time and place through agents of the manufacturer and owner. The ostensible destination of the vessel was Matamoras, Mexico. She started on her voyage from Liverpool on the 6th August, reached Halifax on the 5th September, and left that place for Matamoras on the 14th of the month, and on the 28th was captured, as already stated, entering the port of Wilmington.

abstract: It pains the eye and sickens the heart to witness the general devastation of property in this county, and to hear each sufferer's distressing account of ...
lead_paragraph: It pains the eye and sickens the heart to witness the general devastation of property in this county, and to hear each sufferer's distressing account of his losses. Between the Potomac river and the Pennsylvania line on the one ??? and, and the North and South Mountain on the other, embracing an area of Some twenty square miles of as productive, highly cultivated and beautifully improved land as can be found in the world, war's desolation has done its work most effectually. Miles of fencing have been burned, innumerable fields of wheat have been trampled to the earth and utterly ruined, and at least one-third of all the horses and cattle, forage of various kinds, hoots, shoes and store goods of every description, together with flour in the mills, corn and pats in the granaries, were forcibly taken from their owners and conveyed across the river for the use of the rebel army and the benefit of rebel speculators, who will, no doubt, carry a large portion of this valuable plunder in Richmond and dispose ???prices. It was paid for generally in the scrip of the Confederacy, the rebels fixing the prices, and putting ??? worthless issues on a par with Federal and other good money, which, having ??? such value anywhere, not even in Richmond, was simply robbery of the most atrocious character. Every loyal farmer, merchant, and tradesman has his pockets full of this trash, and nearly every one has tale of his wrong, oppression and pillage to tell, while not a few of the rebel sympathizers, having also suffered in the same way, have now "got their Southern Rights" with a vengeance.

abstract: On the 14th the Earl of A iblie asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether he had received any official report of the attack which is alleged to ...
lead_paragraph: On the 14th the Earl of A iblie asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether he had received any official report of the attack which is alleged to have been made by a ship-of-war of the United States on the ship Margaret and Jessie in British waters. The noble Earl said that, according to the statement which had been published in the Press, the Margaret and Jessie left Charleston harbor on the 27th of May, laden with a cargo of cotton, having eluded the United States vessels at the entrance of the harbor. She continued her voyage until she arrived about 25 miles from Nassau, where she was chased by a United States steamer of war. She immediately made for the shore, and was followed by the steamer, which began to fire upon her, and continued to do so, being at a distance of from one thousand to fifteen hundred yards from the shore, while the Margaret and Jessie was sometimes 300 yards distant, and at no time a greater distance than 400 yards from the land. Several of the shot and shell were picked upon the shore and taken into Nassau. At last the Margaret and Jessie was sunk by a shell from the steamer, and when it was seen that she was sinking a boat was sent off to her from the steamer. On being asked the name of the steamer, the answer was, "The United States ship Savannah." It was said that it had since been ascertained that it was not the Savannah, but the Rhode Island. It appeared to him that the question was not the position of the Rhode Island at the time, but that of the Margaret and Jessie when she was fired upon. He understood that Mr. SEWARD mentioned the matter to Lord LYONS, and intimated that he would make inquiry into the case, and if the facts were as reported in the American papers he would make full reparation for what was done. He (the Earl of Airlie) thought that he should not only make full reparation, but also take steps to prevent a case of this kind occurring again, because not only had a gross outrage been offered by a United States vessel to a friendly Power, but this act of the Captain of the steamer was at variance with the instructions issued by Mr. SEWARD for the guidance of officers of the American navy. Before he sat down he wished to put a question to the noble Earl, of which he had not given him notice. It was stated some little time ago that the officers of the blockading squadron in the port of Charleston had come to the determination to take no more prizes, but to sink every vessel which attempted to enter the port. He could hardly think that this determination had been arrived at, and he hoped the statement was inaccurate, and founded upon a misconception.

abstract: It was announced yesterday that Detective BRAYTON had captured the thieves who stole $13,000 from Mr.RUTTER, the Memphis banker, in a car in the Central depot, on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: It was announced yesterday that Detective BRAYTON had captured the thieves who stole $13,000 from Mr.RUTTER, the Memphis banker, in a car in the Central depot, on Tuesday night. It will be interesting to know how the thing was accomplished. Mr. BRAYTON arrived here last evening with his prisoners, and has communicated some of the particulars as to now he made the arrest. He was in town when the ro???bery was committed, and went to the Central depot a few moments after the bag of money had been stolen. He "spotted" the men who were concerned in the affair, and told them that he knew all about the theft, and demanded admission to share the plunder. To this they assented to avoid arrest. Meanwhile the fellow who had the bag had disappeared, and his confederates knew not where he had gone. They became uneasy, and feared that he had cheated them. They wanted BRAYTON to help them find him. Meanwhile the chap with the money had passed out of the depot and gone to the neighborhood of Washington-square, where he discovered a house building on South- street. He went into the back yard of this house, found a secluded place, cut open the leather sack and removed the contents, putting the gold and bills into his pockets as best he could. This done he threw the bag away, and started on foot for Fairport. The next morning he took a train for the East.

abstract: Gen. LEE has been struggling very hard for the last fortnight to get off the plunder, in the shape of grain and other supplies, which he found in Pennsylvania, and to add to these the corn and cattle of the Shenandoah Valley. It was highly necessary that he should effect this if possible, as the area from which the Confederate army draws its supplies is now rather limited. Not only are they cut off from the vast stores of grain and cattle west of the Mississippi; not only is JOHNSTON's army cut off from the rich harvests of the Yazoo Valley and Northern Mississippi; not only is BRAGG's army deprived of the immense crops which had been grown for him in Southern Tennessee; but LEE's army cannot get supplies at present from anywhere outside of the State of Virginia. An expedition from our army has cut the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad at Wytheville (Va.,) and another expedition has cut the Weldon and Wilmington Road near Tarboro (N.C.) By the former line were brought to Virginia all the hogs, cattle and corn from East Tennessee, and by the latter line provisions were brought up from North Carolina. The only connecting road with the South which Richmond now has, is the line running to Raleigh, and if we may credit the rebel papers, the capacity of that road is exceedingly limited. These breaches of their roads bear very hard upon the rebels, as they cannot repair them soon for want of railroad iron and other materials. It will be remembered that when Col. CARTER cut the East Tennessee and Virginia Road last November, it took them four months to repair the damage he had done.
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE has been struggling very hard for the last fortnight to get off the plunder, in the shape of grain and other supplies, which he found in Pennsylvania, and to add to these the corn and cattle of the Shenandoah Valley. It was highly necessary that he should effect this if possible, as the area from which the Confederate army draws its supplies is now rather limited. Not only are they cut off from the vast stores of grain and cattle west of the Mississippi; not only is JOHNSTON's army cut off from the rich harvests of the Yazoo Valley and Northern Mississippi; not only is BRAGG's army deprived of the immense crops which had been grown for him in Southern Tennessee; but LEE's army cannot get supplies at present from anywhere outside of the State of Virginia. An expedition from our army has cut the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad at Wytheville (Va.,) and another expedition has cut the Weldon and Wilmington Road near Tarboro (N.C.) By the former line were brought to Virginia all the hogs, cattle and corn from East Tennessee, and by the latter line provisions were brought up from North Carolina. The only connecting road with the South which Richmond now has, is the line running to Raleigh, and if we may credit the rebel papers, the capacity of that road is exceedingly limited. These breaches of their roads bear very hard upon the rebels, as they cannot repair them soon for want of railroad iron and other materials. It will be remembered that when Col. CARTER cut the East Tennessee and Virginia Road last November, it took them four months to repair the damage he had done.

abstract: MORGAN is captured at last himself and the whole of his force. Yesterday morning Major WAY, with 250 of the Ninth Michigan cavalry, forced him to an engagement near Salinville, Ohio, and routed him, capturing 240 prisoners, MORGAN himself, however, escaping with 300 men; but they were all subsequently captured by Gen. SHACKLEFORD near New-Lisbon.
lead_paragraph: MORGAN is captured at last himself and the whole of his force. Yesterday morning Major WAY, with 250 of the Ninth Michigan cavalry, forced him to an engagement near Salinville, Ohio, and routed him, capturing 240 prisoners, MORGAN himself, however, escaping with 300 men; but they were all subsequently captured by Gen. SHACKLEFORD near New-Lisbon. The General announces his good fortune in a dispatch to Gen. BURNSIDE, which we publish elsewhere.

abstract: a western soldier
snippet: a western soldier
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. RUSSELL, of the London Times, in one of his letters from the Northwest, which he has published in his "Diary," gives a lively account of one Mr. OGLESBY whom he met in Illinois, who had raised a regiment of volunteers, and who struck the Englishman by "his shrewdness, simple honesty and zeal." Mr. OGLESBY told RUSSELL that "he had begun life in utmost obscurity, but that somehow or other he got into a lawyer's office, and there by hard drudgery, by mother wit and industry, notwithstanding a defective education, he had raised himself, not only to independence, but to such a position that a thousand men had gathered at his call, and selected one who had never led a company in his life to be their Colonel." He is further described as being an excellent orator of the Western school, who made good homely, telling speeches to his men. "I'm not as good as your Frenchmen of the schools of Paris," said he, "nor am I equal to the Russian Colonels I met at St. Petersburgh, who sketched me out how they had beaten you Britishers at Sebastopol; but I know I can do good straight fighting with my boys when I get a chance. There is a good deal in training, to be sure, but nature tells too."

lead_paragraph: The draft for this city was concluded at a quarter before 12 o'clock, amidst loud cheers. Throughout the proceedings the large audience was in the best possible humor, evidently enjoying the announcements, as keenly as if they were listening to the quips, and witnessing the drolleries of a first-class comedian. As the name of a party in the hall, or of any person well known to the crowd, was rung out, there was an explosion of cheers.

abstract: -- A few days ago the foreign news bag of the Associated Press, which was sent from this City to Boston, to go out in one of the Cunard steamers, was, through a blunder committed in the office of the Association at Boston, placed on the train for New-York, instead of the steamer. The blunder was not discovered until the bag had reached Worcester, about an hour before the time of the departure of the steamer. Here was a dilemma, for there was no down train for several hours, while the bag contained most important, exclusive intelligence for the European Associated Press, beside several hundred private commercial dispatches for all parts of Europe. The telegraph, however, was resorted to, through which the Superintendent, at Worcester, of the Railroad, was informed of the difficulty. The result was that a special locomotive was dispatched to Boston with the unlucky bag, which was delivered in Boston within fifty minutes after its arrival in Worcester, and in ample time to be placed on board of the steamer. The incident is worth noting as an evidence of the promptness of movement, as well as the accommodating disposition of the Superintendent alluded to.
lead_paragraph: -- A few days ago the foreign news bag of the Associated Press, which was sent from this City to Boston, to go out in one of the Cunard steamers, was, through a blunder committed in the office of the Association at Boston, placed on the train for New-York, instead of the steamer. The blunder was not discovered until the bag had reached Worcester, about an hour before the time of the departure of the steamer. Here was a dilemma, for there was no down train for several hours, while the bag contained most important, exclusive intelligence for the European Associated Press, beside several hundred private commercial dispatches for all parts of Europe. The telegraph, however, was resorted to, through which the Superintendent, at Worcester, of the Railroad, was informed of the difficulty. The result was that a special locomotive was dispatched to Boston with the unlucky bag, which was delivered in Boston within fifty minutes after its arrival in Worcester, and in ample time to be placed on board of the steamer. The incident is worth noting as an evidence of the promptness of movement, as well as the accommodating disposition of the Superintendent alluded to.

abstract: -- On Saturday night, June 11, an immense crowd gathered in front of the residence of Brig.-  Gen. Emory, commanding defences of New-Orleans. The General was loudly cheered, and in response to repeated calls made a few remarks. He said the Mississippi was now in our possession, and will never be abandoned. He referred in patriotic terms to the recent glorious victories of our arms, and in conclusion, called upon them to give three cheers for the officers and soldiers of the arms and navy, who have achieved our success. The cheers were given with a will, the band played the National at???s, and the torchlight procession moved off, to display their enthusiasm in other parts of the city.
lead_paragraph: -- On Saturday night, June 11, an immense crowd gathered in front of the residence of Brig.- Gen. Emory, commanding defences of New-Orleans. The cheers were given with a will, the band played the National at???s, and the torchlight procession moved off, to display their enthusiasm in other parts of the city.

abstract: INCENDIARY FIRES. -- During Sunday, three fires, all believed to be the work of design, occurred in Brooklyn, E.D. The first was discovered at 2 o'clock, yesterday morning, in the African Church in Devoe-street, near Union-avenue. The building, which was a frame structure, was entirely destroyed, involving a loss of about $1,000.....About two hours later, flames were discovered bursting forth from the varnish factory of Messrs. FAY & WOODS, in North Ninth-street, near Sixth, but only about $100 damage resulted. Subsequently, this same building was again fired, and extinguished almost immediately was afterwards....Last evening, at 7 o'clock, the match manufactory of Mr. FRITZ, in Wyckoff, near Lorimer-street, was found to be on fire. The building was of brick, two stories in height, and was completely gutted. Loss $1,000; insured.
lead_paragraph: INCENDIARY FIRES. -- During Sunday, three fires, all believed to be the work of design, occurred in Brooklyn, E.D. abstract: -- The new class of Monitors, thirty-seven in all, which are now building for river and harbor defence, are spoken of by scientific men as able to meet all requirements. Some are building here, and are being rapidly urged to completion. It is expected that all will be finished by January. Capt. ERICSSON's Superintending engineer, W.K. THOMAS. Esq., of this City, has been appointed inspector of iron-clad steamers now being constructed.

abstract: Fortune and the month of July have been so decidedly adverse to the rebel armies both in the East and in the West, and their prospects for the future look so beclouded and hopeless, that people generally have come to the conclusion that their game is already utterly lost, and that all that now remains for us to do is to march to an easy, speedy and final victory.
lead_paragraph: Fortune and the month of July have been so decidedly adverse to the rebel armies both in the East and in the West, and their prospects for the future look so beclouded and hopeless, that people generally have come to the conclusion that their game is already utterly lost, and that all that now remains for us to do is to march to an easy, speedy and final victory. It is a very agreeable anticipation, but we have no idea it will be realized as easily or rapidly as is supposed.

abstract: The report of the taking of Huntsville, Ala., by Maj.-Gen. STANLEY, is confirmed. He entered that city yesterday morning without opposition. He had captured some six hundred horses, two hundred of  them having contraband riders.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamships City of New-  York at this port, and Scotia, off Cape Race, we receive advices from Europe one week, later -- to the 19th inst. The City of New-York's news was published in full in yesterday's TIMES. A telegraphic summary of the Scotia's news is given this morning. A report had reached England by the Barbados steamer that the California steamship Moses Taylor had been captured by the Alabama, which thus secured a million dollars in gold. The report is of course without any foundation whatever. No such amount of treasure has been shipped for New-York for several months. Our London files by the City of New-York bring us the proceedings of the British House of Commons on the 13th, the occasion when the debate on Mr. ROEBUCK's motion for the recognition of the South was to have been continued. The news expected by that gentleman from America not having arrived, he concluded to withdraw his motion, and after some desultory debate the matter was dropped. In the course of the debate Mr. LINDSAY took occasion to give his promised version of the interview of himself and Mr. ROEBUCK with the French Emperor. It does not differ from that already given. Another call was made on the 14th, in the House of Lords, for information regarding the case of the Margaret and Jessie, fired into on the Bahama coast by the gunboat Rhode Island, but Earl RUSSELL had no further information to give. The news of the battles of Gettysburgh had been received, and caused considerable sensation. There was much anxiety for the details. The English journals generally accord much praise to the Union troops for their steadiness and valor. The London Times, however, cannot see the ground for Mr. LINCOLN's hopeful anticipations, and says that looking to Vicksburgh and Port Hudson the chances are "decidedly against the Federals." The Russian reply to the propositions of England, France, and Austria, on the Polish question, had been received, but was not made public. It was believed to assent to the six points, but to propose an amnesty instead of an armistice. The Liverpool cotton market was firm. Breadstuffs and provisions were steady. Consols, 93@93 1/3.

abstract: JOHN SMITH was arrested yesterday by Officer CARROLL, on a warrant issued by Coroner NAUMANN charged with having caused the death of MARTIN DALBY, by shooting him with a pistol, on the evening of Tuesday, July 15.
lead_paragraph: JOHN SMITH was arrested yesterday by Officer CARROLL, on a warrant issued by Coroner NAUMANN charged with having caused the death of MARTIN DALBY, by shooting him with a pistol, on the evening of Tuesday, July 15. A large company of men and boys, of which SMITH is said to have been a leader, made an attack on DALEY's house, No. 159 Greenwich- street. They plundered it of everything valuable and then undertook to set it on fire. While DALEY was trying to protect his property, SMITH shot him in the abdomen, from the effects of which he died a day or two after. The testimony given upon the inquest has been heretofore published in the TIMES. The prisoner was committed to the Toombs to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Massett, Stephen C., (Jeems Pipes;) Drifting About; Kemble, Frances; Journal of a Residence on a Georgia Plantation; Wilson, John, (Christopher North;) Memoir of by his Daughter; Norton, Hon. Mrs; Lost and Saved
snippet: Massett, Stephen C., (Jeems Pipes;) Drifting About; Kemble, Frances; Journal of a Residence on a Georgia Plantation; Wilson, John, (Christopher North;) Memoir of by his Daughter; Norton, Hon. Mrs; Lost and Saved
lead_paragraph: This indignant protest of a woman, highly gifted, energetic, impulsive, against a system, in the midst of which she was suddenly thrown, is destined to be very widely read. Though unquestionably what it professes to be, a Journal, written from day to day -- the outpouring of a full heart under overwrought feelings to the ear of a distant friend -- it conveys a higher idea of Mrs. KEMBLE's talents as a writer, than her more finished and ornate productions. Verse is often very "blank" indeed when compared with the burning words extorted by an ever-present sense of cruel injury and irremediable wrong. It can scarcely he said that the Journal throws much absolutely new light on the relations of Southern Slavery to the parties who suffer from its contact. Common repute, and hundreds of sensation stories, have made us familiar with the foul and loathsome incidents necessarily involved in the existence of hereditary servitude. Its chief value is the directness of the testimony it affords on the subject. Neither particulars of time, place or person are wanting to its details, and the effect of one story of suffering thus individualized and localized, is greater than that of a host of vague and flying rumors, or the most elaborate pictures of the novelist. No room exists for doubting the purpose of the publication. There is something solemn in evoking for the destruction of the system which sanctioned them, these memories of buried and forgotten oppression, whose cry has long been silent on earth, whatever record it may elsewhere bear. The authoress informs us that the slaves among whom her experience was unwillingly gained, have long since been sold and dispersed; the islands where the scene of the journal is laid are now in the occupation of the United States troops, and she would fain hope that the condition of things it describes has vanished, never to be renewed. The tints of the work are, however, not entirely sombre. The brilliancy of nature's coloring in Southern scenery, its unspeakable rural solitudes, its wildernesses of uncultivated and ungathered flowers, the softened blending of air, earth and sky in the golden haze of its sunsets, all impressed themselves vividly on the northern lady who saw them for the first time, and they are faithfully mirrored, while the freshness of early feelings was retained, in the pages of the Journal. The instances of gratitude shown by the slaves for the unaccustomed succor and sympathy of a kind and Christian mistress who flings her brave heart into the work, are often unspeakably touching. Even the system of slavery itself can be shorn of much of its horrors by the alleviation of personal influences. Those "happy accidents," amiable despots, occur sometimes in the plantation as on a throne. Mr. BUTLER's slaves had suffered from the long-continued absenteeism of their owners, but other neighboring properties had been more conscientiously administered by the proprietors, and showed better results.

abstract: Advices from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, received to-night, say that, during the past week, our troops have not been idle, but, by a close scrutiny of LEE's movements, have, by rapid marches, succeeded in baffling his several attempts to enter Eastern Virginia, and forestalled his attempted possession of the gaps of the Blue Ridge.

abstract: -- Rev. Jas. L. Vallandigham, (brother of the noted C.L. Vallandigham,) pastor of a Presbyterian church in the vicinity of Newark, Delaware, was arrested, together with Dr. Nathan Hayes Clark, at Newark, on Friday last, by Capt. Thos. M. Wenie, commander of the Provost Guard at Wilmington, Del. The cause of the arrest is not stated, but both of the prisoners took the oath of allegiance and were released.

abstract: Early on the morning of the 24th the attention of Capt. GADSDEN was called to a black smoke some distance to the northward and eastword.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of the 24th the attention of Capt. GADSDEN was called to a black smoke some distance to the northward and eastword. He paid little regard to the matter, however, until an hour and a quarter later, when he observed that he was overhauling a steamer and that she left in her wake a number of bales of compressed cotton. Watching the craft more closely her movements were seen to be suspicious. She made and shortened sail, altered her course and acted otherwise in a strange way. By 7 1/2 o'clock Capt. GADSDEN had passed as many as 100 bales of the cotton, and the hull of the steamer being now distinctly visible, he was satisfied that she was a blockade-runner. Although his vessel is only a transport, and is not armed for aggressive purposes, Capt. GADSDEN determined to give chase and capture this friend of John Secesh. The superior speed of the Arago in a few hours brought her up to the stranger, who obeyed the somewhat imperative summons to "heave to," which was given by a couple of whizzing rifle- shots from the Arago. The troops on board the transport were now all under arms to act as boarding party, if necessary, and a boat was sent to the stranger, with an armed crew, ordering the Captain to come on board.

abstract: The preparations necessary for the reception of the conscripts have been begun on Long Island, in Boston harbor, and tents and various things needed for the accommodation of the men were forwarded on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The preparations necessary for the reception of the conscripts have been begun on Long Island, in Boston harbor, and tents and various things needed for the accommodation of the men were forwarded on Wednesday. There are now about four hundred, including the substitutes, who are ready to be sent down. Soldiers will be detailed to act as guards of the camp, and the conscripts will probably not be drilled in the use of the rifle until they reach the regiment to which they may be sent.

abstract: The Dangers to from Factionists
snippet: The Dangers to from Factionists
lead_paragraph: The factionists of the day have clamored loudly about the encroachments of the Government upon personal liberty, and the fearful peril of military despotism. They have systematically met every vigorous step of the Government in its own self-defence by this hue and cry. They have never tired of bawling, "The liberties of the people are in danger! the liberties of the people are in danger!" It was in this manner that the passions of the ignorant were gradually wrought up to the uncontrollable pitch that has just precipitated itself in flame and blood.

abstract: On Thursday, the 16th, a severe fight occurred between Gen. BLUNT and the rebel Gen. COOPER, at Elk Creek, fifty miles south of Fort Gibson, which resulted in a complete Union victory. Gen. BLUNT had twenty-four hundred men and twelve guns; COOPER five thousand, on his own ground.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: -- Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday on the body of a girl named ADELIA CUNNINGHAM, aged 11 years, who was accidentally shot, on Saturday evening, by a pistol in the hands of her brother. The father of the deceased is a policeman of the Seventeenth Precinct, and resides at No. 246 East Eleventh-street. On Saturday afternoon he gave his son a revolver, with instructions to clean it. While the son was in the act of performing this duty, one of the barrels was discharged. The ball passed through one of his fingers and lodged in the neck of his sister, who was standing about three feet from him. She died almost instantly.

abstract: Now that order is restored in Warsaw, the business at the two theatres that remain open on Broadway has revived to a prosperous and remunerative standard. No alteration has taken place in the bills, and none is either necessary or contemplated. At Niblo's Garden the "Duke's Motto" is still the all-sufficient attraction, whilst at the Winter Garden Mr. FRANK WOOD's very spirited and laughable extravaganza of "Leah the Forsook" keeps the town in merriment and good humor. Both these pieces will suffice for the Summer season, which has but another month to run. At Barnum's Museum the dramatic season has come to a close, but the miscellaneous entertainments are still of a most varied and attractive character. An hour in any part of the day or evening can always be pleasantly spent at this establishment.

abstract: Vice-President STEPHENS, who is on his way to the South, stopped at Charlotte, N.C., on Friday night, and was serenaded by a large concourse of citizens. In reply he made them a speech about an hour in length. He commenced by alluding to the invasion of Maryland and Pennsylvania by Gen. LEE's army; said that it had whipped the enemy on their own soil and obtained vast supplies for our own men, and was now ready to again meet the enemy on a new field. Whatever might be the movements and objects of Gen. LEE, he had entire confidence in his ability to accomplish what he undertook, for in ability and intellect he was a head and shoulders above any man in the Yankee army. He commended Gen. LEE for keeping his own secrets, and told the people not to be discouraged because they did not hear from LEE over his own signature. He would come out all right in the end.

abstract: Officers STEVENSON and KELLY, of the Twenty-  ninth Precinct, reported, yesterday, that on Saturday evening last they conveyed to the Station-house of that Precinct a large and valuable lot of goods, which were recovered by them from house No. 533 Third-  avenue. The following is a list of a portion of the stolen articles. One large chest, well filled; one small chest, one large trunk; two small trunks; several carpet-rugs; a number of fine table-spreads; a large quantity of ladies boots and shoes; numerous decanters, wash-pitchers, mantel ornaments, plated silver-ware of every description, consisting of cups, teapots, sugar-bowls, knives, forks, spoons, &c., &c.; also female wearing apparel of the most costly kind, such as silk dresses, shawls, furs, laces, &c., besides a great amount of other goods impossible to enumerate.

abstract: the capture of
snippet: the capture of
lead_paragraph: A daintier bit of dessert after the glorious repast of Union victories which loyal souls have lately enjoyed could hardly have been devised than that announced to-day -- the capture of JOHN MORGAN. It is precisely what was wanting to fill up the measure of perfect satisfaction. The whole affair has something of the piquant interest of a comedy, with the dramatic requirements all fulfilled. He came -- be saw -- and he was caught!

abstract: Fair warning was given by the Yankees of  their intention to organize 100,000 mounted men, and ravage the country far and wide. Southern newspapers did all in their power to awaken the people to ...
lead_paragraph: Fair warning was given by the Yankees of their intention to organize 100,000 mounted men, and ravage the country far and wide. Southern newspapers did all in their power to awaken the people to a sense of danger, to keep them from trusting to the aid of the Government, which already had its hands more than full, and to inculcate the lesson of self-reliance. These efforts of the Press were rewarded with but little success, owing, it is to be feared, to the inveterate indolence of the Southern people.

abstract: Account of Operations in Tennesses
snippet: Account of Operations in Tennesses
lead_paragraph: Col. WILDER, whose brigade of mounted infantry in ROSECRANS' army has been frequently noticed recently for its daring exploits and ceaseless activity, was in our city yesterday on a brief visit home to adjust some private business. He left Nashville on Tuesday, and Tuliahoma on Monday morning, bringing news from the advance of the Army of the Cumberland to the 20th inst. He informs us that the latest and safest news from BRAGG's army is that it is concentrated at Chattanooga, with its supplies at Atlanta. Only rations for a week are kept at Chattanooga, so that if compelled to retreat no great amount of stores need be abandoned. One brigade is at Bridgeport. BRAGG evidently intends to make the Tennessee River his base of operations. The desertions from his army, the Colonel says, are far more numerous than has been represented, and are chiefly Tennessee, Kentucky and North Alabama men. The Tennesseans will not leave the State any more, and they, with other deserters, are forming guerrilla bands to resist any force sent to compel them into either army. This movement concerns us but little, as our Government does not propose to force rebel deserters into our ranks, but it may prove a very serious annoyance to the rebels, if the war lasts long enough to give them a chance to feel it. On one occasion a deserter came into Col. WILDER's lines, and inquired what would be done with him if he took the oath of allegiance. On being assured that he would be allowed to go home and stay there, he went out and returned with 46 more, who had been waiting to learn then fate before they ventured too far, and these 47 men were all from one company of ???, the desertions just about annihilating it. The Colonel mentioned the name of the Captain and the regiment of this "cleaned out" company, but we have forgotten it. Fully 7,000 Tennesseeans have left the rebel army, and, with the Kentuckians and Alabamians, at least 10,000 have deserted since the retreat from Tuliahoma. The country is full of them. BRAGG's force, the Colonel thinks, cannot exceed 40,000 men, if it is even that strong. ROSECRANS' army is much stronger -- how much it would do no good to tell. But for the tremendous rains and freshets which preceded and accompanied WILPER's last expedition, and blocked his way completely, there is little doubt that BRAGG would have had his retreat cut off, and been compelled to fight, with the certainly of being terribly defeated, if not destroyed.

abstract: New-York; Greenwich-street, fall of a house--particulars
snippet: New-York; Greenwich-street, fall of a house--particulars
lead_paragraph: The falling in on Saturday afternoon of the warehouse occupied by Messrs. PHELPS & ADAMS, on the southeast corner of Greenwich and Morris streets, of which an account was given yesterday, is attributed, the occupants state, by builders and others capable of judging, to some defect in its construction in the centre. It was new, completed about June 1, and leased by Messrs. PHELPS & ADAMS with the assurance that it was capable of being fully stored with flour, and at no time had they suspicion or intimation of its being unsafe. At the time of the accident it was partially stored with flour, tobacco, whisky, &c., and storage men say, well stored. The loss to the firm is not ascertained, but is certainly large: that to those having goods on storage will be small. Messrs, PHELPS & ADAMS have transferred their office temporarily to Dr. WALKER's, opposite.

abstract: The Siege of
snippet: The Siege of
lead_paragraph: The tidings from Charleston, whatever its real purport be whether the assailants of Fort Wagner have met with a repulse as decided as the braggart bulletins of BEAUREGARD claim, or a mere partial check will not surprise anyone who has formed an adequate conception of the defences of that city. The reduction of that stronghhold is precisely the most difficult special bit of work in the whole field of military operations. The best engineers in the rebel service bare not labored in vain for two years to make it as nearly impregnable as possible. LEE, JOHNSTON, BEAUREGARD and RIPLEY have in succession exhausted all the resources of their art to put out of reach of successful assault a city which both an intense local pride, and its great value as a port of entry for blockade-runners, prompt the rebels to hold at all hazard. We should, therefore, expect just such stops and checks.
headline: {'main': 'The Siege of Charleston.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Siege of Charleston.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The fact that volunteers sent in excess of the former quotas are to be credited to the District of County on the draft, (and which the Express alone of the city journals has noticed,) is one of the greatest importance here. The whole number called for from this Congressional District is 2,015, of which this county is already credited with 262 excess, and Orleans County 108, making 370 to be deducted. It is impossible to give with correctness an estimate at present of the number who have gone since, but it is known to be several hundred, probably enough in this county at least to lessen the burden of the draft at least one-half.

abstract: The steamer Roanoke, from Havana on July 22, arrived yesterday. Through Purser MALLORY we learn that just as the steamer was about to leave the bay of Havana a great smoke was seen in the direction of Reglas, evidently proceeding from an extensive conflagration. Barges, boats and steamers were seen crossing from the city loaded with troops and men. As the Roanoke got under way a clear view was obtained of the burning scene. The fire had taken in the extensive Almancenes, or warehouses, of Messrs. FESSER, situated on the Reglas wharf. This immense range of warehouses consists of about fifty buildings divided midway by a street and the Station-house of the Reglas and Matamoras Railroad. The fire had commenced in the fifth building of the range, and under the influence of the strong east wind had already rapidly consumed sixteen buildings, and there appeared no prospect of arresting the progress of the flames before they reached the street and the Railroad Station. If the railroad depot should burn nothing could possibly stop the fire unil all the remaining warehouses to the west were destroyed. From passengers on the Roanoke who were well conversant with the locality and the contents of the warehouses already destroyed it is estimated that sugar to the value of over $4,000,000 was burned. There is said to be no insurance on the buildings or contents.

abstract: The steamship Roanoke, which arrived yesterday from Havana, brought highly important news from Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Roanoke, which arrived yesterday from Havana, brought highly important news from Mexico. The dates are from Vera Cruz to the 13th inst., and from the Capital to the 10th. On the latter day the Assembly of Notables, being duly assembled by a previous convocation, declared unanimously, with the exception of two votes, that the Mexican nation, through them, selected the Empire as the form of Government, and through them proclaimed the Archduke MAXIMILLIAN, of Austria, Emperor of Mexico, and that, should his Highness refuse the throne thus offered him, they implored the Emperor of the French to select a person in whom he had full confidence to occupy the throne of Mexico. This precipitancy of FOREY, in the matter of the Government of Mexico, is bitterly condemned by the Spanish Press at Havana. Tampico has been declared in a state of siege by the Governor of the Southern District, who is resolved to hold the place against the French. An expedition against it was being organized at Vera Cruz. Much sickness was reported as prevailing there.

abstract: The accounts from the Northern island of New-  Zealand represent the natives in a state of anarchy. The report of the murder of two officers and six soldiers of the Fifty-seventh regiment is confirmed. They had, apparently, been shot down without a moment's notice, and the bodies were all terribly mutilated. On the news reaching New-Plymouth, the alarm-gun was fired, and messengers were dispatched to bring into town all those who were out on their farms and at work in the Bush. A Gazette was published calling out the militia and warning the people not to go beyond the Omala stockade at night. Fully 200 militia and volunteers were told off for patrol duty.
lead_paragraph: The accounts from the Northern island of New- Zealand represent the natives in a state of anarchy. abstract: Retreat
snippet: Retreat
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE's army is out of the Shenandoah Valley, and is again back on the upper waters of the Rappahannock, from which two months ago it set forth to capture Washington. Our special telegraphic dispatches affirming these facts are very positive, and quite reliable. One of our dispatches is based on the ocular observation of one of our correspondents, who himself, from a mountain height, watched for two days the march of the rebel army. The two corps of HILL and LONGSTREET reached Culpepper Court- house on Friday last, and the third corps, that of EWELL, has undoubtedly followed in their wake. One of the dispatches says that they passed through Chester Gap of the Blue Ridge, six miles west of Manassas Gap; but our own dispatch says their march was through Thornton's Gap, twenty miles south of Chester Gap, and from thence to Sperryville, and so on down to Culpepper Court- house, and probably to Fredericksburgh.

abstract: veto of the draft; exemption
snippet: veto of the draft; exemption
lead_paragraph: Mayor OPDYKE, with a bold fidelity that entitles him to the thanks of every good citizen, has interposed his veto against the scheme of propitiating the mob by making the City pay substitute money for every man drafted. He sets forth his objections, in the Message which appears in another column, with a distinctness and force that must carry conviction to every fair mind. However the Common Council may see fit to treat this veto, enlightened public opinion will certainly sustain it. This largess to the mob was warranted neither by law nor by expediency.

abstract: Crittenden, Hon. John J., at Frankfort, Ky.
snippet: Crittenden, Hon. John J., at Frankfort, Ky.
lead_paragraph: The death of this venerable statesman is announced by telegraph as having occurred on Sunday morning last at his home, Frankfort, Ky., at the advanced age of seventy-seven years. For nearly half a century the name of JOHN JAY CRITTENDEN has been conspicuously before the country in connection with the National Legislature. He was born in Woodford County. Ky., about 1785, and began life as a lawyer in Hopkinsville, but soon removed to Frankfort, where he enjoyed an excellent practice. Before he had attained the age of thirty-one his townsmen elected him to represent them in the State Legislature, and for several years he filled the office of Speaker of the Kentucky House of Representatives. Valuing the high qualities of mind and heart with which he was eminently endowed, his constituents elected him in 1817 to a seat in the United States Senate, his term commencing at the same date with the Presidency of Mr. MONROE, whom he supported. From 1817 to 1819, from 1835 to 1841, from 1842 to 1849, and from 1855 to 1861, he served in the Senate. Twice he was a member of the Cabinet, having accepted the post of Attorney-General in 1841, under President HARRISON, and being again called to that position in 1850 on the accession of Mr. FILLMORE to the Presidential chair, after the death of President TAYLOR. In 1848 he was elected by a large majority on the Whig nomination for Governor of his native State. In early life Mr. CRITTENDEN belonged to the Republican, and subsequently to the Whig party, but later he was identified with the Americans. He was ever a devoted friend of HENRY CLAY, supporting him in most of the measures that he advocated. He always favored the protective policy, voting for the Tariff of 1842, and against that of 1846. The United States Bank project he strenuously favored and opposed the Sub-Treasury system. In 1835 he opposed Mr. CALHOUN's bill empowering Postmasters to abstract from the mails documents hostile to slavery. He was unfavorable to the remission of Gen. JACKSON's fine for contempt of court in declaring martial law at New-Orleans. In 1842 the question of apportionment came up, and he advocated the smallest ratio of representation, arguing that with more representatives the House would become more democratic. The establishment of a preemptive system in favor of actual settlers on the public lands being before the Senate, in 1841, he moved an amendment denying the privileges of the act to aliens who had not made a declaration of their intention to become citizens, and this he supported in several speeches. Mr. CRITTENDEN also spoke often upon the Oregon boundary question, deprecating haste and excitement, favoring peace, though not at the expense of honor, and supporting such measures as seemed calculated to bring it about. The same sentiments characterize his numerous speeches on the annexation of Texas, which he opposed as unconstitutional, unwise and unnecessary, and on the Mexican war, which he strove to bring to a peaceful termination as early as practicable. In 1858, in the debate upon the alleged illegal exercise of the right of search by Great Britain, he manifested the same conciliatory spirit. In 1848 he opposed Mr. HANNEGAN's bill, providing for the military occupation of Yucatan, and, subsequently, in 1858, took ground against interference in the affairs of Central America. In 1856 he opposed the admission of Kansas under the Topeka Constitution; voted against the repeal of the territorial laws, and in favor of Mr. TOOMBS's Kansas bill, on the ground that it was a peace measure, however objectionable it might be in some of its features. In 1858 he opposed the admission of Kansas under the Lecompton Constitution, alleging that that instrument was a fraud upon the people, and did not represent the will of the majority, and afterward offered a substitute for the bill, which somewhat modified, passed the House, but was defeated in the Senate. It provided for the submission of the Lecompton instrument to the vote of the people of Kansas, to be ratified as the Constitution if approved by a majority, and if otherwise, empowering the formation of a new Constitution. Just previous to the close of his last Senatorial term, after the secession of South Carolina, Mr. CRITTENDEN, true to the conciliatory policy which was the marked feature of his public career, laid before the Senate those compromise resolutions generally known as the "Crittenden propositions," hoping thereby to avert the threatened storm of secession. These propositions he advocated with all the art of oratory of which he was master; but his arguments failed to influence the opinions of a majority of members, and the resolutions were defeated. Throughout the trials and unhappiness that have since visited the nation Mr. CRITTENDEN has remained loyal to the Union and consistent to his views, eliciting from all men -- even from those who differed most widely from him in opinion -- the respect which is never withheld from those against whom the breath of slander has never whispered.

abstract: The unfortunate ITURBIDE ruled but ten months, when the crown tumbled from his head, and he vamoosed from Mexico -- to which country he returned subsequently only to be executed as a traitor. We doubt very much if the newly-proclaimed Mexican Empire of MAXIMILIAN I. will endure as long as that of his imperial prototype, AUGUSTIN I. It is true we are told the Mexicans are very enthusiastic for the Empire now; but the Emperor ITURBIDE informs us, in the sketch of his career written by himself, that on the proclamation of the first Empire, "'Long live AUGUSTIN I.' was the universal cry of the army and of the people." If MAXIMILLIAN really puts on the imperial purple, we venture to hint for his benefit the probability that it will soon be torn off him, and that its hue then will be crimson.

abstract: New developments of French policy
snippet: New developments of French policy
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the highly important intelligence that a Council of Notables, assembled by a previous convocation, in the City of Mexico, proclaimed the Empire on the 10th inst., the Austrian Archduke MAXIMILLIAN to fill the throne. Should that personage decline the honor, LOUIS NAPOLEON is implored to select some one in whom he has full confidence to wear the purple.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 16th, Mr. S. FITZGERALD gave notice that either on the report of Supply, or of Ways and Means, be would ask the noble lord at the head of the Government a question on a subject of much interest.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 16th, Mr. S. FITZGERALD gave notice that either on the report of Supply, or of Ways and Means, be would ask the noble lord at the head of the Government a question on a subject of much interest. Last year he directed attention to the circumstance that the American Government had adopted the practice of requiring bonds to be given by the exporters of goods that no portion of such goods should be sent into the hands of any person in the Confederate States. The noble lord then promised to communicate with the American Government on that matter, and he saw that there had been a correspondence, which was printed in the American blue-book, but to which there was no allusion in any of the papers presented to Parliament. The question he had to ask was, whether he was aware that, notwithstanding the remonstrance of Her Majesty's Government, and the warning that the practice in question was contrary to treaty, it was still persisted in by the American Government; and whether he would state what course Her Majesty's Government intended to take in the matter. He would now ask the Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether any further information had been received with regard to the case of the Margaret Jessie.

abstract: During the past few days the conscription has steadily progressed.
lead_paragraph: During the past few days the conscription has steadily progressed. The utmost order and quiet have characterized the different drafts, and the Quaker city may congratulate itself that the proud name which it has earned as a law-abiding people received new distinction. The entire upper portion of the city, with the exception of the Eleventh Ward, has been visited by the Provost-Marshals, and the conscription has been enforced in West Philadelphia also. There have been three Districts drawn -- the Third, Fourth and Fifth -- and there yet remains the lower portion of the city, comprised in the First and Second Districts.

abstract: candidate for Congress in the Fourth Kentucky District, is having rather a hard, time in his canvass, the district being overrun by guerrillas. They obtained knowledge a few days ago that Mr. HARDING was at Campbellsville, and at once formed a plan for capturing him. N??? means of escape were left Mr. H. but to take to the woods, and these be improved, remaining in ambush during an entire day and night, the rebels passing all around his place of concealment, and within a few paces of where he was. They occupied themselves with chasing horses and negroes, which, like himself, had fled to the woods for safety. It is reported that Mr. HARDING has since reached his home unharmed, but that the surrounding country is infested with small bands of rebels, rendering it imprudent for him to resume his canvass. However, he has visited and spoken in all the counties of his district but three, and the canvass of these for the present will, for prudential reasons, be abandoned.

abstract: NELSON, C.J. -- The vessel in this case was captured on the 25th of May, 1861, off Cape Henry, by the Quaker City. She belonged at the time to citizens of Virginia and residents of Richmond. Three-eighths of the cargo, coffee from Rio Janiero, belonged to the house of J.L. Phipps & Co., of New-  York, British subjects. The other five-eights belonged to the owners of the vessel, but was claimed by the house of Phipps & Co. for a heavy advance made at Rio on the 26th of April preceding the capture. The advance was made in the usual way upon the property shipped, and a lien undoubtedly attached to the interest of the owners of the five-eighth, and would have entitled Phipps & Co. to reimbursement out of the proceeds. But it does not appear that there was any special arrangement at the time of the advance by which a special interest in the coffee was acquired beyond the usual lien to secure reimbursement. The claimant was offered an opportunity for further proofs on this point, which was not accepted. We concur, therefore, in the decree below against the vessel and portion of the cargo condemned. Decree affirmed.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be bad at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The services of the Metropolitan Police, officers and men, during the Riot Week, won for them the admiration and confidence of the community.
lead_paragraph: The services of the Metropolitan Police, officers and men, during the Riot Week, won for them the admiration and confidence of the community. Never did men meet an emergency so fearful with more promptness, unanimity and courage, and never was hazardous and prolonged duty discharged with more willingness and fidelity. There was no flinching or faltering in any quarter, and to their courageous and unaided efforts from Monday's afternoon until Tuesday's can be attributed the safety of the more valuable portions of the City. The riot broke upon them unexpectedly, and when they were the only force to meet it; rallying on sudden warning, they did meet it, and by their well concerted action, their speedy movements, and their determined assaults upon the mob in the different localities, they gave the rioters no time to correctly estimate their own strength or properly estimate the weakness, at the time, of the authorities. Had it not been for this, there is scarce a doubt but that a concentrated and formidable demonstration would have been made against the lower portion of the City, and a period of destruction, pillage and carnage have ensued to an extent most fearful, and to which what did occur would have been as nothing.

abstract: ed yesterday on a warrant issued by Coroner NORRIS, charging him with killing his wife, JANE FABRELLY.
lead_paragraph: ed yesterday on a warrant issued by Coroner NORRIS, charging him with killing his wife, JANE FABRELLY. The parties occupied the rear basement. Both were addicted to drinking. Whenever the husband brought home any money it was spent for liquor. They had frequent quarrels and annoyed the neighborhood very much. On Sunday evening some liquor was brought into the house, and the FARRELLY's and occupants of the same premises named GOODMAN, got to drinking, and all became more or less intoxicated. A quarrel arose between deceased and her husband, and the latter beat his wife. The other parties separated them. She ran into the back yard. FARRELLY pursued her, and picking up a wash-board, struck her on the head and knocked her down. While down, as alleged, he struck her on the neck with the edge of the board, breaking the spinal column and causing almost instant death. Information was given to the Police, and Officer OSBORN, of the Forty-first Precinct, arrested the accused. He is held to await the Coroner's inquest.

abstract: NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel was captured in the port of New-York, on the 21st of August, 1861, by Government officers. She was laden at the port of Newbern, N.C., with spirits of turpentine, and left that port the 23d of July, 1861. There was no actual blockade of Newbern at the time. The vessel belongs to H.A. McLeod, a British subject, but resident in Charleston, S.C., at the time of capture, and the corgo to A. Wade, a resident of Newbern, and citizen of North Carolina. The vessel and cargo were condemned as enemies property in the Court below, but acquitted on charge of breaking the blockade.
lead_paragraph: NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel was captured in the port of New-York, on the 21st of August, 1861, by Government officers. She was laden at the port of Newbern, N.C., with spirits of turpentine, and left that port the 23d of July, 1861. There was no actual blockade of Newbern at the time. The vessel belongs to H.A. The vessel and cargo were condemned as enemies property in the Court below, but acquitted on charge of breaking the blockade.

abstract: -- Roundsmen GUNNER and ROBERTS, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, who have been so active in arresting the villains engaged in the murder and subsequent hanging of ABRAHAM FRANKLIN, the colored man, corner of Twenty-eighth-street and Seventh avenue, during the late riots, took another man into custody Sunday night, charged with being a principal in the murder. The prisoner's name is GEORGE GLASS; he is an Irish laborer, 53 years of age, and lives in West Twenty-  seventh-street. The witness against GLASS is MARTIN VREELAND, who makes affidavit that on the afternoon of the murder he saw GLASS enter FRANKLIN's apartments and soon brought him out, followed by the mob. The rioters beat and kicked the unfortunate negro for nearly a block, and at the corner of Twenty-eighth-street and Seventh-avenue they hung him. At the same time the buildings occupied by the colored people were repeatedly set on fire, but the firemen extinguished the flames. VREELAND further states that while the villains were murdering FRANKLIN, GLASS cried out, "Hang the -- nigger." The witness has been acquainted with Glass for sixteen years, and fully identified him as the man who brought FRANKLIN from the house and delivered him to the mob. The prisoner stoutly denies his guilt. He was taken before Justice KELLY, and locked up for trial without ball.

abstract: The Stimers Court of Inquiry having adjourned, it is no longer necessary to keep back a report of such of the proceedings as may interest the public.
lead_paragraph: The Stimers Court of Inquiry having adjourned, it is no longer necessary to keep back a report of such of the proceedings as may interest the public. The subject immediately before the Court was a personal difference between Admiral DUPONT and Chief Engineer STIMERS. In investigating it, however, several important facts relative to the value of our iron-clad vessels were elicited, and we subjoin a report of the evidence relating to them. It may not be out of place to say, that nearly all the professional testimony given corroborates the views of Capts. DRAYTON and WORDEN, the only witness materially differing from them being a gentleman of the Press, whose evidence has already been printed in the New-York papers. Annexed is the most interesting portion of the unpublished records:

abstract: There are about 150 drafted men and substitutes now in the conscript camp at Grape Vine Point -- and on Saturday evening an attempt was made by a number of the substitutes who had received their money, to run away and leave Uncle Sam so much "out." There was at the time -- it was early in the evening -- but a single guard, instead of a double guard, as is usual, and a rush was made of about ten or fifteen, who were fired on, and all compelled to return to quarters except seven as we understand, who at the time escaped, and two of whom we hear have since been retaken. They attempted to swim across. It is hard to tell whether one or two of those who have not been found were hit with bullets or not; but one man whose descriptive list that was sent over to the hospital, does not agree at all with his statements to the Surgeons there, was badly wounded -- a ball passing through his breast, and shattering his left arm so that amputation above the elbow had to be performed yesterday morning, which was done by Dr. LINDSLEY, assisted by Dr. TOWNSEND and other Surgeons. A letter was found in the camp written to some woman, in which the writer states that he had already made something, and expected by selling himself times enough to clear at least $2,000 by his operations. During the disturbance some one threw a brick at the guard from a window, and fifteen shots were instantly fired into the building, but, so far as we can find, without any fatal effect. We have no doubt many who offer themselves as substitutes, do so with a deliberate intention to take the money and cheat the Government; but that game seems about played out. The party who got to handsomely punished called himself JOHN MCCARTEN, or JOHNSON, and he came from Toronto, C.W. He is about 25 years old. We have been told that an attempt of the kind was made on Friday night, and the guard shot the thief.

They attempted to swim across. It is hard to tell whether one or two of those who have not been found were hit with bullets or not; but one man whose descriptive list that was sent over to the hospital, does not agree at all with his statements to the Surgeons there, was badly wounded -- a ball passing through his breast, and shattering his left arm so that amputation above the elbow had to be performed yesterday morning, which was done by Dr. LINDSLEY, assisted by Dr. TOWNSEND and other Surgeons. A letter was found in the camp written to some woman, in which the writer states that he had already made something, and expected by selling himself times enough to clear at least $2,000 by his operations. During the disturbance some one threw a brick at the guard from a window, and fifteen shots were instantly fired into the building, but, so far as we can find, without any fatal effect. The party who got to handsomely punished called himself JOHN MCCARTEN, or JOHNSON, and he came from Toronto, C.W. He is about 25 years old. We have been told that an attempt of the kind was made on Friday night, and the guard shot the thief.

abstract: NELSON, C.J. -- This vessel and cargo were captured on the 25th April, 1862, in the gulf stream, about one hundred miles from land, and two days out from Nassau, N.P., on a voyage from the latter place to Baltimore and back. Her cargo, which was put on board at Nassau, consisted of salt, coffee, soap, merchandise, &c. The vessel is owned by Roberts, a merchant, and resident of Nassau, and British subject. Her cargo by Sawyer and Menendez of the same place -- the one a British subject, and the other Spanish. According to the evidence, the vessel was in her proper course pursuing her voyage to Baltimore, and without any intent to run the blockade of any of the Confederate ports. She seems to have been convicted on suspicion from hearsay evidence, and report that she had run the blockade of Charleston on her previous voyage; and further, that she was still the property of a citizen and resident of some of the Southern States. We are not satisfied that these facts, or any of them, have been established by competent proof. The cargo, it is admitted, belongs to British and Spanish subjects.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR has issued general orders to encourage enlistments and for the payment of bounties.
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR has issued general orders to encourage enlistments and for the payment of bounties. The State bounty to recruits is fixed at seventy-five dollars, of which sum ten dollars will be paid on enlistment, and the remainder before leaving the State. The bounty for reenlistment is one hundred and fifty dollars, of which thirty dollars are paid down. A soldier belonging to the State of New-York, who enlists in the field, is entitled to the one hundred and fifty dollars bounty, under the foregoing form, provided the Paymaster, upon whom this duty is enjoined, passes his name to the credit of the State.

abstract: The whole result appears to be that the Federals in the second engagement did not recover the ground they had lost in the first.
lead_paragraph: The whole result appears to be that the Federals in the second engagement did not recover the ground they had lost in the first. But the conflict must have been as Gen. MEADE describes it, severe. He more than once mentions the heavy losses his troops have sustained, and infers that the Confederates must have suffered equally. The proportion of officers is again unusually large. Three Federal Generals have fallen, and four are returned as wounded. In fact, though the Government has been ??? of "promise" in the confuse of the second day to justify the president in issuing an address to the public on the event, his words seem ??? by a sense of a loss among the troops too heavy for the slight result their courage has purchased. A retreat, a drawn battle, and another, probably greater engagement inevitable, there was scarcity enough of success in the achievement of the army to enable the President to rise to the full tone of congratulation.

abstract: Riots; Confidence in Life and Property Shaken
snippet: Riots; Confidence in Life and Property Shaken
lead_paragraph: The unbroken prosperity which we have so long enjoyed, has begotten amongst us a sort of contempt for all theorizing about governments, and for what are called "tendencies" in politics, which is now likely to work a good deal of mischief, or rather to let a good deal of mischief be worked. It has been long the opinion of thoughtful men, that the great cities would eventually impose a strain on our political system that it would not stand, and that the application, without change or modification, to masses of men composed of such materials as the population of New-York, and living together under such conditions as it lives under, was full of danger, and would sooner or later bring discredit upon the whole democratic system, if it did not positively break it down. Nothing they have ever said, however, has produced the slightest impression, for the simple reason that successful money-making has such a tonic effect on the nerves, that people engaged in it can hardly ever be persuaded, except by the actual occurrence of disaster, that any state of things in which they are able to accumulate so rapidly, is either very bad or will not last their time.

abstract: We have this morning, from our special correspondent with the Army of the Potomac, definite information regarding the positions at present occupied by LEE'S rebels.
lead_paragraph: We have this morning, from our special correspondent with the Army of the Potomac, definite information regarding the positions at present occupied by LEE's rebels. A.P. HILL's and LONGSTREET's corps have certainly escaped into Eastern Virginia -- the one through Cheater and the other through Thornton's Gap -- while EWELL's corps is still in the Shenandoah Valley. The positions of our own forces cannot, of course, be revealed, but the record of skirmishes and fights made by our correspondent, sufficiently indicates that they are not idle.

abstract: The ship Leonidas, Capt. WOOD, from Montevideo, arrived at this port yesterday, having on board as cargo 165 mules, all in fine condition, losing only six during a passage of fifty-seven days. This, we believe, is the only cargo of mules ever brought into this port from Montevideo. The ship lies off the Battery.

WOOD, from Montevideo, arrived at this port yesterday, having on board as cargo 165 mules, all in fine condition, losing only six during a passage of fifty-seven days. This, we believe, is the only cargo of mules ever brought into this port from Montevideo. The ship lies off the Battery.

abstract: We learn that this place is perfectly deserted, and left in an almost desolate condition, the grass and weeds growing all over the place, and but four or five families living there. It is considered as neutral ground by both the enemy and our troops there being a white flag sailed up in the place. Our men frequently go over in little sail boats to gather figs that grow in rich abundance there.

abstract: The schooner Albert Mason, Capt. DOUGLAS, arrived yesterday in ballast, from Port Roval, S.C., which place she is reported to have left on the morning of Sunday, the 26th. Capt. abstract: The United States forces under Gen. DIX in the Department of the East, are being collected and organized for any future emergency that may arise in connection with the enforcement of the draft. They will act in concert with the militia under Gen. SANDFORD. About 1,100 men from the various militia regiments are kept constantly on duty, and are detailed to assist the Police in the recovery of property stolen during the riots. During the first two days of the riots about 5,000 stand of arms were stolen by the mob from various place, of which only 500 have yet been recovered. Great pains have evidently been taken to secrete these arms, and it is the opinion of Gen. SANDFORD that, it the riots are renewed, the authorities will have to contend with an armed mob instead of with stones, brickbats and bludgeons. The mob will, however, be without artillery or cavalry, and no doubt is felt of the ability of the military authorities to promptly suppress any future disturbance, whether it takes the shape of a mob in arms or without arms.

abstract: CHAS. A. HURD, late second mate of the American ship Swallow, arrived here from Hamburg yesterday, having been sent home by the American Consul at that place, charged with the murder of JNO. RUSSELL, a seaman on board the Swallow, while on her passage from Callao to Hamburg. RUSSELL was an old man, and is alleged to have been beaten and otherwise ill-  treated by the second mate, to such an extent as to cause his death on the 27th of April last. HURD was taken before United States Commissioner OSBORNE, by whom he was committed for examination on Thursday next.
