abstract: The torn and tattered battle-flag of the Sixty-  ninth regiment, which was in the house of Provost-  Marshal NUGENT when it was burnt by the mob, was yesterday recovered, and is once more in the possession or Col. NUGENT. It appears that the flag was thrown from the window of the dwelling by the rioters, and picked up by the firemen, who took it to the engine house of Engine Company No. 45, where it has been safely kept. Col. NUGENT has also recovered the elegant sword presented to him in 1854 by the Irish Fusileers. It was found by the police in possession of a boy, who was playing with it in one of the streets up town. The hilt was broken, and the pearls and other ornaments with which it was studded were gone. Col. NUGENT intends to preserve it in its present state, as a memento of the gallantry of the "left wing of LEE's army," and a counterpart of the old flag, which was such a terror to the right wing. abstract: City of London; Trial Trip and Description
snippet: City of London; Trial Trip and Description
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, about 400 gentlemen assembled on board the new and magnificent steamship City of London, by invitation of the agent of the line, for a pleasure trip down the bay. Among the party were Surveyor ANDREWS, Postmaster WAKEMAN, and numerous officers of the British frigate Challenger, and other vessels lying in the harbor. The guests were conveyed to the steamer by means of a tender which left Pier No. 44, North River, every fifteen minutes until 11 A.M., the hour of the steamer's sailing. The vessel was gaily decked with the English, American, and other national colors, and as she passed down the river attracted considerable attention from the crowds gathered on the piers. As she neared her consort, the City of New-York, that vessel fired a salute and dipped her colors, which compliment was repeated by the Scotia, of the Cunard line, and other steamers which happened to be at anchor at the time. Four frigates -- representing the American, English, French and Spanish navies -- were also passed, the crews of each mounting the yards and giving nine hearty cheers. The City of London replied to the honors with the customary salute, and the guests on board did not fail to do their share of cheering, and otherwise manifest their delight. GRAFFULA's Seventh regiment band was in attendance, and opened the musical entertainment with the stirring air, "God Save the Queen." This was followed by American national and patriotic airs, and before the steamer returned to her pier a variety of most delightful music was discoursed, to the unfeigned gratification of the guests. When about ten miles beyond Sandy Hook, the company were invited to enter the spacious cabin and partake of a banquet, which had been prepared under the skilled management of DELMONICO. It is supposed, of course, that almost every one has heard of that famous co???erer, and it may be said with truth, that on this occasion he surpassed himself in the arrangement of the tables and the variety of delicacy of the viands placed thereon. Before the party separated, the healths of Queen VICTORIA and President LINCOLM were drank, and ???ousts complimentary to the City of London, to the Captain, P.C. PETRIE, and to the agent of the line, Mr. JOHN DALE, were given and responded to. The whole affair was a complete success, everyone on hand receiving all the attention he could possibly desire, both from the officers and the assistants. The steamer returned to Pier 44 at about 7 P.M.

lead_paragraph: The leading organ of the rioters has informed the public within a few days that the Democratic party rejects "both the Southern specific for peace and prosperity -- homogeneity of institutions through a Confederacy all Slave," and the Radical "specific against rebellion -- homogeneity of social institutions through the abolition of Slavery;" that it holds, on the contrary, "that a Confederate Republic can flourish, part slave and part free; that there is no irrepressible conflict between Freedom and Slavery," &c.

abstract: Coroner COLLINS held an inquest on Monday afternoon upon the body of PATRICK McKENNA, a native of Ireland, aged about 34 years, who was found that morning in the dock foot of Fourteenth-street, East River.
lead_paragraph: Coroner COLLINS held an inquest on Monday afternoon upon the body of PATRICK McKENNA, a native of Ireland, aged about 34 years, who was found that morning in the dock foot of Fourteenth-street, East River. There was no testimony given as to the manner of his death, and a verdict of death by drowning was rendered. There were some bruises discovered on the head and face, but these were thought to have been produced by his falling against some stones in the dock.

abstract: Campaign, Prospects of the
snippet: Campaign, Prospects of the
lead_paragraph: Last Winter's campaign culminated in the battle of Fredericksburgh, under BURNSIDE; the Spring campaign culminated in the battle of Chancellorsville, under HOOKER; the Summer campaign appears to have culminated in the battle of Gettysburgh, under MEADE. The army of LEE has now returned to its simple duty of covering Richmond, and standing on the defensive until attacked by our troops. The fact of LEE's retreat indicates his inability to cope with the Army of the Potomac when it is properly concentrated and skillfully handled. Nothing less than a certain and practical knowledge of this would have led him to abandon the campaign -- a campaign based on the largest plans, looking to the highest ends, opening with the greatest promise, carried on with the most boundless audacity, but closing not only with the loss of a battle and with a retreat, not merely in confusion to his plans and ruin to his prospects, but with the blasting of all hopes of success in any project of invasion in the future.

abstract: Provost-Marshal NUGENT has received no further instructions relative to a renewal of the, draft, but he expects to receive orders to proceed with the drawing as soon as the question is settled with regard to the quota due from this, City. All sorts of absurd claims are being urged upon the Government authorities relative to the troops heretofore furnished by this City, some even going so far as to claim that New-York has furnished an excess over her quota in previous calls sufficient to cover the entire number now required of this City. The Government certainly ought to be able to ascertain the facts about this matter, and the sooner this is done, and the draft resumed here, if, as there is no doubt, it is to be resumed, the better will it be for all concerned. The acts of the mob have had the effect to ???nul all opposition to the draft among thinking people, and there is an anxious desire on the part of law-abiding citizens that the law should be obeyed here as elsewhere, and that New-  York has no right or reason to refuse or evade furnishing her Just-quota of recruits. We are informed by Provost-Marshal NUGENT that the enrollment is completed in all the districts, and he is ready to resume the draft at any time. The statement in a morning paper, that the enrollment in the Fourth District was only completed on Monday last, is incorrect. It has been completed in all the Districts for more than a week. Duplicates of each enrollment list are preserved, and nothing would be gained by the mob if they succeeded in destroying the list kept at the place of drafting. It is scarcely probable, however, that there will be any interference with the drawing, whenever it is resumed. It is a notable fact in the late riots, that the mob attacked only such places as were known to be without the means of resistance. Hereafter they will find few places that are not prepared to meet them.

abstract: The examination of MATTHEW POWERS, F. HAMNERS, PATRICK KIERNAN and BARNEY FAGAN, was concluded yesterday, before His Honor the Mayor. N. NESBIT, Esq., appeared for prisoners. The evidence of arson against POWERS was conclusive, bail was refused, and be was committed. The evidence as accessories against the others was also conclusive, and they were held in $2,000 bail each; failing to get it, they were returned to the Tombs.

abstract: Expelling Invaders of
snippet: Expelling Invaders of
lead_paragraph: When Kentucky was nominally annexed to the Southern Confederacy, and a bogus State Government and a rebel army had position on her soil, every Press and every speaker in the South overflowed with tumid rhetoric, the burden of which was the necessity of immediately driving "the Yankee invaders" from the soil of Kentucky. Later in the day the situation was changed; the irrepressible Yankees were found in uncomfortable numbers in Tennessee, and ISHAM G. HARRIS, the vagabond rebel Governor of that State, and all the military spouters of the Confederacy, fell to haranguing the Southern heart frantically, and the one great lesson taught was, the duty of rising en masse and driving "the Yankee invaders" from the soil of Tennessee. Later still the situation was changed again, and the State of Mississippi was reached -- long secure in its interior position, and an asylum to which the itinerant Governors of Kentucky, Tennessee and Arkansas had escaped. It was the turn of Gov. PETTUS now to flagellate the dormant chivalry of the South and especially of Mississippi, and urge it to rally in dozens, scores and hundreds, until a mighty army was raised and "the Yankee invaders" expelled from the sacred soil of Mississippi. But to this day his rhetoric has borne no fruit, and Gov. PETTUS is now seeking the asylum he used to offer to others.

abstract: Eight of the ten substitute, who had been accepted, clothed with regular army suite, and quartered for safe-keeping in Piertan Hall, skedaddled sometime between 2 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, by lowering themselves from a front window to the sidewalk on Fourth-street.
lead_paragraph: Eight of the ten substitute, who had been accepted, clothed with regular army suite, and quartered for safe-keeping in Piertan Hall, skedaddled sometime between 2 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, by lowering themselves from a front window to the sidewalk on Fourth-street. The deserters cut their blankets into strips, knotted them together, and then, probably, drew up the rope with which some accomplices outside furnished them, and by which they effected their escape.

abstract: The Governor  of New-Jersey has just issued a proclamation stating that no draft has been ordered in that State, and that thirty days will be allowed for the purpose of raising the required number of men by volunteering.
lead_paragraph: -- The Governor of New-Jersey has just issued a proclamation stating that no draft has been ordered in that State, and that thirty days will be allowed for the purpose of raising the required number of men by volunteering. If, at the end of thirty days, the quota required from the State is not made up, the draft will be enforced only for the deficiency. Gov. PARKER would not, of course, issue such a paper except with the knowledge and approbation, of the War Department. We shall therefore have the experiment fairly tried, whether, as the opponents of the Conscription aver, the military ardor of the people is sufficient, if appealed to, to furnish all the soldiers needed in the further prosecution of the war.

abstract: Now that the Mississippi is completely in our possession, and the Confederacy permanently bisected, the one supreme necessity for the ending of the war is the destruction of LEE'S army. The fact cannot be too distinctly recognized, or too closely acted upon.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Mississippi is completely in our possession, and the Confederacy permanently bisected, the one supreme necessity for the ending of the war is the destruction of LEE'S army. The fact cannot be too distinctly recognized, or too closely acted upon. It should alike shape the military plans of the Government, and regulate the expectations of the people. As CATO used to finish every speech of his in the Senate, on whatever subject, with the words: "My opinion is that Carthage must be destroyed," so, in every council of war, and every popular convention, whatever the business in hand, the last thing heard ought to be, "Lee's army must be done for."
headline: {'main': 'The One Thing Indispensable.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The One Thing Indispensable.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Conkling vs. Conkling. -- Separations from bed and board forever, or for a limited time, are authorized by the laws of this State. In cases, first, of cruel and inhuman treatment by the husband of his wife second, such conduct on the part of the husband toward his wife as may ???ender it unsafe and improper for her to cohabit with him, third, the abandonment of the wife by the husband, and his refusal or neglect to provide for her. It is also provided that the defendant in any such suit may be permitted to prove in his justification the ill-conduct of the complainant, and, on establishing such defence to the satisfaction of the Court, the bill shall be dismissed.

lead_paragraph: The camp at New-Dorp is situated about five miles from the Clifton or Vanderbilt Landing, and can be reached by the Staten Island cars. It is situated in a pleasant part of the island, and in all respects superior to any camp yet located there, and the condition is excellent. The hospitals are kept in the best of order, under the supervision of Dr. CLARKE, the Fest Surgeon, and his assistant, Dr. MILSPAUGH.

abstract: The battle of
snippet: The battle of
lead_paragraph: In one account of the battle of Falling Waters, I notice the infantry is mentioned as having something to do with that fight. There was no infantry engaged. It was exclusively a cavalry fight, and by the Michigan brigade, the First, Fifth, Sixth and Seventh regiments -- Gen. CUSTER's brigade. The guns flags and earthworks were captured by them, and to the Michiganders alone, with Gen. KILPATRICK's body guard, (First Ohio, Capt. JONES,) belongs the honor of that day. Gen. BUFORD's cavalry command aided after the earthworks had been captured. The charge made upon the earthworks was one of the most gallant on record -- a squadron of fifty-seven men charging upon three or four brigades behind earthworks, killing one Major-General, (PETTIGREW,) capturing more than 1,000 prisoners, and strewing the field with the killed and wounded of the enemy. Eighteen of this gallant band of Michiganders there died nobly for their country. In justice to the gallant men of the Sixth Michigan cavalry, in justice to their friends, and as a simple recognition of the services of this glorious band, I herewith annex a full list, furnished at my request, of the men who participated in the charge at Falling Waters, that their names may be known to posterity, even if their noble conduct is not rewarded by their own State or the nation.

abstract: Yesterday a large detachment of United States marines arrived here from the National Capital, and were subsequently quartered in the Marine barracks OR Flushing-avenue. Another troop arrived from Philadelphia last evening, and a third has been here since Monday. All these are to be concentrated in one body, and to be sent to Charleston, to reinforce the Marine corps there. Officers accompany the troops, which are all excellently drilled, and in a state of the most perfect discipline. An inspection of the battalion will take place to-day or to-morrow at the navy-yard, under the surveillance of Major GARLAND, the Commandant of the Marine garrison of the New-York station. Over 400 men, in addition to those already here, are expected in a few days.

abstract: Detective ROACH yesterday arrested a lad named JACOB LONG, aged 14 years, charged with having been engaged in causing the death of the negro JAMES COSTELLO, who was beaten to death by the mob on the morning of Wednesday, the 15th inst., in Thirty-second-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues. The accused was arrested in a butcher shop on the corner of Sixth-avenue and Thirty-second street, where he was employed. He admits that he threw two paving-stones at deceased, one of which struck him on the head and the other on his legs. The prisoner could not say whether COSTELLO was dead at the time he threw the stones. He was confident that he was dead before he was hung.

abstract: Stephen T. Clarke vs. James Brooks and Erasmus Brooks. -- BRADY, J. -- The plaintiff owning but one-  sixth of the copartnership property, and the defendants being solvent, I think from the nature of the firm property that the defendants should be appointed receivers upon filing a bond in fifty thousand dollars, with the provision in the order that they carry on the business as usual until the coming in of the report of the referee who may be appointed to ascertain and settle the accounts between the parties, or until the further order of this Court.

abstract: Advocacy of Mexican Invasion
snippet: Advocacy of Mexican Invasion
lead_paragraph: -- The World has been a persistent partisan advocate of the French invasion of Mexico. It has denounced the Mexican nation and advocated French rule. The news of French victories in the neighboring Republic has been heralded forth in its columns with joy and self-gratulation -- while it has had its malignant flings??? at those who have persistently exposed and denounced the French invasion of Mexico and its ulterior purposes. It is not necessary to look far back in the columns of the World for the shameful evidence of all this. In its issue of the 2d ult., after joyfully commenting on the fall of Puebla, and remarking that "American journalism has been made ridiculous by the most obstinate perversions and misrepresentations, as well of the Mexican policy of NAPOLEON III. as of the actual events of the Mexican campaign of his troops," it goes on to speak as follows:

abstract: The Central train, last evening, brought down from Gordonsville about three hundred and fifty Yankees, captured in a fight at Snicker's Gap, on Friday. We were unable to obtain any particular of the affair beyond the report that Gen. HILL's corps dislodged the enemy who were holding the pass, killing a number and capturing the prisoners who arrived here yesterday.

abstract: An inquest was held at St. Luke's Hospital, by Coroner RANNEY, on the body of FRANCIS MCCADE, a youth of 18 years, who died from the effects of a gunshot wound received on the corner of Thirty-sixth-  street and Ninth-avenue, during the riot of Tuesday, the 14th inst. It was in testimony before the Coroner that during the march of the military through the streets on that occasion, the rioters threw large quantities of bricks at them from the tops of houses; the mob also hallooed, groaned and defied the military to do their worst, and at the first discharge of musketry deceased was struck in the right groin with a Minie ball. It did not appear that he had anything to do with the rioters, but seemed to be operating with a fire company.

abstract: A sufferer by the Combahee raid sums up his sorrows in the following sentence: "What contributed most to my mortification was, that in my whole gang of slaves, among whom there were any amount of Aarons, Abrahams, Isaacs and Jacobs, there was not one Abdlel not one remained loyal to the rebel."
lead_paragraph: A sufferer by the Combahee raid sums up his sorrows in the following sentence: "What contributed most to my mortification was, that in my whole gang of slaves, among whom there were any amount of Aarons, Abrahams, Isaacs and Jacobs, there was not one Abdlel not one remained loyal to the rebel." This is the complaint of hundreds and thousands of other sufferers. The most petted, trusted and seemingly devoted slaves are found wanting in the hour of trial. Hence inferences adverse to the institution of slavery.

abstract: The rebel prize steamer Merrimac came into this port this morning, in charge of Acting Ensign STODDARD, United States Navy. She was captured, by the United States gunboat Iroquois, Commander CASE, on the morning of the 25th, having run the blockade at Wil mington the night previous, after a chase of seven hours. She is a side-wheel Iron steamer of 535 tons measurement, 600 horse power, and built in London in 1862 for the rebel Government. She has a cargo of 576 bales and 34 half bales cotton, 11 kegs tobacco and a small quantity of turpentine, &c. The Merrimac, Lizzie, and another rebel steamer ran the blockade together. The two former are captured. The third is as yet free.

abstract: ROBBERY AND ATTEMPTED MURDER. -- Tuesday afternoon a German, recently arrived in this country, named CHARLES STOCKLEIN, architect and topographical engineer, accompanied by several friends, appeared before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, and entered a complaint against a man named FRANCIS VINCENTZ, keeper of a lager-bier shop, and dealer in dogs, charging him with robbery, and attempting to take his life. It appears that on Monday the complainant, who is in the employ of Mr. HOOVER, architect, at Newark, attended a pic-nic at Tivoli, remaining there until midnight. Upon returning to Newark, he found that he had been locked out, when VINCENTZ, who had also attended the pic-nic, and had represented himself as a friend of Mr. HOOVER's, invited STOECKLEIN to go to East Newark and stop at his house over night. The latter, supposing, of course, that if he was a friend of Mr. HOOVER's it was all right, went over to East Newark, where the two arrived between 3 and 4 o'clock in the morning. Upon entering the bar-room, VINCENTZ requested STOECKLEIN to sit down while he went into the back room for a light. In a few minutes after VINCENTZ returned, and STOECKLEIN was immediately set upon by two ferocious dogs, one of them said to be a blood-hound, and he was bitten and lacerated on his arms and legs in about twenty different places. While grappling with one of the animals, VINCENTZ rushed up and dealt him a heavy blow over the forehead with a sword which laid him insensible on the floor, inflicting a gash three inches in length. When STOECKLIN came to consciousness about daylight he found his money missing, and himself a prisoner locked in the room. Although very much exhausted from loss of blood, the injured man succeeded in making his escape through a window, and with his clothes torn to rags and covered with blood, made his way to the house of Mr. STEPHENSON, and the latter gentleman kindly conveyed him to Newark, where his wounds were properly dressed. A warrant was placed in the hands of Chief of Police REILY, and Detective KILCAULEY, of Jersey City, and the officers, assisted by Chief WAMBOLD, of Newark, arrested the accused at the latter named place. VINCENTZ was, brought to Jersey City last evening and committed to the City Prison, to await an examination before Recorder MARTINDALE.

Upon returning to Newark, he found that he had been locked out, when VINCENTZ, who had also attended the pic-nic, and had represented himself as a friend of Mr. HOOVER's, invited STOECKLEIN to go to East Newark and stop at his house over night. Upon entering the bar-room, VINCENTZ requested STOECKLEIN to sit down while he went into the back room for a light. In a few minutes after VINCENTZ returned, and STOECKLEIN was immediately set upon by two ferocious dogs, one of them said to be a blood-hound, and he was bitten and lacerated on his arms and legs in about twenty different places. While grappling with one of the animals, VINCENTZ rushed up and dealt him a heavy blow over the forehead with a sword which laid him insensible on the floor, inflicting a gash three inches in length. When STOECKLIN came to consciousness about daylight he found his money missing, and himself a prisoner locked in the room. abstract: Pollitz vs. Witte; Construction of Contract
snippet: Pollitz vs. Witte; Construction of Contract
lead_paragraph: Otto W. Pollitz et al. vs. Melchior C.G. Witte. -- The defendant, in February, 1861, through a broker, purchased of the plaintiffs fifteen casks of cream of tartar at a stipulated price, to arrive by a certain vessel from Marseilles. At the time of the purchase the duty on the article was fixed at $12 per cask, and this rate of duty continued up to April 1 following, when cream of tartar was permitted, by a change of the tariff law to be entered free of duty. The vessel arived about March 15, and some days after, the plaintiffs, instead of delivering the article sold, entered it in bond at the Custom-house, and sent it to the public stores of the United States Government, from whence, about the 17th of April, it was taken by them, duty free, and delivered to and accepted by the defendant under his contract of purchase. In accordance with the terms of the same contract, he has paid the plaintiffs the price agreed, less $12 per cask, which was the duty chargeable at the time of the purchase, and also at the time the vessel arrived, and which he refuses to pay upon the ground that the charge of the tariff inured to his benefit and not to that of the plaintiffs. To test this right this action is brought.
headline: {'main': 'Decision on the Construction of a Contract and the Payment of Import Duties.; COMMON PLEAS GENERAL TERM. abstract: The people ought not to lose sight of the immense work which the Sanitary Commission is doing for the aid and relief of the army.
lead_paragraph: The people ought not to lose sight of the immense work which the Sanitary Commission is doing for the aid and relief of the army. Since the battle of Gettysburgh it has sent to the Army of the Potomac alone over 20,000 pounds of fresh bread, 20,000 pounds of fresh mutton and poultry, 10,000 pounds of condensed beef soup, 9,000 pounds of condensed milk, 5,000 pounds of fresh butter, 10,000 dozen of fresh eggs, 5 tons of fresh vegetables, 4,000 pounds of sweet chocolate, 4,000 pairs of shoes and slippers, 1 ton of tamarinds, 300 boxes of lemons and oranges; of jellies, farinaceous food, wines, spirits, cordials, sponges, towels, lint, bandages, socks and hospital clothing. many car-loads.

abstract: Seabrook Island was evacuated by our forces yesterday at 12 o'clock M., after safely removing all the stores, ammunition, etc. The rebs came down and shelled us out of our picket posts last Saturday afternoon, and made a show as if advancing in force. They advanced to the woods and burnt one or two of our picket shanties, but did not deem it prudent to advance any further.

abstract: This stereotyped expression "in good spirits"  may be heard at any street corner, and even in any news journal of the day. It is the language both parties in this gigantic war employ, from time to time, to describe their respective feelings. It is sometimes sincerely uttered, sometimes hypocritically. It is the expression of a cheerful courage, it is also the deceitful language in which some disguise their anxieties.
lead_paragraph: From the Richmond Christian Advocate.

abstract: Coroner COLLIN concluded the inquest yesterday in the case of PATRICK MCKINNIE, who is alleged to have been beaten to death by a gang of rioters in the Eleventh Ward, as stated in yesterday's TIMES. A mass of testimony was taken, which tended to show that the deceased was badly beaten by CHARLES FLYNN and others, and was then thrown overboard. The jury rendered the following verdict: "That the deceased came to his death by blows received at the hands of CHARLES FLYNN and others, and that he was then thrown into the water before life was extent, by some person or persons unknown."
lead_paragraph: Coroner COLLIN concluded the inquest yesterday in the case of PATRICK MCKINNIE, who is alleged to have been beaten to death by a gang of rioters in the Eleventh Ward, as stated in yesterday's TIMES. abstract: The body of the colored man which was found near the grain-elevator above South Ferry, Brooklyn, last week, was yesterday identified by his relatives residing in New-York, as SAMUEL JOHNSON. They stated that he was employed in a store in New-York, and resided in Williamsburgh; that on the evening of the fourth day of the riot, on his way home, he was met at the ferry by a body of rioters, attacked and beaten, and thrown overboard; that while in the water he raised up his hands and cried out "for God's sake, save my life," when he sunk and was seen no more. The head of deceased presented evidence of having been beaten with clubs, but as there was no direct testimony when the inquest was held a verdict of found drowned, was rendered.
lead_paragraph: The body of the colored man which was found near the grain-elevator above South Ferry, Brooklyn, last week, was yesterday identified by his relatives residing in New-York, as SAMUEL JOHNSON. abstract: Why does not the Government complete the draft in this City? Is it really truckling to the mob? Has its courage oozed out? These are questions that for the last week have been in the mouths of all true men, and it is high time they were explicitly answered. Evasions, and excuses, and ambiguous outgivings of what is going to be done to-morrow or next week, have had their day. The public has been surfeited with them up to the very verge of disgust. It has at last come to consider them nothing less than bald impostures; and we fear justly.

abstract: Our Special Correspondent telegraphs from the Army of the Potomac, under date of yesterday, that the army now occupies practically the same line that it did two months ago, and that the recent active movements will necessarily be followed by a period of comparative inaction.
lead_paragraph: Our Special Correspondent telegraphs from the Army of the Potomac, under date of yesterday, that the army now occupies practically the same line that it did two months ago, and that the recent active movements will necessarily be followed by a period of comparative inaction. During the next month the cavalry is expected to do most of the fighting. Our correspondent reiterates his statement that LONGSTREET'S and HILL'S commands passed through Thornton's, and not Chester, Gap. and says that they are now encamped between Culpepper and Gordonsville, while EWELL'S corps, or the bulk of it, is now moving through the Shenandoah Valley -- detachments of it occasionally threatening our outposts.

abstract: -- Our local columns, this morning, contain mention of a boy, five years old, who was drowned in the North River on Tuesday; of another boy, eight years old, who was drowned in the East River on the same day; of another boy, eleven years old, who was drowned the same day in the same river; of a man who was drowned the same day, in the North River; and of the dead body of another man being found in the same water. Not a day passes but there are more or less men and boys who lose their lives in the rivers skirting this City. Some of the men may be drunk or crazy, but this cannot be said of the children. It is the result of carelessness or folly. Parents who value their children should be careful about permitting them to play at large in the vicinity of the piers, or to go in swimming amid the deep and dangerous currents that prevail in these parts of the North and East Rivers.

abstract: On Monday last a man, said to be a Jew broker, made his appearance in Westchester, Penn., accompanied by a dozen others, whom he represented as anxious to serve as substitutes, for a consideration. Although some of the men, it is said, boasted of having taken part in the New-York riots, yet they were eagerly caught up by drafted men, and engaged at various prices as substitutes. Two of the number were sharp enough to get their money before being mustered in, and they immediately skedaddled. Four others were accepted by the Enrollment Board, and sent to the barracks, but three out of the number turned up missing the next morning. They were pursued by the Deputy Provost-Marshall and by dint of threats, and the more powerful argument of a loaded revolver, were induced to return, when they were lodged in jail for safe keeping. Three others escaped, and have not yet been caught. Most of the men were more or less disfigured about the face and hands, and there is little doubt that their boasts were true about their having been engaged in the riots in this City. Would it not be well for the authorities to dispatch a Detective to Westchester, and ascertain who these men are? He might possibly find among them the notorious leader of the riot in Eighth-avenue, JOHN RILEY, who, instead of being remanded to the Tombs by Judge MCCUNN, as he promised the District Attorney he should be, was placed in the custody of Officer EGAN, and immediately made his escape, a result which the Judge undoubtedly knew the probabilities were all in favor of.

abstract: A VOLUNTEER WOUNDED IN THE RIOTS. A case especially worthy of the attention of the public is that of MYRON AUSTIN, a returned soldier, a member of the Eighth regiment, N.Y.S.N.G.
lead_paragraph: A VOLUNTEER WOUNDED IN THE RIOTS. -- A case especially worthy of the attention of the public is that of MYRON AUSTIN, a returned soldier, a member of the Eighth regiment, N.Y.S.N.G. He volunteered his services to aid in suppressing the riot, and joined the Zouaves, under Col. WINSLOW. On Wednesday, 15th inst., at the fight between the military and the rioters, corner of First-avenue and Nineteenth- street, he was shot while in the act of firing off a howitzer. The ball passed entirely through his knee, inflicting a terrible wound which will render him a cripple for life. After being wounded he was carried to a doctor's house in the vicinity, where he was tracked by the vengeful mob clamoring for and led by his blood. He had to escape hence by the rear, crawling, wounded as he was, over several fences, and finally utterly exhausted, fell in the yard of those who proved to be friends. They took him into the house and secreted him, the next morning kindly conveying him in a carriage to his home No. 119 Varick- street. Mr. AUSTEN is a young man of excellent habits, worthy, industrious, and while volunteering his services to the City has suffered an injury which will confine him a long time, and incapacitate him for the further pursuit of his business, which is that of a grain measurer.

abstract: -- A vigorous effort is now in progress to give increased energy to the operations of this important organization by securing larger donations to assist it in prosecuting its philanthropic labors. The Ladies' Army Relief Association occupies a field of labor which no other organization completely fills. Its agents, who are women of tried experience, engage themselves about the hospitals and upon the battlefield, conveying food and nourishment to the wounded, and caring for them in every way in which the Government nurses cannot look after them. Although their functions are of the first importance they are not recognized by the Government, nor do they receive any pay for it, hence the necessity of private contributions. Mrs. Senator HARLAN is President of the Association; Mrs. S.P. EDSON Vice-President; Mrs. E. STAATS, of Washington, Secretary, and Judge J.N. GRANGER, of the Land Office, Washington, Treasurer.

abstract: Onondaga, The, Iron Battery; Launch
snippet: Onondaga, The, Iron Battery; Launch
lead_paragraph: For nearly a year past it has been generally known that some kind of a peculiar war-vessel was in process of construction at the Continental Iron Works, Greenpoint, L.I. Exactly what this novel specimen of naval architecture might be, the curious in such matters had no opportunity of discovering, as all the work has been done and the vessel made ready for launching, under an immense shed, which effectually concealed operations from inquisitive but uninvited people. It is not to be wondered at, therefore, under these circumstances, that an unusually large number of spectators were drawn together, yesterday morning, by the announcement that the mysterious vessel was to be set afloat. Tide neither waits for ships nor men, consequently the managers of the launch were compelled to accommodate themselves to the full flood-time of this even-tenored despot, and fix the somewhat early hour of 8 for the event. Neither this fact nor the unsettled state of the weather proved sufficient, as we have before intimated, to keep back the spectators. Long before the time fixed upon, every available point of observation had its occupant. The piers were packed, vessels in the vicinity were crowded, and the river was lively with tugboats and smaller craft.

abstract: Officer BROWN, of the Thirteenth Ward, arrested MICHAEL MONOHAN, a young Irishman twenty years of age, by occupation a boiler maker, charged with rioting and felonious assault and battery, on complaint of Mr. JOHN E. RICHARDS, of No. 53 Tompkins street, and DANIEL ANTHONY, Esq., residing at No. 59 Mangin-street. The complainants positively identify MONOHAN as taking an active part in the late riots, and he also assaulted Mr. RICHARDS with a large club. The offender was taken before Justice STEERS, and fully committed for trial without bail.

abstract: The completion of the enrollment in Delaware shows that the number of men subject to the draft of the first class is 10,760, of whom 8,181 are white, and 2,599 colored. Of these Newcastle County has 3,683 white and 1,161 colored; Kent, 2,022 white, 889 colored; Sussex. 2,479 white, 594 colored. The number of men of the second class is not stated. The quota of the State for the present draft has not vet been announced by the Secretary of War, but it is rumored that it will be somewhere between 800 and 1,200.

lead_paragraph: We have a report from Matamoras, Mexico, by way of New-Orleans, that 7,000 French troops were on their way there from Vera Craz. abstract: At present there are five foreign men-of-war in this port. Two of them are of the English navy, two of the French and one of the Spanish. The English are the Challenger and Jason, both screw steam corvettes, the former carrying 22 guns, and commanded by Capt. JOHN J. KENNEDY, and the latter having 21 guns, commanded by Capt. EDWARD P.B. VAN DONOP. The Guerriere is a French steam frigate bears the flag of Rear-Admiral REGNAUD, carries thirty-six guns, and is commanded by Capt. LAPEROUSE. The other, also French, is the Renaudire, a steam gunboat mounting three guns, and is commanded by Capt. LE CARDINAL. The Princessa de Asturia is a Spanish frigate, commanded by Capt. SANTIAGO. The Challenger and Guerriere arrived here some weeks ago. The other vessels came in at a recent date. Three of them, also an American frigate, lie near each other just opposite the Battery. They present a neat, trim appearance, and are almost constantly receiving visitors. These five vessels, together with the many American war vessels that are in the immediate vicinity, form quite a formidable fleet. Occasionally a visit from some distinguished naval officer calls for a salute, and like compliment is now and then paid an outward bound ocean steamer. It is uncertain how long the vessels will remain here.

abstract: THE DRAFT IN JERSEY CITY. -- A meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City was held Tuesday evening to hear report on the Mayor's message, recommending an appropriation for bounties to fill up he quota of the city. The Committee reported resolutions to pay $200 bounty to each man mustered into the United States service, and that the Finance Committee report a plan for raising the money; also that recruiting stations be opened in each Ward. The quota required it about 425 men. The resolutions were unanimously adopted. The recruiting offices will be opened to-day, Aldermen Geddit, Gafney, Decker, Nafew. Ege and Kane being the Committee to attend to them. About $85,000 will be the aggregate of the bounties. In addition to the amounts offered by the Government and City, $50 bounty is paid by the County, making a total to veteran soldiers and nine months' men of $868.

abstract: Negro soldiers have now been in battles at Port Hudson and at Milliken's Bend in Louisiana, at Helena in Arkansas, at Morris Island in South Carolina, and at or near Fort Gibson, in the Indian Territory.
lead_paragraph: Negro soldiers have now been in battles at Port Hudson and at Milliken's Bend in Louisiana, at Helena in Arkansas, at Morris Island in South Carolina, and at or near Fort Gibson, in the Indian Territory. In two of these instances they assaulted fortified positions, and led the assault; in two they fought on the defensive, and in one they attacked rebel infantry. In all of them they acted in conjunction with white troops, and under command of white officers. In some instances they acted with distinguished bravery, and in nearly all they acted as well as could be expected of raw troops. Some of these negroes were from the Cotton States; others from the New- England States, and others from the Slave States of the Northwest. Those who fought at Port Hudson were from New-Orleans; those who fought at Battery Wagner were from Boston; those who fought at Helena and Young's Point were from the river counties of Arkansas, Mississippi and Tennessee; those who fought in the Indian Territory were from Missouri.

abstract: While every other man one meets is anxiously inquiring when the draft is to be renewed in this City, it is a source of much annoyance and vexation, especially if one is a reporter, and therefore supposed to know all about it, not to be able to give any information at all in regard thereto. On inquiry of the Provost-  Marshal yesterday, it was stated, what has so often been restated before, that no further instructions had been received from Washington relative to the subject. Some difficulty has been experienced in securing buildings in which to make the drawing, in place of those that were burnt by the mob, but the Provost-Marshal has determined, in case he is unsuccessful in securing other places, to make the drawing upon the ruins of those buildings. Out of the ashes of lawlessness and riot, it is hoped will arise a Phoenix of law and order.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the United States gunboat Paul Jones, from Charleston, July 26, we learn that the siege of Fort Wagner still continued. Gen. GILLMORE had succeeded in erecting a battery of heavy siege guns within 1,000 yards of Fort Wagner. Everything was progressing favorably. Fort Sumter, and Fort Johnston on James Island kept a continual fire on the Federal forces on Morris Island; the casualties to the Federal forces averaged about six per day.

abstract: Wish to Return to the Union; The Restoration of
snippet: Wish to Return to the Union; The Restoration of
lead_paragraph: The public attention has not, for some time, been called to the civil condition of the State of Teneessee, which, since BRAGG'S retreat, is peculiar and anomalous. There is now no large army, either rebel or Union, planted on its soil. The army of Gen. ROSECRANS, though nominally still in the State, is pressing upon and felt by Alabama and Georgia more than by Tennessee. While the State is therefore delivered from the presence of military rule, it has no civil government anywhere erected or respected. There are no courts, no laws, no civil administration, no body politic, no taxation nor representation. The population of the State, reduced by the war to perhaps 800,000. is in utter social and political chaos.
headline: {'main': 'Tennessee Restored.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Tennessee Restored.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Humbugs about, exploded by the War
snippet: Humbugs about, exploded by the War
lead_paragraph: It is amusing what havoc this war is making among dogmas and pet ideas. It sweeps them down by the wholesale, sparing no section of the country nor any party. Probably there is not a white man between the Gulf and the Lakes who has not had a favorite notion knocked in the head within the last two years. That great final repository of humbugs, MILTON's Limbo of Vanity "o'er the backside of the world," is crammed with recent American accessions.

abstract: CHARGE OF HIGHWAY ROBBERY. JOHN GREENAN, JOHN McLAUGHLIN, MICHAEL SALMON and JOHN WILSON, were arrested by the Twenty-first Precinct Police, charged with highway robbery on complaint of MICHAEL LYNCH, of Minerva, Essex County, this State.
lead_paragraph: CHARGE OF HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- JOHN GREENAN, JOHN McLAUGHLIN, MICHAEL SALMON and JOHN WILSON, were arrested by the Twenty-first Precinct Police, charged with highway robbery on complaint of MICHAEL LYNCH, of Minerva, Essex County, this State. While standing on the corner of Twenty- eighth-street and Second-avenue late at night, LYNCH was attacked by a gang of rowdies, one of whom struck him from behind, knocked him down, and forcibly took from his possession a wallet containing $207, besides his gold watch. After the crime had been committed, Officers WATERS and SMITH found the prisoners together in Thirty-second-street, and on being confronted with LYNCH, he recognized WILSON and GREENAN as the men who knocked him down and aided in rifling his pockets. The prisoners were all taken before Justice KELLY, and committed for examination.

abstract: During Monday night last a furious storm of wind and rain set in from the northeast, increasing to a perfect gale. The steamer P.H. Field started from Watkins with a tow of ten boats, and encountered this gale in his heaviest violence after passing Long Point. Here the lake is about five miles wide, and is subject to a heavy sea.
lead_paragraph: From the Geneva Gazette, July 24.

abstract: There are about 200 drafted men and substitutes at Grapevine Point, the conscript camp near New-Haven. Saturday night, ten or fifteen substitutes who had received their pay, attempted to run the guard and escape, but were fired upon. Most of them were driven back to the camp, but four or five escaped. One fellow, calling himself JOHN MCCARTEN, of Toronto, was hit and his arm shattered so that amputation was necessary. A letter was found in the camp written to some woman, in which the writer states that he had already made something, and expected by selling himself times enough to cleat at least $2,000 by his operations.
lead_paragraph: There are about 200 drafted men and substitutes at Grapevine Point, the conscript camp near New-Haven. A letter was found in the camp written to some woman, in which the writer states that he had already made something, and expected by selling himself times enough to cleat at least $2,000 by his operations.

abstract: DEATHS BY DROWNING. A lad 14 years of age, named JOSEPH THOMAS, accidentally fell from a steamboat near Fulton Ferry on Wednesday, and was drowned. The deceased was about going on a picnic excursion.The body was not recovered.... A boy, named JOHN J. BIRMINGHAM, was drowned while bathing at the foot of Jerolemon-street.
lead_paragraph: DEATHS BY DROWNING. -- A lad 14 years of age, named JOSEPH THOMAS, accidentally fell from a steamboat near Fulton Ferry on Wednesday, and was drowned. The deceased was about going on a picnic excursion.The body was not recovered.... A boy, named JOHN J. BIRMINGHAM, was drowned while bathing at the foot of Jerolemon-street. He was accompanied by two other boys, who had also got beyond their depth, but were rescued. The body of deceased was found soon afterward.... Coroner RYDER held an inquest at Coney Island Point on Wednesday, upon the body of a man found floating near the beach. Deceased was about 35 years old, five feet six inches in height, and dressed in a woolen shirt, black cloth pantaloons, cotton hose and black gaiters. In the pockets was a $10 bill and fifty cents in postal currency, a spectacle case and knife. The name "HAWK, alias SEWARD, alias PECK, 186," was marked on the lining. The verdict was, "Found drowned." Further information can be obtained of Coroner RYDER, of Gravesend, Kings County.

abstract: This event took place yesterday, and although the weather was threatening, which no doubt prevented numbers from venturing out, vet there was a numerous attendance of the patrons of the trotting courses, and quite a number by the cars on the Brooklyn and Jamaica Railroad, which were faithfully run according to the announcement in the advertisements -- a point which will be as well attended to hereafter by the new President and Superintendent of the road, for the convenience of the visitors to the future trots on the course, as it has been on the present occasion.
